HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 6-25-00: Salient Facts: Sperm Banks;
Take It to the Bank

BYLINE: By Jeff Stryker 

 BODY:

A DIFFERENT KIND OF WORLD BANK
Need further evidence that the forces transforming life as we know it -- you know, global economic interdependence, the Internet -- really are changing everything? Take artificial insemination. Sperm banking is now global; consumers are no longer limited to the small donor pools at local mom-and-pop sperm banks. The Denmark-based Cryos has recently generated media interest because of its aggressive marketing in the American, European and Australian markets. With an avowed goal of becoming the McDonald's of sperm banking, Cryos delivers sperm packed in dry ice or liquid nitrogen to more than two dozen countries. Consumers in many smaller European countries favor the Cryos product because cultural, regulatory or economic factors render local sperm banks impractical. Denmark is also regulated less strictly than its neighbors: Danish donors, for example, are permitted to sire as many as 25 offspring before mandatory retirement; in England, the maximum number is 10.
 
SEMINAL MOMENTS
The first reported instance of donor insemination took place in 1884, when a medical school professor in Philadelphia prevailed upon his best-looking student to donate sperm. The chloroformed patient never even knew what happened; she thought she was being examined yet again to determine the reasons for her inability to conceive. As techniques for freezing and thawing sperm were perfected in the 1950's, the medical establishment solidified its paternalistic role in deciding who got access to artificial insemination. (On the plus side, the involvement of physicians helped remove the stigma of adultery from the procedure, which one court initially declared "contrary to public policy and good morals.") The acme of medical hubris was probably reached in the early 1990's, when Dr. Cecil Jacobson, then of northern Virginia, was discovered to have inseminated unwitting patients (as many as 75, according to some claims) with his own sperm. He maintained he had been doing his patients a favor by providing fresh rather than frozen sperm from a smart (if rotund) doctor. The reluctance of doctors and sperm banks to open their doors to all comers eventually sparked the creation of specialized operations. In Oakland, Calif., for example, Rainbow Flag Health Services, a "known-donor sperm bank," specializes in gay and bisexual donors who seek some modest role in the life of their offspring. 
 
THE GOOD FATHER
When sperm banking first became popular in the 1950's and 1960's, donated semen was often mixed with the husband's to allow for at least the possibility of biological parenthood. The donor was selected to match the looks of the husband, at least in terms of race, hair color and eye color. As recently as 15 years ago, a one-line description of the donor was the industry standard. Now, a dozen-page medical and family history is typical. Today's sperm shoppers want to know more than the cause of the donor's maternal grandfather's death or the shape of his nose. Many of the approximately 100 sperm banks operating in the United States offer catalogs with varying amounts of background information on available donors, and thousands of profiles are available online. The Georgia-based Xytex offers baby pictures of donors, current photographs and 10-minute videotape bios, plus a donor essay about interests and hobbies that includes "a message to you or your future children."
 
REGULAR OR HIGH OCTANE?
Now that Ivy League eggs fetch as much as $50,000 on the open market, it's no surprise that sperm banks would make similar efforts at product differentiation. The notorious Repository for Germinal Choice of Escondido, Calif., famous for its Nobel Prize-winning donors, closed its doors last year, but Virginia's Fairfax Cryobank has stepped into the breach with its "Fairfax Doctorate Donors"; since April 1999 the firm has offered, at a third more than the usual charges, sperm from medical, law, Ph.D. and other students and graduates. Cryos offers three grades of sperm, including an "extra" version that contains twice the number of highly motile sperm as its "regular" brand.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 22; Column 3; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 6-25-00: On Language;
Never Said It

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
'Let them eat cake." Those words have come ringing down the centuries as the height of hauteur. Marie Antoinette was never able to live them down, even after the queen followed her husband, Louis XVI, to the guillotine after the French Revolution. To this day, whenever a hardhearted trickle-downer suggests that a rising tide lifts all the boats, he or she is denounced for having "an arrogant let-them-eat-cake attitude," unconcerned with the needs of the common people.
She never said it. The source of this canard is the sixth book of "The Confessions of Jean-Jacques Rousseau": "At length I recollected the thoughtless saying of a great princess, who, on being informed that the country people had no bread, replied, 'Let them eat cake."' (The words, in French, read "Qu'ils mangent de la brioche.") 
 However, these words were written in or about 1770, the same year the daughter of the emperor of the Holy Roman Empire arrived in France to marry its crown prince. Rousseau was attributing that saying to some other "great princess." The truth about Marie was just the opposite: she recognized the need for austerity at court and reduced the royal household staff, but in so doing offended snooty nobles, who proceeded to down-mouth her for posterity. I get incensed at this historical linguistic injustice every time I look up the phrase.
Nor is that the only never-said-it. Who can forget "The Guard dies, but never surrenders" ("Le Garde meurt, mais ne se rend pas")? The Count Cambronne, the head of Napoleon's most loyal troops at the Battle of Waterloo, to whom it was attributed, went to his grave wishing we would forget it, because he insisted that he never said it. A half-century after the battle, the writer Edouard Fournier credited a reporter named Rougemont with the creation of the ringing phrase. It may be counter-apocryphal, but some say the count's battlefield response to a demand for surrender was the expletive "merde!" -- a favorite Hemingway word for excrement sometimes referred to in France as "le mot de Cambronne."
These belated corrections are made here today because of a response received after a correction of a more recent misconception: Richard Nixon's never-said "I have a secret plan to end the war." I challenged anyone to come up with a contemporary citation directly quoting the 1968 candidate saying it; nobody ever has.
Because word got around the White House that great misattributions were being straightened out in this space, the following handwritten note came in from Samuel R. Berger, national security adviser: "Bill -- Since you have asserted frequently that Bill Clinton is the 'architect of the strategic partnership' with Beijing, and because you are a stickler for the facts, I would like you to show me one instance in which the President describes the relationship as a strategic partnership."
Gee, could it be that Clinton is being unjustly saddled with a never-said-it? You can get hundreds of citation hits on the databases when you type in "strategic partnership" and "Clinton." An article in Japan's daily Yomiuri Shimbun in 1998: "Last year, Chinese President Jiang Zemin visited the United States, and this year, U.S. President Bill Clinton returned the visit. On both occasions, the two countries began using the term 'strategic partnership' between the two powers to describe their relationship." Robyn Lim wrote recently in The International Herald Tribune, "Two years ago, Mr. Clinton announced a 'strategic partnership' with China." And a vituperative right-wing New York Times columnist (albeit a stickler for the facts) has been writing frequently of "Clinton, architect of the discredited 'strategic partnership' with Beijing." Could we all be wrong?
Berger goes on: "On many occasions we have said that we would hope to develop a strategic partnership, i.e., described it as an aspirational goal. But there is a big difference between describing an objective for the future and what exists today. I can provide you what the President actually said in Beijing."
And so, upon my eager request, he did. On July 3, 1998, the president (Times style, unlike White House style, is to lowercase the name of the office) said in Hong Kong, "My view is that the potential we have for a strategic partnership is quite strong." This followed by five days Jiang Zemin's usage: "progress in the direction of building a constructive strategic partnership."
In each case, and in a dozen other citations provided by the White House, the Clinton context is, as Berger asserts, "aspirational" -- a hope for the future. If the future were the only context for the Clinton use of the phrase, then all of us who have been deriding the president as "architect of the discredited policy of a strategic partnership" -- as if it signified his notion of a present state of affairs -- would surely owe him and his advisers abject apologies.
And yet there is the problem of the Clinton statement to business leaders in Shanghai on July 1, 1998, dutifully provided by the White House. Discussing normal trade treatment for China, an issue then known as M.F.N. (for "most favored nation"), Clinton warned what would happen if Congress did not respond to his plea to vote to renew the normal treatment. "Failure to renew that would sever our economic ties," he said, "denying us the benefits of China's growth, endangering the strategic partnership, turning our back on the world's largest nation at a time when cooperation for peace and stability is more important and more productive than ever."
When Berger saw that citation, he must have uttered an American translation of le mot de Cambronne, but to his credit he did not remove it from the file. A close analysis of the structure of that sentence, especially its concluding "at a time" clause, indicates clearly that the president was speaking of the strategic partnership as something now in existence -- a current relationship that would be endangered if Congress failed to act as he wished. Had he only put prospective, potential or hoped-for in front of the key phrase, the Berger hypothesis would have been unchallengeable.
You could say in Clinton's defense that he was adlibbing and intended to follow the agreed-upon future formulation but just slipped into the present tense on a single occasion. And it is undeniable that the other Clinton and Jiang citations follow the prospective-relationship formula.
What's fair? We should recall the raw deals that loose historians have given the brioche-free Marie Antoinette, the die-hard count and the secret-plan-less Nixon. Unless other usages surface, accuracy-stickling Sinophobes should limit themselves to castigating "the 'strategic partnership' that Clinton frequently hoped for and in one instance suggested his policy produced."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey;
For First Time Since 80's, Trenton Is to Get a Hotel

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A FULL-SERVICE hotel and conference center is to go up in the Lafayette Yard area of Trenton, giving the city a hotel for the first time since the 1980's and bringing to an end its unenviable distinction as the only state capital without lodging for visitors.
Making the more than $46 million hotel a reality was not easy. It took three years of planning and a financing structure that required state and city subsidies, the creation of a nonprofit corporation to issue $31 million in tax-exempt bonds, and a city guarantee for the bonds. Local officials say that the 197-room hotel, to be operated by Marriott Conference Centers, part of the Marriott hotel chain, will be a new anchor in their longterm plan to revive Trenton as a tourist destination and boost the economy of the city, whose industrial base has withered over the last few decades. 
 The other anchors -- a 6,150-seat minor-league baseball stadium and a 10,600-seat hockey arena -- were constructed in the last few years with public and private funds. Douglas H. Palmer, the mayor of Trenton, said that the hotel would strengthen that base because "it will bring in over 60,000 people a year who will spend the night and have money to spend in the city."
Mayor Palmer said the hope is that housing, office and retail space would rise around the hotel, the stadium and the arena -- which are in a half-mile area -- and will spur other development. The hotel is about a block and half from the state capitol.
The hotel project, on which site work began in April, will also include an $11.9 million, 657-car parking garage, which was financed by the Trenton Parking Authority in a separate bond issue. It will take shape on a 3.5-acre site at Lafayette and South Warren Streets, which is owned by the city and the Trenton Parking Authority and was formerly a public parking lot. The seven-story hotel, scheduled to open in early 2002, will be linked to the adjacent Trenton War Memorial, a state historic landmark used for concerts and other cultural events that recently underwent a $38 million renovation. The last hotel in Trenton, the Capital Plaza Hotel, closed in 1986.
The Marriott Conference Hotel at Lafayette Yard is to be built by Acquest-New Jersey, a subsidiary of Acquest Realty Advisors, a development, management and advisory company in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., together with Zeiger Enterprises of Trenton. The hotel will be owned by the private, nonprofit Lafayette Yard Community Development Corporation, which was set up to sell the $31 million in tax-exempt bonds and whose directors include city and community leaders.
Alan Mallach, the development corporation's chairman, said that the city had stayed the course because "giving up on the hotel was giving up on the future of downtown Trenton."
Mr. Mallach, a former director of housing and economic development for Trenton, said that the city had guaranteed the bonds because "the choice was to wait for the project to happen through the private sector, or have the city prime the pump."
Mayor Palmer said that "it was a risk worth taking."
John A. Fox, a senior vice president at PKF Consulting, a real estate and hotel consulting firm in Manhattan, said that financing new full-service hotels is difficult, particularly in downtown urban locations, despite a still strong lodging market and a shortage of such hotels. Among the reasons, he said, are rising interest rates and increasing construction costs.
That combination, said Robert Bowers, a vice president at Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn., is even more difficult with full-service hotels. Such hotels, he said, have meeting rooms, restaurants and shops, and are more expensive to build than are lodgings without those amenities, such as limited-service hotels, which have been driving new construction.
Mr. Bowers's company reported that of the 3,393 hotels built nationally from January 1998 to April 2000, only 335 were full-service hotels. Only one of the 38 hotels built in New Jersey during the same period, the Meadowlands Plaza Hotel in Secaucus, was a full-service lodging, according to Smith Travel Research.
"So unless developers can secure below-market financing or obtain public subsidies," Mr. Fox said, "the numbers often don't pencil out." Bond-based financing is becoming a more prevalent way to finance such hotels, he said.
In the case of the more than $46 million Trenton hotel, which at times seemed would never be built, the financing evolved in three stages, with the city's involvement increasing at each stage, said Robert Powell, a managing director at Nassau Capital Advisors in Princeton, which represented the city in the project.
FROM the start the state committed $8.175 million in loans to the project, he said; the city contributed the land as well as $7.25 million in subsidies. Despite the public money, a healthy hotel market and a commitment from Marriott, the developers tried unsuccessfully through mid-1998 to raise the remaining money. "The projected return on the private investment was not high enough to justify what was perceived to be a risky investment in Trenton's untested market," Mr. Powell said.
Early in 1999 the focus shifted to public financing and to the creation of the nonprofit development corporation to issue $31 million in tax-exempt bonds, backed by the project. But it took until last November to structure the deal and turn the state's $8.175 million loan commitment into actual funds, Mr. Powell said, adding that by then interest rates had reached 8.5 percent -- based on the bonds' unrated status, and the market's weak appetite for high-yield bonds -- rendering the project financially unfeasible.
The solution was to get the city to guarantee the bonds, a move the mayor and the City Council agreed to. The six-member Council approved the guarantee by a vote of 5 to 1. Doing so increased the rating of the bonds and lowered the interest rate to 5.7 percent, which made the project more economically viable by reducing the debt service on the bonds from an average of $2.6 million a year to $2.1 million, Mr. Powell said. That lowered the break-even occupancy rate for the hotel to 60 percent from 70 percent, which he said gave city officials the assurance they needed to back the bonds.
Also comforting, he said, was a $2.1 million reserve fund -- part of the $31 million bond issue -- the city could tap, if necessary, to pay the debt service on the hotel. In addition, any profit from the hotel -- Marriott receives a management fee -- flows back to the city, Mr. Powell said.
The commitment of the city and state to the project and to transforming Trenton into a tourist destination is what persuaded Marriott to remain involved, said Terry Harwood, the vice president and general manager of Marriott Conference Centers. Mr. Harwood said that his company, which runs several lodgings in central New Jersey, including a full-service hotel in nearby Princeton, also concluded there was a market for the project in Trenton.
According to Smith Travel Research, the hotel occupancy rate in the area around Trenton, which has 46 lodgings with 4,700 rooms, was 69.7 percent in the 12 months ended in April, a figure relatively unchanged from 1999. The average daily room rate, according to Smith Travel Research, rose 5.5 percent, to $102.
Mr. Harwood said that 15,000 to 19,000 guests yearly at the Princeton Marriott "are coming out of Trenton and would stay in downtown Trenton" if it had a hotel. He said that the Princeton hotel has an average occupancy rate of 80 percent and a turnaway rate of 5 percent.
The main business for the Trenton hotel, Mr. Harwood said, will be conferences, which are projected to account for 70 to 75 percent of its occupancy, compared with 40 percent at many other hotels. The 10,000 square feet of meeting space planned at the hotel will be added to the 5,000 square feet of such space as well as the 1,900-seat amphitheater at the War Memorial, which Marriott will market and manage.
The hotel has been designed to blend with its neighbor. The architects are Ford Farewell Mills and Gatsch, and Johnson Jones, both of Princeton.
Mr. Harwood said that the balance of the business at the hotel, which will have a 120-seat restaurant, will be from business and leisure travelers. He said that room rates are expected to be at least $5 a night lower than those at his company's Princeton hotel, where daily rates range from $150 to $170.
The challenge ahead, said Mr. Mallach of the development corporation, is to draw other commercial and retail projects downtown, including restaurants and offices, and to link the hotel with the arena and baseball stadium and existing historic attractions.
To that end, the hotel is being made the centerpiece of a Heritage Tourism master plan being advanced by the city and Mercer County. The plan seeks to promote historic sites in Trenton and the surrounding area, including the Old Barracks, the Trenton Battle Monument and the Princeton Battlefield.
"The hotel in and of itself is not the answer to turning Trenton into a destination," Mayor Palmer said. "The plan now is to take advantage of the city's location and history."

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
A Passion That Began At the Water Hole

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
L. JOHN WILKERSON was 7 when he dug up a shiny stone arrowhead at a water hole near the family's small ranch in Elko, Nev. Collecting arrowheads remained a passion throughout his youth, spent among the children of ranchers and Shoshone Indians, and much later, when he returned from college to work summers as a cowboy and do research on the economics of raising cattle in the West. Yet he never dreamed that in finding that arrowhead at the water hole he had taken his first step toward becoming, 50 years later, the president of the Museum of American Folk Art in New York.
Today, Mr. Wilkerson is a venture capitalist specializing in medical technology at Galen Associates, a New York firm of which he was a founding partner in 1995. (He had just sold the Wilkerson Group, a consulting firm on medical industry technology that he had started 20 years earlier, to I.B.M.) But he still owns the 60 stone arrowheads he amassed decades ago. "The real jewels -- maybe 10 -- are long and skinny, shaped to travel the farthest," he said. 
 These days, he and his wife, Barbara, are avid collectors with broader interests. Color-splashed barber poles, carousel carvings and apothecary chests enliven his office in Rockefeller Center. Boldly patterned aboriginal spirit paintings add graphic intensity to the interiors of their country home in Pennsylvania. Late-20th-century abstract sculpture fills the gardens of their home in New Jersey, while American folk art reigns supreme indoors.
As the Wilkersons acquired folk art, they met other collectors at, among other places, the Museum of American Folk Art. Mr. Wilkerson became a trustee in 1994, became treasurer in 1996 and late last year was elected board president, replacing Ralph Esmerian, a pre-eminent collector of American folk art, who had been president since 1979. (He remains as board chairman.) Mr. Esmerian had helped Robert Bishop, then the director, guide the institution through turbulent times. Under their leadership, it grew from a one-room museum with a collection of 184 objects, and deeply in debt, to a formidable institution with many masterpieces among its 4,000 objects. It organizes exhibitions that travel throughout the world, and, under its current director, Gerard C. Wertkin, it is building a $22 million museum on West 53rd Street, due to open late next year.
Mr. Wilkerson hopes to build on the success of his predecessors, placing even more emphasis on the business aspects of the museum. "For the last 20 years, the leadership at the museum had focused 75 percent on its collections and curatorial activities and 25 percent on its business management," he said. "Today with everything we have on our plate -- the building going up and an endowment being planned for major acquisitions -- it is a more balanced equation, 50-50."
The Wilkersons are already involved in the museum in other ways, lending pieces for exhibitions. Their 9-foot-long "Angel Gabriel" weathervane was hard to miss in the museum's show marking the millennium. And they have many articles that may be exhibited in the future. Their other weathervanes -- in the shape of horses, cows, angels and American Indians -- hang floor to ceiling in the entrance hall of their home. Pennsylvania German cabbage cutters, embellished with cutouts of hearts and hands, cover a wall in the kitchen. And painted furniture, shop signs, trade figures and watercolors are spread throughout the rest of the house. In this crowded environment, you have to look closely to see the complexity in the haunted Munchlike expression in a woman's face in a gouache by Bill Traylor.
Mrs. Wilkerson had a head start on her husband as a folk-art collector: she bought her first piece -- an 1880's cherry end table -- when she was 14. But he proved a fast learner, succumbing quickly to the easy charm, optimism and diversity of folk art. They began collecting after they were married 33 years ago, and furnished their first home on a tight budget with painted chests, tables and a desk, paying less than $100 for most pieces. By the 1970's, they were buying decorative objects and weathervanes.
The first vane they bought was by J. Howard & Co. of West Bridgewater, Mass. "We knew he was our guy; his vanes were the most striking," Mr. Wilkerson said. "In the 1980's, we decided that we would develop the most comprehensive collection of weathervanes by Howard. We've probably done just that -- nobody else would be so crazy."
Of the 57 vanes they own, 27 are by Howard, a competitor in the 1860's of the better-known manufacturers A. L. Jewell of Waltham, Mass., and J. W. Fiske of New York. Howard specialized in using zinc and copper to achieve a better balance in his vanes. And he made stepping horses of exceptional grace, while Jewell strove for more dynamic movement in his all-copper horses. This characteristic is seen in a Wilkerson treasure, a patinated flying horse by Jewell, its tail and mane borne high by the wind.
The Wilkersons also realize that their involvement in the museum is having an impact on their collecting: they are trying to upgrade what they buy and to better document the pieces that they own. But their biggest problem as collectors, they say, is that they have never sold or given away anything from their collection. "We can't seem to say goodbye," Mr. Wilkerson said. "We have a lot to learn from the curators at the museum on how to fashion and continuously refine a collection."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION/RADIO;
Britain Laughs, and Wonders At Whom It's Really Laughing

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN; Andrew Ross Sorkin reports from London for The New York Times.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
CLAD in his bright yellow athletic warm-up suit, Tommy Hilfiger skull cap, sunglasses and dangling gold chains, the British cult comic character Ali G conducted one of his trademark hoax interviews on his hit late-night television program here with Tony Benn, a longtime member of Parliament and ardent socialist, completely straight-faced.
"These unemployed -- they just chillin' innit, man?" he quizzed a serious-looking Mr. Benn, who appeared thrown by his seemingly black interviewer's unusual style of questioning and choice of clothing. "Is goin' on strike jus' like 'avin' a sickie?" 
 Without a hint of laughter, Ali G probed further. "Does welfare not just encourage young girls to go out and get jiggy with Mr. Biggy?"
Mr. Benn was clearly not in on the joke, in part because he was the punch line, and in part because the comedian who plays Ali G is not a black product of the inner city; he is a white, Jewish graduate of Cambridge University.
But Ali G's audience ate up the segment, repeating bits from the interview at pubs around town for weeks, making "Mr. Biggy" a momentary pop-culture reference among the 20-something generation.
The politician acknowledged after the prank interview that he never realized he was being duped.
Mr. Benn has not been the only one to fall for the tongue-in-cheek antics of Ali G, who has become the television icon of the moment here. A long line of well-known politicians and academics have been suckered. On a trip to the United States, Ali G asked an unsuspecting Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., the former secretary of state, "Is it true that Reagan and Thatcher was doin' it?" He followed up with, "Do you t'ink it's worth nukin' Russia now, while it's weak?"
Played by 28-year-old Sacha Baron Cohen from North London, the Ali G character tries to mock young, white, middle-class suburban men who presume to act stereotypically black, as well as the way in which an older generation reacts to them. His language is a potpourri of American gangsta rap and the Indian and Caribbean accents of the British working class. Mr. Baron Cohen even created a fictitious gang, laughingly called Staines Massive (after the London suburb of Staines), which, of course, is led by Ali G.
The Ali G character has become a lightning rod for praise and controversy, stirring the English to applaud Ali G, who represents a new form of comedy that speaks to a younger generation, and at the same time to condemn the character as another example of racism that has sadly been accepted by a broad and impressionable audience.
The character was created two years ago for several segments on a late-night comedy program called "The 11 O'Clock Show" on Channel 4. The Ali G character, who duped unsuspecting public figures into interviews under the pretense that he was the host of a public affairs program for teenagers, became so popular that an entire weekly television series, "Da Ali G Show," was built around the character by the same network. A home video of the original Ali G segments has become a top seller in Britain, and another video may be on its way.
His shtick has hit such a nerve that Mr. Baron Cohen is set to appear in Madonna's next music video as Ali G and is working on a script for the movie production company Working Title, which made "Four Weddings and a Funeral" and "Notting Hill," about making a movie based on the Ali G character.
It remains unclear whether Mr. Baron Cohen's brand of humor can attract a broad audience beyond Britain and whether it would be accepted without protest elsewhere. While there have been reports here that Talkback Productions, which produces "Da Ali G Show," may try to take the program across the Atlantic, it will almost surely receive an onslaught of criticism from a multitude of minority groups.
Here in England, the Ali G character has come under attack in some circles. Mr. Baron Cohen has received death threats and is regularly condemned in the press. "The fact that he has been a success should not be treated as an excuse to quash discussion about the propriety of the act," a commentator wrote recently in the daily newspaper The Guardian. "If the black and white minstrels weren't funny, then why is Ali G?"
But Ali G's defenders say the act is less about poking fun at minority stereotypes than mocking ignorant whites. "He is about a white kid pretending to be black," said a spokesman for Channel 4. "He is satirizing the way white kids try to copy the black street culture and look ridiculous. If it's offensive to anyone, it's offensive to white people."
Harry Thompson, co-creator and producer of "Da Ali G Show," believes the Ali G character just follows the model of a long list of comedians who have successfully inspired laughs through a bit of racism in Britain.
"Just as Alf Garnett became a hero to bad-tempered racists in the 1960's, and Loadsamoney inspired London football fans to wave wads of cash at their northern counterparts in the 1980's, so Ali has become a cultural magnet for inarticulate youth in the 2000's," Mr. Thompson wrote in The Sunday Times.
"It's a perverse but welcome accolade for one of the most brilliant comic talents that I've ever encountered."
Mr. Baron Cohen refused to be interviewed for this article. In fact, his agent and production company were so worried that Mr. Baron Cohen would become recognizable in the United States because of media coverage -- and therefore unable to successfully pull pranks on future interview subjects -- that they refused to provide "production" photos of Ali G in full garb regularly handed out to British media organizations, or allow photographs to be taken of him as Ali G. (The picture that accompanies this article was obtained from a photo agency.)
But Ali G's cover may not be blown after all. In one of the better-known segments, he is dragged away from an environmental protest by a policeman. "Is it because I's black?" he says. Without even a second glance, the officer replies, "Not at all."

PUB-DATE: June 25, 2000

SECTION: Section 2; Page 4; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2708 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
A Combo of Actors Learns the Joy of Jamming

BYLINE: By WILBORN HAMPTON; Wilborn Hampton is an editor of The New York Times Book Review who occasionally writes about theater.

 BODY:
TOWARD the end of August Wilson's "Jitney," at the Second Stage Theater Off Broadway, the drivers and other denizens of Becker's Car Service return to their storefront office after a funeral. As they enter one by one, you realize you have come to know these characters so well that you feel you have shared the loss with them, as though you, too, are a member of the mourning party.
Even before that final scene, the indelible performances of the nine cast members in "Jitney" have made their characters so familiar that you may believe you have lived in Pittsburgh's Hill District all your life and that your own family has used Becker's for years, to be ferried to the grocery store, washeteria or visits to relatives. 
 You know that if Turnbo shows up, he's going to grumble about being kept waiting and start gossiping; if Fielding gets the call, he's going to try to cadge a dollar extra for a pint of whiskey; if it's Youngblood, he's going to complain about carrying anything in his pristine trunk; if it's Doub or Becker himself, you're going to get a little chit-chat with the ride. You know that Shealy runs the numbers game and that Philmore is the doorman at the hotel. You wonder whether Youngblood will finally be tamed by Rena and whether they will ever get married, now that their boy is 2 years old. And you will probably know all about Booster, Becker's son, who is due to get out of prison soon.
This sense of familiarity begins, of course, with the richly poetic language of Mr. Wilson, a two-time Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright whose Broadway hits include "Ma Rainey's Black Bottom," "Fences," "Joe Turner's Come and Gone," "Two Trains Running" and "Seven Guitars." But while "Jitney" is very funny in the idiosyncrasies of its characters, it is also a poignant evocation of the aspirations of the late 1970's that cuts across color lines, but that happens to be told from an African-American perspective. That it is so full of hope against so much disappointment reflects the indomitable spirit of all Americans whether, as one actor in the cast put it, "black, white or green."
On the surface, the play deals with the social and economic troubles of the time through the impending forced closing of the car service business, which will put the drivers out of jobs. But as with all meaningful plays, "Jitney" operates on deeper levels as well. There is the theme of forgiveness in the release of Becker's son from prison, the sense of wasted lives and compromised dignity in the stories of the older drivers and the dreams for the future through the stormy relationship between Youngblood and Rena. In the end, it is a play about the meaning of love.
Just as composers must rely on musicians to convey the emotional force of their music, playwrights depend on actors to bring their characters to life. And the actors in Marion McClinton's staging of "Jitney" are pitch-perfect.
The comparisons to music are not idle. In a recent conversation with the nine-member cast at the theater, more than one spoke of their performances and the play in musical terms, as did Mr. McClinton. If the actors are the playwright's musicians, the director is the conductor. And in casting the play, the quality Mr. McClinton said he looked for first was the actor's ability to make the extra effort to be an ensemble player rather than just another virtuosic soloist.
"You can tell in auditions whether an actor is an ensemble actor," Mr. McClinton said in a telephone interview from his home in St. Louis. "Often at an audition it's simply: 'Look at me! Look at me!' But when there's give and take between actors, you know you have a team player."
"Hearing 'Jitney' is like listening to the Modern Jazz Quartet," Mr. McClinton added. "Each of the characters has his or her solo, but they've also got to be there as backup for the others."
For Barry Shabaka Henley, who plays Doub, a middle-aged driver, each performance "is like a jam session."
Y OU come in with your own instrument every night," he said, "and you've got to be ready to jump in and play as hard as you can. You get juiced up and feed off each other's riffs. You just can't wait to get out there and play."
The references to soloists and sidemen are especially apt for "Jitney." Each of the characters has a monologue that helps define his or her persona. For Willis Burks II, who plays the numbers runner Shealy, it's a hilarious story about a jinx a woman has put on his love life; for Anthony Chisholm, who is the alcoholic driver Fielding, it's a rueful tale about once being a tailor for Billy Eckstein; for Paul Butler's Becker, it's an account of his wife's death; and for Mr. Henley's Doub, it's about his service in the Korean War, stacking dead bodies: "Six high -- not five, not seven. But always six high." It's a gripping speech, splendidly delivered by Mr. Henley.
But it is brought home to the audience with even greater force by the attention with which Russell Hornsby, who plays Youngblood, a Vietnam veteran himself, listens to it.
One of the first lessons in Acting 101 is that you have to listen to the actor who is speaking (instead of, say, trying to remember your own next line or listening for your cue or trying to steal a scene by distracting attention from the speaker). It is a lesson some actors learn better than others. Few do it as well as the nine actors in "Jitney," whose entire cast was cited for its work with an Obie award.
Mr. Hornsby listens a lot in "Jitney." It is Youngblood, for example, to whom the story of Becker's son's crime is related. Mr. Hornsby must hear the tale eight times a week with a growing amazement and anger that will transfer to the audience almost by osmosis.
"What makes all this work for me is the fellowship we have with each other," Mr. Hornsby said. "We're truly engaged onstage because we're engaged in real life. I ask a question out there and listen because I want to know."
Mr. Burks agreed: "It's something really quite extraordinary we have here. It lets you go out there and hear each moment for the first time every night."
Michole Briana White, who plays Youngblood's independent-minded girlfriend, Rena, said she had been astonished at "the amount of professionalism in the cast" from the first reading of the play. "Ensemble work is not about ego," she said. "It's all about moving the story forward. Everybody puts ego aside in this group."
Another advantage of having a cast that has been working together for so long is the split-second accuracy of timing and blocking with which the action moves. Each actor knows where the others are going to be onstage and at what tempo each scene will develop.
"It's like the Chicago Bulls during their championship years," Mr. Chisholm said. "It's like you are dribbling down court full speed and pass the ball behind your back without looking and you know somebody's there to take it and dunk it."
Mr. Henley interjected: "That was the Harlem Globetrotters." Mr. Chisholm shot back: "The Bulls did it, too."
Certainly the metaphor is apt. In several scenes, especially one toward the end in which an argument develops over a $10 contribution for funeral flowers, the entire cast moves with the precision of a fast break in basketball or the intricacy of a timing pass pattern in football.
ANOTHER mark of the cast's distinction is the way the actors build their characters through small personal traits -- a slight tremor in Mr. Chisholm's hand or the way he fumbles with the cap on a half-pint of whiskey; how Mr. Butler uses a fedora to create Becker's aura of respectability; the way Mr. Burks and Mr. Hornsby consult the small notebooks in which each keeps the figures that define their success in life. It is through such specificity that the audience comes to know them.
Describing the cast's closeness, Leo V. Finnie III, who plays the doorman Philmore, said: "About 45 minutes before the show every night, we all get together and talk about what we've been doing. 'What was your day like?"What's been going on?' "
Mr. Henley added: "I love every member of this cast. Oh, we may argue from time to time, but it's like family arguing. Some nights we all hold hands before we go on."
Mr. Chisholm, who has appeared in four of Mr. Wilson's plays, said: "In all of August's plays something happens that puts you in a different kind of place. But in this one, with this cast, there is an intangible cohesiveness you don't find in the others."
Mr. McClinton, the director, also spoke of the "intangible element" that has evolved in this production. "It's not something you can direct," he said. "It doesn't often happen with a cast. And with this one it's developed over the long period of time they've been doing it."
Indeed, one of the reasons behind the success of this staging of "Jitney" is the length of time many in the cast have been performing it. It has long been Mr. Wilson's habit that his plays tour the country in various regional theaters while he polishes them with rewrites before they land in New York.
"Jitney," which was the first play Mr. Wilson wrote in his cycle dealing with the African-American experience in each decade of the 20th century, was originally produced in 1979 in his native Pittsburgh. The present version, for which the author made revisions, was first staged in 1996 for the Pittsburgh Public Theater, and four of the nine current cast members have been with it since its inception. But it has not been a straight path to New York. Along the way it has played in Baltimore, Boston, Chicago, Washington and Los Angeles, among other cities.
Stephen McKinley Henderson, who plays Turnbo, said that some of the actors had made sacrifices to stay with the play. "We wouldn't know where it was going next," he said. "The Pittsburgh production was supposed to be it. But just as we were winding up, somebody else said they wanted to do it. We'd do that one, and then another theater would want it."
Mr. Burks said that some of the actors would take other jobs in between productions. "I worked on a couple of movies, but I would always be available for the next time someone wanted to do it."
The dedication of the actors to the play had been there from the beginning, Mr. Butler said: "It evolved from the very first reading. It was like we all looked at each other and said, 'We gotta go! We gotta go!' "
The initial enthusiasm has been infectious for those who have joined the cast since. Carl Lumbly, who plays Becker's son, Booster, is the newest member. "I just feel gratitude for being part of this group," he said. "To be with a cast that is committed to meeting and then topping the bar every time."
The length of time in a role can have its drawbacks. Actors can get tired of a character and end up delivering perfunctory readings while walking through the part. In theater it's called "mailing in a performance." This has not happened in "Jitney."
"The play itself is so exciting," Mr. Hornsby said. "I look forward to doing it every night. It's an emotional thing for everybody."
Mr. Henderson agreed that the play was the main reason. "We've all sort of made a mission out of this," he said. "Because of August. And also because at some point you begin to realize that you're delivering something that's important."
Ms. White said another factor was that the cast keeps working on their characters. "After every performance, Russell and I talk about how our scene worked that night," she said, referring to a confrontation she and Mr. Hornsby have in which Ms. White delivers a virtual manifesto on behalf of black women. "We discuss the performance and ask ourselves how we can improve it. Do I need to listen more? Should I put my foot down more? You can't play the same notes every night. That's what keeps it alive and fresh."
Every season that includes a new August Wilson play is a reminder of the vast mine of talent among black actors in this country that one rarely gets to see onstage.
Have opportunities increased over recent years for black actors? Has the movement known as nontraditional casting -- using minority and female actors in roles written for white males -- made any difference?
"It goes in cycles," Mr. Henley said. "I think there were even more black shows in the 70's than there are now. Black actors are a reflection of black workers in other fields. When it's convenient for us to be seen, we'll be seen. If Hollywood sees there's no danger of losing money on a black project, then they'll do it. When 'Waiting to Exhale' did well, everybody thought, 'Finally, a black movie made money, now we'll finally see more.' But it doesn't happen. The trend goes back and forth."
Mr. Chisholm said he saw more opportunities for African-American actors on television than the stage: "Today, because there are more television channels, there are more chances to get something done -- a miniseries or some project like that. But as far as the theater is concerned, the chances are few and far between. Sometimes you have to wait for years."
Regional theaters, Mr. Henderson said, "are good for this."
"There is a lot of theater between L.A. and New York," he noted. "Actors get work because of these companies. We need more of them so we can have ensembles. Because, you know, for actors, there are no unimportant roles."
Mr. Chisholm agreed. "I'm an actor. I can play a lizard, anything. I've worked in 'nontraditional' theater. I did 'Of Mice and Men.' Played Slim. The great Joe Fields did a Willy Loman. We as actors want to act. But first of all, I'm an African-American. And putting all politics aside, what we need is more producers, more writers and, as a people, more cohesiveness. We as black people have got to support the theater. If people all came to see 'Jitney,' it would run for 10 years."
Mr. Henderson, who is on the faculty of the State University of New York, Buffalo, said: "It depends on what you mean by 'nontraditional' and 'traditional.' I've had people say to me: 'You're a good actor. You should be doing Shakespeare or Shaw.' I'm all for black actors doing those roles. But don't tell me playing those roles has to be the goal of my career. This is a big country and it is all of our stories that make it great. People should listen to all the stories. If you don't get 'Joe Turner's Come and Gone' or are uncomfortable about it, still go out and see it."
MR. HENLEY said that one of the reasons "Jitney" is "so special is the thread of universality in it that makes it more accessible to white people." Some of Mr. Wilson's plays "agitate a white audience," Mr. Henley said.
Mr. Chisholm, who appeared in "Two Trains Running," compared the audiences that came to that play and those at "Jitney." "You get a very different feeling from the audiences for 'Jitney,' " he said.
For Ms. White: "This play is so moving. Although it is set in the 1970's, it still applies to women today. I can totally relate to Rena. She was ahead of her time. For her to have the kind of courage she does -- to say 'I love myself first' -- she was taking a big risk."
One reason for the wide appeal of "Jitney" is the undercurrent of hope and forgiveness that flows through the play, often even unstated, as when two antagonists who have a bitter running feud resume playing checkers in the final scene.
"This play really reflects its time for black Americans," Mr. Lumbly said. "It's the 70's. Vietnam is over and we black people thought stuff was finally going to happen for us. Our dreams were on fire. And then nothing happened. We saw our dreams start to wither. This was also true for black actors."
Mr. Lumbly recalled that when he and Mr. Butler made the movie "To Sleep With Anger," a 1990 black drama in which they also played father and son, "Somebody wrote that we were 'underknown' actors. But that implies that stardom is what I should be striving for. I don't agree with that. As black actors, we should be concentrating simply on becoming better artists."
One thing is certain. The cast members of "Jitney" are having the time of their lives acting in it. "We're all so excited about this play," Mr. Burks said wistfully, "that I sometimes wish I could just sit in the audience and watch us."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 15; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 785 words

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM;
Of Eggs and Single Baskets

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AS baby boomers, we are getting a reputation. We take heat for our questionable cell-phone habits, the big trucks we drive and our overall obsession with money. Now investment advisers are shaking their heads over how we invest. We are, they say, incredibly risk-prone and oblivious to the lessons of history.
We know that, of course, and it seems that many of us don't care. 
 But I do. I stubbornly hang on to my Coca-Cola and Disney stock, refusing to dump these stodgy issues and invest in dot-coms. I own Treasury bills. About 45 percent of my 401(k) account is in money-market and bond funds, the remainder in a stock fund. I have four children, and that makes me cautious.
Not so the rest of my generation, said Steven W. Kaye, president of the American Economic Planning Group in Watchung, N.J. Mr. Kaye advises many people my age and is amazed at the chances they take.
"No group in history has taken on the risks that the baby boomer generation has," he said. "People were more diversified in the past. The generation just before the boomers had a high concentration of health stocks, but nothing like the baby boomers and their technology craze. The group as a whole doesn't seem to care about risk as much."
Tom Mucciolo, 45, president of Medianet Inc., a Manhattan company that teaches people how to make presentations, said he does care -- but is confident that he has made the right choice. Almost all of his investments are in stocks, and about 65 percent of those are technology companies. Yes, he knows it's risky. Yes, he knows he's not diversified. "I'm banking on technology," he said.
"If you talk to an investment adviser, they'll say this guy should have his head examined," Mr. Mucciolo added. "But I'm comfortable with the risk, because it is my risk. I have continual earnings power and time to recover" if the market falls.
Howard S. Cohen, 49, a cardiologist in Warren, N.J., said he has about 80 percent of his portfolio in technology stocks. Like Mr. Mucciolo, he is confident in the sector, and in his ability to recover from any downturn. Still, he said, his position makes him nervous.
"Oh yes, I'm scared," he said about the spring meltdown in the Nasdaq. "When the stock market takes a 30 percent correction, and I'm looking at my savings taking a 30 percent hit, it's very unsettling."
He said that he watches the market closely and that he would become more conservative if the market fell into an extended decline, an event he conceded he has never experienced.
Mr. Kaye says that is part of the problem. "Older people have a better chance of remembering 1972 through '74," he said. "Boomers can't conceive that the S.& P. could lose 50 percent over a three-year period. We're seeing them not being afraid to put 70 percent of their money in technology, because they think that's where the entire future is. They don't realize that there have been other booms and busts, like oil stocks in the early 1980's."
He said some boomers had another habit: loading up exclusively on their employer's stock, leaving them doubly vulnerable if their company falters.
Diane M. Hogan, 43, of Flemington, N.J. accepted that risk with her company, Charles Schwab, which at one time made up most of her portfolio.
She bought the stock through the employee stock plan, and although she said many friends thought she was crazy, she stuck with the strategy for more than a decade. When she left Schwab last year, the value of her stock had grown to about $4 million. It's hard to point fingers when a strategy works. "I don't want to say that it was dumb luck, but I just left it there and forgot about it," she said. "I never thought that I would become a multimillionaire."
She has since sold much of the Schwab stock, but she remains about 70 percent invested in equities -- although in a more diverse portfolio.
"I'm a very risky person," she said. "I sort of feel that you have to take some chances."
NOT with my money, I don't. Those four college educations I'm facing chase me to work every day, and I'm not about to start playing with the money I've worked so hard to put aside. When my T-bills mature, I'm planning to roll them over, not put the money in the latest start-up. I don't have the stomach for what Mr. Mucciolo thinks is fun.
"The game itself is the excitement, more than the actual reward," he said. "If every stock went up 1,000 percent, would I stop playing? No, because it's about the activity, not the result of the activity."
Or as Dr. Cohen said: "It's almost like going on a roller-coaster. You look forward to it, it's scary, but if you get through it successfully, it was quite a ride."
For the record, I hate roller-coasters.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 6; Column 2; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1151 words

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK;
Filling a Niche in the Island's Health Care Industry

BYLINE: By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
AFTER being pronounced dead by medical personnel -- twice -- Charles Lobello, 64, was feeling particularly appreciative of his current rehabilitative facility.
At two hospitals "they told me I'm a walking miracle," said the Flushing resident and emphysema sufferer. "I think the people who work here are the miracles." 
 "Here" is the Glengariff Health Care Center, a 262-bed subacute care center housed in a former mansion in Glen Cove. Glengariff, and a 120-bed sister facility in Port Jefferson, help hospital patients make the transition from acute care to home in a resplendent setting.
Mr. Lobello said he does not recall the circumstances of his most recent brush with death, but when he regained consciousness last month it was not in the Flushing hospital where he was admitted, but in a sunny room of Glengariff, one of the Pratt estates and originally known as Poplar Hill.
The Gold Coast mansion, built in 1907, was turned into a nursing center in 1948. In 1971 a developer, Irwin Miness, bought the property and put up a new nursing home, reserving the mansion for administrative use. A quarter century later his son Michael turned the mansion into a subacute care provider, one of a few on Long Island dedicated to that niche.
The niche reflects changing medical economics: hospitals provide increasingly expensive medical care while curtailing length of stay, while community hospitals, which once provided lower levels of care for longer time periods, now focus on more lucrative specialties.
Most patients are in middle- to late-middle age, suffering from neuromuscular disorders, bone fractures, brain and spinal cord injuries, and amputations. During an average stay of about 25 days, they receive medical and therapeutic services intended to support their return to independent living.
The proprietor's ambitions extend far beyond Long Island. Certain that subacute care is destined to grow, and determined to speed that process, two years ago Mr. Miness launched an independent providers' organization, the New York Health Providers and Subacute Network. It has grown to 13 members who collectively provide 700 acute beds in the greater New York area. Mr. Miness, a developer's son who inherited the trade's fondness for superlatives, calls it "the largest subacute care network in the Northeast."
While common in other parts of the country, subacute care remains unusual on Long Island and throughout New York. The state has not defined standards for subacute care centers.
"At first the idea of a subacute was difficult for doctors here to accept," said Dr. Luigi Capobianco, a senior partner with the North Country Community Physicians, a medical practice based in Glen Cove. "We hadn't been trained in this approach. But we see it's good for the patient. Among physicians, acceptance keeps growing."
The approach, in this case, brings a business consultant's efficiency emphasis to bear on health care delivery, where costs continue to far outpace inflation. At the Glenhaven Health Care Organization, which encompasses Mr. Miness's two facilities, costs are cut by making certain services available at nearby hospitals or clinics. For example, both centers accept patients around the clock, but neither has an emergency room. Nurses provide care that has traditionally been provided directly by doctors.
Its advocates say the practice allows physicians to expand their caseload. "The nurse practitioners are my eyes and ears," said Dr. Capobianco, who spends 12 to 14 hours a week at Glengariff, treating patients from his practice.
Occupying a niche somewhere between the single-minded focus on medical service delivery characterized by today's hospitals and the geriatric, residential orientation of most long-term facilities, the Glengariff centers look well beyond those models, at the same time working within the restraints imposed by both regulatory agencies and third-party payers. The physical therapy area is plush enough to be the gym at a private resort; staffers are attentive and walls are decorated with calming prints of floral arrangements and evocative landscapes. Promotional materials tout the center as a "beautiful, peaceful retreat" offering "a panoramic view of Long Island's Gold Coast."
It is easy to imagine Frederick B. Pratt, the original owner, returning home any day.
Mr. Miness described the center as a rehabilitative and complex medical subacute health care facility catering to a niche that has previously been overlooked: too healthy for hospitals, too young for a nursing home, too ill at the moment to go home.
He said the average convalescent is aged 63, although some are as young as 16. "This is not a nursing home population," he said. "These people are younger, mentally aware. They are here for a 23-day average stay. Long-term-care patients stay 18 months on average, in comparison. So this is a different population in every way, neither acute nor long-term."
While many other places offer subacute care services, only a few market to patients, insurers and hospital discharge planners as offering that specific level of service in all of their facility.
"We have made an enormous adjustment, and investment, to be able to say we do this," Mr. Miness said. "Staffing costs are higher. Pharmacy costs have escalated enormously. Meal costs have as well, and we have totally upgraded them in terms of quality and choice."
During a tour of Glengariff, its chief operating officer, Kenneth R. Winston, greeted many patients by name and chatted with rehab staff about their progress.
"We make it a point not to have a hospital kind of environment," Mr. Winston said as he walked past an indoor shuffleboard court. Pointing to one of the dozens of colorful prints framed and displayed on the walls, he added, "The worst thing in a residential environment is sterility. You won't find that feeling here."
While several other organizations on Long Island offer subacute services, the total number of beds is still well under 500, clearly below need, according to Bill Pascocello, incoming president of the New York State Health Facilities Association.
"We're in discussion with the state to create a subacute category, so facilities will be able to explain to consumers clearly and precisely the level of care they are offering," said Ed Stafford, executive director of the industry group.
On a recent afternoon, Jennie Bugge was sitting in a cozy room outfitted with a stove, oven and refrigerator. The 81-year-old Elmont resident, who suffered a stroke and was transferred to Glengariff three weeks ago, sat in a wheelchair while an occupational therapist helped her learn again how to prepare simple meals.
"This is just a sandwich, but these days it takes me quite a while to do so and then clean up," she said with an uncomplaining smile. "They're helping me here so when I go home I can do it by myself."

HEADLINE: Old Baltimore Inner-City High-Rise Gets a New Life

BYLINE: By CHARLES BELFOURE 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
WHEN the elegant marble lobby and mosaic-tiled corridors are restored in an $8 million renovation that is to be completed next month, the Riviera apartment house will be the fourth of five onetime luxury high-rises on what was once one of this city's most prestigious streets to be rehabilitated in the last six years.
It will join the Emersonian, the Esplanade and Temple Gardens, all of which have been refurbished in recent years. The reconstruction has included replacing the floors of rabbit-warren-like apartments to create more spacious units that are closer to the buildings' original layouts. 
 The Riviera's developers have set market-rate rents for its apartments, seeking affluent tenants for the inner-city location by emphasizing such things as a new entrance to the building from a fenced and gated parking lot and the equipping of all apartments with a T-1 high-speed Internet connection.
Traditionally a city of two- and three-story homes, Baltimore built few large apartment houses before World War II, but these four buildings on Druid Park Lake Drive overlooking the city's main park and its reservoir were the finest of their kind from 1912 to the early 1960's. Now after 35 years of decline, they are again desirable places to live.
The six-story 92,000-square-foot Riviera was built in 1914. It was vacant when it was foreclosed on by the Housing and Urban Development Department in the mid-1990's. The building was acquired by the Baltimore City Department of Housing and Community Development, which issued a request for proposals for its reuse.
In 1998, the team of Pennrose Properties, a development firm from Philadelphia, and Reservoir Hill Hope, a local nonprofit developer, won the right to rehabilitate the Riviera. The project was the first in Baltimore for Pennrose, a company that has developed more than 5,000 units of multifamily housing, including many historic properties, in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware and Washington.
Renovations in the 1960's and 1970's had cut the apartments into a warren of tiny units for subsidized housing, totally obliterating most of the original apartment layouts. One of the few things left from the 1914 design was a six-story-spiral fire escape slide, discovered behind a wall during demolition.
The Riviera originally had eight apartments per floor. It now has nine units per floor: seven two-bedrooms of 1,200 to 1,600 square feet, and two one-bedrooms of about 700 square feet. All 54 units have either open porches or enclosed sun rooms with views of the park or downtown Baltimore.
To redesign the apartments, the building had to be almost gutted. But because it was a Baltimore City landmark and eligible for state and federal tax credit equity for its historic status, many elements were retained. The lobby, with walls of marble and a coffered plaster ceiling, and the mosaic-tiled corridor floors with their original plaster cove moldings were all integrated into the new design, along with new lighting.
As an additional condition for historic tax credit status, four apartments facing the park on the sixth floor and one apartment each on floors one through five, a total of nine units, had to retain or duplicate original interior detailing, like window trim, parquet flooring and baseboards. The brick and stone Classical Revival exterior along with its sheet metal cornice were restored.
The Riviera's market-rate apartments are intended for professionals who work in the city. Rents will be $560 to $800 for the two-bedrooms and $600 for the one-bedrooms.
The building is two miles northwest of the Inner Harbor, the city's hottest rental market, where rents start at $800 for a one-bedroom and $1,200 for two.
"The Riviera will have all the amenities of a high-scale building," said Mark Dambly, vice president and a partner of Pennrose. "There'll be a business center in the basement that offers Internet access, fax and copying machines, as well as a fitness center." A new entrance at the rear of the building will lead to a gated parking lot.
A completely market-rate building tailored for professionals in this location is unusual. The building abuts Reservoir Hill, a once affluent neighborhood of elegant town houses that has been in decline since the early 1960's. Some in the neighborhood are pleased that the units are not subsidized. "This is a sign that says that this community is worth investing in," said Curtis Jones, the board president of Reservoir Hill Hope and pastor of nearby Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.
Aside from the developer's own equity and the historic tax credits, Pennrose received $5 million in loans from HUD and Baltimore City.
By the early 1990's, the Emersonian, the Esplanade and Temple Gardens had suffered the same fate as the Riviera. When the State of Maryland decided to package all of them in a request for proposals in 1994, the Emersonian and the Esplanade were in such rundown condition that the remaining tenants had to be moved to Temple Gardens.
Roizman Development of Plymouth Meeting, Pa., and the Baltimore Housing Partnership won the contract and called the project Renaissance Plaza. Since the three buildings made up the Eutaw-Madison Apartment House National Register District, they were eligible for historic tax credit equity.
LIKE the Riviera, each building had interior features, like distinctive lobbies and corridors, to preserve. "Besides restoring the exteriors, we established historic zones to be preserved," said Patricia Massey, who was project manager and director of the Baltimore Housing Partnership and who now runs her own firm, Katia Development.
The oldest of the three, the nine-story Esplanade, built in 1912, was the first to be completed in 1994. Temple Gardens, at 14 stories the tallest building in Baltimore when it was built in 1926, came next in 1995.
The last to be finished, in 1996, was the Emersonian, an eight-story building constructed in 1915 by Issac Emerson, the creator of Bromo-Seltzer.
With 84 of the 301 apartments at market-rate rents and the rest either subsidized or with income restrictions, the three buildings have had a 99 percent occupancy rate. The entire cost of Renaissance Plaza was $20 million.
The fifth apartment house, at 903 Druid Park Lake Drive -- adjacent to the Riviera -- is vacant. It is on the market for $525,000.
Until the early 1900's, Baltimore's wealthy lived in town houses in the center city or in suburban villas at its outskirts. Apartment living was considered lower class until the first luxury apartment house was built on Eutaw Place, an elite residential district. Once the rich adopted this life style, other apartment buildings were erected, notably at Druid Park Lake Drive, which intersects the entry to Eutaw Place.
Still, high-rise apartment living (six stories or more by Baltimore's definition) had limited appeal, and fewer than two dozen were built before World War II. "A lot of people said these buildings should be demolished, but we re-established that living along the lake was a glamorous thing," Ms. Massey said.

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL;
Celebrating the Man Who Celebrates Ships

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER; E-mail address: lijournal@nytimes.com

 BODY:
ASK Frank O. Braynard about airplanes and he'll reply with words like ghastly, ugly and unpleasant. Talk about cars and he'll dismiss you with a wave of his hand. "The automobile is a passing fad," he said.
But question Mr. Braynard about ocean liners, ask him how many smokestacks the Titanic had (four) and watch the smile crinkle through his wrinkles. Then he'll happily whisk you to his inner sanctum, a book-, file- and memorabilia-stuffed area in the heart of his Sea Cliff basement stacked with information about ships. Breathing hard -- the stairs are not easy to maneuver at age 84 -- he'll take out the framed sketch of the Leviathan that he drew in 1923. 
 "I was able to draw the Leviathan as a 7-year-old child would, but I misspelled my own name," said Mr. Braynard, a maritime historian and artist. "Which is most important? The ship of course, not my name."
Years later, he interviewed 3,000 people and wrote six encyclopedic volumes about the boat, dubbing it "the world's greatest ship." Among the troops who voyaged on the liner after it was seized from Germany was a young assistant secretary of the navy, Franklin D. Roosevelt.
"Ships made America; I love being involved with ships and ship people," Mr. Braynard said, pulling open a drawer brimming with drawings and paintings, including a poster of the Lusitania, a cutaway of the Royal Caribbean Line's Voyager of the Sea, and the Normandie.
The stories of the cathedrals that cruise the seas tumble forth, enough anecdotes to fill the 37 books Mr. Braynard has written and illustrated, from his 1947 tome "Lives of the Liners" to two volumes in the works. Note the piles of postcard reproductions of his pen and ink sketches of ships from the Exodus to the Fire Islander ferry. Among his nautical souvenirs: a large metal "S" from the bow of the Stockholm. When it hit the Andrea Doria in 1956, that was the only letter that survived.
In his second-floor office, Mr. Braynard is compiling sketches for a book about smokestacks. Only 11 vessels had four, his beloved Leviathan only three. The Betsy Ross, a flop of a ship, had an unusual single smokestack. He keeps 400 maritime paintings in the attic.
Born in Sea Cliff, raised in Glen Cove, Mr. Braynard went to bed by the 7 o'clock ship whistles in Hempstead Harbor and traveled to his family's summer home on Martha's Vineyard by steamship.
For his lifelong celebration of shipping, Mr. Braynard received an honorary doctorate from the United States Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point during commencement exercises on Monday. But there was a time when his seafaring expertise was not enough.
"I flunked my Ph.D.," Mr. Braynard said, recalling the two oral examinations he flubbed as a doctoral candidate in history at Columbia University. "All I knew was ships."
The experience made him realize that shipping was his calling. He went to work for the American Merchant Marine Institute, a trade association, then got a job as a ship reporter at The New York Herald Tribune, later going into public relations.
Though sailing wasn't really his area of interest, Mr. Braynard brought the parade of tall ships to New York Harbor, first in 1964, then as Operation Sail '76 in honor of the bicentennial.
In 1979 he became curator of the American Merchant Marine Museum at the Merchant Marine Academy. He retired earlier this year.
But Mr. Braynard and his wife, Doris, continue to ply the seas. In August, they're slated for three one-week cruises on the Disney Magic. On board, he'll lecture about ocean liners and she'll give talks on opera.
Where are they going? "I don't know," Mr. Braynard said. "The Caribbean somewhere. I don't care where we go. It's the ship that counts to me."
 
STAR Graduates
As a young adolescent, Harold Jean-Louis was terribly introverted. He was a good student, but too shy to raise his hand or give a presentation in class.
Though she excelled in class, Leniece Dean had an attitude problem. When her counselor tried to speak with her, Leniece would walk away.
But when they entered the ninth grade at Wyandanch Memorial High School, Harold and Leniece were offered slots in the STAR program (Success Through Academic Readiness), sponsored by the Lake Success-based Institute for Student Achievement. Like the 397 students in the academic enrichment and counseling program in the Hempstead, Roosevelt and Wyandanch schools, they were identified as at-risk youth.
During the 10 hours a week they spent in the STAR classroom at their high school over the next four years, Mr. Jean-Louis, 18, and Ms. Dean, 18, received help with homework, reviewed for Regents and prepared for the SAT. They attended communications and career workshops. Counselors coached them on social skills, lauded their every achievement and helped with family issues. To broaden their horizons, the STAR pupils visited the Apollo Theater, took ski trips, ice skated in Rockefeller Center and went on college tours.
Yesterday Mr. Jean-Louis, the son of Haitian immigrants who barely speak English, graduated as the valedictorian of his class. Though Wyandanch doesn't offer either advanced-placement or honors courses, when he starts Syracuse University this fall, Mr. Jean-Louis will have accumulated 21 college credits. Ms. Dean was the class salutatorian. She plans to study business administration at St. John's University in Queens.
Of the 24 seniors in the STAR program at Wyandanch High, 20 plan to go to college.
"In my freshman year, there were a lot of different groups I wasn't part of," said Mr. Jean-Louis, the first in his family to attend college. "I was more of an observer. This program came along and I started speaking in class and giving presentations. It's made me more outspoken."
Ms. Dean said the STAR instructors made sure their students succeeded. "If you didn't want to go to class, they walked you to class; they kept tabs on us," Ms. Dean said.
During her final semester of high school, Ms. Dean studied fashion merchandising and design at the Lewis A. Wilson Technological Center, a vocational school in Dix Hills. After college, she plans to start a fashion design company with her best friend and fellow STAR student, Kellie Wyatt, 18.
"Our area is perceived to be villainous and recalcitrant," Mr. Jean-Louis said, reviewing his valedictory theme. "What we are perceived to be is not what we are. Everything they said we couldn't do, we have done. We set the precedent that we can achieve anything we set our minds to."
 
Top Twins
Since the day they were born, each weighing 7 pounds 14 ounces, Jason and Cory Mingelgreen have done just about everything together. They share a room in their Cedarhurst home. They have the same group of friends. So it wasn't surprising when the 17-year-old identical twins split the top spots in Lawrence High School's class of 2000.
"We just try to help each other," Jason said. "It was a friendly competition. I tried to do better than him, but obviously I didn't come out at the top." Cory, the class valedictorian, finished his high school career with a 99.05 average. Jason, the salutatorian, had a 98.77.
Even their rigorous schedule was almost identical: advanced-placement English, advanced-placement physics, advanced-placement government and BC calculus. They were in different advanced-placement economics sections. Jason took advanced-placement Spanish while Cory took a math projects course.
Usually they did their homework together. "It goes quicker that way," Cory said. "We're definitely able to help each other. In my case, because I'm not the super all-around student, I know I wouldn't be No. 1 if it weren't for him helping me."
Jason, who was the editor in chief and sports editor of the school paper, The Mental Pabulum, said he is the better writer and linguist. Cory, who placed fourth in mathematics in the Intel competition in May, is the math and science honcho.
Both work for the Five Towns Community Chest Youth Board. Both are Advanced Placement Scholars and in the National Honor Society. Both like to play basketball on their driveway. But there are differences.
"He may be No. 1, but I'm older," said Jason, born five minutes before his brother. "I'm taller," said Cory, who stands 6-foot-1, nearly two inches taller than his twin.
After working this summer as cabana boys in Atlantic Beach, the Mingelgreens are going separate ways for the first time. Cory will attend Lehigh University's integrated business and engineering honors program. Jason plans to study broadcast journalism and business at Syracuse.
At Lawrence High School's recent senior awards ceremony, Cory received eight awards, Jason got seven.
But who's counting? "It would have been better if I was No. 1 and he was No. 2," Jason said.
"I disagree," Cory replied.
