HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS;
When the Utility Company Is Not Con Ed

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

DATELINE: EASTCHESTER

 BODY:
GEORGE TURNER, a real estate agent and entrepreneur, began to despise Con Edison more than two decades ago. For 21 years, he sent the company monthly checks for electricity and gas service for one simple reason: there was no alternative.
But in June 1999, Mr. Turner received what he considers a blessing in the mail: a letter from Con Edison with a long list of utility companies he could sign up with. State deregulation was forcing the company to open the door to competitors. 
"To tell you the truth, I was just very fed up with Con Edison," Mr. Turner, 64, said. "They have a very strange attitude when you call about something. Anytime I have a chance to deal with someone other than Con Edison, I will take that opportunity, even if it is a slim amount I'll save."
Mr. Turner has signed up with SmartEnergy.com, and while he is only saving a couple of dollars a month, he is pleased. It is refreshing, he said, to hear the voice of someone who was eager to have his business. "Plus, it is a dot-com company, and I am on the computer all day," he said, "so it is easy to deal with."
Some other companies are Central Hudson Enterprises Corporation of Poughkeepsie; Econnergy Energy Company of Pomona, N.J.; and Robinson Enery of Elmsford.
Thousands of residents have signed up with new providers in recent months, according to the State Public Service Commission. And many more may do so as a result of state action last month lifting price controls and allowing utilities to base prices on market conditions. That means that over the summer, when demand is high, Con Edison can raise rates, if it chooses.
SmartEnergy of Woburn, Mass., is offering a yearly fixed-rate plan, which would not be subject to month-to-month rate fluctuations. Company officials would not release the number of Westchester residents who had signed up, but they said that 20 percent of their New York State customers are in the county.
"A lot of people don't really understand what they are getting into this summer," said Gautam Chandra, the president and chief executive of SmartEnergy.
"Utility rates will fluctuate this summer, and a lot of people could be paying a lot more with their host utility. "This is the time to look at other options."
For their part, Con Edison officials said they have introduced a new online service to search for the best prices to help customers avoid rate spikes.
Mr. Chandra's company has begun a multimillion-dollar marketing campaign directed at Westchester customers.
The change was one step in a three-year drive to eliminate many of the monopoly-era pricing regulations governing the state's electricity industry and to help Con Edison ease into a more competitive market, said David C. Flanagan, a spokesman for the Public Service Commission.
The SmartEnergy.com campaign, which included billboards and radio spots, began on April 1. On a number of levels, the push comes at a difficult time for Con Edison. The company is still suffering from last year's public relations setbacks after blackouts in Westchester and New York City. And last month county officials filed a lawsuit to prevent the company from passing on to consumers the costs of a radioactive leak at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant.
Since April, consumers have been charged an additional $2 a month on average to cover the $600,000 a day that Con Edison says it is spending to buy replacement power from other utilities because of the shutdown of the plant.
SmartEnergy is among several online electricity providers that have slowly been expanding across the country. Customers can sign up for service by logging onto its Web site at www.smartenergy.com and then entering their ZIP code to see what is offered in their area.
Although the Con Edison network is still used to deliver power, deregulation has forced the company to let smaller providers sell electricity to Con Edison's customers -- possibly at a lower rate.
Jon F. Sorenson, the chief marketing officer of SmartEnergy, said the company was also offering a combined fixed-rate plan for natural gas. He added that customers receive one bill for both services and a bonus of $25 and 1,000 airline miles for signing up. The air miles plan continues, with customers receiving one mile for each $1 they spend. The fixed rate plan costs about 6.59 cents per kilowatt-hour of electricity in Westchester, about a penny and a half less than the company's similar plan in Manhattan, Mr. Sorenson said.
"It still was not much of a saving," Mr. Turner noted. "But I just said, 'Thank God it is not Con Edison.' "

HEADLINE: JAZZ SOLOS;
Ellington's Other Side

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Regarding Ben Ratliff's thought-provoking arguments regarding the overindulgent jazz soloist and the need for a "jazz literature" "The Solo Retreats From the Spotlight in Jazz," May 28 : I found that Keith Jarrett's response to the article Letter to the Editor, June 11 partly supported, rather than denied, Mr. Ratliff's point. Yes, as Mr. Jarrett pointed out, Duke Ellington's music sounds lifeless without master improvisers to bring it to life. But let's remember, also, that Ellington is one of the few jazz artists whose ratio of solo time to notation is almost equal. It is, of course, the solos that make the written music come alive, but the reverse is equally true. How many jazz artists today are producing notated material that is as lengthy, complex and perfectly ever-present as Duke? I believe that jazz is certainly in need of more Ben Websters, but perhaps in more dire need of composers like Ellington. No one is denying that jazz springs to life in the midst of a great solo. But can anyone deny that jazz needs to grow by expressing itself in new and perhaps more challenging ways compositionally? I believe a critical issue lies unaddressed, one that is fundamental to the ascendancy of jazz soloing: economics. All over America, and especially in New York, jazz musicians have been making about $50 a night for more than 30 years. And since Duke's time the performing opportunities (the real way the music grows) have considerably diminished. How can you ask a musician to rehearse complicated charts that may take him or her hours or days to master under these conditions? His response, whether tacit or out loud, will be to turn the composer down in favor of a situation where he can "just blow." Mingus went through this 40 years ago; nothing's changed. If more of us had a Lincoln Center to commission us, trust me, there'd be a lot of ink flying around.
 
JOEL HARRISON
Manhattan 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Three Scholars' Tales of Courage

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

 BODY:
TALK to any of the newly named Jandon Scholars, and the word resilience comes to mind. Battling financial and family problems, these students struggled to maintain their grades, their equilibrium and their dreams of a college education.
The first 12 recipients of the new scholarships, which recognize academic achievement among low-income high school students, will head to college this fall. The students, from public high schools in Westchester, will each receive $10,000 over four years to help pay tuition. 
The program is financed by the Jandon Foundation, a private family foundation started by Jane and Donald Cecil of Harrison. Mr. Cecil is a co-founder of Cumberland Associates, an investment firm in Manhattan. The County Social Services Department identified promising students whose families were living below the poverty level. Scholarship recipients were then selected by an academic panel, which considered the students' grades, Scholastic Achievement Test scores and character. Here are some of their stories:
 
Neelam Gidwaney
Neelam Gidwaney still remembers her father's beautiful hair. But that image is soon replaced with those of his illness -- epileptic convulsions, wheelchairs and partial paralysis. Neelam's father, who became ill with a brain tumor when she was in second grade, died a month before her 16th birthday.
"He was sick for most of my childhood," Neelam said. "I have a vivid memory of my mom helping him out of the shower and seeing for the first time that he had no hair. I was just shocked. I kept thinking, "What's going on with my dad?"'
To protect Neelam, her family held back the truth of her father's diagnosis, even telling her once: "Daddy is like tarnished silver. The doctors will polish him up and make him shiny again."
But the reality of her father's illness colored her childhood. Medical and financial crises were constant, and Neelam began working in fifth grade. She earned money in elementary school by baby-sitting. By high school she had held jobs as a lifeguard, a cashier, a pharmacist's assistant and a restaurant hostess.
Despite all the pressures, Neelam maintained an outstanding academic record at Dobbs Ferry High School, with a 3.8 grade point average in advanced placement courses, National Honor Society membership and many achievement awards.
This fall she will attend SUNY Binghamton, where she has been accepted into a combined college and medical degree program. After completing four undergraduate years, she is guaranteed admission at Syracuse Medical School.
Becoming a doctor has been a dream since childhood. "When my father was diagnosed with cancer it was hard for me to accept it," she said. "And no one would take the time to explain it to us. Part of my wanting to be a doctor is that I wanted the peace of mind of knowing what really happened and why it happened. Even young children have a right to know."
 
Kelly Marie Jones
In her school's production of "Peter Pan," Kelly Jones played one of the lost children. It was poignantly fitting. When Kelly was 15, her mother left home, taking most of the family's possessions and leaving behind a note saying she not be back.
Kelly's father, who was estranged from her mother, then tried to prove that he was not her father. DNA tests proved that he was, and he had to continue paying child support.
Yet throughout this trauma, Kelly maintained her 94.5 average at Peekskill High School. She played on a number of sports and performed in musicals. This fall, she will attend SUNY Oneota.
"I just knew I had to make my life better," Kelly said. "I wanted to be stronger than my mom, and I had to overcome what had happened."
Kelly said the support of teachers and good friends helped see her through difficult times. She and her three younger siblings live with her grandparents, who receive assistance from Social Services. Kelly works at Macy's about 20 hours a week. After college, she hopes to pursue a master's degree and a doctorate. Her dream is to become a high school social studies teacher.
"I realize I have many goals in life, and that it's going to take a lot of hard work, but I feel I'm ready for the challenge," she said.
 
Deyci Rodriguez
Deyci Rodriguez came to this country from the Dominican Republic when she was 5. She learned English quickly, became an honors student and was active in school sports. Both her parents held skilled jobs, and they lived in a big house in Sleepy Hollow.
But life began to change for Decyi in her teens. First, her father became ill and could no longer work. Shortly after that, Deyci's mother injured her back and had to leave her job as a nurse. The family moved to an apartment and began to receive public assistance.
For Deyci, there was no more time for cross country, track or softball. She had always held some kind of job while attending school, but now she works 30 hours a week. She returns home from her job as a cashier at 10:30 p.m. and then begins her homework, sometimes working until 2 or 3 a.m. to finish her studies.
Through it all, she has maintained a grade point average of over 94. This fall she will attend New York University. She is interested in a business career and hopes one day to own her own accounting business.
As a Hispanic, Deyci said she had often been told that women were not as strong or intelligent as men. Deyci said her inspiration has always been her mother. Mrs. Rodriguez, who grew up in a poor village in the Dominican Republic, completed college and got her nursing degree.
"My mother has raised me to be a strong, independent young woman," Deyci said. "There no longer is a question of my success. I will succeed -- the question now is when and where."

HEADLINE: DOWN THE SHORE;
Help Wanted: Flexible Hours, Ocean View

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: STONE HARBOR

 BODY:
Madlynn Zurawski collapsed into the corner chair near the stage in Coffee Talk, her little coffeehouse in this South Jersey shore town. The morning rush was through and Ms. Zurawski had a few minutes to recharge before the lunch crowd.
Business is great, but Ms. Zurawski has little time to enjoy that fact. It seems that the economy has also been good for the young people who used to beg for summer jobs at the shore, and the supply of job seekers is scarce. 
 The lament stretches from Sandy Hook to Cape May: The usual torrent of young people who want to work hard, earn some cash, party hard and come back for another cycle the next day is dwindling. With a few exceptions, jobs -- even the glamorous job of lifeguard -- are either going wanting or have taken a lot more time and effort to fill.
Richard Samuelson, owner of Poor Richard's Inn, a Cape May bed and breakfast, spoke of the young people who have traditionally come from Ireland to work at the Jersey Shore. "The Irish kids used to come here, work very hard and party hard," he said. "Now, I think the economy is good there, so the kids who come here do so mostly to party, not work." .
So, Mr. Samuelson said, it takes more to lure workers. "I'm willing to pay $10 an hour for chambermaid work, which is mostly changing sheets, but even high school girls reject that," he said. "High school. Ten bucks an hour for clean work. It's a new world."
That world includes fewer college students looking for work. Mz. Zurawski said:"I have had to hire more local high school kids than ever before. Rentals have gone up in price around here, so I think there are fewer college kids who want to come down and spend that kind of money."
Across from Ms. Zurawski sat Jennifer Dailey, who owns People, People, a women's clothing store around the corner from Coffee Talk. Ms. Dailey has always been able to hire knowledgeable employees a little older than the summertime norm.
"My ideal person, well, now they are tending bar because that's where the money is," she said. "It's tough for me to have to hire high school kids, but that seems to be what I have to do. It's a new reality."
Nor was his situation at all unique.
"It seems -- and I don't want to sound like an old fogy," said 48-year-old Bill Gehlhaus, co-owner of Keansburg Amusement Park and Runaway Rapids Waterpark in Monmouth County, "that work is not on a lot of young people's minds.
"Maybe some are going to school, but I'm thinking that Mom and Dad have a little more money and are giving them bigger allowances so they don't have to work in the summer," Mr. Gehlhaus said.
"We've never had it like this year," he continued. "We have 175 employees, and we'd really like to have 200. Sometimes, my brother Hank and I have to get out and man the rides, and we own the place. We have good workers, but you don't want them working too many hours early in the summer and burn them out. It's a long summer and you dont want to over-stress them."
Down on the Wildwood boardwalk, the Morey Organization has had to be creative with incentives to keep the 1,700 seasonal workers at its three amusement piers and two water parks.
"We know that kids who come to the shore to work come for social reasons as well," said Denise Beckson, the Morey operations manager. "So we sponsor a soccer team and a volleyball team. We have pizza parties and one after-work party each week. We do scavenger hunts and give prizes, like backpacks, in recognition of good work.
"It helps, especially since most of the people we hire are 18 to 22," she said. "When you can work outside and later party with 1,700 people your own age, we figure that's a way to attract good workers."
Morey uses mostly American college students early in the summer, but by mid-August, when they begin to go back to school, the remainder of the Morey workforce is foreign students on four-month work visas whom Morey and other employers find through student-worker agencies. In the past, most of these workers came from Ireland. But Ms. Beckson said this year's crew comes from Jamaica, Belarus, Russia, Poland, Finland, Ireland -- "really all over."
Ms. Beckson said Morey likes these student workers because they have to be motivated to apply for the work visa, and some take English lessons to qualify. "They can often be better than the American workers," she said.
Frank Russo-Alesi, the borough administrator in Belmar, a middle-class Monmouth County Shore resort town, said he felt he had been lucky, that summer special police and lifeguarding jobs have filled nicely. Jerome Joyce, the lieutenant of the beach patrol in Avalon, in Cape May County, said he had enough lifeguards but that beach-tag checkers have been at a premium.
"In the past you had to be 18, but now we have checkers who are 16," he said. Mr. Joyce said there were even incentive programs for beach-tag checkers: an extra $1.50 a day if they stay through Labor Day, a $25 bonus for selling extra beach tags. "It's just hard to get college kids, especially if they have to pay higher rents. They need more money, which we really can't afford. So we have to use younger girls who come down here with their parents."
Down a few miles in Stone Harbor, the main shopping drag of 96th Street is still full of help-wanted signs. Some are creative, like that at the Eagle's Eye clothing store ("Our Customers Make Our Best Employees"), and others seem a little more desperate, like the "Help Wanted" crayon-on-cardboard sign in the window of the Stone Harbor Fudge Factory.
The True Value hardware store in the middle of the shopping strip has restocked its "Help Wanted" sign shelf.
"In fact, we just finally took our own Help Wanted sign out of the window this week ourselves," said one True Value manager. "It never used to be a problem to hire people to work here for the summer. To be into the first week of summer still hiring, well, there must be a lot of well-off kids out there."

HEADLINE: Don't Blame Racial Bias In Bedford Budget Fight

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Regarding the article "Behind Bedford School Budget Fight: Economic and Ethnic Divisions" last Sunday:
As I read the article, at first I was angered. 
 After finishing the article I was incensed.
To say that the Bedford school budget was voted down because of ethnic division is totally without fact. The reason that your reporter could find nobody to be quoted about the "largely unspoken resentment" toward the Hispanic population is because it is a small, very small number of people who feel this way -- if there are any at all.
As one of the 606 Bedford Village voters to vote no on this budget, I did not do it because I am anti-Hispanic, as your article implies.
I voted no because the Bedford school board spends money as if they have unlimited money.
As a middle-class, tax-paying New Yorker, it is tough enough making ends meet. But when the cost of living goes up only 3 percent and the school board wants a raise of 8.5 percent, something is wrong.
Everybody wants better schools, but to keep on throwing money at the schools is not the answer.
We tell children to not waste the money we give them each week. To be careful and spend that money wisely, and by doing this we try to teach them to live within their means.
Why can't the Bedford school board learn this lesson?
 
MICHAEL GRAF
Bedford

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Rachel Freeman, Bruce Wilson

 BODY:
Rachel Marin Freeman, a daughter of Lucile and Harry L. Freeman of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Bruce Bridges Wilson, a son of Kay Wilson and Dr. Jack Wilson of Mountain Home, Ark. The Rev. Dr. Theodore R. Rosche, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Decatur House Museum in Washington.
Ms. Freeman, 32, is keeping her name. She is the Midwest economic development specialist for the Department of Housing and Urban Development in Chicago. From 1995 to 1997, she was the general director of the Volkhov Business Incubator, which assists businesses operated by women in Volkhov, Russia; she remains a director of the organization. She graduated from Middlebury College and received an M.B.A. from the University of Michigan. 
 Her father, who retired as the executive vice president of American Express in New York, is the chairman and founder of the Mark Twain Institute, an organization in Chevy Chase that gives grants for economic research. Her mother retired as the head of the public library in Poolesville, Md.
Mr. Wilson, 34, is a senior manager at Andersen Consulting in Chicago. He received a bachelor's degree and an M.B.A. from Washington University. His mother retired as an English teacher at the Mountain Home High School. His father is a family physician in Mountain Home.
The couple, who met at a wedding in 1998, credit the bride's dog, Sunder, a Central Asian shepherd, with bringing them together. When they were first dating, Ms. Freeman was touched by the care Mr. Wilson lavished on Sunder when the dog became ill.
"I knew then that he was a good person," she said.
The dog also played a part in moving the couple closer together and keeping them there. Early in their relationship, Ms. Freeman decided to move to Chicago, where Mr. Wilson was living, because she felt the climate would suit the dog. Later, Mr. Wilson passed up a job in Singapore, which was too steamy for Sunder.
"I have no illusions that if I weren't somebody who really enjoys that sort of close man-dog relationship, the connection wouldn't have been there," Mr. Wilson said.
While the dog did not attend the wedding, her picture was affixed above a copy of the couple's wedding vows, which the guests signed.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Yesterday, a Grimy S.R.O.; Today, a Tourists' Haven

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
The Park View Hotel, at 55 West 110th Street, was once a landing pad for West African immigrants, providing an enduring, if bitter, first impression of New York. Five years ago, there was a term for it: "Doing the 110."
While they lived there, these recent arrivals worked as taxi drivers, street vendors and students, trying to climb the rungs of New York's economic ladder to escape the grimy gray single-room-occupancy hotel, which they shared with a handful of native New Yorkers, many of them welfare recipients. 
 Fast forward five years:
A group of young Swedish tourists linger in the hotel lobby, which is painted in vibrant blues, oranges and yellows and has large leatherette ottomans dispersed around low-lying tables. They plan a day of trips downtown, as clerks at the front desk, wearing matching orange suits, chirpily greet arriving guests from France or England.
The Park View, like much of this block on the northern edge of Central Park, has undergone an enormous transition in recent years. Now a refurbished youth hostel, the hotel, owned by Tenrit Studios, charges visitors $26 to $110 a night for either a shared or private room.
Among the other nearby improvements, the Harlem Meer, the 11-acre lake at the northeastern edge of the park, was restored during the 1990's with the help of the Central Park Conservancy. And the Transit Authority recently completed renovation of the subway station at 110th Street and Lenox Avenue, which had been shuttered for 15 years.
Responding to the change, local businesses have cleaned up their storefronts and added matching green awnings to create a uniform look. Aliyyah Baylor, president of Make My Cake, which owns a bakery on 110th Street, grew up in the neighborhood and has seen the change.
"You've got the same people here, but the appearance is different," she said. "There has been a redeveloping of businesses that were not in operation for many years. You have landlords who are now going for a different look, more of a comfortable look, not just your average bodega."
Gunnar Carlson, a 26-year-old Swede who was visiting his fellow tourists in the Park View lobby, said he had gone to 110th Street the last time he was in New York, in 1993. "It's a lot nicer now than it was then," he said.
But not everyone sees this change as positive. Elizabeth Kane, director of the West Side S.R.O. Law Project, a tenant group, said that in the Park View renovation many tenants "were brutally treated and driven out of the building."
Tenrit Studios did not respond to numerous requests for comment. But Robert Blanche, the general manager of the Park View Hotel, said 50 permanent tenants remained in the building and that the owners had tried to be sensitive to their needs since they bought the building in October 1999.
"I don't know about any complaints," he said. "But we've turned this property around 250 percent, not only for the permanent tenants but for the community at large." NINA SIEGAL
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photos: The newly refurbished Park View Hotel at 55 West 110th Street has a brightly lit lobby and rooms that rent for $26 to $110 a night. A reminder of its rougher days is the razor wire on the roof. (Photographs by James Estrin/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "TURNAROUND: A Central Park North Revival"
The area around 110th Street and Lenox Avenue has undergone a number of changes in recent years:
 
Early 1990's -- The Harlem Meer is restored and Duck Island, a natural refuge for wild fowl, is created in its center.
1993 -- Dana Discovery Center, a science center for children at Central Park's north end, is renovated and reopened.
1996 -- Playground at north end of park is renovated.
Late 1990's -- Businesses along Lenox Avenue near 110th Street put up green awnings.
1998 -- Refurbished subway station at 110th Street and Lenox Avenue opens.
October 1999 -- Renovation of Park View Hotel begins.
April 2000 -- Park View reopens as a youth hostel.

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for BIJAN NAMDAR ZANGANEH;
Toward Oil Price Stability, Step by Step

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE

DATELINE: VIENNA

 BODY:
DRESSED modestly in his native collarless garb, occasionally fingering a strand of prayer beads, Bijan Namdar Zanganeh, Iran's petroleum minister, led a contingent of similarly reserved, gray-bearded men who together played the role of wild card last week during the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries here.
When high oil prices drove OPEC to raise output in March, the Iranians, led by Mr. Zanganeh, publicly rebelled, complaining of one too many late-night phone calls to negotiators from Bill Richardson, the American energy secretary. (Ultimately, they increased their country's exports.) Last week, however, with crude oil once above $30 a barrel and OPEC again under pressure to raise production, the Iranians quickly went along with the majority. 
 After weathering the manic dips and rises of oil prices over the last 18 months, Mr. Zanganeh, like other OPEC representatives, craves stability, which he believes the plan to raise output by 708,000 barrels a day should afford. It also helped, Mr. Zanganeh said, that there were no more trans-Atlantic phone calls interrupting the talks.
Mr. Zanganeh, born in 1952, is a civil engineer by training. He became petroleum minister in 1997.
First at a press briefing and then in his hotel suite, Mr. Zanganeh discussed the rationale behind OPEC's latest decisions and their impact on the global oil market. Following are excerpts from the conversation. NEELA BANERJEE
 
Q. Have you had discussions with United States companies about developing new oil and gas fields?
 
A. We have had many discussions with U.S. companies. But they have unacceptable limitations on their activity in Iran placed on them by the administration. I don't think it's good for open and free trade. It's a decision that goes against both sides. It deprives U.S. companies from participating in our projects. We have money to develop our fields, but we would prefer to have the participation of first-class foreign companies.
 
Q. How did the atmosphere of this OPEC session vary from that of the last one, which seemed full of tension?
 
A. We had a very good atmosphere this time. In our last meeting, all the members complained of U.S. intervention. We didn't feel external political pressure this time.
 
Q. How did OPEC arrive at the figure of 708,000 barrels a day?
 
A. It was a compromise, and we will support it and respect it. We ourselves will be producing 104,000 barrels a day more. The decision was not hard, because we had decided before that if the price got up to $30 a barrel, we would increase production by 500,000 barrels a day.
And it's all very close: a matter of oil being $2 more a barrel than $30 and producing 200,000 barrels more than 500,000 barrels. That is all much the same.
We only validated our previous decision.
 
Q. How would you respond to criticism from the United States and other nations that this agreement does not go far enough to dampen high oil prices?
 
A. We felt we must be very careful in this situation to test the market. If the market needs more oil, we will produce it. We have an automatic mechanism for it. And there are only three months before our next meeting, which will give us time to see the effect of this decision. Step by step, we will test how much the market needs.
We are looking for a stable price, not necessarily high or low.
Now we are planning for oil to play a smaller role in our budget. We would like to use the revenues from oil to create funds that would support our private sector.
 
Q. What is the automatic mechanism you have now within OPEC to increase production if your latest decision does not bring down oil prices? And why is there so much secrecy around it?
 
A. This is what you call a gentlemen's agreement. Let's just say that.

HEADLINE: Personal Business;
From Gore and Bush, Uncooked Retirement Stew

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
FEW issues point up the ideological gulf between the likely major-party presidential candidates more clearly than their approaches to inducing Americans to save more for retirement.
Vice President Al Gore, the Democrat, wants the government to provide a subsidy of as much as $3 for each $1 that a worker kicks in to his or her retirement kitty; this proposed new entitlement program is intended to favor the relative have-nots. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the tax-cutting Republican, will probably endorse a plan under which the kitty will be fattened by redirecting taxes that now help finance Social Security. 
 The two sides have in common a recognition that voters want Social Security's long-term health to be seriously debated, not avoided as taboo. And they share a belief that shortfalls in retirement security are best made up in the financial markets.
Mr. Bush was first to publicly sketch out a plan. But Mr. Gore, who used to attack the idea of investing Social Security money in stocks, has laid out his proposal in much greater detail.
Now that the debate has been joined in earnest, some investment advisers have begun tentatively sizing up the competing plans, neither of which is yet concrete enough to reward close financial scrutiny. Indeed, Mr. Bush has yet to provide the most crucial single number: the portion of the 12.4 percent Social Security tax, half of which is paid by employers, that he would divert into private investment accounts. That, he contends, is a job for legislators.
Despite the vagueness, though, one preliminary finding has emerged: Assuming that cash can be spared to take advantage of the government's matching offer, for most people Mr. Gore offers more.
"The Gore plan would be better," at least in terms of the greatest benefit for the greatest number, said Thomas P. Ochsenschlager, a specialist in personal taxation in the Arlington, Va., office of Grant Thornton, the accounting firm. He pointed to the way it would give a couple earning $30,000 a year and able to save $1,000 in the plan an extra $3,000 in matching money, and to how it would leave existing Social Security benefits unchanged.
BUT the Gore plan becomes much less attractive as incomes rise, with the matching money dwindling to zero for households earning more than $100,000. Other advisers, looking beyond the raw figures, take a dimmer view.
"My clients would be hard-pressed to see that they would benefit from the Gore plan," said Carol I. Johnson, a financial planner at Voellinger, Simpson & Associates, an accounting firm in Belleville, Ill. She said this group, 30 percent of whom have household incomes of less than $100,000, are more interested in ensuring the solvency of Social Security, which is neither "fixed" nor undermined by the Gore plan, than they are in a new entitlement program.
Under Mr. Gore's proposal, which would be voluntary and phased in over 10 years, the government's match would take the form of a tax credit -- a dollar-for-dollar reduction in income tax. The credit would be refundable, meaning that if it exceeded your income tax liability, the Treasury would write you a check for the difference.
Your money would be pooled with the government's in a tax-deferred account managed by professionals who would invest it broadly, avoiding individual stocks. A typical household could expect the account to swell to about $200,000 over 35 years, according to plan's architects. Funds could be tapped without penalty for college tuition, heavy medical expenses or a first home.
Mr. Bush is much bolder, proposing to modify the Social Security system itself, an initiative that he will bill as addressing impending shortfalls in the system's finances but critics say could instead put the system in greater jeopardy.
Mr. Bush has said he wants to let workers divert an unspecified share of the Social Security taxes that they and their employers pay into self-managed personal accounts. In return, the workers would agree to accept a smaller guaranteed retirement benefit from Social Security, which would be deprived of the diverted revenue.
A wide variety of specific proposals could fit into what Mr. Bush calls his "framework." But one plan that is being promoted by a close Bush adviser, Martin S. Feldstein of Harvard University, is a suitable proxy. Dr. Feldstein would have the government deposit 2 percent of each individual's income into a privately managed portfolio, three-fifths invested in stocks and two-fifths in corporate bonds, a mix that would have yielded a 6 percent annual return, adjusted for inflation, over the last 50 years.
Dr. Feldstein, who served as chief economic adviser to the Reagan Administration, calculates that a 21-year-old who follows this plan to retirement would have an even chance of beating the currently projected Social Security benefit by at least one-third. Conversely, he figures that the chances of winding up with less than 90 percent of what Social Security alone would have yielded are below 1 in 10.
WHILE financial planners say it is not yet possible to compare the plans with any rigor, they tend to prefer that of Mr. Bush, perhaps because it is skewed to mainly benefit the well-to-do who are their main clients.
"The 60-40 plan sounds better," said W. Michael Cooper, a planner in Lexington, Ky. "This business about the tax credit I'm not comfortable with," he added, citing administrative complexity and opportunity for fraud, among other factors.
Steve Garrett, manager of financial planning services at A. G. Edwards, the St. Louis-based brokerage firm, said he doubted whether lower-income families could muster even the modest amount of cash needed to qualify for Mr. Gore's credits.
Many workers taking part in the Gore plan would do so with money otherwise destined for 401(k) plans, which would throw the balance of lower-paid and higher-paid workers in such plans out of kilter and severely limit employers' ability to offer them, according to Dan Halpin, a benefits specialist with Grant Thornton.
Paul A. Levis of Summit Financial Consultants in Yonkers said that even the Bush-Feldstein plan, with its 40 percent bond requirement, would be too timidly invested for his taste. Referring to his daughter, Ashlie, who recently graduated from college, he asked, "Why not give her the ability to put 100 percent" in stock mutual funds?
Then there was Mary B. Hevener, a payroll tax expert for Weil, Gotshal & Manges, who said she was "hard-pressed to say which one is worse," a generous-to-the-poor Gore plan that seems to invite wholesale cheating or a Bush plan that she said risks aggravating, rather than reducing, the threat posed to the Social Security System by the aging of the baby boom generation.
"The richer and older you are, the more you're going to go toward Bush," Ms. Hevener said, but "the crooks are going to like Gore better."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Chart/Photos: "Sizing Up the Plans"
The two major presidential candidates have taken sharply different approaches to enhancing retirement savings with investments in the financial markets. Because very few specifics of the George W. Bush's plan have been announced, details of a version promoted by a close Bush adviser, the economist Martin Feldstein, are used in this comparison.
 
GORE PLAN
 
Basic concept: Government-subsidized investment accounts akin to 401(k)'s, separate from Social Security.
 
Where money would come from: Individual savings, augmented with matching income-tax credits.
 
Ceiling on deposits: $2,000 a year per person, including any matching funds.
 
Impact on government finances: Tax credits would reduce federal tax revenue by $200 billion over 10 years.
 
INVESTMENT COMPONENT
 
Options: Professionally managed, limited to broad-based investments like mutual funds.
 
Risk: A market crash could sharply reduce the accounts' value.
 
Safety net: Existing Social Security benefits would not be affected, no matter what happened to the accounts.
 
BENEFIT FOR:
 
Low-income people: A 3-for-1 match on deposits, assuming that the taxpayer can afford to set aside any savings in the first place.
 
Middle-and high-income people: Deposits are tax deductible, but the matching ratio declines as income rises, phasing out entirely above income of $100,000 a year for a couple.
 
BUSH PLAN (FELDSTEIN VERSION)
 
Basic concept: Individual investment accounts replace some Social Security benefits for participants.
 
Where money would come from: Diversion of some tax money that would otherwise go to Social Security.
 
Ceiling on deposits: Two percent of earnings, up to the maximum taxed for Social Security ($76,200 this year).
 
Impact on government finances: Reduces flow of money to Social Security by an undetermined amount.
 
INVESTMENT COMPONENT
 
Options: Individuals manage investments in approved stock-bond portfolios.
 
Risk: A market crash could reduce retirement income to less than projected Social Security benefits.
 
Safety net: For participants who stick to a balanced portfolio of stocks and bonds, the government might guarantee benefits at least equalling Social Security.
 
BENEFIT FOR:
 
Low-income people: Participation would not require extra savings, but people who have little income would get little or no benefit.
 
Middle-and high-income people: The more money a person makes, the greater the potential benefit, up to the ceiling on deposits.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk
