HEADLINE: The World: An Inseparable Church and State;
On Greeks Playing the Euro Card

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
ON Monday, the European Union tapped Greece to become the latest member to adopt the euro as a common currency. The approval was recognition that Greece, and its newly trimmed economy, was ready to join the club of modern Europe.
On Wednesday, Orthodox church leaders gathered hundreds of thousands of protesters carrying Greek flags and crucifixes in what was the second mass demonstration this month to protest the government's decision to remove religious affiliation from state identity cards, which brings it in line with other members of the European Union. 
 The government views the change as a way to protect minorities and a natural step on the path to European integration and custom. The church, however, views it as an assault on Greek nationalism and identity, and its own authority. "Resist, my dear Christians," Archbishop Christodoulos told cheering crowds. "The forces of globalization and religious marginalization are out to get us."
The clash between national identity and the homogenized political values of a newly integrated Europe is found in other countries eager to be let in. These days, Greece is a society tugged in opposite directions, as it tries to reconcile its past with its uncertain future. It is a member of the European Union and of NATO, yet it is also the poorest country in the European Union and the only one where the Orthodox faith is dominant. Though the country has placed its economic future in Europe, it is also a Balkan nation, bound by history and geography to ancient, unresolved conflicts and festering grievances.
Interest rates, inflation and government spending are the criteria for entrance into the euro. But membership has other implicit rules of conduct, including religious pluralism and commitment to security. Greece has passed the economic hurdle, but still struggles with the social and cultural costs.
Church and state are not separate in Greece, where 97 percent of the population is Orthodox, and the constitution stipulates that the Orthodox religion is dominant. The country's small Muslim minority is viewed with suspicion by many Greeks who are insecure about Turkey, and who view the recent, new waves of immigration, particularly from Albania, as a source of crime and unemployment.
The country has not taken the same steps to eradicate left-wing terrorism that Germany and Italy took in the 1980's. The Greek terrorist organization November 17, which earlier this month took responsibility for the assassination of the British defense attache in Athens, has committed hundreds of assassinations and bombings in the last 25 years without a single arrest. Greece's failure to combat terrorism successfully is one of the most glaring clashes between the country and its Western partners. The American ambassador to Greece, R. Nicholas Burns, called terrorism "the defining issue between Greece's past and future." There are others.
Greece's loyalty to its allies was most sharply put to the test during the NATO bombing campaign in Serbia. The socialist government of Prime Minister Costas Simitis felt bound to support, or at least not inhibit, the allied bombing campaign, but 99 percent of Greek citizens fiercely opposed the war, prompted by sympathy for the Serbs, who share their faith, and a deeply ingrained anti-Americanism forged when Washington supported the military junta that ruled Greece from 1969 to 1974.
Membership in the euro brings economic and social upheavals that worry many who may not immediately benefit from a new global economy. "The church doesn't exactly speak for them, but it is expressing their anxieties," said Nikiforos Diamandoros, a political science professor who is also Greece's ombudsman.
The country's large population of self-employed small-business men and civil servants are two groups least likely to thrive under globalization, he said. "People who feel threatened by a new economic order have conflated the state identity card with cultural identity," Professor Diamandoros said.
Nationalism has lost some of its political edge as Greece seeks integration with Europe and rapprochement with Turkey, but insecurity about the economic and social costs of assimilation has helped it resurface. While Mr. Simitis's socialist party, Pasok, has shed much of the left-wing populism of the past and toed a more centrist, pro-European line, along with the opposition party, the Greek Orthodox Church has filled the vacuum.
And it is heeded. The church played a huge role in preserving Greek language and culture under the Ottoman Empire. It was one of the few institutions providing moral leadership during the Nazi occupation. Even Greeks who are not particularly religious are not dismissive of the church's role.
AND perhaps emboldened by the popularity of its anti-NATO stance during the war in Kosovo, the church has asserted itself more strongly of late. The church is worried that the country plans to institute a separation of church and state, which among other things would drastically reduce church income.
The battle over the identity cards hit a nerve throughout Greek society. More than 70 percent support adopting the euro, viewing it as a passport to economic growth and stability.
Yet, in a recent poll, 40 percent said they supported the church's stance on identity cards. And that seems to be less about religious fervor than the tension between Greece's traditionalist past and modern future.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
The Border War For the Bibulous

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL 

 BODY:
L'ECOLE NO. 41 is a bustling little winery in Lowden, Wash., not far from Walla Walla. Their 1997 Columbia River Cabernet Sauvignon is a wine to put plenty of better-known California cabernets to shame. But they don't make much wine at L'Ecole No. 41 and unless you plan to be traveling in eastern Washington soon, you may have trouble finding it.
You could ask them to send you a case, but that would be unwise, at least without some advice from your lawyer. In most of this country, you can buy just about anything by phone or over the Internet, from guns to pornography, and have it shipped to your home. Try it with wine, though, and you may be committing a felony. 
 Since Prohibition ended 67 years ago, wine and spirits have made their way to consumers through the so-called three-tiered system -- intended to keep mobsters out of the booze business. Wineries must sell their products to a licensed wholesaler, who sells it to a licensed retailer. Producers may not own any part of the wholesalers, who may have no financial interest in retailers.
Over the last 30 years, however, the number of American wineries has exploded, while the number of wholesalers has plummeted, squeezing all but the larger producers out of the distribution system. There are some 800 wineries in California alone, producing more than 4,000 different wines. But 500 of these producers are tiny, producing perhaps 1 percent of all California wine. Nationally, just 49 wineries produce 90 percent of the domestic wine Americans drink.
Most of the wines that are unavailable beyond the states in which they are made are expensive, but wine lovers, and there are a lot of them, don't want their choices dictated by a few distributors. "The price doesn't bother me," said a New York stockbroker with an extensive wine cellar, "it's the fact that I can't buy them here and I can't have them shipped to me."
Wholesalers, on the other hand, are terrified of direct shipment, which would enable anyone to surf the Web for interesting wines, and order them via credit card or phone. In fact, there is already a thriving direct shipment business for small case lots of wine.
"What began as a cottage industry catering to collectors of hard-to-find wines has become a coast-to-coast $1-billion-a-year enterprise," an industry trade group, the Wine and Spirits Wholesalers of America, warned in a statement last year. The Wine Institute, the research and promotional arm of the wine producers, contends that the figure is closer to $350 million.
Direct shipment "in most states illegally bypasses laws requiring alcohol sellers to be licensed by the state," the wholesalers group said. "It also avoids taxes and makes it easier for underage people to purchase alcohol."
To bring home the supposed danger to the nation's youth from mail-order wine, the industry staged events at which teenagers purchased wine and spirits over the phone or Internet. Direct shipment supporters promptly filled wine publications and Web sites with parodies depicting 14-year-olds guzzling illegally obtained Mondavi Reserve Cabernet and Chateau Lafite-Rothschild in their basements.
Underage drinking and tax collection are problems, said John DeLuca, president of the Wine Institute. But the "loss of income from the direct sales" was the wholesalers' real worry, he said.
This would appear to be the case, since the wine distributors have said that they would support direct shipment, if wine sellers "clear" their sales. Clear, in this case, means paying a commission to wholesalers and retailers for doing nothing. One start-up, called WineShopper.com, says that by using this system, it will supply "thousands of wines" directly to the consumer or to a retailer nearby.
Both the wholesalers and the wineries claim the law for their side. The wholesalers and the states cite the 21st Amendment, which gives the states the right to regulate the liquor industry within their borders. The wineries and consumer groups claim that to single out wine for special controls is discriminatory and a restraint of trade, violating the Interstate Commerce Clause, the Sherman Antitrust Act and even the First Amendment.
FEDERAL district courts in Indiana and Texas have thrown out laws banning direct shipment -- both decisions are on appeal -- and similar suits are pending in half a dozen other states. In the meantime, according to the Wine Institute, 30 states allow some form of direct shipment. Thirteen of them reciprocate with other wine-producing states, some demand permits, some limit the amount of wine a consumer can buy, and 10 allow intrastate shipments only.
Until this legal patchwork is sorted out by the courts, John S. Dyson, former New York State commissioner of agriculture and deputy mayor for finance and economic development under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, seems to have discovered the nearest thing to a solution.
Mr. Dyson was enamored of the wines of Williams Selyem, a small winery in Healdsburg, Calif., which sells all its famous pinot noirs to an exclusive mail order list. Soon after Williams Selyem told its customers that that law prevented it from shipping any more wine to New York, Mr. Dyson bought the winery for $9.5 million. He already owned Millbrook Vineyards in New York State, and as a vintner was entitled to ship wines from California with impunity.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Portraits of Southern Lives Show a Record of Pain and Progress

BYLINE: By HOWELL RAINES 

 BODY:
For someone who knew the South during the days of de jure segregation, The New York Times's series on race in America describes a world of routine social interaction that could be imagined only by rebels, visionaries and dreamers -- almost all of them black -- from the vantage point of, say, Birmingham in 1957. As the series shows, the new multiracial society announced into our national consciousness by the breakthrough victories of the Southern civil rights movement is not free of economic and cultural tensions, of mistrust and plain old prejudice. The series documents that no part of America, North or South, East or West, has fully created what Representative John Lewis calls "the beloved community." It also shows that what was once viewed as a regional story told in black and white is now national in scope and multi-ethnic in content.
All that said, I found that three articles set in my native South stirred a desire to bear witness to the persistence of some distinctly regional themes in this broad narrative about race in America's new century. For example, it seemed especially appropriate to me that the series began with Kevin Sack's story on June 4 about an integrated Pentecostal congregation in suburban Atlanta. Think of the historical convergences in that setting and subject. 
 Atlanta was the spiritual capital of the Confederate South, the intellectual home of the New South economic-development movement, and the command center of the civil rights revolution and the black preachers who led it. The centrality of the black church to racial transformation in America can hardly be overstated. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and his colleagues forged the stories of Moses and Jesus into mighty social weapons. Nor can the failure of the white church in the South be overstated. Its preachers stood in fearful silence. Its congregants tried to ignore the inner voices insisting that belief in the gospels allowed but one response to segregation. While Mr. Sack's reporting found that the Assembly of God Tabernacle may not have perfected the beloved community, its members' effort to do so, within the twin shadows of Stone Mountain and Ebenezer Baptist Church, seems to me apt and momentous.
Ebenezer's most famous pastor, Dr. King, had a special genius for defining the links between economic oppression and racial conflict. His lessons in that regard came to mind when I read Charlie LeDuff's article on June 16 about the black, white, Mexican and Native-American work force at the Smithfield Packing Company's plant in Tar Heel, N.C. For generations, Northern industrial corporations treated the South as a colonial enterprise. They used black-white tensions to keep out unions and fattened their profits through a two-tiered wage system -- low pay for whites, lower still for blacks. In comparison, tenant farmers enjoyed a kind of rough parity. The crop-lien system kept blacks and whites equally impoverished, although blacks could be hanged as well as starved.
But whether in the factory or on the farm, Southern workers were schooled to understand a brutal financial fact. If you will not take this harsh, low-paying, dead-end job, some other hungry person will. What is taking place in North Carolina shows that in the Southern industrial environment, change does not always bring progress. The tough-minded employer in Tar Heel is a Southern firm. Mexican immigrants have replaced blacks and Appalachian whites as the workers willing to take the lowest wages with the fewest complaints. And according to Mr. LeDuff's reporting, there is still truth to Dr. King's teaching that the competition among poor people for grinding jobs brews frustrations that are expressed through racial conflict.
It is a far piece from Tar Heel to Natchitoches, La., where Ginger Thompson reported on the effort to preserve Magnolia Plantation. That article last Thursday reminded me of perhaps the greatest scholarly lesson of the last half-century of race relations in the Southern region and the country at large. That lesson is simply that we may more accurately speak of American histories, rather than a single, monolithic American history. From Colonial Williamsburg to Acadian Louisiana, most preservation efforts have focused on preserving the big house and celebrating the lives of its inhabitants. At Williamsburg and later at Magnolia, a National Park Service ranger named Carla Cowles worked to add the buildings and human histories of the slave quarter to the story of the big house.
Ms. Thompson's article is too complex to summarize here, but the resonant quote with which it ended lingers in recollection as a comment on a broad swath of social experience. That experience has consisted of remarkable levels of social integration in places like the Atlanta church, new levels of intellectual honesty about the past in Natchitoches and, less happily, a persistence of obdurate patterns in Tar Heel and many other places as well. Betty Hertzog, the 70-year-old owner of Magnolia Plantation, spoke of moving away from a property that has been in her family for 200 years. She would depart knowing, of course, that Magnolia Plantation will be used to teach a version of Southern history far more complex than that associated with the traditional plantation "tours" of decades past.
"Used to be that it was hard to leave this old place," Ms. Hertzog said. "But now it's harder and harder to stay."
Something similar might be said about race relations in America today. As The Times's series documents, those relations are full of tension at both the philosophical and quotidian levels. But for millions of Americans of all colors, staying in the old place was not, in the end, a tolerable possibility.

HEADLINE: INVESTING: FUNDS WATCH;
Finding Profits In Abandoned Debt

BYLINE: International Herald Tribune

 BODY:
Julian Adams followed the Korean summit meeting earlier this month with keen interest. Apart from the fact that it was the first event of its kind in half a century, the meeting fascinated him for a very tangible reason: Kim Jong Il, the elusive North Korean leader, owes him some money.
Mr. Adams manages the $7 million Aberdeen Exotic Debt fund, which specializes in debt issued by five countries -- Cuba, Iraq, North Korea, Serbia and Sudan. For various political reasons, these countries are not on the buy lists of most emerging-markets mutual fund managers, but they have nevertheless managed to run up debt to foreign banks that they are having trouble repaying. 
 Indeed, the economic backdrops in these countries are poor, and the prospects of repayment -- of interest, let alone principal -- are seen by the market as remote at best, Mr. Adams said.
A result is that prices have fallen to levels that factor in just about every further bad thing that may happen. Sudan's debt, for example, can be bought for 3.5 cents on the dollar.
Aside from the Korean meeting, a number of other developments in the world could give such debt a boost, Mr. Adams said. The climb in oil prices is bringing desperately needed foreign currency to Sudan, for instance. And in the aftermath of the Elian Gonzalez custody dispute, the United States Congress could ease the Cuban trade embargo.
"It's a tiny part of the market, but there's a lot going on with the countries involved," Mr. Adams said.
But that is the problem: As heartening as these developments may be, they have not done much to lift prices. In the days after the Korean meeting, for example, the price of North Korean debt moved up only slightly.
Two or three years ago, North Korean and Cuban debt traded at 59 cents and 28 cents on the dollar, respectively. At the beginning of June, both traded at about 10 cents on the dollar.
Investors in Aberdeen Exotic, based in London, should be prepared for a long and bumpy ride, and lawyers caution that Americans are prohibited from most kinds of Cuban investments in which the fund is engaged. (Investors should be relatively wealthy too, as the minimum investment for the fund is $100,000.)
Since its start on Jan. 31 through June 9, Aberdeen Exotic has had a return of 8.9 percent.
But Mr. Adams is waiting for the big score. "We're not investing to make 10 percent," he said. "We're investing to make 100 percent."
Over the last week, as the market has absorbed the news of the lifting of American financial sanctions against North Korea, the price of its debt has risen from 10 cents on the dollar to 14.25 cents. North Korean debt represents Aberdeen Exotic's largest country exposure, accounting for about 35 percent of assets.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY;
Cash Remains the Best Perk

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
With dot-com madness apparently on the wane, technology workers might want to take advantage of the perks while they last. For now, technology companies are finding that they must offer employees everything from game rooms to massage therapy and laundry services to keep them happy.
Finding, hiring and retaining top-notch employees is the biggest challenge for most of the 500 high-technology chief executives surveyed recently by Deloitte & Touche, the consulting firm. Fifty-five percent said it was important to dangle creative workplace perks to attract the best workers. 
 ActionPoint, a software company in San Jose, Calif., has a game room. Analytical Graphics. in Malvern, Pa., provides dry cleaning, haircuts, laundry sites and massage services at the office.
Of course, that old standby -- cash -- is still No. 1. Some 98 percent of the chief executives said bonuses remained the ultimate incentive.

HEADLINE: The Outer Limits Of Antitrust Law

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Microsoft Will Test Justices' Prowess" (June 4) asked whether the Supreme Court justices have the technical competence to address the Microsoft antitrust case. As a former antitrust lawyer, I think that the court will have little difficulty.
But the important question is whether existing antitrust legislation, conceived 100 years ago, is an appropriate standard for evaluating anticompetitive behavior today. 
 Consider that the economy was heavily industrialized at the turn of the 20th century and that railroads were the only effective means of transportation. Entry barriers to new competitors were formidable. A railroad or steel company that engaged in anticompetitive conduct could do enormous economic damage. Contrast that to today's high-tech world where the half-life of firms is very short, business models are rapidly rendered obsolete, and there are often no appreciable entry barriers.
As powerful as Microsoft may be, it is fair to question whether its current business model will even be relevant in 10 years.
This is not to say that high-technology companies are incapable of anticompetitive conduct, or that the antitrust laws should be scrapped. To the contrary. But the question remains whether the antitrust laws should be amended in light of today's different economic world. The statute books are full of examples where the Congress has recognized that unique industry characteristics call for a unique regulatory regime.
But judges are not legislators; the task of revisiting antitrust policy belongs to Congress. The court may correctly apply the law in this case, but we may regret the consequences.
 
NICHOLAS P. MOROS
Cherry Hills Village, Colo., June 4

Re: "$5 Billion Benefit Seen From LIPA Rate Cut" June 4 :
The benefit of mortgaging our future to reap a minor gain today escapes me. The rate cut was financed by floating a bond whose principal and interest will be repaid by all New York State taxpayers. Lilco's Shoreham financial folly lives on, now subsidized by innocents throughout the state who have never even heard of Shoreham, while Lilco/LIPA managers and stockholders continue to escape from their mischief unscathed.

HEADLINE: Statehouse Journal;
Economic Crisis Costly For Louisiana Governor

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: BATON ROUGE, La., June 22

 BODY:
For a few high-flying months in his first term, Mike Foster might have been the most popular governor in America, riding a brief economic boom and his Harley-Davidson Road King to unheard-of approval ratings in the range of 70 percent to 80 percent.
But the good years never seem to last long in Louisiana. Inevitably, they are overtaken by an extreme statewide poverty virtually unparalleled in the nation, along with an addiction to oil revenues that frequently run dry. When this year's state budget could not be balanced without a sales tax increase on food, Mike Foster fell back to earth, hard. And it is unclear whether the economy will allow him to ascend again in the last three years of his second term. 
 A poll released on Monday by Southern Media and Opinion Research found that Mr. Foster now has an approval rating of 54.8 percent, which many governors might consider a blessing. But in April, the same poll gave him an approval rating of 69.4 percent, and in March 1999, his approval reached a high of 82 percent. Bernie R. Pinsonat, who conducted the poll, said the governor's popularity has been in a "free fall" since the budget crisis developed earlier this year after several years of surpluses.
Mr. Foster, a gruff, wealthy Republican who often spends weekends at his private duck-hunting camp, has never been popular among the state's black residents, particularly after admitting that in 1995 he secretly bought the contributors list of David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan wizard. But he has always had a strong following among rural and suburban white voters, and among business leaders. Both groups seem to be deserting him now.
"He was the darling of the business community during his first term," said Pete deGravelles, chairman of the Greater Lafayette Chamber of Commerce and a boyhood friend of Mr. Foster. "But he really shocked us after he was re-elected last year. All of a sudden he was talking about a whole bunch of new business taxes. It was a whole different tone, and a lot of people were disappointed."
Even legislators of his own party have criticized how the governor handled what became a surprise fiscal emergency. Gathered in the state's Capitol this week for an unusual special session to complete the budget, several lawmakers said they wished Mr. Foster had better informed the public about the state's economic condition.
"Frankly, he isn't exactly the great communicator," said state Representative Victor T. Stelly, a Republican from Lake Charles. "We've had governors like Edwin Edwards and Buddy Roemer who could charm the socks off a billy goat, and he's not the charismatic type."
Mr. Foster, who says he has no political ambitions after he is required to leave office in 2004, insisted that he is not concerned about the falloff in popularity. "That's what happens when you have a budget crisis pop up on you," he said in an interview, though he acknowledged that he could have done better in explaining the teetering economy to the public.
"I guess I've had a difficult time getting that across," he said. "After you have a few good years, people aren't prepared for a downturn, they haven't had that much pain. There's a kind of disconnect there that makes it very difficult to govern."
Louisiana is one of the few states that is having trouble balancing its budget in a period of national prosperity, but its economy and civic health have always followed a different course than the rest of the nation, or even the South. It has the second-highest poverty rate of any state (after much-smaller New Mexico), and the gap between its wealthiest and poorest residents is the nation's widest and is growing. This month it was ranked the worst state for children by the Annie E. Casey Foundation, a private, charitable organization based in Baltimore.
And according to census data, Louisiana was the only Southern state where more people moved out than moved in during the 1990's. While 3.6 million Americans moved to the South, Louisiana experienced a net migration loss of 140,000 people.
Mr. Foster, like several of his predecessors, has tried to solve some long-term problems by improving the state's educational system. But he has found that his state does not have enough money to bring teacher salaries into line even with the rest of the South, a region that already trails the national average. The state is one of the most lightly taxed in the country.
For decades, state government relied on the oil and gas industry as a reliable source of revenue that provided up to 40 percent of the state budget as recently as the 1980's. But with the depletion of the state's energy resources, oil is now supplying less than 10 percent of the budget, and the state is relying on gambling, a high sales tax and a low income tax for most of its revenues.
After the price of oil dropped precipitously last year, the industry laid off nearly 13,000 people, which quickly rippled through the economy and produced a sharp plunge in state revenues. Loren C. Scott, an economics professor at Louisiana State University, said the governor and the Legislature also engaged in some questionable budgeting practices, such as using one-time revenues from the national tobacco settlement for operating expenses.
And so this year, faced with a budget deficit of nearly $400 million, the governor and the Legislature raised the state sales tax on food and utilities by a penny to 4 cents on the dollar, cut personal income tax deductions and increased taxes on telephone calls and tobacco. Many Democratic legislators were furious that business lobbyists prevented any new taxes on the oil and gas industry or on casino gambling, and education advocates said the package did little to improve the state's school system.
At the same time, though, the Legislature sent a proposed constitutional amendment to voters that would lower the state's dependence on the sales tax, while raising the income tax enough to increase teacher salaries. Economists say such a change would finally allow state revenues to grow with the economy, unlike the current system in which more than half of revenues come from sales taxes.
But considering the mood the voters are in, few people expect the amendment to pass in November. Mr. Foster acknowledges the difficulty he faces in selling the tax package, hoping he still has a reserve of popularity left from which to draw.
"Of course we're undertaxed, but no one wants to hear that from me," he said. "I'm just going to have to tell people and not worry about the consequences. We're in the worst of all worlds if I have to start worrying about what my popularity is."

HEADLINE: RECKONINGS;
Driving Under the Influence

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN; Maureen Dowd is on vacation.

 BODY:
There's something almost reassuring about how predictably our politicians have reacted to those high gasoline prices in the Midwest. The president, oddly unwilling to criticize his own Environmental Protection Agency, hints broadly that oil companies are rigging the market. The governor of Texas, oddly unwilling to criticize oil companies, blames excessive government regulation. Major Strasser has been shot -- round up the usual suspects!
But a sober report from the Congressional Research Service blames neither the E.P.A. nor the oil companies -- though a close reading suggests that both deserve a slap on the wrist for being caught unawares by a shortage they should have seen coming. And the report also answers the obvious question raised by other theories -- why this is happening in Chicago and Milwaukee, but not in New York. 
 What's special about the Midwest? Well, for one thing, it's a long way from the ocean. (No!) So the preferred method of delivery for petroleum and petroleum products is by pipeline. And as it happens two important pipelines have had problems -- a fire in one, a leak in the other -- whose aftereffects are still disrupting supply. The C.R.S. report attributes about half of the 50-cent differential between gasoline prices in the Midwest and elsewhere to pipeline troubles.
The other thing that's special about the Midwest is that it is America's agricultural heartland, where the corn is as high as an elephant's eye -- and the ethanol lobby is even more powerful than it is elsewhere. And the C.R.S. thinks that the other half of the differential is due to local rules in corn-belt cities, which force refiners to meet new federal environmental regulations using ethanol rather than other, technically less demanding gasoline additives.
The use of ethanol -- the same stuff that gives beer its buzz -- as a fuel is one of those bad ideas that just won't go away. Back in the late-70's ethanol produced from corn was promoted as the perfect answer to the energy crisis: it was renewable, it was domestic, and it was supposed to be less polluting.
A couple of decades and quite a few billion dollars in subsidies and tax breaks later -- gasoline that contains 10 percent ethanol still pays lower taxes, amounting to a 54-cent subsidy per gallon of ethanol -- it is clear that the fuel's virtues were exaggerated. For one thing, modern farming is an energy-intensive business, and still more energy is needed to convert corn into ethanol. So this is a fuel that requires almost as much energy to produce as it releases when you burn it. True, ethanol is an "oxidant" that helps gasoline run cleaner; but other oxidants are easier to deal with. Those other oxidants pose pollution problems; but so does ethanol, which tends to make gasoline evaporate too easily, contributing to smog in the summer months. Put it all together and you have a product with no special virtue to recommend it, certainly no virtue that warrants a billion or so dollars a year in tax breaks and subsidies.
But the political influence of the ethanol producers has proved untouchable. Or perhaps I should say "producer" rather than "producers." Most of the benefit from ethanol's special status goes not to the farmers but to those who turn corn into ethanol, and about half that business is controlled by one company: Archer Daniels Midland, the company that runs all those ads during news programs. Actually, those ads are a giveaway: when people spend large sums trying to convince you of how wonderful they are, without then trying to sell you something, you ought to suspect that they are up to no good. And in the past, A.D.M. -- one of the nation's biggest political contributors -- was up to quite a lot of no good: price-fixing, influence-buying, you name it.
To be fair, the Midwest gasoline squeeze wasn't a predictable result of the ethanol lobby's efforts. Were it not for the other factors -- extremely low inventories, surging demand from a booming, S.U.V.-driving economy and all that -- the rules that force Midwestern refiners to use ethanol wouldn't have had such spectacular consequences. Still, perhaps this summer of discontent will have a good effect, by alerting the public to a large, ongoing, bipartisan example of really bad policy. 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section 4; Page 17; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1018 words

HEADLINE: 50,000 Genes, and We Know Them All (Almost)

BYLINE: By David Baltimore; David Baltimore, the president of the California Institute of Technology, won the Nobel prize in medicine in 1975.

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif.

 BODY:
Humans have no more genetic secrets; our genes are a book open to all to read. It is expected that the federal government and Celera Genomics will announce tomorrow that a rough draft of the total genetic constitution of the human species, its genome, has been completed. The draft information is on a Web site, available to the world.
The genome is really a generic representation of our genes -- each of us actually carries small variations on the basic sequence. We already know hundreds of thousands of the major variants that occur. But our own personal genetic endowments are discoverable only at high cost, though the price is likely to descend rapidly. 
 How does the genome change our lives now that these secrets are laid so bare?
First, it confirms something obvious and expected, yet controversial: our genes look much like those of fruit flies, worms and even plants. Should there be any doubt -- and, unfortunately, there is vehement doubt in some circles -- the genome shows that we all descended from the same humble beginnings and that the connections are written in our genes. That should be, but won't be, the end of creationism.
The genome also tells us much about an organism's complexity. The differences between us and flies is poorly measured by the number of genes encoded in our DNA. Although there is much work left to do to determine the total number of human genes -- and a famous bet is in progress on the final number -- it is looking like 50,000 is a reasonable estimate.
That is not that far away from our estimate of the number of genes in a fly (14,000) or a worm (18,000). Yet we are much more complex than such lowly critters. How can so few more genes generate so much more apparent complexity? The answer is partly that flies and worms have lots of genes that do specific things for them. The genes that encode the basic functions of life -- for people, flies, worms and even bacteria -- are only a few hundred to a few thousand.
The other genes elaborate the specific characteristics of particular organisms. A single gene can be responsible for a great complexity of functions. Genes are just information encoded along a long string of the chemical DNA; they cannot do anything themselves. What genes encode is the structures of proteins, which are the working machinery of living beings. They let us walk and talk and think big thoughts.
One gene can encode many, often 10 or more, different proteins. To carry out different activities, the proteins can vary in amount, be put in different combinations, or be modified. It is the number of proteins, not genes, that determine complexity -- and that is where the true complexity of human life will be measured.
The genome will also speed up work for scientists. The information from the federal program has been placed on the Web as it was acquired and has already been very useful. It will have an increasing impact. No longer will science and medicine proceed with deep uncertainty over how many genes relate to a particular process. No longer will students and postdoctoral fellows spend long months trying to isolate genes -- they will now simply look them up on the Web. We will now have a wholly new ability: to ask scientific questions about not a single gene, but the entire genome. Now drugs can be developed for every protein to alter its function and help clear up a malfunction.
However, we should not think that now biology will simply be a process of tying up loose ends. The DNA sequence tells us little about the functions of the genes or their role in the body's overall economy. At best, the sequence lets us infer a gene's capabilities, but only experiments will validate or invalidate those inferences. Even experiments on the entire genome will generally only pose questions that need to be answered by experiments on single genes.
My guess is that the next half-century will be taken up with understanding the roles of each of the human genes. And that will only happen if the projected financing for the work of the National Institutes of Health is continued. Moreover, this first draft of the genome is hardly the last word. The federal program is committed to a high-quality, virtually error-free product, and that is a year or two off. Funding for this effort needs to be maintained.
Finally, the race to complete the genome tells us much about how scientific research should be conducted. There has been extensive media coverage of the acrimonious competition between the government program and that of Celera. But we should put this in perspective and recognize that the government program was centrally organized and therefore had to settle on a single strategy. This compromised a central value of science, testing multiple strategies. That is the essence of scientific competition. Thus, Celera's ability to amass the resources necessary to compete with the federal program helped move the whole effort forward in a more fluid, and ultimately, more effective way. That the two programs plan to coordinate their efforts and publish their genome findings in the same issue of a journal represents a healthier relationship.
The very celebration of the completion of the human genome is a rare day in the history of science: an event of historic significance is recognized not in retrospect, but as it is happening. It shows the scientific community at its best and most modern, carrying out a program requiring elaborate collaboration, new technology and the latest computer-assisted methods.
Modern biology is a science of information. The sequencing of the genome is a landmark of progress in specifying information, decoding it into its many coded meanings and learning how it goes wrong in disease. While it is a moment worthy of the attention of every human, we should not mistake progress for a solution. There is yet much hard work to be done.
It will take many decades to fully comprehend the magnificence of the DNA edifice built over four billion years of evolution and held in the nucleus of each cell of the body of each organism on earth.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Votes in Congress

 BODY:
Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.
 
Senate
 
1. Hate Crimes: Vote on an amendment to a defense authorization bill that would expand federal jurisdiction for crimes based on race, religion and national origin, and would add sex and handicapped status to the categories covered, as well as sexual orientation. Approved 57 to 42, June 20.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
One Community's Lawbreakers Are Another's Growth Industry

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

DATELINE: ROMULUS, N.Y.

 BODY:
FROM his front porch, Ray Zajac can hear the inmates' voices rising through the double set of glistening razor-wire fences across Main Street. The late afternoon chanting of men exercising in the drug treatment center is money to his ears.
"The city is subsidizing us by producing these criminals," said Mr. Zajac, meaning New York City. "It's not a nice thing to say, but it's true." 
 That subsidy is about to soar. Once the state's Five Points prison opens here in August, Romulus will be home to 3,200 free-ranging souls and 2,200 inmates. The free-rangers aren't complaining.
"It's a salvation to us," said Mr. Zajac, who has run this Finger Lakes town as the elected supervisor for 29 years.
Romulus is a village saved by prisons.
The state psychiatric hospital on Main Street closed in 1995, but reopened as the Department of Correctional Services' Willard Drug Treatment Campus. The 11,000-acre Seneca Army Depot began closing that same year, but the state came through with the $180 million prison now being completed on a secluded corner of the base.
"It's the largest construction project ever in the Finger Lakes," said Michael F. Nozzolio, the local state senator and chairman of the Senate's corrections committee, who brought home this juicy morsel of bacon. Beyond the projected 638 full-time jobs and 191 spinoff jobs, the prison will also rescue Romulus from its own sewage.
Waste water from about 200 homes near the prison site and Romulus's only school ran through the Army's system for decades. With the Army leaving, the hamlet would need a new system, which it could not afford. But the prison's water and sewer system will serve the town, as well, and pay the local sewer district, which will run it, an estimated $2 million a year, said the district's administrator, the same Ray Zajac.
"It's a big business, crime is," he said.
Political, too. Sentiment is growing in New York State to rethink drug laws that have helped push the prison population over 71,000, and last week the state's chief judge announced an effort to send more addicts to treatment rather than jail. But the Legislature ended its session Friday with no action on proposals to ease the state's harshest drug statutes, the Rockefeller-era laws that mandate minimum sentences of 15 years to life for possession or sale of small amounts of drugs -- stiffer sentences than the minimums for rape or manslaughter. Fear of appearing weak on crime overcame political will.
The inaction in Albany and the construction activity here, 160 miles west, demonstrate that there is just one safe political course when it comes to sentencing wrongdoers: put the pedal to the metal.
But don't blame Romulus.
ASIDE from some better-off folks with houses on serene Seneca Lake, Romulus is a collection of three tattered hamlets that largely lived off the state mental hospital and the cold war threat of global conflict that kept the World War II Army depot alive until the Berlin Wall fell. The world has changed, and now Romulus will have a drug treatment center, a maximum security prison and a nonprofit center for troubled youths that Gov. George E. Pataki helped inaugurate on Wednesday.
"We're going from government to government," said Dennis Aloia, the Seneca County manager. "When you're a hungry area, like this place is, you're willing to accept things other places aren't."
Prisons are bonanzas in depressed areas, and Glenn R. Cooke, Seneca County's development director, calls Senator Nozzolio "our rainmaker." The senator has six prisons in his district, and the public policy group City Project says more than a third of the state's prisons are in the districts of three senators, Mr. Nozzolio included.
In Romulus, Sandy Lynd, the postmaster, is expecting business to skyrocket. Dianna LaPrade said the medical office where she works as a nurse had hired an additional doctor, anticipating an influx of prison employees. And she said the guard jobs, with good pay and benefits, will give grown children a reason to stay in town. "It's a nice touch," she said.
But if the world changes again and there is a move to reduce the nation's world-beating incarceration rate, it will cause economic upheaval for places like Romulus. Not that anyone is expecting, as Mr. Zajac said, "all the criminals to find the Lord" or for all the politicians to go soft.
"I think it's less likely that will happen," Mr. Zajac said, "than the Berlin Wall coming down."

HEADLINE: U.S. Sizes Up North Korea As a Partner In Business

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, June 24

 BODY:
With the easing of economic sanctions against North Korea by the Clinton administration this week, American corporations based here are beginning to assess business opportunities in a country that has been out of bounds for five decades.
North Korea, a country of 22 million people, many of them deprived of all but the most basic needs, represents an unknown world for American business, but one with prospects both large and small: businessmen here see the need for everything from large transportation and energy projects to modest consumer goods. 
 The president of the American Chamber of Commerce here, Jeffrey D. Jones, says that sketchy data indicate that North Koreans earn a wage of about $150 to $200 a month, much of it disposable income because the state provides housing and basic food. If these wage figures are correct, Mr. Jones said, they exceed disposable income in parts of post-Communist Eastern Europe. However, North Koreans who have fled to China in droves to escape famine have suggested that families are spending almost all their money on food.
And Mr. Jones warned that the process of opening up North Korea would be slow, in large part because of its government's wariness about contact with outsiders.
In a meeting with American business leaders, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said, without giving specifics, that Washington was eager to encourage North Korea, one of the last outposts of strict Communist economy, to move into the international commercial system.
Businessmen said they envisioned North Korea developing credibility with major Western powers and then becoming eligible for funds from the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank.
This would lay the groundwork for major infrastructure projects, which in turn would attract basic chemical, petrochemical, plastics and paints industries.
Many analysts have predicted that the bare-bones North Korean economy, propped up lately by deliveries of food, fertilizer and fuel from South Korea, China, Japan and the United States, will collapse.
But some modest optimism has emerged, especially since the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, visited China last month. He was urged by his Chinese allies to follow them in opening up his economy and was taken around computer companies in Beijing.
Telecommunications, including mobile phones, which are becoming a promising investment sector in China, will take years to open up in North Korea, Mr. Jones said.
Only 4.9 percent of households are believed to have phones in North Korea, according to South Korean statistics.
A joint South-North economic committee was set up during the summit meeting of the two Korean leaders 10 days ago, and this panel is likely, in the beginning, to become the main conduit for business in the North.
Some South Korean companies already do such business, but Mr. Jones, a lawyer here, cautioned that of the four ventures with North Korea that he had been involved in, only one was still going.
Mr. Jones quoted the head of a major South Korean corporation as suggesting that there was no need for American businesses to fret about competition: as the South Korean had said, "If you are worried about a slice of the pie, there is no pie yet."

HEADLINE: Summary of Major Actions of the Legislature's 223rd Session

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 24

 BODY:
The 223rd session of the New York State Legislature roared to a close Friday, with a head-spinning succession of deals on major issues that made this the most productive session in recent memory.
The Senate, the Assembly and Gov. George E. Pataki agreed on a far-reaching package of gun controls, a major overhaul of the state's sexual assault laws and a law providing heavier penalties for hate crimes. On the final day of the session, they reached agreement on a law allowing patients to look up doctors' malpractice histories, a few days after striking a deal on a law requiring parental notification when pesticides are used in schools, and possible neighborhood notification when they are used on lawns. 
 It was a session marked early by feuding between Mr. Pataki and a fellow Republican, the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, that had some Republicans saying the governor was trying to overthrow the Senate leader. Later, it was the Democrats' turn to fight among themselves. The Assembly majority leader, Michael J. Bragman, attempted a coup against the speaker, Sheldon Silver, that failed and left the Democrats splintered and wary of each other.
But relations between the two parties -- particularly between Mr. Silver and Mr. Pataki -- were remarkably calm throughout, with little of the partisan carping, personal attacks and legislative paralysis that have marked the last several years.
The state budget was completed on May 5, just 35 days overdue, in the least contentious process since 1993, after years of budgets that ran two, three, even four months late. That averted the gridlock of previous years, when the focus on the overdue budget prevented work on other issues.
A persistent theme of the session was the Senate Republicans' moving further than ever to the left, fearful of their prospects in November. They only grudgingly accepted bills on gun control, hate crimes, pesticide notification and other subjects long embraced by the Assembly Democrats.
The Democrats gave ground on the sexual assault laws, but over all, won more big legislative victories than in any other year since Mr. Pataki became governor.
Lawmakers were unable to reach agreement on a few notable issues, including a bill that would have required legislative approval and a local referendum for a proposed Indian casino in the Catskills, and proposed rule changes for Republican presidential primaries.
In the Assembly, 9,938 bills were introduced and 1,036 were passed. In the Senate, 7,038 bills were introduced and 1,261 were passed. Some 681 bills passed both houses. Mr. Pataki has signed 94 of those.
 
Budget
The state, continuing to enjoy the bounty of the economic boom, is awash in tax revenues that allowed a significant increase in spending and sizable tax cuts at the same time. Lawmakers approved a $77.5 billion budget, up 5.7 percent from the year before, with tax cuts that will eventually be worth $1.2 billion a year.
They increased spending on education by 8.7 percent, to more than $13 billion, including continued expansion of the two-year-old program to provide prekindergarten classes for 4-year-olds and smaller class sizes in the early grades.
The largess extended to college students, who saw state tuition assistance increase significantly, and to the elderly, who saw a doubling of the state program to help the low-income elderly pay for prescription drugs.
Medicaid, the largest part of the budget at $29 billion and the spending area that had generated the most pitched battles since Mr. Pataki became governor, was never an issue. As part of a deal reached in December on health coverage for the uninsured, the governor agreed that for the first time he would not try to cut Medicaid, the health care program for the poor.
At the governor's insistence, the budget included the first limits ever placed on New York's state debt, the highest in the nation. The ceilings will go into effect gradually over more than a decade, but they were welcomed by Wall Street rating agencies. The budget also greatly increased the size of the state's various reserve funds, to more than $3 billion.
At the same time, Mr. Pataki and the Legislature agreed to put a $3.8 billion bond act before voters in November to help pay for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's capital program and improvements to the state's roads and bridges.

Crime and Justice

Decriminalizes the possession and sale of hypodermic needles without a doctor's prescription.

AWAITING SIGNATURE
Would ban assault weapons, mirroring the federal ban, and allow local prosecutors to enforce the law.

LEGISLATION ENACTED
 Imposes limits on state debt, eventually restricting it to 4 percent of the annual personal income of state residents, down from more than 6 percent now.
Provides $180 million to help local governments cover the costs of Family Health Plus, a new program to assist low-income people in acquiring health insurance.
Provides $105 million in aid to Nassau County, in return for the county's making $260 million in budget cuts over the next four years, and provides that if those cuts are not made, the state can impose a financial control board on the county.
Creates the Nassau Interim Financing Authority to sell bonds on behalf of the county.
Raises the limit on New York City's debt by $4 billion.
Provides $45 million in emergency aid to the Buffalo schools.
Provides $10 million in emergency aid to the Yonkers schools.

AWAITING SIGNATURE
Would revise the State Constitution to make the language gender-neutral.

LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have changed the rules for Republican presidential primaries in New York to make it virtually automatic for well-known candidates to get on the ballot, and to simplify the ballot itself.
Would have banned largely unregulated "soft money" campaign contributions and imposed new, lower limits on contributions made directly to candidates and parties.
Would have provided for public financing of campaigns.
Would have required that the Assembly and the Senate convene a conference committee to work out their differences when both houses pass bills that are substantially similar.

HEADLINE: FOLLOWING UP

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY

 BODY:

Jilted Hospital Suing Doctor on the Move
The case of Dr. Andrew Wiznia, a pediatric AIDS specialist formerly with Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, now with Jacobi Medical Center, is proceeding through the state courts. At issue: how a doctor should notify patients when changing hospitals, and whether the hospital left behind can claim damages for lost grant money and patients.
Dr. Wiznia, who had worked in a Bronx-Lebanon clinic treating 180 children with H.I.V. and 250 healthy children born to H.I.V.-infected parents, moved to Jacobi in April 1999, though Bronx-Lebanon had tried unsuccessfully to keep him from seeing patients at Jacobi for six months. 
 Bronx-Lebanon also said Dr. Wiznia used its records illegally in writing his patients of the move, and left them little choice but to go with him. Dr. Wiznia said he had followed standard procedure in notifying the patients, using his own records to get their addresses. The court ruled against him in December, but he is appealing.
Bronx-Lebanon also charged that he had applied to transfer a federal grant supporting the unit from Bronx-Lebanon, a private hospital, to Jacobi, a public one, while still on Bronx-Lebanon's payroll.
Dr. Wiznia acknowledged that he applied for the grant for Jacobi before he told Bronx-Lebanon he would be leaving, but he said Bronx-Lebanon's permission was required before the grant could be moved.
Francis Carling, the lawyer for Bronx-Lebanon, countered that Dr. Wiznia left it no time to apply for grants on its own. The hospital said that because it permanently lost grants and patients, it is also suing him and his partners for damages. Dr. Wiznia said that no damages were incurred because a hospital cannot profit from research grants or Medicaid patients.

Shifting Battleground For Small Harlem Stores
When a white-owned clothing store in Harlem refused to renew the sublease of a popular black-owned record store in 1995, Morris Powell was at the forefront of protests as head of the 125th Street Vendors Association. The battle ended tragically. As the angry demonstrations dragged on, a man walked into the store, Freddy's clothing, began shooting and set a fire that killed seven workers and himself.
Today, Mr. Powell's concerns echo his protests five years ago but reflect a changing Harlem. With a group called the Diallo Coalition, named for the unarmed black man killed by the police, Mr. Powell has distributed leaflets outside Harlem USA, the new mall on 125th Street that includes Disney, Old Navy and HMV.
He and others are concerned by the city's recent attempts to evict Mart 125, where dozens of small businesses operate on city-owned property. There is fear that the national chains, and the rent increases that come with them, will keep smaller vendors from enjoying the economic boom that is reaching 125th Street.
"We still have them under boycott," Mr. Powell said of Harlem USA. "Our community is overwhelmingly run by other people, of not the same race, and it's unfair, to say the least."
Bill Perkins, the councilman for central and east Harlem, said he disagreed with the city's desire to lease the property to the highest bidder.
Mart 125 is fighting the eviction in court, he said.
"Why can't Harlemites, small entrepreneurs who were here during the lean times, take advantage of the better times?" Mr. Perkins asked. "The so-called gentrification or whatever that people to some extent welcome can be a double-edged sword, reflected in the struggle that merchants at Mart 125 are having." TINA KELLEY

HEADLINE: Candidates Courting Hispanic Vote

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: DENVER, June 24

 BODY:
"Yo quiero mucho," Vice President Al Gore roared in a campaign speech here on Thursday night before the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials, assuring its members that he loved them very much.
For many Hispanic Americans, especially those eager to vote in this year's presidential election, Mr. Gore and his probable Republican opponent, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, have turned the campaign into a virtual love-fest. Describing themselves as the "soccer moms" of the 2000 elections, Hispanic voters say they have never been courted so aggressively by presidential candidates, giving Hispanics electoral leverage they never had before. 
 And most of the seminars at the association's annual conference here this week were designed to expand the power in the future.
"All of a sudden, we're hot," said Victor Hernandez, a member of the Lubbock, Tex., city council. "The parties see us as an opportunity but also a potential threat. They know they have to deal with us, and they know it's better to deal with us as an ally rather than a foe."
The amorous turn, a more profound difference in Republican strategy than in Democratic, evolves directly from demographic shifts: Hispanics are now the fastest growing bloc of ethnic voters. The changes are especially significant in the nine states with the largest Hispanic populations. Led by California, New York and Texas, they account for 202 electoral votes -- or 75 percent of the 270 needed to win the White House.
An analysis by the Latino group commonly known as Naleo (Na-LAY-o) predicts that the Hispanic share of the 2000 presidential vote will rise to 5.4 percent from 4.7 percent in 1996, giving Latino voters the power to influence an otherwise close election, particularly in several important states, including California and Florida.
But even if one presidential candidate wins by a wide margin this year, Latino advocates were taking no chances for the future. With seminars this week like "Developing your stump speech," "Working with your party" and "Coordinating with issue constituencies," Naleo officials taught their members how to get more Hispanics into the elective pipeline to make Hispanic voters even more powerful beyond 2000.
Panel moderators included specialists on issues that Hispanic voters consistently cite as most important to them -- public education, health care and economic development -- as well as political strategists from both major parties.
Arturo Vargas, the Naleo executive director, said about 5,100 Hispanics hold elective office around the country but half of them as members of local school boards, making for a relatively flat triangle of success. Over the last 10 years, the number of Hispanics in Congress has risen to 19 from 11; the number of state lawmakers has increased to 189 from 135; and seven Hispanics hold statewide offices.
But with the nation's Hispanic population increasing, to 31.8 million by last year from 22.4 million in 1990, according to the Census Bureau, and an analysis by the association of turnout in 1992 and 1996 suggesting that more Latinos are voting while other groups are voting less often, Mr. Vargas said the number of Hispanic elected officials was certain to rise. As a result, Naleo officials have made sharing political advice and counsel the thrust of their conference in this, an election year.
"We want to focus attention on November and the role Latinos will play in the election," he said, reflecting on the mission of the three-day conference. "But we also want to stress professional development. We want people to leave here with new information so they can do better at their jobs in the future with strategies to win. Someplace soon, we want to have a future governor and a U.S. senator."
Judging by their campaign efforts this year, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore recognize the importance of winning the Hispanic vote. That is not necessarily a new strategy for Democrats, but it is for Republicans. And many Republican Party leaders say that with Mr. Bush, whose state has a significant Latino population, they have the right candidate to expand their base, even though aides said a scheduling conflict prevented him from attending the Naleo conference.
While Hispanic voters have traditionally supported Democratic candidates, they have shown a new open-mindedness in recent elections toward Republicans. By some estimates, Mr. Bush won as much as 47 percent of the Hispanic vote in his re-election as governor in 1998. The same year, Tony Garza, a Republican, won election as Texas Railroad Commissioner, a powerful position overseeing oil, gas and public utilities.
Californians elected three Hispanic Republicans to the state legislature in 1998, even as Gray Davis, a Democrat, won the governor's race, a result that reflected, at least among Hispanics, a repudiation of the policies of his predecessor, Pete Wilson, who opposed social services for immigrants, affirmative action and bilingual education in public schools.
Like the vice president, Mr. Bush often uses Spanish in speaking to Latino crowds, boasting that his policies in Texas have been good for Hispanics. Also, he often reminds Latino voters of his sister-in-law's heritage: Columba Bush, who is married to his brother, Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, was born in Mexico, and their 24-year-old son, George P. Bush, who speaks fluent Spanish, has become an active campaigner for his uncle.
In addition, many Hispanics complain that Democratic candidates, recognizing the historic gap between Hispanics and Republicans, take the Hispanic vote for granted.
"Bush is uniquely positioned with a proven record of winning Hispanic votes," said Michael Madrid, a Republican political consultant who led the seminar on stump speeches. He said that Mr. Bush's attractiveness to Hispanic voters "is as much the messenger as the message."
Republicans still appear to have some distance to cover before they capture a majority of the Hispanic vote in any big state. As Mr. Vargas pointed out, only in the last few years have Republicans paid much attention to Hispanic voters, compared with President Clinton and Mr. Gore, who made them a priority in the last two elections. President Bush won only 19 percent of the Hispanic vote in 1992, Mr. Madrid said, and Senator Bob Dole fared worse four years later, with 13 percent.
"It's not been for lack of trying," Gov. Bill Owens of Colorado said on Friday, addressing problems Republicans have had connecting with Hispanics. "We had it under President Reagan, but for all the assets Bob Dole had, he was not a warm-and-fuzzy guy. He didn't have the ability to connect. George Bush does. He'll be very competitive with Hispanics this year."
Despite recent progress by Republicans, they still encounter problems. For example, in New Mexico, where Latinos account for a third of the vote and four Hispanics (all Democrats) hold statewide offices, the state Republican Party has included only two Hispanics among its 21-member delegation to the national convention in August.
And here, Mr. Vargas said, Mr. Bush's absence "sends a message that speaks for itself." Mr. Bush was represented at a luncheon on Friday by Mr. Owens and one of his Colorado cabinet members, Larry E. Trujillo, who recently switched from Democrat to Republican.
As for the future, Mr. Hernandez, the Lubbock city official, said it would be a mistake for either party to take Hispanics lightly. "We no longer want a piece of the pie," he said, referring to their growing political might. "We want to be in the kitchen, deciding what kind of pie to make."

HEADLINE: CLINTON PROPOSING MUCH LARGER PLAN FOR DRUG BENEFITS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
President Clinton announced a major change in his proposal for Medicare drug benefits today, making it much more generous to millions of elderly people and much more costly to the federal government.
The new proposal came four days before the House of Representatives is scheduled to vote on a Republican proposal to offer drug benefits, through private insurance companies, to all 39 million people on Medicare. 
 Mr. Clinton said his revised proposal would cost $79 billion over five years, or more than twice as much as the $38 billion proposal he sent Congress as part of his budget request in February. The House Republican plan would cost nearly $40 billion over five years.
In his weekly radio address today, Mr. Clinton said he was "deeply concerned" about the proposal drafted by House Republicans.
"What they have proposed is not a Medicare benefit," Mr. Clinton said. "It's a private insurance program which many seniors and people with disabilities simply won't be able to afford."
Mr. Clinton said he wanted to use surplus tax dollars to ensure that no older American would have to pay more than $4,000 a year in drug costs.
The president said he would submit his new proposal to Congress in the next few days. Congress, controlled by Republicans, is unlikely to approve it right away. But experience suggests that Mr. Clinton's proposal could influence Congress and nudge it in the direction he wants to go as the legislative process unfolds under the political pressures of this election year.
Mr. Clinton said his plan "would be affordable and dependable, and give every senior equal coverage."
But in the Republican response, Representative Nancy L. Johnson of Connecticut said the House Republican plan was better.
"We provide a choice of at least two plans for seniors," Mrs. Johnson said. "Under the president's approach, our seniors would have only one choice. The government would mandate a one-size-fits-all plan, and a senior would just have to take it or leave it."
The cost of the president's proposal has soared in the last year, as he offered richer benefits and more realistic cost estimates. When he unveiled his initial plan in June 1999, he said it would cost $118 billion over 10 years. In February, he put the 10-year cost at $195 billion: $160 billion for basic drug coverage, plus $35 billion to help people with very high drug expenses.
Today, Mr. Clinton offered what he described as an improved version of his proposal, which he said would cost $253 billion over 10 years. That is more than twice the cost estimate for his original proposal.
The White House said the more generous drug benefits were possible because a booming economy had produced a gusher of federal revenue, increasing projections of the budget surplus in the next decade.
The House Republican proposal was approved on a party-line vote in the Ways and Means Committee on Wednesday. It would use almost all of the $40 billion allowed for drug benefits in the five-year budget blueprint that Congress adopted in April.
Today, a White House official said the administration did not "feel in any way constrained" by the $40 billion figure. Under House rules, it would not be in order to consider a bill that increased Medicare spending by more than that amount.
White House officials said they hoped that the House Rules Committee would allow an exception to the rules, so Democrats could offer an alternative costing $100 billion over five years. The Democratic proposal, besides providing $79 billion worth of drug benefits to the elderly, would increase Medicare payments to hospitals and other health care providers by $21 billion over five years.
Republicans said they agreed on the need to assist health care providers and would offer a separate bill later this year, to restore some of the Medicare money cut in 1997.
Under Mr. Clinton's original proposal, the government would have paid half of the first $2,000 in drug expenses incurred by a Medicare beneficiary, starting in 2003. Under the new proposal, benefits would start a year earlier, in 2002. "Seniors and people with disabilities need prescription drug coverage as soon as possible," the White House said.
Mr. Clinton specified today, for the first time, how he would protect elderly people who have high prescription drug expenses. Under his proposal, no Medicare beneficiary would have to spend more than $4,000 a year on prescription drugs. Medicare would pay all costs beyond that.
In February, Mr. Clinton said he wanted to provide some type of "protection against catastrophic drug costs," starting in 2006, but he gave no details. Today, he fleshed out his proposal and said he wanted to start the extra coverage in 2002, along with the basic benefits.
Under his proposal, Mr. Clinton said today, Medicare beneficiaries would not have to pay anything extra for catastrophic coverage. Premiums for the enhanced benefits would be the same as the premiums he specified in February just for basic drug coverage: $25 a month in 2002, rising to about $50 in 2009.
Under the House Republican plan, the government would pay subsidies to insurance companies to encourage them to sell insurance covering the drug costs of Medicare beneficiaries. Premiums and benefits could vary from one plan to another. Under a typical policy, the beneficiary would pay premiums of $37 a month and a deductible of $250 a year. The insurance policy would pay half of the next $2,100 in drug costs, and the beneficiary's out-of-pocket costs would be limited to $6,000 a year.
Mr. Clinton also proposed today to pay health maintenance organizations to provide prescription drugs to Medicare beneficiaries, starting in 2001. About 6 million of the 39 million Medicare recipients, or 16 percent, are in H.M.O.'s. Most of the health plans offer drug benefits, but Medicare does not require such benefits, nor does it explicitly pay for them.
White House officials said they hoped that the prospect of such federal subsidies, $25 billion over 5 years and $75 billion over 10 years, would encourage health plans to participate in Medicare. In the last two years, many H.M.O.'s have withdrawn from Medicare or curtailed their participation, saying federal payments were inadequate.
