HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY: Networking in Southern California;
'Anti-Silicon Valley' Broadcom Chief Rules in the Wired World

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: IRVINE, Calif.

 BODY:
"We are not an amorphous sea of communists," Henry T. Nicholas 3rd, co-founder of the Broadcom Corporation, said, rolling his eyes in disgust.
He had just arrived at his Southern California office -- forehead damp from a morning workout, three-piece suit snug against his 6-foot-6 frame -- and already he was ripping into one of his pet peeves of the new economy: open cubicle space. 
 Sure, Andrew S. Grove, the Intel chairman, had a cubicle, "but it was ceremonial," Mr. Nicholas said. "If an employee wants to shut his door, he should be able to do it." That is what his colleagues used to do when he worked as a young engineer in the once-vibrant aerospace industry here in the Los Angeles region, far from precious Northern California.
In fact, a lot of things bug Mr. Nicholas about the way Silicon Valley technology companies are run these days -- like executives who allow employees to bring dogs to work, turning offices into playgrounds. Or the way venture capitalists have become all but gods in the new technological order.
But Broadcom, whose engineers design silicon chips that quickly send voice, data and video over cable lines, has risen to the top of its game as the photographic negative of a Silicon Valley company. And its leader is the antithesis of the new age, new economy Zen master. At Broadcom, as Mr. Nicholas makes clear, "I run the show."
In practice that means rousing subordinates from their beds past midnight when he wants to talk about a project, or dictating the company's dress code: suits for engineers and managers when customers visit, and no khakis or jeans. "We like to think of ourselves as the anti-Silicon Valley company," said Mr. Nicholas, who is known as Nick. "You are not going to be worshiped here, but you will spend time getting to build a product that only you can do."
It is no wonder he is called Darth Vader by fans and competitors alike. For like Darth Vader, the 40-year-old Mr. Nicholas wants to rule a universe -- in this case the wired universe.
It was in 1991 that the former silicon chip designer, who has a Ph.D. in electrical engineering, teamed up with Henry Samueli, his friend and former professor, to start Broadcom. Their timing was impeccable. The Internet was just taking off and networking equipment makers needed chips to convert slow-moving analog signals into faster digital ones.
Broadcom's chips are in 90 percent of all digital television set-top boxes and cable modems and 65 percent of local area computer networks, analysts estimate. So far, only Lucent Technologies and Intel's Level One subsidiary have challenged Broadcom's networking products, and Texas Instruments is its only rival in cable modems. And Broadcom has taken the lead in making chips for the burgeoning market for broadband home networking.
Market share like that is hard to come by. So it is no surprise that Broadcom was one of the brightest initial public offerings of 1998 -- up 500 percent from its offering price by the end of that year and up 1,095 percent from its offering through Friday -- making Mr. Nicholas and Mr. Samueli, who each own 16 percent of the company, worth more than $5 billion each.
That competitive advantage could well continue, said Joseph Osha, senior semiconductor analyst for Merrill Lynch. He predicts earnings at Broadcom, which has a market capitalization of $35 billion, will grow 125 percent in fiscal 2000 as consumers and businesses crave more interactive capabilities over the Internet.
Mr. Osha attributes a recent slump in Broadcom's stock price (down 35 percent from its March high) to overall technology malaise. "It's fairly difficult to counterinvade their space," Mr. Osha said. Add to that the notion that Internet shopping and entertainment are fast becoming one, and Broadcom's technology looks even more valuable.
But Mr. Nicholas keeps pressing Broadcom to maintain its edge. "The joke is he gets by on liquid protein and two hours of sleep a night," Mr. Osha said, which may not be far from the truth. Broadcom's corporate culture reflects Mr. Nicholas's own tendency to work 18-hour days until a project is done.
"You have to take yourself to the absolute limits of human behavior," he said, his arms slicing the air. "The whole concept is you leave nothing in reserve."
As if to prove his point, he pulled out a random page from his running schedule from the summer of 1997 and recounted in gory detail a day in June when he was so sick he threw up in a patch of grass and logged that season's worst workout. But 20 days later, he said with pride, he tied his personal best. "It was complete focus on getting a task done," he said. "That is the culture we are trying to create here."
And how do the citizens of that culture respond?
Engineers are attracted to Broadcom for the same reasons they flock to Silicon Valley: stock options that are worth millions. But while Mr. Nicholas and his currency may attract talent, it is Mr. Samueli, now the company's chief technology officer, who patches up hurt feelings after Mr. Nicholas's frequent expletive-laced tirades.
"They view me as more their mentor and father," the 45-year-old Mr. Samueli said. "I'm there for them to complain to."
Mehdi Hatamian, an engineer and project director who has worked at Broadcom for four years, recalled an incident in late 1996 when one of the chips his team was designing had a flaw that needed fixing. Mr. Nicholas was displeased with the time it was taking and called a meeting to tell the team so. For several minutes he raged, demanding to know who was responsible for the flaw. He finally turned to Mr. Hatamian, who said Mr. Nicholas angrily growled, "You are responsible for this."
"Nick, did you come here to blame me or get a problem solved?" Mr. Hatamian shot back, challenging Mr. Nicholas to fire him. Mr. Hatamian then outlined his plan for fixing the chip design, and after a two--hour grilling, returned to his office and, for several days, worked until 3:30 a.m. until the problem was fixed.
Even board members have asked him to ratchet down, Mr. Nicholas acknowledged. At a directors meeting last year, he said, some questioned whether it was wise for their highly visible chief executive to continue sky diving. He scoffed at the suggestion that he stop, citing statistics that showed his hobby -- which he practices several times yearly -- was safe. Besides, Mr. Nicholas said drolly, "They know if I died it would be the ultimate failure, and I hate to lose."
Still his antics, at times, are nothing short of a public relations nightmare. He has the same sort of toys as his Silicon Valley peers -- the Lamborghini Diablo Roadster, the 15,000-square-foot estate, the jet leasing company. And last year, he and Mr. Samueli flirted with buying the Anaheim Angels baseball team and the Mighty Ducks hockey team.
But unlike the rich men up north, he is more outlandish in his boyish tastes. He loves the rock band Metallica, keeps a metal skull on his desk and a personal trainer on call 24 hours and brags about all-night drinking binges in Las Vegas.
Once, Mr. Nicholas recalled, he tried to strip an investment banker at a winter conference in Utah and roll him in the snow because he thought the banker was too uptight. "I love to torture those guys," he said. And last New Year's Eve, he sponsored a battle of the bands at a party at his house in Laguna Hills, offering the best group a $2,000 grand prize. Why? He wanted to teach the bands a lesson. "I made it a competition because the world is competitive," he said.
But he caused the biggest stir on his 40th birthday last October when he invited MTV's band of the year, Orgy, to play at his home. Mr. Nicholas laughed when asked about the porn star who showed up at the party and the police officers who told him to turn the music down. Yes, they were there, he said. "We had a lot of beautiful women show up unattached." But it was not so funny when the party was reported in The Los Angeles Times and he got a call from his mother. "I mean, my mom read that stuff," he said recently, his sheepish grin fading.
Mr. Nicholas's wife, Stacey, a former electrical engineer to whom he has been married to for 13 years and has had three children with, said she had come to terms with his bad boy reputation.
"I trust his judgment," she said. Most recently, they spent three days with her college friends, river-rafting, Mr. Nicholas leaving the cell phone and attitude behind.
"People at Broadcom see the game face all the time," she said. "His favorite line is, 'Don't tell anyone. Don't let them know.' "
And how do his hijinks play in the investment community? "As far as I'm concerned if they put up the numbers, who cares what he does?" said Mr. Osha, the analyst.
Mr. Nicholas was born in Cincinnati in 1959. After his parents divorced in 1965, he moved with his mother to Malibu, Calif. He graduated from Santa Monica High School in 1977 and attended the United States Air Force Academy, in part to rebel against his liberal upbringing and the Southern California surf culture that shaped his teenage years. He quickly learned that Malibu's hang- 10 aesthetic was the exception in society, not the norm.
"Imagine my surprise when I realized that by rebelling I began to conform like everybody else," he said.
But when he learned he was too tall to fly fighter jets, he left the academy and enrolled at the University of California at Los Angeles, where he graduated with a degree in electrical engineering in 1981. That same year, he met Mr. Samueli at the military contractor TRW Inc., where they both worked. Later, Mr. Samueli went to teach in the engineering department at U.C.L.A., and Mr. Nicholas followed, becoming his first Ph.D. candidate and completing the degree in 1997.
The two men's lives are intertwined. While studying for his doctorate, Mr. Nicholas left TRW and, in 1988, became a founding consultant at PairGain Technologies, a maker of communications equipment, which Mr. Samueli co-founded with two other partners. But he wanted to run his own company, he said, so he started Broadcom in his bedroom in 1991. Mr. Samueli joined the company full-time four years later.
With business success has come celebrity -- if not notoriety. Mr. Nicholas is aware of the names he is called, some too profane to repeat. "People ask engineers all the time here, 'How could you work for that jerk?' " he said. But Mr. Nicholas says his behavior is often misunderstood, and his wildest antics are intended more to shock than to offend.
"I'm kind of a sarcastic guy," he said. "I love to engage people in conversations, like saying, maybe ritual human sacrifices are O.K."
Of course, he is joking. But "people will take me seriously," he said, "or they'll agree with me."
This he chalks up to his fabulous wealth; people are accepting of his outrageous behavior. "Wealth doesn't change people," he said. "It changes the way people treat you."
While he spends plenty on toys, Mr. Nicholas is also generous with charities. He likes theater and has donated millions to the South Coast Repertory and the Orange County Performing Arts Center. He also gave 10,000 Broadcom shares to the University of California at Irvine's intercollegiate athletic department, which was earmarked for the crew team, of which he was a member at U.C.L.A.
And having fun is as much a response to his grueling work schedule as it is making up for lost time. "I end up doing more extreme things because I have less of a life," he said. "I figure I pull an all-nighter for work. Why not do it for fun?" And if there is any doubt, consider his cross-country adventure in January. Mr. Nicholas had planned to fly a helicopter from Miami to California with the goal of gaining enough hours to earn his solo helicopter pilot license.
He had two distractions. First, he was fatigued. He had slept on the plane from Irvine to Miami the morning after his all-night New Year's Eve party. When he arrived in Miami that afternoon, he found himself "loading up on five cups of coffee" to stay alert.
He also had an investor meeting scheduled back in California for Jan. 3, which meant he had a little more than two days to complete the helicopter flight. The first day he left Miami late and spent the night in a small hotel in Tampa, Fla., mosquitoes buzzing in his ears. Still tired on the second day, he did not get as far as he had expected he would. So he ended the flight in Louisiana, calling for a jet to take him home, while the instructor flew the helicopter back to its hangar.
Looking back, he said his expectations were unrealistic and he should have allocated a week for the trip. Even simply recounting the incident still makes him visibly angry. "I really wanted to power through it," he said.

HEADLINE: Vast Rally for Democracy Opens in a Polish Castle

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WARSAW, June 25

 BODY:
A gathering of just over one hundred nations that are either democracies or meet a loose definition of aspiring to be, opened here tonight in the splendor of this city's ancient royal castle. But the grit and sacrifice of modern democratic struggles were in the forefront of many delegates' minds.
The nations, representing various threads of democratic rule, assembled to issue a pledge to uphold basic democratic principles. They range from tiny Mali, the African country chosen as a model for a continent largely bereft of democratic ways, to India, the world's most populous democracy, to the United States, the prime mover of the conference. 
 The document they plan to issue, to be known as the Warsaw Declaration, will stipulate elements of democracy: free and fair elections; the rule of law; freedom of religion and the press; freedom from torture or arbitrary arrest and the right of opposition parties and trade unions to organize.
The organizers -- the United States, Poland, India, Mali, Portugal, South Korea and the Czech Republic -- say they hope that the declaration will gain the currency of the Helsinki Declaration of 1975. From a start fraught with skepticism, that declaration has helped move human rights from an internal matter for individual nations to a global issue.
Whether that goal will be realized here remained an open question. Unlike many international groupings, this group does not plan to establish any institutional machinery to monitor progress or penalize laggards.
Rather, organizing officials hope to form an assembly of the willing whose members will promote cooperation to strengthen democracy in places where it is struggling to grow or in danger of being extinguished. They also hope that the conference, which is to convene again in Seoul in 2002, will gain enough muscle that some of those excluded this time will try to make enough progress to be invited then.
In a symbolic gesture intended to set the tone, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright spoke today in Gdansk, the birthplace of the Solidarity movement, which helped topple Communism in Poland and opened the way to a flourishing democracy.
"While democracy in the long run is the most stable form of government, in the short run, it is among the most fragile," Dr. Albright said in a speech at Gdansk University.
"Good democracies, like good neighbors, can help and strengthen each other by showing solidarity, sharing knowledge, and providing concrete assistance whether in good times or bad," she said.
The guest list for the conference, as well as the composition of the seven-member convening committee, has stirred as much interest as the content of the program -- involving about 70 foreign ministers.
American officials have gone out of their way to insist that the conference is not a made-in-America affair, although the plan was hatched by Morton H. Halperin, the State Department's chief of policy planning, and taken up with the Polish foreign minister, Bronislaw Geremek, at the NATO summit meeting in Washington last year.
Mr. Geremek, a dissident under Polish Communism, agreed that Poland would be the host.
The assistant secretary of state for human rights, Harold H. Koh, said that concocting the invitation list was something akin to organizing a large wedding with seven sets of parents.
But in the end, he said, "I'm not someone who believes that you judge the quality of the wedding by who is or is not attending."
Among those not invited were Iran, even though it recently held elections; the countries of Central Asia, although several have made progress toward freeing their economies; Taiwan, because it is not a member of the United Nations, and many countries of Southeast Asia.
There was never any question of inviting China or Saudi Arabia, the organizers said.
There was considerable discussion on Iran, but an official said it was excluded because of the current summary espionage trial of 13 Jews. Further, Iran remains on the State Department's list of nations that sponsor terrorism.
The conference drew some opposition from Russia, which took offense that China, Belarus and Serbia were excluded. The Russian foreign minister, Igor S. Ivanov, is staying away and will be represented by a relatively junior minister.
Among the well-established democracies, attitudes toward the conference have ranged from the relative enthusiasm of Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer of Germany to pained tolerance from France, Britain and Australia, organizing officials said. The British foreign secretary, Robin Cook, decided at the last moment to stay at home and monitor the election results in Zimbabwe, a former British colony that was not invited.
In Africa, Kenya, a country that the United States has traditionally supported, was included in the guest list despite widespread corruption and human rights abuses.
One purpose of the conference will be to discuss how to stop democracy from backsliding.
Austria, which is being ostracized by some European neighbors after including the rightist Freedom Party of Jorg Haider in the government, will be here. But officials said Austria may well be used as an example of how to support those within a society who work for democracy while showing displeasure with those who work against it.

HEADLINE: Chinese Town's Main Export: Its Young Men

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: FUZHOU, China, June 23

 BODY:
Ting Jiang, near here, is known locally as the "widow's village," a quiet former farming town whose dwindling population consists almost entirely of old people, children and women. Residents estimate that the town has lost more than 80 percent of its men between the ages of 20 and 40 in the last 10 years.
But don't weep for Ting Jiang. It is an unabashedly prosperous place, peppered with lavish multistory tile houses, some with elevators and pools. The kids wear Gap clothes. Cell phones are a standard accessory. And its widows are only widows in the Sunday football sense: Ting Jiang's missing men are still very much alive -- almost all working illegally in restaurants and on construction sites, thousands of miles away, in the United States. 
 Increasingly, their "widows" are following. "Of course I plan to go to join my husband," said a woman from Ting Jiang who gave only her family name, Shi. Ms. Shi calls her husband weekly at a phone number that begins with 904 -- a.k.a. northern Florida.
"We know exactly what life is like there," she said. "Sure, work is hard, but with tips you can make more than $2,000 a month." Here in Fujian Province, with casual labor, they can earn the equivalent of $40, she said, adding: "So no one in the village works before they go to America. There's no point."
Just days after the British authorities discovered the bodies of 58 Chinese who were being smuggled into England in the back of a tomato truck, the grisly news was all the talk in the towns around Fuzhou, home to some if not all of the dead.
But people here regarded it with the same mixture of sadness and disengagement that frequent fliers have when they hear of a plane crash. They may hesitate awhile, but they will go again. For places like Ting Jiang, the long, arduous and expensive journeys that hundreds of thousands of Chinese have undertaken to be smuggled to the West have generally proved a satisfying and sound economic investment.
And that despite a cost of up to $70,000 that must be paid to the smugglers -- called snakeheads -- who make the travel arrangements, and despite the tortuous emigration sagas, which at best involve flying through a series of countries with forged travel documents and at worst mean crossing borders on foot or packed in airless trucks, disguised as tomatoes.
"This is a calculated risk, like many others that rational people take," said a Western scholar, who spoke on condition of anonymity because the Chinese consider the issue of illegal immigration so sensitive. "People live in California even though there are earthquakes. Most of the Chinese do get through and are very successful, both in terms of sending money home and bringing more relatives over."
In fact there are relatively few attractive employment options in this seaside area of southern China, where most of China's recent illegal immigrants to the West come from.
Farming pays little. There is little local industry. The people have rural residency permits and cannot legally move to Chinese cities. Although millions of rural migrants live in cities like Shanghai and Beijing, they live on the fringes of society, working in the most menial jobs.
Moving to New York or Los Angeles is a better-tested strategy here, and certainly more rewarding. In fact, you could say that in places like Ting Jiang or Changle, a township near Fuzhou, emigration to the West is the local industry, which most men enter by the time they are 30.
Those who have the means pay for airplane travel, avoiding what are widely acknowledged to be the greater hazards and hardships of an overland or boat passage. Those who lack the means go anyway.
Chinese officials are cracking down on smuggling, and those who are caught are jailed or fined. And in the wake of the deaths in England, local officials here were aggressively detaining foreign reporters to avoid coverage of what they termed an embarrassing story.
Western embassies in China have highlighted the sufferings of illegal migration, but to little effect. "To be successful locally means you have to emigrate," the Western scholar said. "That is the local definition of success."
Ms. Shi estimates that in her generation alone, dozens from her extended family have gone illegally to the United States, including her husband and three of four siblings. The first one went in the late 1980's. Since then, those who are there have helped those who wanted to follow, lending money to pay for the passage, providing shelter and first jobs, setting up appointments with American immigration lawyers. It has only gotten easier.
Her oldest brother first tried in 1990, by paying a snakehead for overland passage via Europe. He was arrested in Austria and sent home again. His next attempt -- aboard the now infamous freighter Golden Venture, which ran aground off New York in June 1993 -- landed him in an Immigration and Naturalization Service prison for two years. He applied for asylum but ultimately gave up and went home to China.
Two years ago, Ms. Shi said, he took a package tour to Thailand, where he went AWOL as planned and met up with his snakehead. Traveling on false documents, he was flown to a third country and then, after two months, to the United States, where he now works in a restaurant.
Since then, Ms. Shi's older sister has also gone by plane. With ample financing from relatives in America, the family has now generally sworn off the most complicated routes and certainly boat travel, which they consider more dangerous.
A cousin overstayed a fake business visa (price, $50,000). Ms. Shi's 25-year-old brother, a university graduate, is hoping that the snakehead will provide him with a fake marriage to an American ($70,000).
The huge immigration flow that has sprinkled hundreds of thousands of Chinese across the United States and Europe is remarkably localized in its origin, with a vast majority of migrants coming from a small number of townships surrounding Fu zhou. Because of the distances involved, experts say, smuggling Fujianese has become a vast multinational business that some have described as immensely profitable. Prices are based on market principles, depending on the route chosen and local demand. For example, people here say passage to the United States (about $60,000) is more expensive than passage to England (about $45,000), which is in turn more expensive than passage to Hungary or Japan (about $12,000).
After more than a decade of development, certain towns have acquired self-perpetuating predilections for certain destinations.
In Fuqing the destination of choice is Japan. In Sanming it is Eastern and Central Europe, often Hungary, where a large Chinese community has taken root since the fall of Communism in Europe in 1989 loosened travel across the former Soviet bloc. And in the more prosperous areas of Changle and Ting Jiang, the United States is the end point.
The routes vary from snakehead to snakehead and month to month, depending on where the international smuggling rings can find safe havens and obtain the required counterfeit visas or passports.
Experts say passage to the United States often involves several stops, perhaps a three-month stint in Latin America before crossing over from Mexico, or a stay in Hong Kong or Guam, for example. Although nobody knows for sure, academics and residents of Fujian said grueling boat journeys are probably less common than other routes.
Experts say the worst abuses generally occur during slow periods, since some snakeheads then allow poor migrants to pay on credit plans that leave them deeply in debt or travel to new towns to recruit naive passengers.
But studies suggest that this is the exception. In a recently published book about Fujianese migrants, "Smuggled Chinese," Ko-Lin Chin of Rutgers University reported that a vast majority of the 300 people he studied had borrowed their passage fees from relatives at little or no interest. And 86 percent said they were having no trouble meeting their financial obligations.
While people here say there are certainly good and bad snakeheads, they generally regard them as honest businessmen providing a valuable service. They point out that most snakeheads collect the bulk of their fees once the migrants have safely arrived at their destination.
More important still, since a snakehead's business is through word of mouth, he will quickly go bankrupt if his human cargo is routinely intercepted or, worse, ends up dying in a truck of tomatoes.
 Reports from Fujian this weekend in the Hong Kong press said the snakehead who had organized the fatal trip to England had been forced to flee his hometown, his house stoned by angry locals.
The migrants are a mixed group of high- and middle-income Chinese, the poorest usually excluded by the high fees demanded by the traffickers. When they get to their destination, they either disappear into the vast local Fujianese community or -- if they are from wealthier families -- they may even find a lawyer to request political asylum.
"The women say they are fleeing China's family planning system," said one man, explaining that they may be forced to undergo sterilization if they have two sons, for example. He added that "another popular method is to say you're a member of Falun Gong and your family is being persecuted." China banned the Falun Gong spiritual group last summer and has arrested thousands of members who have refused to renounce its practices.
Although the illegal immigrants know that such attempts are generally unsuccessful, they often calculate bail fees into the cost of the journey to America and avoid potential jail time, people here said.
Also, the asylum process can last for years, allowing them time to establish roots in the West in the meantime. They get jobs, sometimes marry Americans and have babies -- who get American passports.
Towns like Ting Jiang are frequently home to such American-born babies, whose hard-working parents send them back to China to be raised by grandparents.
Plenty of money goes home too: by 1993, $30 million at the Changle branch of the Bank of China came from overseas, according to Professor Chin's book. Much of the money goes to building and decorating huge, elaborate family homes, as much status symbols as residences, since only one or two older family members are left in China to live there.
In the short term, life in the United States is terribly hard even for the more successful migrants, who tend to work long hours at low wage jobs to pay relatives back for their passage. As illegal immigrants, they live in fear, often afraid to enrol children in school or visit a hospital. Despite frequent phone calls, they are separated from families.
Ms. Shi's brother-in-law, who is only now applying for political asylum in Los Angeles, has not seen his teenage children since they were toddlers.
But with so many routes, and so many relatives already living abroad, people like Ms. Shi count on a bright future overseas, even though they cannot predict exactly when or how they will get there.
"I will probably go in two or three years, since my husband is up for asylum soon," said Ms. Shi. Then she shrugged, saying, "If that doesn't work, I'll find another way."

HEADLINE: For Lazio on Parade Day, Stump Is a Milking Stool

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

DATELINE: GETZVILLE, N.Y., June 25

 BODY:
After a tumultuous week, Representative Rick A. Lazio headed for comfortable ground in upstate New York today, expressing little regret over his decision not to attend the gay pride parade in Manhattan in favor of courting voters on a dairy farm north of Albany and at a chamber of commerce dinner in this town a few miles northeast of Buffalo.
While his Democratic opponent in the Senate race, Hillary Rodham Clinton, marched in the annual Gay and Lesbian Pride parade, Mr. Lazio admired farm animals and ate breakfast with scores of supporters as he toured a farm in West Charlton, in Saratoga County. 
 Mr. Lazio suggested he had missed the parade to hew to an ambitious schedule that calls for campaigning heavily upstate -- where political analysts believe the race could be won or lost -- while balancing the demands of his Congressional duties.
"You just have to make choices between a lot of invitations that you get," said Mr. Lazio, who said he had generally supported legislation backed by gay rights advocates, including financing for AIDS programs, though some describe his record as mixed.
Mr. Lazio had been criticized by Mrs. Clinton, gay rights advocates and even some Republicans last week for his decision to miss the parade, which organizers had hoped he would attend to demonstrate tolerance. Republicans nationwide have recently made overtures to the gay groups to affirm their support for diversity.
The parade controversy came during a week in which Mr. Lazio faced new attack ads by Mrs. Clinton and in which he confirmed that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating whether his windfall profit three years ago in the stock of a company controlled by his campaign contributors had resulted from inside information.
Mr. Lazio soldiered on, however, and those issues came up only when they were raised by reporters at his two stops.
On his visit to the farm, Mr. Lazio highlighted his promise to search for ways to stabilize milk prices. He supports federal legislation to allow New York to join the Northeast Dairy Compact, a milk-price-fixing arrangement among six New England states that farmers say will bring them more money.
"The value of being here is gaining an understanding of the issues that affect farmers, dairy farmers in particular," Mr. Lazio said.
Later, he attended the Amherst Chamber of Commerce reception in Getzville.
As he often does when campaigning upstate, he spoke of the need to fight for low taxes and focus on economic development programs that would spread prosperity throughout New York.
Mr. Lazio suggested that his duties in Washington, in which he has sought to be present for most votes but has missed some, left him at a disadvantage.

HEADLINE: Energy Cooperative to Offer Customers 'Green' Electricity

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., June 24

 BODY:
Creating the energy industry's equivalent of an organic food store, a Connecticut company is to announce Monday that it will begin selling what it calls "green" electricity, generated not from oil or nuclear reactors, but from renewable sources like wind, water and methane gas captured from garbage dumps.
Naturally, it will be more expensive -- about $5 to $6 more a month. But the company, the Connecticut Energy Cooperative, is betting that some customers will be willing to pay a premium for it. Those who do not mind fossil fuels can still buy traditional power. 
 The cooperative plans to begin offering the service on July 1, the day that state legislation deregulating the electricity industry takes full effect. Green power will be available in most parts of the state, including most of Fairfield County. The cooperative, which also sells oil, natural gas and propane and long-distance telephone service, is like a food co-op, operating nonprofit to reduce prices for its members, both homeowners and businesses.
State Representative Bob Maddox, who is leaving the Legislature after this year to work for the co-op full time as its director of marketing, said he thought people would gladly pay more for the green energy "for their own health," reducing pollution.
"The monthly pricing difference for the average family in Connecticut will be about the same as the cost of a Big Mac with super-size fries and a Coke," said Mr. Maddox, a Republican from Litchfield County, who lives in a solar-powered home in Bethlehem and drives a Honda Insight, a gas-electric hybrid car that gets up to 70 miles per gallon.
Green electricity is already available in parts of California, Pennsylvania and New Jersey, but not New York State. In New Jersey, it is sold by two companies, Connectiv Power Delivery and Green Mountain Energy.
The cooperative's electricity will come from wind in upstate New York, landfill gases in New Hampshire and small hydroelectric plants in Connecticut. The co-op will also sell non-green electricity at prices Mr. Maddox says will be lower than rates charged by Connecticut Power and Light and United Illuminating.
As with organic food, the motives of providers of clean energy can be both environmental and political. Although hydropower is green energy, the co-op will not do business with Hydro-Quebec, the large government-owned utility in Canada, which has been criticized by environmentalists. Hydro-Quebec, which has long called such criticism unwarranted, backed off from its most controversial project, called Great Whale, in 1994. Critics said the project would have flooded Indian tribal lands in Canada and destroyed subarctic wilderness.
Whatever their reasons for choosing green energy, customers who want it will simply be able to call the co-op or visit its Web site, www.energyforme.com. Customers who sign up will not necessarily have green energy going through the outlets in their homes; rather, they are paying to increase the amount of renewable energy on the local power grid, proportional to their monthly usage.
Because customers have no way of knowing what kind of electricity they are paying for, many companies offering green power, including the Connecticut cooperative, have joined the Green-e Renewable Electricity Certification Program, run by the Center for Resource Solutions, an environmental group in San Francisco.
To be certified, power providers must disclose their sources of energy and demonstrate that at least 50 percent of the supply comes from renewable sources.
Ashok Gupta, an economist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, said a cooperative selling both green and traditional energy is "like a cereal company offering healthy cereal and not-so-healthy cereal."
"It's a great thing," he said. "It gives people choices. Avoid coal, nuclear and Hydro-Quebec, and buy green power."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore to Unveil A Plan to Foster Cleaner Energy

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
Under fire from Republicans who say he has no energy plan, Vice President Al Gore will propose on Tuesday an array of economic incentives to encourage cleaner technologies intended to reduce the nation's dependency on foreign oil, aides said today.
The aides said Mr. Gore would call for billions of dollars in tax breaks, low-interest loans, grants and other federal subsidies to encourage consumers to buy clean-energy products, like alternative-fuel cars or solar houses, and to encourage companies to develop sources of energy that do not burn oil. 
 In recent days, Mr. Gore has come under sharp attack by his likely Republican rival, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, for having supported higher gas taxes in the past. Mr. Bush has also accused the Clinton administration of idly allowing gasoline prices to rise steeply this summer. Prices at the pump have soared nationwide, rising as much as 50 cents a gallon in parts of the Midwest, an important battleground region in the presidential race.
Mr. Gore's advisers counter that they can turn the issue to their advantage by portraying Mr. Bush, a former executive with a small oil company, as a pawn of big oil producers whose profits have risen sharply over the last year. Mr. Gore's aides say they are planning an offensive this week in which surrogates will attack Mr. Bush's ties to the oil industry while the vice president focuses on a more positive message.
o In an early taste of those attacks, Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, said today on "Fox News Sunday," "It seems to me what Mr. Bush and what the Republicans are saying and the oil companies are saying is that their answer to the crisis is to keep their profits up."
Mr. Gore had planned to devote this week to discussing the environment in his three-week "progress and prosperity" tour. But with gasoline prices dominating the news in the Midwest, he has chosen to shift gears somewhat and focus his message as much on reducing oil prices and consumption as on cleaning up the environment.
Mr. Gore's aides declined to provide specifics on the cost of the plan. They said the vice president would propose setting aside part of the federal surplus in a protected "environmental trust fund" that would pay for the proposals.
The aides acknowledged that Mr. Gore's new proposals would have little short-term effect on oil prices. But they noted that he had already called for having the Federal Trade Commission investigate possible price gouging by the oil industry and had urged the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase production.
Under the plan that the aides said Mr. Gore would unveil this week, he would provide tax breaks to encourage consumers and small-business owners to buy houses, cars, hot-water heaters and other products that were energy efficient. His aides said the plan would expand on a similar proposal by President Clinton that would cost $9 billion over 10 years.
Mr. Gore would also propose federal subsidies to help utility companies upgrade or replace coal-fired power plants that are the source of much of the air pollution that causes acid rain and smog along the Eastern seaboard, the aides said.
In addition, they said, the plan would call for expanding federal spending on mass transit and having the federal government help underwrite investments in cleaner, energy-efficient technologies.
Dan Bartlett, a spokesman for Mr. Bush, said of Mr. Gore's proposals, "After eight years of weak leadership on energy issues, Al Gore is proposing nothing new." He added, "One thing that is consistent is Al Gore's longtime support of higher gas prices."
In 1993, Mr. Gore cast the tie-breaking vote in the Senate for the administration's economic stimulus plan, which was intended to reduce the budget deficit by cutting spending and raising some taxes, including taxes on gasoline. Some Republicans in Congress are now calling for suspending all or part of that federal gasoline tax.
Governor Bush has tried to use Mr. Gore's writings to accuse him of wanting to increase gasoline taxes as a means of discouraging consumption. Last week, Mr. Bush read a passage from Mr. Gore's 1992 book "Earth in the Balance" that described "higher taxes on fossil fuels" as "one of the logical first steps in changing our policies in a manner consistent with a more responsible approach to the environment."
But Mr. Gore's aides say that the Republicans have willfully misread "Earth in the Balance." The book proposed taxing companies that emit carbon dioxide, a byproduct of burning fossil fuels that is also a significant component of smog. But Mr. Gore also proposed reducing payroll taxes for those companies so that they would not have to increase prices to consumers.
In turn, the Gore campaign has circulated copies of a 1992 letter from Mr. Bush warning that his father, President George Bush, who was then seeking re-election, might lose support in some oil-producing states because he "is viewed as favoring cheap energy." Mr. Gore's aides contend the letter demonstrates that Governor Bush is more concerned about protecting oil companies' profits than reducing retail prices.
Mr. Bartlett said today that Governor Bush was simply urging his father's administration to support a tax break for small, independent oil companies that could help them increase production. He said that Mr. Gore, then a senator from Tennessee, also supported that tax break.
During Mr. Gore's swing through Pennsylvania, Ohio and parts of the Midwest this week, the aides said, he will argue that cleaning up the environment could help the economy, rather than hinder it.
The aides said that the vice president would assert, for instance, that American companies could reap large profits from selling products that help clean the environment to developing nations. And, the aides said, he would argue that American consumers were "ravenous" for products that were cleaner and more energy efficient.
"The environment and the economy are really one and the same thing," Mr. Gore said to a group of Democrats in Miami on Saturday night.

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Monday about Vice President Al Gore's plan to encourage consumers to buy clean-energy products misstated the environmental impact of carbon dioxide. It is a heat-trapping gas associated with global warming, not a component of smog.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Grab That Third Rail

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Today workers outnumber retirees and the workers' taxes pay the retirees' benefits. But tomorrow, when retirees far outnumber workers, the Social Security system will need infusions from Treasury or a tax increase to pay benefits.
 
 Thus, the central domestic issue of the 2000 presidential campaign seems to boil down to this: What do we do now to make sure government will help support tomorrow's old folks?
 But boil it down further: Who will be an old folk? The answer to that unasked question is the key to what alarmists label "saving Social Security."
 Give both George Bush and Al Gore credit for daring to touch what used to be called "the third rail of American politics." Their differing approaches offer voters a clear political choice unrelated to personality.
 Bush's plan calls for taking one-sixth of the present payroll tax and allowing workers to invest it in mutual funds in individual accounts. The intent is to get a return on that investment that is higher than the present rate; that equity growth would supplement the Social Security benefit decades from now.
 Gore found he could not get away with labeling that "a risky scheme" because more than half of Americans are now stock market investors and know that in the long run, broad indexes do better than risk-free bonds.
 That drove him to come up with his own plan to supplement Social Security with an individual savings account for low-income workers. Gore would have government encourage them to save a little each year by adding matching funds, similar to the corporate match of 401(k) plans. For the lowest-income worker, government would add three dollars for every one saved.
 As you would expect, economists for both candidates are busily trashing the other guy's plan. Bush's conservative team derides the Gore plan as another government handout to redistribute income, while Gore's liberal advocates downmouth the Bush proposal as a dire threat to future Social Security benefits.
 Far be it from me to appear even-handed, but if the economy continues to generate trillions in surpluses - that is, if the good times roll on and on as far as the eye can squint - there is merit in both approaches. Let Bush's middle-class workers get the benefit of long-range stock growth, and let Gore's working poor have their sayings enhanced; that way, everybody's nest egg would be tax-deferred to allow the buildup of different degrees of financial security for all.
 Such a consensus is forming. But this nagging doubt remains: What if the good times don't continuously roll? What if we are as mistaken about eternal surpluses as we so recently were about eternal deficits?
 This is where the need appears to define on "old folk." In 1935, when Social Security was luanched, life expectancy was in the mid-sixties. Pegging the retirement age at 65 was shrewd; it meant that not too many people would live to collect benefits for long.
 But now American life expectancy is nearing the mid-seventies. That blessing means that more of us will be around many more years collecting our benefits. The system was not built for such good news.
 Here's the message deemed too third-railly to touch: if we want to maintain Social Security benefits without raising taxes or raiding the Treasury, we are going to have to index retirement age to longevity.
 Not for workers about to retire; that would be denying legitimate expectations. But a worker now under 50 should be assured of full benefits when he retires at 72, or if great advances are made in curing heart disease and cancer, older than that.
 What about the desire of many, after a lifetime of hard work, to go fishing or just loaf around? Brain scientists tell us that's the road to degeneration and dulling of senses. Instead of early retirement, workers should be planning second careers, corporate executives creating plans to better utilize older workers, politicians thinking of incentives to keep workers' minds and bodies active and productive.
 As our lives inexorably lengthen, the way not to lose our marbles is to keep using them. Indexing the retirement age to longevity will help ensure financial security with mental acuity. It has to be part of the reform mix. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Booming Economy Helping California Improve Its Schools

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 25

 BODY:
California is used to defining national notions of biggest and best: It has the most people, the longest coastline and the tallest mountain, Mount Whitney in the majestic High Sierra, in the 48 contiguous states. But when it comes to public education, California has been more like another of its famous landmarks: Death Valley, the lowest spot in the United States.
Depending on who is doing the counting, and how, California in recent years has ranked about 40th in spending per pupil, only slightly better in its high school graduation rate, and last in students per teacher, students per principal, students per librarian and students per guidance counselor. When the state's high cost of living is factored into spending per pupil, California fares even worse, ranking with poor states like Mississippi. 
 But with the state's budget flush in a booming economy, schools are getting some long overdue help. In the past two years, Gov. Gray Davis has added about $7 billion for elementary and secondary education, an increase of about 20 percent. The state has also begun ambitious programs to recruit and retain teachers, with tax credits and home loans.
And school districts have turned to noneducators like former Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, who has agreed to lead the Los Angeles system, in an effort to bring political savvy to the task of replacing and repairing crowded schools.
But in reality, California, a rich state that helped lead the post-Sputnik push for public education in the 1960's, has fallen so far behind that even six straight years of spending increases have left the latest generation of state officials and union leaders struggling to meet what would seem a modest goal: the national average in spending per pupil of roughly $6,600. And many experts have warned that little has also been done to insulate California's public schools, which are unusually dependent on state revenues, against economic downturns.
"The schools have been starved for at least a quarter of a century," Mr. Davis acknowledged in an interview. "I expect that we can right the ship and point it in a new direction. But this is a multiyear effort that will extend well beyond my governorship."
Indeed, it was Mr. Davis's Republican predecessor, Pete Wilson, who began the turnaround, fighting for smaller class sizes and new student achievement tests (though the smaller classes resulted in the hiring of a flood of uncredentialed teachers).
Recent polls have consistently shown that residents rank the quality of public education as the biggest problem facing California. But conditions in some schools have remained so bad that civil rights groups filed a lawsuit in state court last month contending that the disparities violated the state constitutional guarantee of free and equal public education for all.
The problems include textbooks that refer to the Soviet Union in the present tense, crumbling toilets and teachers who show horror movies in class.
Just this month, one Los Angeles school reported that the American flags in several classrooms still had 48 stars.
The origins of the decline are complex and much debated. But one reality stands out: Since Proposition 13 limited local property tax rates in 1978 and shifted principal responsibility for school finance to the state, California's system has become vulnerable to swings in the economy.
In addition, a landmark court decision that required rough parity in spending among districts had the effect of lowering the overall average, not increasing it, and education spending as a share of the state's personal income shrank dramatically.
Like his Republican predecessors, Mr. Davis has been unwilling to press for broad tax increases or changes in the property tax system from an electorate that complains about education but seems unwilling to pay to improve it.
A statewide survey in February by the Public Policy Institute of California, a nonpartisan research group, found that a majority of Californians knew the state ranked below average in education spending, and three-quarters of those surveyed said they would support a ballot measure to reach the national average. But when told state officials estimated that such a measure could result in annual tax increases of $4 billion by 2005, fewer than 6 in 10 voters still said they supported the measure.
Similarly, while another survey by the institute found that a majority of Californians thought the quality of education was a big problem, and nearly 4 in 10 thought the schools had gotten worse, a ballot measure that would have let a simply majority approve local school bonds narrowly failed in March.
"It's really clear that people sense there's a problem, and they'd like to see something done about it," said Mark Baldassare, the institute's survey director and the author of "California in the New Millennium: The Changing Social and Political Landscape" (University of California Press, 2000). "But many Californians are not comfortable with the idea of providing additional resources in terms of their own tax dollars. This has been a constant theme for the past 20 years now: a recognition that our institutions don't have the resources they need, but an unwillingness on the part of many voters to see themselves as part of the solution."
A group of Silicon Valley executives, with Mr. Davis and Mr. Wilson, are leading the charge for a ballot measure this fall that would lower the threshold for approving local bond issues to 55 percent of the vote from the current 66 percent.
The state's largest teachers union, mollified by Mr. Davis's spending proposals, has dropped its plan for a ballot referendum that would have forced California to reach the national spending average on education, a goal that the union's president now says is not much to celebrate in any case.
"If California, the seventh-largest economy in the world, has national average funding, that isn't so great, because there are 16 industrialized countries, and the United States ranks 14th in the funding of K-12 schools," said Wayne Johnson, president of the 500,000-member California Teachers Association. "Being average is no great shakes, but people are acting as if that's the panacea."
Calculating that average, and comparing California's standing, is complicated, because the most recent statistics, based on actual spending compiled by the National Education Association, are for the 1997-98 school year, when California ranked 40th, with per-pupil spending of $5,627, compared with the national average of $6,638.
There are disputes about whether the California figures fully reflect all sources of spending, but Davis administration officials have estimated that California's spending is now at least $6,672, though other states have also increased spending so the national average, when recalculated, would presumably rise.
And education experts note that per-pupil spending alone is not necessarily a reliable indicator of quality, pointing to the District of Columbia, which has relatively high spending per pupil but deeply troubled schools.
It is perhaps more revealing that California ranks poorly in a range of ways, from students per computer to students per teacher. In 1997, California ranked 14th in the nation with a per capita personal income of $26,218, for example, while ranking 45th in education expenditures per $1,000 of personal income, with $34 of every $1,000 going toward public education, compared with $45 in New Jersey and $44 in New York.
"All these problems are at least indirectly related to money, and the shortage of money over a sequence of decades," said Barbara Miller, research director of Ed Source, a nonpartisan research group that tracks education issues in California. "It hasn't been a sudden change. Instead, it's been a steady drift, as money was tight and districts sought to make the cuts as far away from the classroom as possible and things like maintenance were virtually forgotten. Then class sizes grew, fewer computers were purchased and on and on."
Because teachers' unions have remained politically powerful, teachers' salaries here have absorbed a significant share of spending increases over the last two decades, and have remained relatively high. But the state is struggling to attract and retain teachers and is facing a projected shortage of perhaps 300,000.
Mr. Davis, the first Democratic governor since Jerry Brown in the mid-1970's, made it clear that he intended to devote the biggest share of the state's current budget surpluses to education. He went so far as to propose exempting teachers from the state's income tax, an idea rejected by legislative leaders in favor of a smaller tax credit.
But the governor has said he has no plans to seek any broad tax increases. And despite his opposition to Proposition 13 when it passed, and his continued skepticism about it, he has no plans to tinker with the measure's 1 percent limit on local property tax rates, which cut local property tax revenues for education in half.
Bill Carrick, a Democratic consultant here, said Mr. Davis was "a genuine bean-counter."
"His politics are defined by his experience as Jerry's chief of staff when Proposition 13 was passed, and he will do anything he can to avoid having to raise taxes," Mr. Carrick said. "I also think philosophically he doesn't like these straitjacket fiscal formulas, like promising to reach a certain spending level by a certain date."
As it is, under another ballot measure, Proposition 98, about 40 percent of the state's general fund spending is reserved for education, and much of that is already parceled out for several specified programs, like special education, and is not available for basic expenses like maintenance. And because California's school finance system, almost alone among the states, is controlled by the state, it is highly dependent on economically driven shifts in personal income tax receipts, and localities are relatively powerless to use the more stable property tax to make improvements on their own.
But Mr. Davis points to the effort to lower the approval threshold for local school bonds as an example of a structural change he is fighting for.
"This is a very tall order, and people are not anxious in this state to spend more money," he said, "but I believe if we run a really good campaign, we can pull this off. That's a structural change that presumably will allow local communities to make a decision to take unto themselves more bonded indebtedness."
Some experts remain skeptical.
"They haven't restructured the finance system in any significant way," said Michael W. Kirst, a former president of the State Board of Education and now a professor of education at Stanford University. "They have just taken the existing system and gotten more because of the flush times. But there is nothing to protect us from the next recession."

HEADLINE: At Democracy's Picnic, Paris Supplies Ants

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WARSAW, June 26

 BODY:
France offered an antidote today to some of the celebratory tone of the conference on democracy here that was spearheaded by the United States, saying that imposing democracy on a country could have the opposite result.
Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine of France cited Fidel Castro and Saddam Hussein as examples of authoritarian leaders who had only been reinforced either by military force or economic sanctions. 
 Further, he contended, while President Carter clearly did not intend to bring about the Islamic revolution in Iran, his policies had essentially helped bring about that result.
Morton H. Halperin, chief of policy planning at the State Department, parried Mr. Vedrine's statements, saying that the conference was not about the "export" of democracy but about enabling countries that had "chosen" democracy to help one another.
Mr. Vedrine spoke to the gathering in the chamber of the Polish Parliament after opening remarks by the host, Foreign Minister Bronislaw Geremek. Mr. Vedrine then went out of his way to brief American reporters on his thoughts about democracy and how his philosophy on democracy differed from what he saw as the themes for the conference.
He was careful not to attack the particulars of the conference, saying he had nothing to do with its organization and had come at the express request of his friend, Mr. Geremek. He did not mention Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, whose conference this essentially is and who is seeking to make the theme of democracy the lodestar of her tenure.
Instead of lending itself to easy converts, perhaps like religion, he said, democracy is "always a process of evolution." And, he said, it overwhelmingly involves long maturing internal processes within nations such as in economics, the collective state of mind and -- in the end -- politics.
Definitions aside, the French foreign minister appeared vexed about the appearance that developed democracies are lecturing others. Nobody, he suggested, has a magic formula for "transforming Russia into a huge Finland, or China into a huge South Korea."
"Let's not be self-congratulatory," Mr. Vedrine added. "Our democracies still have room for improvement." He singled out the role of money in influencing policy in developed democracies as "terrifying" and bemoaned the apathy of citizens.
Representatives from more than 100 countries, including foreign ministers from many of them, are meeting here under the rubric "Toward a Community of Democracies." The notion is to encourage deeper democracy in the world by having countries commit themselves to a set of principles laid out in what is being called the Warsaw Declaration.
American officials have argued during the last few days that while the number of countries with democratic attributes has vastly increased -- by their count from 30 to 120 since 1974 -- much needs to be done to consolidate democratic gains in the weakest nations and stop backsliding in others.
Countries that were judged by a seven-nation vetting committee to be at least aspiring to democratic standards were invited.
The conference, whose formal sessions began today and will close Tuesday, is split into two entities: speeches and panels at the Parliament for government leaders and a parallel gathering of nongovernmental organizations in a building across town.
Two prominent groups, the Washington-based Freedom House, and the Stefan Batory Foundation, which was founded in Poland by the financier George Soros, were asked by the State Department to organize the parallel meeting, featuring speeches by human rights figures from around the world.
State Department officials called the parallel meeting the World Forum on Democracy, seeming to echo the title of the annual conference at Davos, Switzerland, the World Economic Forum. And they said they hoped that the forum would take on a life of its own and become the equivalent of a "Davos of Democracy." Leaders of some groups grumbled today that they found the comparison demeaning since they had been working on building democracy at the grass-roots level for many years.
One of the emerging themes of the discussions today was the issue of national sovereignty, raised most frontally by Mr. Vedrine but also by others, who took a different approach.
In a moving appeal on video, smuggled out of Burma and shown to the foreign ministers this morning, the Burmese dissident Daw Aung San Suu Kyi urged "the peoples of the free world to work harder toward bringing true democratic progress everywhere."
She was not specific about what kind of action she wanted from the outside world, but she hinted that some kind of intervention was necessary. "Words need to be backed up by action that is united and that is focused on essentials," she said.
In one of his speeches, Mr. Geremek said that in "normal situations" there should be no collision between sovereignty on the one hand and human rights and democracy on the other. Nor, he said, did he anticipate that globalization would abolish the idea of the nation state.
But in "exceptional situations," which are "not in fact so very exceptional," he said, human rights and democracy take precedence. One such example is when the state, instead of protecting its citizens, becomes a threat to them. In this and some other cases, the international community cannot stand by and watch, he said, and must say, "It's human rights, stupid."

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Altered States

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
The State Department's decision to no longer use the term "rogue states" to describe the likes of Libya, North Korea or Iran, but to refer to them instead as "states of concern," was one of those policy moves that is easy to ridicule. In fact, let's do that for a moment.
I travel to some of these places and I can't imagine calling home and having my wife ask me, as she often does, "Where are you?" and I answer, "Honey, I'm in a state of concern." That's really going to cause problems. Couldn't we do something more politically correct, like referring to the North Koreas and Iraqs as states that are "legally challenged" or "states in need of Ritalin"? 
 Kidding aside, there is a serious issue behind the State Department's move. On the one hand, it makes sense that we stop calling these countries rogue states, because such blanket categorization can obscure our own thinking and thus our ability to adapt policy and respond to changes.
But on the other hand, categorizing them as "states of concern" doesn't solve all our problems. It implies that there are "states of concern" and everybody else is basically on the right track -- and that is not the case.
You see, there are basically two broad trends in the world today. One, which the State Department has captured, is that due largely to the pressures of globalization, rogue states increasingly do not want to, or can't afford to, remain rogues any longer, and are reaching out.
But due to the same pressures, many new or old democracies are no longer able to remain democracies either -- and this is just as big a concern. I would call these ailing democracies "states of flux," which could turn into "states of despair" or even "states of rage."
Let's look at them all. It is not surprising that the State Department would want to redefine rogue states, because at least some of the rogues are looking to go straight. During the cold war, rogues had more fun. Being a rogue state was a growth industry, because the Soviet Union or China were always there to buy your rogue junk, rebuild your rogue army and subsidize your roguish life style.
But with the collapse of the Soviet Union, and China going from Mao to Merrill Lynch, there is no more superpower to subsidize a roguish life style. Countries that want to grow today have to turn to the supermarkets -- the big global financial markets -- and they not only won't subsidize roguish behavior, they will punish countries for roguish behavior by withholding money to grow.
That's why rogue states wanting to remain rogue states today have to be able to either generate their own income -- with oil, drugs or diamonds -- or be able to terrorize and isolate their people so efficiently that they have no choice but to suffer in silence. But as internal changes in Iran, Syria, North Korea and Cuba all demonstrate, even the most isolated, ideological rogues are finding it harder and harder to go it alone.
So all of these rogue leaders are trying to reach out and open up -- but without giving up power or totally going straight. "All these states realize that gradually opening up their countries and engaging in the global economy is their only answer, but a soft landing for their societies means a hard landing for their regimes," says the Wilson Center's Robert Litwak, author of "Rogue States and U.S. Foreign Policy."
So we are now entering a period in which all these rogue regimes (and China) are going to try to bring their hard states in for soft landings, but without giving up power, and that is going to spark a lot of infighting, backsliding and civil wars.
But these same pressures on countries to open up, get up to speed for globalization and build institutions that are squeezing the rogues are also threatening to turn some old and new democracies -- Pakistan, Indonesia, Venezuela, Colombia, Nigeria, Peru and maybe Russia -- into new rogues. These are the "states of flux" -- countries that opted for democracy, but have been so swamped by corruption and overwhelmed by the difficulties of state-building that their democracies are increasingly imperiled or virtually dead.
The danger is that these states of flux will turn into states of despair (Sierra Leone or Liberia) -- literally failed states. And, if more and more democracies fill that category, it could turn out to be our biggest concern of all.

HEADLINE: World Bank Criticizes Itself Over Chinese Project Near Tibet

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
In a scathing internal assessment, a World Bank inquiry has found that the bank violated its rules when it approved a Chinese antipoverty plan that would involve relocating 58,000 farmers on the edge of Tibet.
The project raised a storm of protest last year from environmental and human rights groups. Those groups contended that the bank was aiding China's effort to dilute the minority Tibetan population, which the Communist leadership has long regarded as a problem. 
 Under the bank plan, $40 million would be spent to relocate some of China's poorest farmers to more fertile land, just outside the Tibet boundary. A result would be to put ethnic Han Chinese farmers into Qinghai, territory that Tibetans consider part of their homeland.
The Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet who was born in the resettlement region, met President Clinton last week. After the meeting, he said that the bank initiative "would be a source of more problems" and that the project should not proceed for the present.
But the arguments have expanded beyond questions of Tibet, becoming a test of whether the bank is sufficiently sensitive to the political and social ramifications of its projects.
In this case, the project pitted James D. Wolfensohn, the politically savvy president of the bank, against the Clinton administration, which recently reappointed him to his post while declaring its opposition to the China project.
Mr. Wolfensohn suspended part of the project last year and referred the case to the internal "inspection panel," after the United States, Germany and a few other nations had contended that the entire program had been mishandled within the bank.
The bank had planned to release the results of its harshly worded report last week, but decided against that at the last moment. A copy of the 160-page document was provided today to The New York Times by sources hostile to the project.
The report refers repeatedly to "confusion" within the bank staff, which seemed unable to agree on what standards to use in judging the project's effects. The report also describes a "disturbingly wide range of divergent and, often, opposing views" on how the bank should interpret its policies on environmental and social issues.
The study suggested, without quite saying, that the bank had bent its rules to accommodate China's leaders, who wanted to borrow millions of dollars interest-free for the project under a program for underdeveloped nations. The project was approved last year just days before China's eligibility for the loans permanently expired because of its rapid growth.
This is not the first time that the bank has been accused of ignoring its rules to bend to the wishes of a major customer. Another internal report, more than a year ago, found that the bank had overlooked the corruption of President Suharto's regime in Indonesia, another major client.
The most critical element of the new report was its finding that the bank had never seriously considered alternative locations for the farmers, sites that would not raise the sensitive questions of whether the bank was helping China dilute the concentration of Tibetans in the region.
The report prompted a sharp response from Mr. Wolfensohn in a private letter to board members. He argued that the guidelines for assessing projects like this one were not hard and fast. The inspection panel, he wrote, is trying to "push the bank in the direction of a literal and mechanistic interpretation of its rules."
Although administration officials view the report as vindicating their views, bank officials said the heavy-handed criticism sounded similar to complaints by charity and activist groups. "The panel is out to change the bank and this was a stalking horse," a bank official said.
The board is to decide on July 6 on a 15-month $2 million study on the environmental and ethnic effects of the resettlement.
The bank's spokesman for Asia, Peter L. Stephens, said the panel had made valid observations about the resettlement plan. He said bank officials now agreed that they should have classified the project as requiring more environmental scrutiny than they did originally. Bank officials also did an arguably poor job on the ethnic effects, Mr. Stephens said.
"There were clearly areas in the surveys that did not give confidence that the results were reliable," he said. "These were judgment calls, and they made some errors."
