SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1330 words

HEADLINE: Fed Unlikely to Raise Rates Now, Analysts Say

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
After a period of rip-roaring growth that fueled fears of inflation, the economy is showing enough signs of slowing that the Federal Reserve will probably leave interest rate policy unchanged when it meets on Tuesday and Wednesday, economists and analysts say.
But as it looks ahead, the Fed faces two big uncertainties that could lead it back to raising rates later in the year. 
 It is not at all clear, Fed officials say, that the slowdown of the last few months will not give way to another resurgence in growth and inflation pressures. In each of the last two years, growth slowed in the spring, only to come storming back.
And even if the economy is cooling, the Fed will have to decide just how cool is cool enough. Indeed, the central bank will have to resolve an internal debate over whether it is sufficient to slow growth to a pace that would keep unemployment at its current level of around 4 percent, or whether it will need to push harder on the brakes and drive unemployment up, perhaps to 5 percent or higher, to ensure that inflation remains in check.
The Fed has raised its benchmark interest rate by 1.75 percentage points, to 6.5 percent, in six increments over the last year. Economic indicators released over the last month have suggested that the higher rates are beginning to rein in the economy by damping the spending of consumers, slowing the pace of job creation and taking some of the steam out of the stock market.
But Fed officials have been wary of declaring that growth is back under control. In public and private statements, they have indicated that they need to see a few more months of data to be sure that the economy is responding as they want it to. And a number of them have emphasized in public appearances in recent weeks not the evidence that growth is slowing, but rather signs that "core" inflation -- excluding often volatile food and energy prices -- is beginning to creep up.
The most recent data, Robert T. Parry, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said in a speech this month, "makes it pretty clear that we've reached a stage where inflation is no longer falling."
Still, Fed officials have done nothing to counter the impression among investors and analysts that they are willing to put policy on hold until August, when they meet next, to give themselves more time to assess the effect of higher rates on the economy. As concerned as they are about inflation, the last thing Fed officials want to do is tighten policy so much that they stamp out the nation's longest economic expansion.
"It looks as if the economy is behaving the way it should under tighter monetary policy," said Allen Sinai, an economist at Primark Decision Economics. "The Fed can wait and define the slowdown and the inflation response more clearly before taking any further action."
If the Fed were to buck the conventional wisdom and raise rates this week, it would probably be in part because of a desire to keep the financial markets from rallying and fueling a rebound in growth. Analysts said the central bank's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee would probably deal with that matter by issuing a strongly worded statement about the continuing threat of inflation, putting investors on notice that further rate increases are possible, if not likely, starting in August.
"They've got to talk tough," said Stephen D. Slifer, an economist at Lehman Brothers in New York. "If they chose not to talk tough, the markets will think they are out of the picture, and if there was an incipient slowdown it would disappear pretty quick."
In both 1998 and 1999, the economy slowed substantially in the second quarter and then picked back up again to growth rates that fanned inflation fears among Fed officials.
This year the economy grew at a 5.4 percent annual pace in the first quarter, and economists think it has slowed to an annual rate below 4 percent in the second quarter, which ends on Friday. There is some reason to think that this slowdown will last longer than its counterparts the last two years.
For one thing, the Fed has tightened monetary policy substantially in the last year. Moreover, the slowdown appears to be spread more evenly across the economy. And higher oil prices relative to the last few years could damp spending by both corporations and consumers by making everything from a tank of gasoline to raw materials more expensive.
Largely because of the acceleration in the growth rate of productivity, or output per hour, economists are increasingly convinced that the economy is capable of sharply higher rates of noninflationary growth than in the past.
Only a few years ago, economists believed that the economy's noninflationary speed limit was annual growth of about 2.25 percent. Most estimates now put trend growth at around 4 percent, or about the estimated current rate of growth.
But to project possible inflationary pressures, the speed limit, or "trend" growth rate, is often looked at in conjunction with the concept of a "natural" unemployment rate, or the jobless rate at which trend growth or higher will set off an inflationary cycle of wage and price increases.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, does not put much stock in the natural unemployment rate concept, but some of his colleagues at the central bank do, most notably Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor. While some economists say the evidence suggests that the natural rate is now down to around 4 percent, Mr. Meyer puts it at 5 to 5.25 percent.
If the economy is slowing, the debate at the Fed could turn to whether a combination of 3.5 to 4 percent growth and 4 percent unemployment will ignite any smoldering inflation pressures -- or whether the Fed should push growth down further, to a level that sends the unemployment rate back toward 5 percent.
"The major question," Mr. Meyer said in a speech earlier this month, "is whether slowing the economy to trend alone will get the job done or whether we need a period of below- trend growth to unwind an imbalance between the levels of aggregate demand and supply."
Mr. Meyer's concern is that inflation has been suppressed until now in part because of temporary factors that are likely to wear off, and that when they do, imbalances in the economy like the very tight labor market will again put upward pressure on wages and prices.
When the temporary factors dissipate, Mr. Meyer said, "not only will there be some rebound in inflation, but unless a transition is made back to sustainable utilization rates, there will be a risk of a continuous upward movement in inflation."
Translation: unemployment would have to rise back to the 5 percent level Mr. Meyer considers sustainable to ensure that inflation cannot get a foothold.
Mr. Meyer puts more faith than many of his colleagues at the Fed in the idea that there are predictable tradeoffs between growth, unemployment and inflation. But he is far from alone among them in questioning whether the Fed might still have to turn the interest rate screws tighter later this year, even at the risk of taking political criticism as Election Day draws near.
Mr. Greenspan is widely viewed as being more open to the idea that the economy can sustain a combination of strong growth and low unemployment without inflation, largely because of his optimistic outlook about continuing improvements in productivity growth.
Like a number of other Fed officials, Mr. Greenspan is likely to resist any calls for further rate increases on the basis of a theoretical relationship between growth, unemployment and inflation. He will probably be guided more by concrete evidence of how the economy develops in coming months.
It is worth noting, however, that the two camps are not debating whether the economy needs to go into recession to wring out any chance of inflation, only whether it should slow to 4 percent or 3 percent, still a healthy performance, or, at worst, 2 percent.

HEADLINE: Idlewild Journal;
Town Works to Revive Its Image as 'Black Eden'

BYLINE: By NICHOLE M. CHRISTIAN 

DATELINE: IDLEWILD, Mich., June 24

 BODY:
Except for the blinking traffic light that hangs over the two-lane highway here, little remains of this tiny town's legacy as the Midwest's first and most famous black resort area.
The light has long served as the only sign to travelers, mostly from Detroit, Chicago, Indianapolis, St. Louis and, occasionally, New York, that they have arrived in the "Black Eden," the nickname this town of winding roads took on in the late 1940's as scores of black intellectuals and entertainers bought small lakeside cottages and made it a swinging summer retreat. 
 In the days of segregation, Idlewild, 180 miles northwest of Detroit on the edge of Manistee National Forest, was one of a handful of places where black professionals could get away and where black entertainers were accorded the accommodations and adoration that Las Vegas and Hollywood denied them. At clubs like El Morocco, Flamingo and Paradise, summer visitors were entertained by the likes of Louis Armstrong, Count Basie, Dinah Washington and Sammy Davis Jr.
Much of what happened here did not make the history books, and many of the motels and nightclubs where the high-stepping took place have been erased by nearly three decades of economic abandonment.
Today, there is nothing especially grand about Idlewild, unless you count the steely determination of a cadre of old-timers who have held on to the tales and photographs of the glory days and are pushing for redevelopment in the town.
"Even with the history, this place has been on a down cycle for a long time," said John Meeks, a 78-year-old retired Detroit teacher who moved to Idlewild in 1975 after vacationing here for more than 30 years.
Mr. Meeks, who calls himself Idlewild's chief executive, is regarded as the architect of the area's revitalization effort. In 1989, he bought the only remaining inn, the Morton Motel, and has spent $350,000 adding air-conditioning, heat and private bathrooms to each of the 17 rooms.
The efforts of Mr. Meeks and other Idlewild enthusiasts are part of a campaign to draw visitors back to the town and rebuild its legacy with events like celebrity book-signings and concerts as well as an annual retreat for black poets. Their goal is to pass on their passion for Idlewild to a younger generation that has the money to buy homes and open businesses.
"We're on the threshold of building a new and improved Idlewild," said Mabel Williams, 69, who is opening a historical center. "The blinking light is going to be a beacon again."
As proof, Mrs. Williams, and most of the other 400 year-round residents, point to the large traffic barrels down the center of the main road. To the average driver, the barrels are covering potholes, but that is progress to local residents, because those holes mark the spots where Idlewild's first sewage system and natural gas lines are being installed. This summer, cable television is expected. Money from the state, appropriated after Idlewild was designated an empowerment zone in 1994, and other federal grants helped pay for the construction and repairs.
Historians are beginning to take greater note of Idlewild's past, particularly its founding in 1912. That is when a wealthy group of white Chicago developers bought 2,700 acres from a Michigan railroad company and began marketing lots, 125 feet by 20 feet, to prominent blacks like W. E. B. Du Bois and Madame C. J. Walker, the cosmetologist considered the United States' first black female millionaire, for $35, or $6 down and $1 a week.
This month, the Henry Ford Museum and Greenfield Village in Dearborn began staging re-enactments of Idlewild's early days. Also, a University of Nebraska professor, Ronald J. Stephens, is putting together a traveling photo exhibit for next year.
Despite renewed interest and visible signs of improvement, Idlewild faces equally obvious hurdles. It is part of Lake County, where 26.4 percent of the roughly 10,000 residents live below the poverty line, more than double the state percentage, according to the 1990 census, the latest figures available. The biggest industry to come into area recently is a new prison for teenage criminals. In Idlewild, one out of five people is 65 or older, and the number of elderly residents continues to increase because most young people here head for the big cities as soon as they finish high school. For those reasons, some argue that Idlewild's vision of rebirth may be too ambitious.
"Integration essentially made Idlewild a rural agricultural ghetto," said Benjamin C. Wilson, a black studies professor at Western Michigan University and a longtime Idlewild researcher who also owns a cottage here. "Now that entertainers can perform anywhere, it will never be what it was. For people who aren't locked into the nostalgia of old Idlewild, there's not much reason to come. And the young people, the life of any community, leave as soon they get their credentials because it's the only way they'll find a job."
But Mr. Meeks said Idlewild's lakes and forests were too valuable to expose them to the potential pollution of industrial companies, even if the factories could offer good jobs. "Martha's Vineyard and Myrtle Beach didn't get to be upscale resort areas by letting smokestack businesses into their backyard," Mr. Meeks said. "We won't either."
Idlewild's history, he added, demands that it become a tourist destination. "You won't find another place in the United States with this kind of natural beauty and cultural import that still belongs to blacks," Mr. Meeks said, glancing at a group of children and anglers along Lake Idlewild, one of the village's five lakes. "We can't just give it away."

HEADLINE: Double Duty for a Microsoft Investigator

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF and MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 26

 BODY:
When a Microsoft law firm needed help recently in tracking down pirates and counterfeiters of the company's software, it turned to a private investigative firm with a reputation for coming up with sensitive information for high-profile clients.
So Microsoft was taken aback this month by reports that linked the firm, Investigative Group International, to mysterious efforts to obtain the trash of a pro-Microsoft trade association in Washington, presumably looking for documents that would embarrass the company as it fought a high-stakes antitrust case. 
 Microsoft officials said today that they had had no idea that the firm was effectively playing both sides of the street in working for and against Microsoft.
"It's bizarre and inappropriate that they would accept a Microsoft anti-piracy assignment while getting paid to attack the company with cash-for-trash tactics," said Vivek Varma, a Microsoft spokesman. "It seems an obvious conflict of interest." He said Microsoft would review the matter.
Investigative Group International, based in Washington, has been in the spotlight before, most recently when it performed investigative work for President Clinton, including research on Paula Jones, one of the president's accusers.
In a telephone interview today, the firm's chairman, Terry Lenzner, said he could not remember whether Microsoft was a client. "I'll have to check that," he said. "I can't confirm we've worked for Microsoft or any other client that hasn't been publicly identified, but I'll look into it." Mr. Lenzner would not comment on reports that his company had been investigating trade organizations and research groups sympathetic to Microsoft. And he would not say whether his firm had taken or paid for trash as part of such an investigation.
Microsoft said its involvement with Mr. Lenzner's company began in March, when a Microsoft law firm, Preston Gates & Ellis, retained the company's Los Angeles office to help hunt down pirates and counterfeiters. The firm was hired to order software and computers and check to see if the software was legitimate, as well as search public records for evidence of dummy companies that the counterfeiters frequently hide behind. When they found illegal activities, they were to notify the authorities.
This month, however, the Lenzner firm and Microsoft were linked in an altogether different connection. On June 1 and June 6, a woman identifying herself as Blanca Lopez offered to pay a cleaning crew to hand over trash from the office of the Association for Competitive Technology, a pro-Microsoft trade group in Washington, according to documents from the company that manages the association's office space. The incident was first reported by Wired.com and The Wall Street Journal.
The documents said the woman had gained entry to the building using keys from another tenant. The tenant, Upstream Technologies, appears to be a dummy corporation that rented the office only last month. And the person named on a credit application for the property, Robert Walters, has been identified in the past as an agent for the Lenzner firm.
A receptionist at the Lenzner firm's Washington office told a caller today, "Mr. Walters is not employed here but I can get a message to him." Phone calls to Mr. Walters over the weekend and today were not returned.
The Lenzner firm has been known to pay for or take trash on occasion, according to a person intimately familiar with its methods. He said the firm had used the tactic in "four or five" of the 8,000 or so cases it has investigated.
He also said the firm had a policy of taking trash only if a lawyer had reviewed the tactic and deemed it legal and if the client who retained the firm had approved the actions.
Who might have retained Mr. Lenzner's firm in an anti-Microsoft effort is not clear.
The trash-buying attempt at the technology association failed, and the woman extending the offer has not been found. But embarrassing documents from other pro-Microsoft groups have found their way into the press in recent months, and at least two of the groups say the documents may have been on stolen computers.
One case involves documents that were the basis for an article in The New York Times last September. It said that newspaper advertisements presented as independent views backing Microsoft in the antitrust case had actually been paid for by Microsoft. The Times said documents showing the connection between Microsoft and the group placing the ads, the Independent Institute, had been provided by a Microsoft adversary associated with the computer industry.
David J. Theroux, president of the Independent Institute, a free-market policy institute in Oakland, Calif., said he believed that the documents "were surreptitiously taken" but "we just don't know how."
"It could have been through our dumpster," he said, "or maybe someone hacked into our system."
But adding to the intrigue, Mr. Theroux said two company laptops were stolen from the office on June 18, 1999. He said the police concluded that the theft appeared to be a "professional job" by someone who cased the offices earlier in the day.
"We're not claiming these laptops were how the information was obtained," Mr. Theroux said, but he said he thought copies of the documents were on the laptops.
In another case, Marty Reiser, a spokesman for the Citizens for a Sound Economy, a free-market lobbying firm, said laptops were taken from its Washington office on three occasions between September and December. A fourth laptop was taken from its Iowa office in January.
Mr. Reiser said the laptops might have had information showing Microsoft among the organization's donors -- information that later appeared in The Washington Post.
"We're fairly certain there is something going on out there and we need to be more careful," he said. "It's still all very coincidental, but who knows?"

HEADLINE: Lazio Takes On Gas Prices And Criticizes Mrs. Clinton

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

DATELINE: CHILI, N.Y., June 26

 BODY:
Latching onto an issue emerging in political campaigns nationwide, Representative Rick A. Lazio turned his focus today to rising gasoline prices, appearing at three upstate stations to call for a repeal or suspension of some fuel taxes and, along the way, criticizing his opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton.
It was the first time in his monthlong campaign that Mr. Lazio, the Republican Senate nominee, made a somewhat detailed policy proposal of his own, choosing an issue that has confounded government officials and customers. The average gas price in New York last week was $1.68, up 41 percent from the $1.18 at this time last year and the highest in raw numbers since state authorities began conducting weekly surveys in the early 1960's. 
 Mr. Lazio called for suspending for six months the 18.3 cents-per-gallon federal gasoline tax. The tax includes a 4.3 cents-per-gallon surcharge that Congress enacted in 1993. Mr. Lazio said he opposed the 1993 surcharge and proposed today that it be repealed.
He blamed the Clinton administration for its energy policies and accused Mrs. Clinton of not recognizing the issue's importance to state residents at a time when she has begun broadcasting a series of hard-hitting advertisements. "While they sling mud, she has remained silent on this issue that affects all New Yorkers," Mr. Lazio said at a gas station in Chili, a suburb in Monroe County, which includes Rochester. "What Mrs. Clinton needs to do is get out of the motorcade, get out of fantasyland and get in contact with the issues that are affecting real New Yorkers, the prices at the pump."
Mrs. Clinton fired back immediately, with her aides issuing statements at Mr. Lazio's appearances, criticizing what they called his previous inaction on reducing fuel prices and now offering what they said was a shortsighted solution that could jeopardize money to fix highways.
Mr. Lazio's decision to focus on such a consumer issue suggested a subtle shift in strategy. He has focused on appearances that either have made for scenic pictures or allowed him to outline his stances as if introducing himself, telling attendees what he favors -- like lower taxes and charter schools in academically poor areas -- but usually not delving into specifics.
The representative also made appearances today at gas stations near Buffalo and in Syracuse to deride the high gas prices, and will continue his campaign swing on Tuesday in the Hudson Valley, again emphasizing the issue before attending a fund-raiser in Manhattan.
His upstate tour followed a week of static on several fronts for the new Senate candidate, including disclosures about investments in stock options that are now in a preliminary investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission and complaints about his absence from the gay pride parade in Manhattan on Sunday.
Mr. Lazio has insisted that his investments are modest and above board. As for the parade, he had previously scheduled events upstate.
"This administration has no energy policy; Mrs. Clinton has no energy policy," Mr. Lazio said in Buffalo, echoing the sentiments of Gov. George W. Bush, who seized on the gas price issue last week. Vice President Al Gore, who has attributed the price spike to gouging by big oil companies, plans on Tuesday to outline his own energy policy, stressing the use of alternative fuels.
The fliers handed out by Mrs. Clinton's aides used quotes by House Republican leaders to bolster the point that repealing gasoline surcharges could be harmful. The Republicans discouraged such measures, the flier said, because they could diminish highway construction funds. Mrs. Clinton's aides again criticized Mr. Lazio for missing a vote earlier this month in the House on a bill that would have created a home heating oil reserve, another energy-related topic that has angered consumers.
Mr. Lazio, who missed the vote as he traveled to New York to campaign, said his vote would not have mattered on the measure, which was defeated 195-193. But Mrs. Clinton disagreed; she also criticized the idea of rolling back the gas taxes before determining the extent to which oil companies are responsible.
Mr. Lazio said any loss in highway money could be replenished by tapping the federal budget surplus. He also said President Clinton had not done enough to pressure oil-producing nations to lower the price of crude oil, an assertion Mr. Clinton and Mrs. Clinton dispute.
"I think if you look at what the administration has done, it certainly has exerted a lot of pressure, and we've seen two increases in supply in the last several months," Mrs. Clinton said at a news conference on the steps of New York City Hall. "And I anticipate that we'll see the price beginning to drop."
She added: "I think the more interesting questions are the relationships between the Republican Party and a lot of the big oil companies. Because if you look at the hearing that Democratic members of the House had in Illinois just a few days ago, they pointed out that there is no reason for the price to be as high as it is, particularly in the Midwest, but also in the rest of the country. I think we need to get to the bottom of whether there are any excess costs being added to the price of oil here in the United States by our domestic producers and distributors."
Industry analysts say New York's high prices result from a variety of factors, including high demand propelled by a strong economy, low supplies and an increase in the price of crude oil. Although the prices are the highest in raw dollar figures, gas prices were higher in the early 1980's, when accounting for inflation, said Peter R. Smith, an analyst with the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority, a state-sponsored advisory agency.
Greg Voll, who owns the Mobil station here where Mr. Lazio spoke, said that despite the price increases, his sales in last year were up about 5 percent, though that might be due in part to a 5-cent discount he offers on Sundays.
"This is a business area," said Mr. Voll, whose station is in an industrial area near the Rochester airport. "And there is a lot more traffic."

HEADLINE: A DREAM FORECLOSED: A special report.;
Buildings' Savior Now a Troubled Landlord

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
This spring, the grievances at 1084-1086 Home Street in the South Bronx piled up like the garbage in the courtyard: sporadic heat and hot water, unpaid light bills, water-cracked walls, rats swaggering through like neighborhood bullies. Hallway graffiti cursed the landlord, who had not bothered to paint over it.
The building's state was not the handiwork of a profiteering landlord. Rather, the overseer of 1084-1086 Home Street is the Banana Kelly Community Improvement Association, a Bronx nonprofit community development corporation once praised as a national model for residents who want to restore failing housing and reclaim lost neighborhoods. 
 Today, its own properties are increasingly troubled, whether by periods without heat or by unrealized plans, as with a former synagogue, empty and encrusted with scaffolding, on Fox Street.
For a group that got its start rehabilitating abandoned buildings, there may be no symbol more dispiriting than 866 Beck Street, a Banana Kelly building that deteriorated so much that it was emptied of tenants and boarded up.
"Our savior has become a slumlord," said Marta Rivera, the chairwoman of the local community board and a tenant at 1084 Home Street since 1987.
The criticism, if harsh, is understandable, given what Banana Kelly, which drew its memorable name from the curve of the Bronx street where it was born, once meant in the South Bronx.
Two decades ago, foundations, reporters and government officials flocked to the Hunts Point-Longwood neighborhoods to see how Banana Kelly had transformed drug-infested, derelict tenements into livable spaces, and had created low-income housing co-ops that proved the salvation of a once-devastated area.
To its critics, the decline of some of Banana Kelly's properties is a physical reflection of the group's internal disarray, which is sketched in remarkably consistent terms by current and former board members, former employees and financial backers.
Local merchants have shunned, and in some cases sued, the organization because of unpaid debts; at least one oil company began demanding cash on delivery. Former employees who have exited through its revolving door contend that top officials used program money for international travel, an accusation that, according to one federal law enforcement official, is being examined by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The group's board, the essential instrument for accountability, has withered to a tiny group that rarely meets.
Banana Kelly's revenues from foundations, government grants and development projects dropped from nearly $6 million in 1994 to barely $3 million in 1998. It currently has no city financing. Its debts, meanwhile, have mounted into the hundreds of thousands of dollars. It is in arrears on six city mortgages, and behind on payroll taxes. At times, its employees say, their offices lacked for toilet paper. Grand plans, most notably a paper recycling plant proposed for the South Bronx, have stalled or failed.
Twenty-two years after its formation, Banana Kelly is one of the Bronx's major landlords. It manages 41 buildings that house formerly homeless and low-income and working-class families. Over the years, it has expanded into a multiservice agency employing 95 people who do everything from managing its properties to counseling AIDS patients.
Its many triumphs have included a 1996 award from the city as an outstanding community-based organization and another at a United Nations conference that year. But its critics say its recent awards reflect an organization coasting on past glories.
The group's chairwoman, Yolanda Rivera, disputed the critics, saying that it is a wonderful time for Banana Kelly, and that she was bringing renewed vigor to righting it financially. She cited the high school the organization started in 1997; the Board of Education has authorized the construction of a building for the school.
Ms. Rivera denies any allegation that money was misused. She said many of the property problems were caused by tenants who had never learned how to live independently, and said politics or mischief motivated many of her critics. She said that the city had been little help in alleviating the organization's debts, and that she deserved credit for keeping Banana Kelly afloat in a trying period. "I'm not ashamed that we continue to operate, that we are healthy," she said.
Her defenders say that she is paying the price for being a successful Hispanic woman. Joe Hall, who worked at Banana Kelly for eight years, said Ms. Rivera embodies "the great paradox of community development in New York": foundations and other institutions say they want to cultivate indigenous leaders like Ms. Rivera, but then are threatened when they succeed.
But for many, Banana Kelly's situation is less paradox than parable, illustrating some of the dangers inherent in the recent history of government's relationship with poor neighborhoods.
During the last few decades, government has stepped back from direct involvement in areas like housing and health care, and instead encouraged community development organizations like Banana Kelly to step into the breach.
Neither oversight nor adequate resources have always followed. When nonprofit organizations have struggled, government overseers have often been ill positioned or unwilling to attempt reform. No government agency even has a complete sense of Banana Kelly's finances.
In part, Banana Kelly's very purpose has protected it. "Not-for-profits in these communities on the housing side are so critical a resource," said Jerilyn Perine, the first deputy commissioner at the city's Department of Housing, Preservation and Development. "We want to see them succeed. We don't want them to fail. Their importance goes simply beyond their own organization. It's not as if if they disappeared, someone will take their place."
 
Out of the Ruins
A Radical Idea: Save Buildings
Banana Kelly bloomed from the ruins, at a time when housing in the South Bronx was being burned, not built. In the 1970's, a group of residents on Kelly Street united to stop the demolition of three buildings on their block.
The group revamped those buildings and won title to them and others from a city desperate to divest itself of abandoned or deteriorating housing. The city provided loans for rehabilitation or gave Banana Kelly newly renovated buildings to manage, usually asking a symbolic pittance in return.
In 1978, Banana Kelly incorporated as a nonprofit corporation providing housing and services. Its adopted as its motto, "Don't Move. Improve."
"Everyone was coming in to see how we did this, how did we get people together," recalled Pearl White, a founding member, who said she could still remember the splinters stinging her hands as she helped rehabilitate the buildings.
Banana Kelly brought tens of millions of dollars in investment to its community and rehabilitated more than 2,000 units of housing; it also suggested that the tide of hopelessness could be turned. Its methods, like sweat equity, allowed residents to trade work for ownership, and its performance won it federal, state and city contracts.
Today, the Banana Kelly Community Improvement Association is an umbrella organization for the limited partnerships and low-income co-ops that own the buildings it manages. It is supposed to collect rents, do maintenance, pay real estate taxes, and make mortgage, water and sewer payments.
Like many community-based housing developers, it is in a difficult financial position. The group's rents are low, and its tenants vulnerable to falling behind in payments. While Banana Kelly has been taken to Housing Court dozens of times, it has had to bring hundreds of delinquent tenants there, incurring legal expenses each time.
The city also handed over properties in need of more work than it provided financing for, said Harold DeRienzo, Banana Kelly's founder, and Ms. Rivera.
Under Ms. Rivera, who became the organization's chief executive in 1991, Banana Kelly undertook various social service operations.
Saying she wanted to wean both tenants and the organization from dependence on government, Ms. Rivera also turned to large-scale economic development. In 1992, Banana Kelly joined with the Natural Resources Defense Council, a national environmental advocacy organization, to develop a paper recycling plant to be built in the South Bronx.
The plant was designed by Maya Lin, best known for the Vietnam War Memorial in Washington, and praised by President Clinton.
But it has yet to be built; financing and politics have postponed it indefinitely. Like a castle in the air, it drained personnel and attention from an organization struggling on the ground.
 
Staff Turnover
A Poor Record Of Management
As Banana Kelly grew, its infrastructure was being stretched. When Ms. Rivera took over, she dismissed a number of staff members, saying an excess of professionals had distanced the agency from the community.
In subsequent years, new employees and executives have come, but few have stayed long. Many have been fired in the agency's many purges during the last eight years. Even today, Ms. Rivera said, most of the staff is brand-new.
But the agency eventually became overwhelmed, current and former officials said. Financial backers of Banana Kelly describe almost willfully incompetent financial management. They say Banana Kelly never found a workable system for collecting and tracking rents and expenditures, and did a poor job of separating its various operations. It missed tax advantages, and a $2 million state grant awarded in 1998 to renovate 866 Beck Street and another building is being withheld pending an updated audited financial statement, state officials said.
There is also the nearly $1 million owed for water and sewer services, more than $500,000 in real estate taxes, the overdue $127,000 an oil company is trying to collect, the liens and lawsuits over the years from accountants, hardware stores and others.
Former employees describe continual pressures to use money earmarked for specific programs to offset those debts, and say programs and maintenance operations had to run on shoestrings. Superintendents reached into their own pockets to buy everything from paint to oil; the group's former president said he had to take out a loan to make the payroll.
But as employees were scrounging, Ms. Rivera and a few associates were traveling, as part of an international venture the group established several years ago.
By Ms. Rivera's own admission, some part of the organization's dwindling resources -- what she calls general, or unrestricted funds -- were used to pay for that travel, including a trip to a conference in Kenya for her and several associates.
"We got a good group rate," she said.
But, as part of an investigation into Banana Kelly's finances, the F.B.I. is looking at whether federal program money was used to pay for that trip and whether Ms. Rivera's relatives went with her, a federal law enforcement official said.
Among those on the Africa trip was a Bronx-based consultant who did particularly well under Banana Kelly's auspices. By the time the consultant, Aureo Cardona, left the organization last year, his company, Crescendo Inc., was being paid $15,000 a month to manage Banana Kelly's properties, and he had been given access to a $50,000 expense fund -- to be replenished as needed -- to do "national and international engagements" for the group. And, under a contract he signed with Claude Gooding, the organization's former president, he was to receive $1 million if the recycling plant went to financial closing, which it has not.
Ms. Rivera says she knew nothing about that contract, and the two parted ways after The New York Post reported the deal last year. Mr. Cardona is now suing Banana Kelly for back pay, saying his contract was breached, and would not discuss his history with the group.
Another frequent traveler was Mr. Hall, who was named president of Banana Kelly International. Mr. Hall, who said his salary was $55,000, lived in a Banana Kelly apartment at 814 Manida Street, which is supposed to house low-income tenants exclusively under the group's agreement with the city.
Mr. Hall said he did not know the building was for low-income tenants; Ms. Rivera said she thought it was for low-to-moderate-income tenants.
Ms. Rivera has been at the center of controversy almost since she took charge of the organization in 1991, after having been chairwoman of its board since 1985. She has retained her board chairmanship during her tenure as chief executive, an arrangement that her predecessor, Getz Obstfeld, called "fairly uncommon," and that her critics assert insulates her from accountability.
In recent years, the board has shrunk, with as few as three members, including Ms. Rivera, usually attending no more than one meeting a year. Banana Kelly's bylaws say that "board members are not to be directly involved with management." Yet over the years, in addition to Ms. Rivera, various board members have been employed by Banana Kelly, including Rosemonde Pierre-Louis, a member since 1996, who became the organization's president last fall.
If Ms. Rivera has rewarded the loyal, her critics say, she has been vindictive toward those she sees as disloyal. In February, she fired five building superintendents without notice and has since tried to evict them, although the firings await union arbitration.
"She is the law in Banana Kelly," a fired superintendent, Agripino Morales, said.
 
Tenants Make Do
Buildings Worsen, Repairs Go Undone
But neither deep resentment nor financial travails seem to have affected Banana Kelly, its critics say. As its city financing has dwindled to nothing, it has simply turned to the state and federal governments.
City officials could foreclose on Banana Kelly's mortgages, but feel that doing so would set the community back 20 years. Despite being aware of Banana Kelly's management problems for years, in April 1999 the housing department turned four more buildings over to the group. So tenants make do with the landlord they have.
In Lydia Rios's apartment at 788 Fox Street, a city housing inspector who visited in April left a checklist of violations, from no smoke detector to a leaky ceiling. She shrugged. Each year the housing inspector orders repairs, and they go undone, she said.
Banana Kelly's financial backers and city officials say they have lately become particularly concerned because of deferred maintenance to Banana Kelly's properties.
Ms. Rivera said the organization is seeking a loan to pay off back taxes and to rehabilitate 788 Fox Street and several other buildings. But, she said of tenants, "If conditions were as bad as they sometimes say, they would have moved out."
Given the organization's roots, that sentiment sits poorly with Pearl White, who has sat on Banana Kelly's board since its inception. She said she has futilely challenged Ms. Rivera's actions and demanded more records. She was warned, she said, that if she spoke publicly about her concerns, she would be removed from the board.
"I don't want to see any of the buildings end up like the condition we were in," she said, sitting in the apartment on Kelly Street she helped bring back to life with her bare hands more than two decades ago. "I don't want to see Banana Kelly ruined."

Built in 1931; 22 units.
Taxes owed: $10,000

788 Fox Street
Built in 1922; 54 units.
Taxes owed: $220,000
Issues: Leaking ceilings, falling cupboards, graffiti, vacant apartments. Banana Kelly missed an opportunity to apply for an abatement on future taxes.
 
1084-1086 Home Street:
Built in 1925; 56 units.
Taxes owed: $108,000
Issues: Rats, cracked walls, threatened cut-offs of lights, repeated periods without heat and hot water. At least one tenant is suing after falling on a broken stair. Almost all of the commercial spaces are empty.
 
1100 and 1106 West Farms Road
Built in 1901; 30 units.
Taxes owed: $30,618
Issues: Tenants complain of cutoffs of hot water and heat, particularly in winter, and of repairs left undone, from clogged up sinks to broken doors. They say superintendents lacked supplies to do basic repairs.

HEADLINE: Industrial Growth Threatens Scenic Hudson River Valley, Group Warns

BYLINE: By WINNIE HU 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, June 26

 BODY:
The Hudson River Valley, with its lush views and rich cultural landscape, has become one of the most endangered historic sites in the country because of encroaching development by electrical utilities and other industries, the nation's largest privately run preservation group warned today.
The National Trust for Historic Preservation, a nonprofit group based in Washington, chose the verdant, 125-mile stretch from New York City to Albany for its annual list of most endangered places for the first time since it began compiling it in 1988. 
 "It was the fact that there was such a large threat," said Richard Moe, president of the trust. "This could amount to a reindustrialization of the Hudson Valley and undo a lot of the progress that has been made if development isn't checked."
A total of 11 historic sites -- the Hudson Valley was the only major one named in the New York region -- were chosen for this year's list, culled from more than 100 nominated by environmentalists and local government officials for the dubious distinction. Sites on previous lists have included Governors Island in 1998 and Ellis Island in 1997.
The preservation group said today that several proposed power plants, along with growing suburban sprawl along the Hudson River, threatened to pockmark the serene landscape made famous by the 19th-century painters of the Hudson River School.
A power plant in Athens, for instance, would tower over Olana, the home of the painter Frederic Edwin Church. And a Wal-Mart superstore has been proposed not once but twice for a site across from President Franklin D. Roosevelt's home in Hyde Park.
Over the last year, the Hudson Valley has been swept up in a rush to build power plants throughout the Northeast, fueled by the deregulation of electrical utilities and a growing demand for power plants. Gov. George E. Pataki approved plans this month for the $500 million plant in Athens, over the objections of many residents.
Another half-dozen power plants have been proposed for the region in the next few years, as well as a growing number of superstores and several factories, including a $300 million cement plant in Greenport.
While some environmentalists and advocacy groups have opposed these projects, Mr. Pataki and many business leaders have argued that development will bring much-needed economic relief to a region that has been struggling since the 1960's.
Edward Reinfurt, vice president of the influential Business Council of New York State, a lobbying group that represents 5,000 companies, dismissed the suggestion that the Hudson Valley has become endangered.
"In our minds, industry is indeed part of the heritage of the Hudson Valley, and quite frankly, we're delighted to see the return of the steel cranes in Albany and elsewhere," he said. "There is a modest growth, but certainly not growth that threatens, in any way, our communities."
Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki, said the governor has worked to protect the natural resources of the Hudson Valley at the same time that he has pushed economic development. For instance, he said, the state has spent more than $256 million to clean and protect the Hudson River since Mr. Pataki took office in 1995.
"I don't think anyone has done more to protect open spaces and to enhance the Hudson River and its estuaries than Governor Pataki," Mr. McKeon said. "He has a very personal and passionate commitment to the Hudson Valley."
But, he added, "At the same time, we're trying to ensure that we have jobs here at home so our kids don't have to move out of the state."
In January, Mr. McKeon said, the governor appointed a task force of government and environmental leaders to study development issues in the valley and elsewhere around the state. But several environmentalists and advocacy groups said today that the state had not done enough to limit development along the river.
"Our farmland is being consumed at an alarming rate, urban sprawl is moving up the Hudson like a wave, and big-box retail stores are being built on the outskirts of towns and sapping the vitality of our villages and urban centers," said Ned Sullivan, executive director of Scenic Hudson, an advocacy group.
Mr. Sullivan's group was part of a coalition of environmental and citizens groups that filled out a 20-page application nominating the Hudson River Valley as an endangered historic site. Although the designation does not bring money, it does bring renewed public attention to the issue of overdevelopment.
"It has been an effective tool," said Mr. Moe, of the preservation trust, which operates three historic sites in New York, including the Rockefeller estate at Pocantico Hills and the Lower East Side Tenement Museum in New York City. "It's an educational vehicle to make people aware of the threats to different kinds of historic places. It almost always brings favorable attention and resources along with it."

HEADLINE: Home Resales Rise, Yet Little Fear of Effect on Interest Rates

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes rose by a strong 4.3 percent in May and prices crept higher, as pent-up demand caused by a slim choice of homes for sale kept activity buoyant despite higher mortgage rates.
The National Association of Realtors said today that sales in May rose to an annual pace of 5.09 million units from 4.88 million in April. This surpassed expectations of Wall Street economists, who had predicted no change in existing home sales. 
 The data came a day ahead of a Federal Reserve meeting on interest rates, but seemed unlikely to unduly worry policy makers at the central bank who are eager to see signs of a cooling down of the economy.
The strength in home sales was largely attributed to unmet demand as inventories fell to low points in January and February. This left many prospective buyers competing for few homes on the market in recent months, bolstering the sales pace and sending prices higher.
"Some of what we're seeing now are sales to buyers who lost out on multiple bids earlier this year, so a lot of momentum has been carried forward," said Fred Flick, the association's vice president for economic research. "We are expecting sales to slow over the second half of the year."
The association forecasts sales of existing homes -- the largest sector of the housing market, accounting for about 80 percent of overall sales -- to slow this year by 9 percent, to 4.7 million units sold.
James Annable, chief economist at WingspanBank.com, also expects the real estate market to slow, saying that many of the sales that closed in May probably involved buyers trying to lock in mortgage rates before they went higher.
"The Fed will look at this data and probably see it as something of a hiccup," Mr. Annable said.
The Federal Reserve, which has raised interest rates six times in the last year, may be particularly eager to slow existing home sales. Home buyers typically spend heavily on renovations and on major appliances and furniture, kindling the already active economy.
For the last two years, economists have forecast a slowing in the housing market, only to see their expectations dashed.
With that in mind, Sung Won Sohn, Wells Fargo's chief economist, said that any talk of a slowdown this year should be taken with a grain of salt.
"The fundamentals of this economy are still strong," he said. "Consumers have jobs, high confidence and rising real incomes, and mortgage rates have dipped in recent weeks again. If it were not for the shortage of homes available for sale, I think sales would have been even higher."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From the President's Statement on the Budget Surplus

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference today on the South Lawn of the White House about revised figures for the nation's budget surplus, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:
In 1993 when I became president, the federal budget deficit was $290 billion. It was projected to rise to $455 billion this year. The American people wanted a better future, and we offered a new economic course of fiscal discipline, expanded trade, and greater investment in our people and our future. The result has been the longest economic expansion in history, a fiscal turnaround that is stronger, frankly, than any of us had imagined. 
 In fact, in each year since 1993, both economic growth and federal revenues have surpassed our forecasts, and this year is no exception. Today, as required by law, I am releasing the mid-session review of the budget. It shows that our overall budget surplus this year will be $211 billion, more than a $700 billion improvement over where we projected to be in 1993. And we're forecasting a surplus for the next 10 years that is over $1 trillion larger than was forecast just four months ago.
The American people should be very proud of this news. It's the result of their hard work and their support for fiscal discipline. It's proof that we can create a better future for ourselves when we put our minds to it. And it provides a tremendous new opportunity to build an even brighter future if we sustain our prosperity by maintaining our fiscal discipline.
These new surpluses put us in a position to achieve something that would have seemed unimaginable in 1993. As this chart shows, we can now pay down the debt completely by 2012, a year earlier than we projected just four months ago. . . .
Now, why should we do this? Because by paying down the debt, we can keep interest rates lower and free up more capital for private-sector investment, creating more jobs and economic growth for years and years to come.
We can eliminate the burden of paying interest on the debt, which today takes up 12 cents of every federal tax dollar. We can use part of this savings, as I have suggested, to extend the solvency of Social Security to 2057 and of Medicare to 2030.
Now, think about what this means. A 6-year-old today -- we may have some out here -- is living in an America that is $3.5 trillion in debt. If we follow the course I am laying out, we can eliminate that debt by the time the child enters college. The economy will be stronger, his parents' incomes will be greater, the interest rates on college loans will be lower. And 12 years from now, people of my generation will be entering retirement, knowing that Social Security and Medicare will be there for them.
Quite simply, an economic plan that invests in our people and pays down the debt is the wisest choice we can make to honor our values and ensure a better future for our children.
To that end, I propose that we follow Vice President Gore's recommendation and lock away that portion of the surplus that comes from the Medicare taxes people pay. Medicare payroll taxes should not be used to finance tax cuts or other spending. They should be saved for Medicare and Medicare alone. There is already broad bipartisan support for saving the Social Security surplus for debt reduction. It's time to do the same for Medicare, by taking Medicare off budget.
By protecting both Social Security and Medicare surpluses, we can lock in $2.7 trillion of debt reduction in just the next 10 years, enabling us to get the debt entirely gone by 2012. Before we make any other major budget decisions this year, I ask Congress to come together across party lines to protect the Medicare surplus.
Now, a lot of people are saying that because this is an election year, Congress won't get much done. It does not have to be that way. Today, I called House Speaker Hastert and Senator Lott with a proposal to break the logjam and do what we all say we want to do.
We all say we want to provide prescription drug coverage to the millions of senior and disabled Americans on Medicare who currently lack it. I have presented my plan; the Republicans have presented theirs.
We all say we want to end the marriage penalty. I have presented my plan; the Republicans have presented theirs. I believe their marriage penalty, standing on its own and not part of an overall commitment to fiscal discipline and also tilting, I believe, too much toward upper-income Americans, is too big and not targeted toward those who need it most.
But if we can all agree to take Medicare off budget and not use Medicare money for tax cuts or for other spending, then I have told the Republican leaders I would like to make a simple offer. If Congress will pass a plan that gives real voluntary Medicare prescription drug coverage, available and affordable to all seniors and consistent with the principles of my plan, costing roughly $250 billion over 10 years, then I will sign a marriage penalty relief law which also costs roughly $250 billion over 10 years.
This is a proposal for a true compromise. It asks each party to accept some of the positions of the other party in the name of progress. By adopting the vice president's plan to save the Medicare surplus, we will achieve the most significant strengthening of Medicare since the proposal was created in 1965 and deliver the largest tax relief to families in decades. These are goals that both parties and all Americans agree on.
It would be wrong to let politics keep us from seizing the opportunity . . . We can take these actions and still have, according to our new budget projections, substantial resources left over for future budget priorities.
Now, I want to remind the people, however, that this is just a budget projection. It would not be prudent to commit every penny of a future surplus that is just a projection and therefore subject to change. Fiscal discipline helped to create these surpluses; fiscal discipline is what we should continue as we determine how best to use them.
In my mid-session review, therefore, I propose to set aside a $500 billion reserve for America's future, a fund that could eventually be used for any number of key priorities, from retirement savings, to tax cuts, to investments in education, research, health care and environmental protection, to further debt reduction. We should set aside this reserve fund.
At this late date in the fiscal year, with elections looming, it would unrealistic and imprudent for those of us in Washington to decide what to do with this money. That's something that should be debated in the coming months and decided on by the American people this fall. Our obligation is to move forward on those issues that have been fully debated, where there is bipartisan agreement for action.
So this summer, let's set aside the Medicare surpluses and pay down the debt. Let's pass a voluntary prescription drug benefit for seniors and disabled Americans on Medicare, and marriage penalty tax relief for American families.
When that's done, I hope we will also raise the minimum wage, pass a strong, enforceable patients' bill of rights, pass a juvenile justice bill that closes the gun-show loophole, hate crimes legislation and the new markets legislation, and make key investments in education, health care and the environment.
Then, in the election, let's have a vigorous debate about how the remainder of these new surpluses can best be used to advance our nation. It's the right debate to have, and I think we can all agree that it's a debate we are very fortunate to be able to have.
How we use these surpluses in this moment of prosperity will determine America's future for decades to come. Nothing will more surely determine it than making the right choices, if we do the right things to keep our prosperity going, to extend its benefits to people and places not yet fully part of it, to help Americans balance the demands of work and family, to seize the remarkable potential and meet the challenges of globalization and the revolutions of science and information technology.
This is a good day for America. We ought to preserve it for the future and make the most of the moment.

HEADLINE: Clinton Raises Estimate of Surplus And the Stakes on How to Use It

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
President Clinton raised his projection of the federal budget surplus today by nearly $1.3 trillion for the next decade, putting a breathtaking sum of new money on the table as the two parties and their presidential candidates battle over tax cuts, spending and how to prepare for the nation's long-term challenges.
"How we use these surpluses in this moment of prosperity will determine America's future for decades to come," Mr. Clinton told reporters in the Rose Garden. 
 The new estimate put up for political grabs an amount of money two and a half times greater than what the White House had projected less than five months ago.
The robust forecast is the latest result of a strong economy that is rewriting the budget outlook on an almost continuous basis by recasting projections for years to come, even though events could easily undermine those projections.
And those assumptions are promoting an economy that has shown tentative signs of slowing in recent months.
The new estimate brought the total surplus projection to slightly less than $4.2 trillion for 2001 through 2010.
Of that, $2.3 trillion is projected to come from the Social Security system and is considered by both parties to be off limits for tax cuts or spending programs.
The rest -- almost $1.9 trillion, up from $746 billion under the White House's last estimate, in February -- is projected to come from general tax receipts, and is the pot of money that Democrats and Republicans are fighting over.
Seeking to frame the debate over how the money should be used, Mr. Clinton immediately proposed a deal to divide part of the windfall with the Republican majority in Congress.
Mr. Clinton said he would agree to a Republican proposal to cut taxes for married couples by roughly $250 billion over 10 years if the Republicans would go along with his $253 billion plan to add prescription drug coverage to the Medicare system of health insurance for the elderly.
In setting out his budget framework, Mr. Clinton also stressed that he would put the government on a path to eliminate the $3.5 trillion national debt by 2012, a year ahead of his previous schedule, and to use part of the non-Social Security surplus to help extend the solvency of Medicare.
The initial reaction to Mr. Clinton's proposed deal from the two top Republican leaders, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois and Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, fell somewhere between skeptical and dismissive.
Despite Mr. Clinton's clear desire to bring prescription drug coverage to Medicare on his terms before leaving office in seven months, it was unclear whether the two sides would even be able to negotiate during an election season in which they are eager to highlight their differences.
Still, as Mr. Clinton's offer suggested, the surplus, if it materializes, is big enough to give both parties much of what they want, and its sheer size has left Democrats and Republicans alike struggling to get a handle on the politics of potential plenty.
For the last several years, divided government has led to gridlock on tax cuts and major new spending initiatives.
The latest round of surplus numbers -- which are likely to be followed within days or weeks by a similar set of new projections from the Congressional Budget Office -- will only raise the stakes in the election, with both sides asserting that they have a more prudent plan for making the most of the fiscal bounty.
The campaign of Gov. George W. Bush, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, said the new figures vindicated his contention that the nation can afford the large tax cut he has proposed and still have money to create private investment accounts within Social Security, improve education and health care, build a national missile defense system and reduce the debt.
Vice President Al Gore's campaign said the new figures highlighted the benefits of fiscal responsibility and the contrast between his emphasis on shoring up Social Security and Medicare and Mr. Bush's push for a tax cut that would give most of its benefits to the wealthy.
The new surplus projections are to some extent subject to changes in the economy, and any nasty economic surprise could dim the chances of the surpluses materializing.
Mr. Clinton acknowledged as much today. He said it would be a mistake to allocate all the projected surplus at this point, and he proposed a $500 billion "reserve fund" to be held aside until the fiscal situation becomes clearer and voters send a message about what they want to do with the money.
"The projections could be wrong," Mr. Clinton said. "They could be right. That's why we shouldn't spend it all now. And moreover, we're having a debate in which the two candidates have very different notions about what should be done with this moment of prosperity, and the American people ought to have some say in this."
At the same time, Mr. Clinton said, the nation could not be "blind to the fact that we have an enormous opportunity here."
The two parties have already agreed that the Social Security surplus should go only to reducing the national debt or shoring up the retirement system to help it weather the aging of the population.
Nearly all the gain in the numbers released today was in the non-Social Security part of the budget, and Mr. Clinton's aides said the surplus projection was driven up by a combination of the economy's strength and an expectation that at least some of the economic improvement would be long-lasting.
Since late last year, they said, the economy has performed substantially better than anticipated.
Because the economy is bigger now than previously foreseen, it would generate larger-than-anticipated tax revenue even if economic growth from this point on does not exceed the rates that the White House had assumed earlier this year.
But the White House's Office of Management and Budget also revised upward its economic growth assumptions, reflecting a general consensus among economists that the United States is capable of higher rates of noninflationary growth than previously thought.
In the 10 years covered by the projection, the administration now assumes average economic growth of 3 percent a year, up from 2.7 percent estimated by its previous budget projection, in February.
Many economists think that the nation's potential noninflationary growth rate is actually closer to 4 percent.
Of the total increase of $1.275 trillion in the 10-year surplus projection, $984 billion comes from the improved economic outlook.
The projection also includes $375 billion in additional revenue during the decade from technical changes in the estimates of tax receipts. Those increases are offset by an $84 billion reduction in projected receipts stemming from legislation passed so far this year.
Among the biggest technical changes is an upward revision in personal income tax revenues, in part from a surge in capital gains that taxpayers are reaping from stocks they have bought or been awarded by employers as part of their compensation.
In offering to swap a tax reduction for his prescription drug plan, Mr. Clinton was to some extent insulating Mr. Gore and Democrats in Congress from criticism by Republicans, who accuse them of opposing popular tax cuts.
Republicans have been pressing to address what they call the "marriage penalty," the quirk in the tax code that leaves many two-income couples paying more in taxes than they would if they remained single. But the bills they have proposed would give tax cuts to nearly all married couples, even if they do not pay a penalty.
Mr. Clinton also seemed intent on sparking one last round of negotiations with Congressional leaders.
"This is a proposal for true compromise," he said. "It asks each party to accept some of the positions of the other party in the name of progress."

HEADLINE: Archbishop Plans Frequent Learning Visits to Parishes

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

 BODY:
In his first news conference since his installation as New York's ninth archbishop last week, Archbishop Edward M. Egan said yesterday that he planned frequent visits to parishes throughout the archdiocese, as a way of grasping the troubles and strengths of the vast network of churches and schools he now heads, and which he is expected to streamline.
The archbishop, speaking on the eve of his first trip to the Vatican as head of the Roman Catholic Church in New York, also called for an end to the American military's use of the Puerto Rican island of Vieques for bombing practice, and said, in several ways, that he valued Hispanic culture and communities. 
 Comprising 36 percent of the archdiocese's 2.4 million Catholics, Hispanics represent the single largest ethnic block of the archdiocese, which covers Manhattan, the Bronx, Staten Island and seven counties north of the city.
The archbishop, who is expected to be made a cardinal later this year, is to fly to Rome today. On Thursday, the feast day of St. Peter, the archbishop is to receive the white woolen pallium with black crosses, a vestment that he will wear around his neck when he says Mass.
The pallium, dipped in an urn over the spot where many Catholics believe St. Peter is buried, is a symbol of the pope's spiritual link to St. Peter, and of the archbishop's tie to St. Peter and to the pope.
Though Archbishop Egan is running the New York Archdiocese now, Bridgeport, Conn., his last assignment, appeared to remain strong in his heart and mind. Several times yesterday, the archbishop referred to the practices and accomplishments that marked his dozen years there, and the entourage for his trip to Rome will include auxiliary bishops and other officials from both the Bridgeport and New York dioceses.
In response to a question, the archbishop said that he believed the priesthood was getting a "bad rap" as a result of lawsuits alleging that five priests in the Bridgeport Diocese had abused children. In his first substantive public statements on the suits, Archbishop Egan acknowledged that "there have been cases that do have substance."
But in contrast with guidelines from the National Conference of Catholic Bishops urging bishops to minister to the victims of sexual abuse by priests, Archbishop Egan offered no words of comfort or apology to more than a score of plaintiffs who are suing his former diocese for $44 million. Most of the abuse alleged in the lawsuits occurred in the 1970's and 80's. The suits have been going on for more than seven years, and the archbishop said he believed some of the accusations were groundless.
"The fact that the amount of attention given to it, when it's a Catholic priest vs. when it's a minister or a rabbi or the school system or the court system, does sort of upset one," the archbishop said. "Why is the focus always on this particular issue? Yes, it has done damage."
He described that damage as difficulty in recruiting priests and maintaining an esprit de corps, and he said he believed that psychological screening of candidates for the priesthood made abuse less likely nowadays. "I believe the number-one step is, we want to strengthen the number of priests we have in this diocese," he said, "to get our priests to have a sense of oneness, a sense of unity, a sense of mutual support, and of dealing with this other element."
On other issues, however, Archbishop Egan avoided wading into controversy. He did not rule out closing schools or parishes in the archdiocese to reflect demographic or economic changes. Asked whether he had a "personal commitment" to keeping Catholic schools open in minority neighborhoods, the archbishop said: "Yes. However, I do believe we have to stay within our financial possibilities."
He said keeping some schools open in poor areas of the Bridgeport Diocese took "fancy footwork over the first couple of years," and he added that he was in no rush to shutter Catholic schools in New York.
"Give me a little time," Archbishop Egan said, adding that he was "not negative about these schools."
"The schools mean an awful lot to me," he said.
Addressing speculation that the pope would like to see the head of New York's archdiocese made a cardinal, perhaps this fall, the archbishop said, "I think the Holy Father should be encouraged in this way of thinking." Cardinals make up the highest rank in the Roman Catholic church after the pope.

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
MANHATTAN: HOSPITAL BONDS DOWNGRADED
Standard & Poor's has lowered its rating of Beth Israel Medical Center's bonds to junk-bond status. The bond-rating agency also placed the hospital on its list of institutions whose finances warrant close attention by bond holders. Standard & Poor's cited the hospital's weak 1999 operating performance and its shortage of ready cash. Yesterday's downgrade to BB- puts the bonds in the junk category. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT) 

MANHATTAN: BENEFIT FUNDS IN TROUBLE
Two benefit funds for New York City correction officers could slip into insolvency this year because of excessive spending by the union that runs them, Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, left, reported yesterday. The comptroller, in two audits, concluded that the Correction Officers' Benevolent Association was spending far too much on employees' legal bills and prescription drugs for retirees. Norman Seabrook, the union president, said the union was providing the legal assistance and prescription drug coverage its members deserved. Eric Lipton (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: UNION DRIVE AT LAUNDRIES
The nation's largest apparel workers union, the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, announced yesterday that it planned a unionization drive at 15 industrial laundries in New York City. The drive, which includes the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union, will focus first on Waltons, a Bronx-based laundry that handles the linens for several Manhattan hotels. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: ETHICS OFFICER FOR UNION
Lee Saunders, the trustee running District Council 37, New York City's largest union of municipal workers, has appointed Barbara C. Deinhardt the ethical practices officer. The 125,000-member council has been embarrassed recently by the indictment of more than two dozen officials on charges of embezzlement and vote fraud. Ms. Deinhardt, a former general counsel of the state's Department of Labor, will draft rules to enforce the ethics code and to investigate violations. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)
 
GARDEN CITY: POWER FAILURE
A power failure plunged the Nassau County Legislature into darkness yesterday afternoon. The cause was apparently a small fire at a Long Island Power Authority substation. About 7,400 customers lost electricity around 2:30 p.m., but the fire was extinguished and power restored to most customers within three hours. Nina Siegal (NYT)
 
ALBANY: BUDGET DIRECTOR NAMED
Carole Stone, who has been the acting director of the state's Division of the Budget since Jan. 1, was appointed state budget director by Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday. She had been deputy director of the Division of the Budget since 1995 before taking over when her boss, Robert King, was named chancellor of the State University of New York. She is a native of Garden City. (AP)
 
NEW JERSEY
 
TRENTON: OFF-TRACK BETTING
Moving to help New Jersey's horse-racing industry attract gambling dollars lost to casinos, the State Senate's Economic Growth, Agriculture and Tourism Committee yesterday approved a bill to allow off-track and phone-in betting. The bill, which has already been approved by the committee's Assembly counterpart could go to a full vote on Thursday, the last session before the Legislature's summer recess. It would let bettors watching races on television, for example, phone in bets from home. Steve Strunsky (NYT)
 
WOODBRIDGE: NEW TRAIN STATION
New Jersey Transit and Amtrak plan to build a $31 million station and improve platforms at Metropark. In the last five years, New Jersey Transit ridership has grown 17 percent and Amtrak ridership is up 40 percent at Metropark, which is on the Northeast Corridor line. New Jersey Transit will pay the $11 million cost of the platforms and an expansion of the passenger dropoff area and will share the $20 million cost of the station, which is scheduled for completion in 2004. Steve Strunsky (NYT)
 
NEWARK: AIRPORT RISK INDICATED
Air traffic controllers at Newark International Airport have asked the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to eliminate runway intersections created by a $100 million project intended to improve traffic flow. More than $100 million was spent since 1997 on lengthening runways at the airport, which created the intersections to help manage the 1,300 takeoffs and landings each day. Daniel D'Agostino, head of the Newark division of the National Air Traffic Controllers Association, said that planes might cross as many as five times for one takeoff. The Port Authority said it would study the request. (AP)
 
NEWARK: OFFICERS PLEAD NOT GUILTY
Five Orange police officers pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that they violated the civil rights of a man they mistakenly believed had killed a colleague. The man, Earl Faison, died in custody. Judge John C. Lifland of Federal District Court set trial for Aug. 29. A federal indictment accuses the five of beating, robbing and pepper-spraying Mr. Faison after he was arrested and handcuffed last year, and of then attempting to cover up their actions. (AP)

HARTFORD: PARADE ARRESTS
Ten people were arrested in Hartford in connection with disturbances that followed the annual Puerto Rican Day parade, the police said yesterday. Crowd members damaged cars and pelted officers with rocks and bottles in the Park Street area Sunday night, the police said, but no injuries were reported. The police said many of the thousands of people gathered in the area were intoxicated. (AP)
 
HARTFORD: SHERIFFS FILE SUIT
Connecticut's eight elected county sheriffs filed a federal civil rights lawsuit today claiming that a new state law interferes with their constitutional right to free expression and assembly. The lawsuit is the opening volley in what is expected to be a long campaign to influence a statewide referendum in November on whether to abolish the sheriff system. The new law prohibits the county sheriffs from "directly or indirectly" soliciting campaign contributions from any sheriff's deputy or employee, members of the employees' immediate families, or anyone who does business with the sheriffs' departments. It follows years of scandals and allegations of corruption and incompetence.Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
Group Sues to Block Paid Parental Leave

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
The Chamber of Commerce sued the Labor Department today, seeking the repeal of regulations that allow states to offer paid leave to new parents using unemployment benefit dollars.
"They're putting a fund at risk that was set up for unemployed workers," said the vice president of the chamber, Randy Johnson. 
 The regulations, ordered by President Clinton and written by the Labor Department, would allow states to offer unemployment benefits to parents of newborn or newly adopted children who choose to take up to 12 weeks of leave guaranteed under the 1993 Family and Medical Leave Act.
Agency officials did not immediately comment on the lawsuit.
