HEADLINE: The Search for Encores to a Nonevent

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
A year ago, they were the highest-profile technology managers ever, making presentations to top executives and corporate boards, testifying before Congress and spending billions of dollars as the world worked feverishly to avert computer chaos as the year 2000 arrived.
When it did arrive with almost no notable disruptions anywhere, they were relieved, proud and, they acknowledge, surprised. Far sooner than most had expected, it was time to move on. 
 But where? With nothing like Y2K in corporate history, there was no obvious next step for most of those who had managed the biggest repair projects.
Now, nearly six months into the Y2K hereafter, some credit their Y2K assignments with giving their careers a priceless lift. Others think their involvement in what ended up looking to the public like a ridiculously hyped nonevent has held them back.
Most have gone on to e-commerce jobs that may lack the visibility of the Y2K crusade but put them on the cutting edge of Internet development. A few headed for the exit ramp, like Paul H. Couvillion, who ran DuPont's Year 2000 project for more than two years. Mr. Couvillion, 59, is wallpapering his home in the North Carolina mountains, honing his golf game and spending time with grandchildren as he uses up vacation days on his way to early retirement from DuPont in August.
"When I got down to the house, I found one of the clocks had stopped at 11:59 on Dec. 31," he said. "I'm keeping it as a reminder of what would have happened if the work hadn't been done."
Those not looking ahead to retirement had wondered from the start what Y2K would do to their careers. There was no obvious upside in making sure that computers could recognize the digits 00 in dates as the year 2000 rather than 1900 or an invalid entry. The date flaws, if not found and fixed, seemed likely to wreak havoc on the economy and government services. But in the end it was all about dodging a bullet, not creating something new. In short, failure would bring blame for disaster; few thought that success would result in the kind of profit-creating work that normally enhances careers.
No wonder some of Paula Larkin's colleagues reacted as if she had been handed a time bomb when she was named to oversee J. P. Morgan's Year 2000 project in 1996.
"They told me it would be a career-killer," Ms. Larkin recalled recently. "They said that spotlighting people who weren't delivering would make too many enemies within Morgan and that there would be too many outside forces beyond my control."
Fortunately for her, her superiors appreciated the ways she used the Year 2000 challenge to update and streamline the bank's technology and to strengthen its relations with customers, other banks and regulators. In March, Ms. Larkin emerged with a promotion to managing director, a two-month paid sabbatical and a choice of attractive assignments.
"Y2K clearly put me over the top," Ms. Larkin said of her promotion. Before starting on her new assignment as project manager for LabMorgan, the bank's new incubator for Internet-based financial businesses, Ms. Larkin used the time off taking golf lessons and renovating a home on Cape Cod.
Lorraine Gornick felt far less appreciated. A year ago, Ms. Gornick was the longest-serving manager on Sears, Roebuck & Company's Y2K project. She was also the giant retailer's representative to the National Retail Federation's nationwide program to avert panic buying and other Y2K-related disruptions.
So, when she decided to resign to start her own consulting business after wrapping up the repair project, she expected at least to get an attractive counteroffer. It never came, leading her to conclude that her bosses had not paid much attention to her work or put much thought into her future. To reward herself for five years of Y2K labor, she started her firm, Strategy Alliance, as a part-time business to allow time for singing with two choirs in the Chicago area.
"It seems so long ago," she said of Y2K work before leaving this week for a choir festival in Austria. "We knew there wouldn't be much recognition if it went well."
Sears, for its part, says it promised early in 1999 that every member of its Y2K team would get a "meaningful" assignment once the high-risk period was over and that those who stayed found good opportunities. "No one knew where they were going to land at the time she left," said Janice R. Drummond, a Sears spokeswoman.
Many longtime Y2K managers, like Jay Abshier at Texaco Inc., landed in computer security, one of the hottest computer industry niches. The largest contingent, though, moved into cyberspace. Donald Rose, who oversaw Year 2000 preparations for Intel's factories, for example, became co-manager of a new Intel business that markets Internet services to the health care industry. And Del Clark, head of Phillips Petroleum's Y2K project, became director of global e-business overseeing the company's participation on projects like the Web-based procurement exchange that Phillips and 13 other oil and chemical companies set up this year.
"The pent-up demand was in the e-commerce environment," said Brian Robbins, a senior vice president who managed Chase Manhattan's Y2K project and who saw e-business as the logical place to make a splash. "What else could you go into?"
Mr. Robbins began talking about his interest in seeing the bank use Internet technology more efficiently with Steven L. Sheinheit, his boss, as the two shuttled among Chase command posts during the New Year's weekend. He ended up running a new 125-member unit called eSpace Services, which provides technology to Chase business units to help them develop both internal and external Internet applications.
The Internet assignments, like Y2K, often cross traditional boundaries and require tough choices about priorities, according to managers like Brian Cohen, who directed New York City's computer preparations and was named this year as executive director of the city's new E-Government Office, which helps agencies go online. "I have a shirt that says 'Only (blank) days left,' so you can keep reducing the number in the blank," Mr. Cohen said. "It was given to me for Y2K, but it works in my new job, too."
Still, many managers found that prime e-business jobs had been snapped up by others while they were tied up on Y2K work, according to James Devlin, Citibank's Year 2000 project director. And some were sidelined from bidding on promising jobs created by major mergers in the last few years.
"Given what they know now," Mr. Devlin said, "most people I talk to say they wouldn't have stayed with Y2K."

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT;
In the Boom, Desperately Seeking Bean Counters

BYLINE: By GREG WINTER 

 BODY:
When jobs are plentiful but applicants scarce, where do accountants go to drum up enthusiasm for a profession whose very name evokes images of numbers-crunching nerds with penholders in their shirt pockets?
As it turns out, they now go to the one place where hostility to all things uncool burns hottest: high schools. 
 Competing for the smallest pool of college graduates of accounting programs in more than a decade, many of the nation's largest accounting firms and associations have begun grooming talent at secondary schools, the latest battlefield in an industrywide recruitment war. With scholarships and internships in hand, they are hoping to resuscitate a field that is rapidly losing conscripts to the wonders of technology and the glamour of being an entrepreneur.
"We're making big investments in the development of a high school pipeline," said James Hayes, a partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers who sends recruiters to roughly 3,000 schools a year to scout promising students. "High school may almost be too late, and at some point we have to start looking at middle schools."
Which is not to say that the Big Five accounting firms -- Arthur Andersen, Deloitte & Touche, Ernst & Young, KPMG and PricewaterhouseCoopers -- have stopped their hiring efforts on college campuses. In fact, driven by a boom in business, they are crafting ever-wilder ways of grabbing college students' attention and winning their loyalty. Ernst & Young now sends its interns to Disney World, while Arthur Andersen sponsors a national tax Olympics every year that awards the winning school $20,000 in scholarships.
But a 23 percent drop in enrollment in college accounting programs since 1996 -- meaning that about 10,000 fewer accounting graduates come into the workplace -- has persuaded many in the industry to focus on still younger students, before they are whisked away by more scintillating majors. Their goal is not to pluck recruits fresh from high school, but to plant the corporate flag and push college-bound students into the field.
"One objective is to get them exposed to careers in accounting," said Allen Boston, a recruiter with Ernst & Young who offers college scholarships to high school students from 15 states. "The other is to get them to know Ernst & Young."
Leading the charge is the profession's primary association, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, which will send an accounting curriculum to about 10,000 high schools this fall.
As much public relations as instruction, the institute's lessons promote accounting across the disciplines, from physics to social studies. History becomes a class on how sleuthing accountants caught Al Capone; chemistry becomes a chance to set the price of an electric car; and so on. Anything, in fact, to topple the stereotype of the humorless drone in a back room.
Some high school students are buying it. Lindsey Whitneck, who graduated from Bristol Central High School in Connecticut this month, says distaste for her course work had soured her on going to college. But after taking classes with one of the accounting curriculum's designers, she took an after-school bookkeeping job last fall and has now enrolled in Central Connecticut State University to major in accounting.
"It's like accounting saved me," Ms. Whitneck said, although she added: "Everyone in my family thinks it's only a bunch of numbers on paper. They just don't understand."
To be sure, such converts remain rare, college professors say. The profession holds a certain appeal in tough times; when jobs are scarce, a certified public accountant is nearly assured employment. In an economy that promises young people fun and riches elsewhere, however, the profession must redouble its recruiting.
College students "don't want to dedicate themselves to the work it takes to get a technical degree," said Sally Jones, an accounting professor at the University of Virginia, where accounting majors have dropped more than 50 percent since 1992, despite rising applications to the business school.
"There's such a demand for business students that they are going to work in start-ups, finance, everything but accounting," she said.
Making matters worse, almost all states now require an extra year of college courses before students can take exams to get a license in accounting. The new rules, adopted at the accounting institute's urging in the late 1980's, only recently went into effect.
"The timing was unfortunate," said Bea Sanders, the institute's academic director. "Ten years ago, no one imagined that there would be a whole new economy drawing on the pool."
The number of first-time takers of C.P.A. exams has fallen 13 percent since 1992, the institute says. And with fewer accountants to choose from, many firms have taken to raiding one another for talent or simply buying smaller practices.
"There's just nobody left to employ," lamented Kim Fantaci, director of the National Association of Certified Public Accounting Firms, an association of 47 small to midsize practices.
Not surprisingly, the shortage has been a boon to salaries. In an April survey of 70 academic disciplines at more than 120 schools, the National Association of Colleges and Employers reported an 8.8 percent increase in starting pay -- now about $37,000 -- for accounting graduates, second only to the gain for information-systems majors.
But accounting salaries still lag behind those in high technology, and firms have proved reluctant to offer stock options, the holy grail of job seekers these days.
"People feel that they are covering their bets better by getting a broader business degree," said Jane Rubin, an accreditation specialist at the International Association for Management Education.
Ms. Rubin supports efforts to arouse teenagers' curiosity, though she thinks programs so far are insufficient. "There's going to have to be a much more comprehensive master P.R. plan than even what's been envisioned so far," she said.
Maybe so, but the Big Five firms still stand to benefit from the early exposure of their profession to young people. "Eventually these kids are going to be adults with businesses who are going to use their services," said Ms. Sanders, the accounting institute's academic director.
The firms themselves have no illusions about their high-school expeditions. Easily distracted, convinced their careers are eons away, teenagers are moving targets, difficult to track through college and beyond, they acknowledge.
But, they add, they have no choice but to take aim at them.
"As difficult as it is, given the number of high schools that are out there, we need to do more," said William Nickey, New York recruiting director for Deloitte & Touche. "Even if the economy slows down, we're always going to need more accountants than we're currently producing."

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
Japan's Memento Mori

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Japan's Liberal Democratic Party is neither liberal nor democratic. Nor is it exactly a party in either the European or American senses: it is more like a coalition of patronage-driven political machines. And it does not exactly have a track record to be proud of, having presided over a decade of stagnation in an economy that was once the wonder of the world.
Yet despite its apparent vulnerability, not to mention the personal unpopularity of Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori, the L.D.P. managed -- just -- to cling to power in last Sunday's election. The main reason was that the opposition seemed, if anything, even more clueless than the bumbling Mr. Mori about what to do next. And that is something we should all find disturbing. 
 Whenever I write about Japan, I get quizzical letters from Americans who don't see why they should care. The world's second-largest economy is neither doing well enough to provide villains for a Michael Crichton novel nor badly enough to pose any clear and present danger to prosperity elsewhere. So why should anyone without a direct financial stake be interested in its troubles?
The answer -- the reason professional macroeconomists are grimly fascinated by Japan's economic malaise, and you should at least be interested -- is that Japan's sad tale is a reminder that the roots of prosperity may be shallower than we like to think. It's not just the historical parallels, though Japan in the late 80's shared many of the features of America in the early 00's: high growth without inflation, technological dynamism, extremely high stock valuations that analysts somehow managed to rationalize. What is really unsettling about Japan is not so much the fact that it went wrong but the way it went wrong.
If you had polled serious economists a decade ago, and asked whether it was possible for a modern economy to experience a decade of "demand-side" stagnation -- productive capacity going unused because consumers and businesses could not be persuaded to spend enough -- I am sure that 99 percent of them would have answered "no." We had learned the lessons of the Great Depression; never again would the leaders of a major economy make the mistakes that allowed that slump to go on so long. Even now a fair number of my colleagues seem to think that a slump that cannot be cured with a sufficiently low interest rate is theoretically impossible. Yet that's the reality in Japan, and if it can happen there, why not here?
Admittedly, Japan does not look like a nation in the midst of depression, mainly because we have learned something these past 70 years: instead of trying to balance its budget in the face of a slump, the L.D.P. has engaged in huge "pump-priming" deficit spending. Or maybe that's a bad metaphor. Japan's fiscal efforts don't call to mind a farmer getting his pump running so much as sailors frantically bailing out a leaky boat. So far they have succeeded in keeping the boat from sinking, giving themselves time -- but time to do what? Neither the L.D.P. nor the opposition seems to have any idea.
The only Japanese policy makers who have a clear vision of what to do next are its central bankers, who have been preparing the public for the imminent end of their "zero interest rate" policy. Why insist on the need to raise interest rates when the economy is still so depressed, when independent economists are warning that Japan may well slip back into recession later this year? To force structural change: the Bank of Japan believes that it must raise interest rates to force the private sector to become more efficient. This is just a modern version of "Liquidate labor, liquidate stocks, liquidate the farmers, liquidate real estate. . . . It will purge the rottenness out of the system" -- the disastrous advice that Herbert Hoover received from Andrew Mellon, his Treasury secretary.
And that is the other reminder from Japan. In the United States we have come to rely on Alan Greenspan's knack for doing the right thing in an emergency. After seeing the financial crises of both 1987 and 1998 turn out to be manageable, we have come to take sensible, even heroic action on the part of key economic officials for granted. But in reality a good Greenspan is hard to find. So Japan's troubles are a reminder of the lack of wisdom with which the world is usually governed.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Losing Money On the Birds Or Bombers

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
WHEN a politician anywhere in America wants to build a stadium, it is customary to make a pilgrimage here to Oriole Park at Camden Yards. New York City officials have already performed the ritual twice. In 1998 Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani came to watch the Yankees play and personally inspected the luxury sky boxes.
"This is an enormously, an enormously successful project," Mr. Giuliani said then. "When you look at the development that it's helped in part to energize, it really is quite impressive." 
 Yes, the development on the nearby waterfront is impressive: sold-out hotels, bustling stores and restaurants, promenades crowded with tourists. But politicians might get a truer picture if they came when the Orioles are out of town, like this last week in June. The crowds are still here. The hotels routinely sell out on summer weekends even when there is no game.
The crowds were here long before the stadium opened in 1992. This week the city is celebrating the 20th anniversary of Harborplace, the complex of stores and food stands dedicated to what urban planners call "recreational shopping." It was Harborplace, plus a new aquarium and other tourist attractions, that revived the waterfront. The Orioles play only 81 games per year, but recreational shopping never stops.
Maryland taxpayers spent $200 million on Oriole Park, and $210 million more for the adjacent football stadium, which opened in 1998. New York officials have been contemplating both kinds of stadiums for the West Side of Manhattan, at a cost of $1 billion each.
Politicians in New York envision hotels springing up next to a stadium, but that's not happening in Baltimore. There are still warehouses near the Ravens' football stadium. A new hotel is being built, but it's across the harbor -- far from the stadiums but close to stores and tourist attractions.
Oriole Park is a financial success story if you compare it with the football stadium, or with almost any other new stadium. (Cleveland's baseball stadium is the other one held up as a model.) But even it is a money-losing proposition, according to a study by two economists at Johns Hopkins University, Bruce W. Hamilton and Peter Kahn.
"If you're getting more people in the ballpark, you're taking them away from bars and and bowling alleys and places like that," Dr. Hamilton said. Nationally, new stadiums hurt the economy by diverting investment from more productive enterprises. Locally, they make sense only by attracting money from out-of-towners.
"New York City, like Baltimore, can draw people from nearby jurisdictions," Dr. Hamilton said. "You can rip off people from New Jersey just like we can try to rip off people from Washington. The problem is that they're not going to bring in enough money from New Jersey to justify spending a billion dollars on a stadium."
ATTENDANCE at the Orioles' games rose after they moved to Camden Yards, with about 70 percent of the new revenue coming from out of state. The result, according to the Hopkins study, has been new jobs and tax revenues worth about $3 million annually, which is $11 million less than what the stadium costs taxpayers. That works out to a loss of about $15 annually for each household in Baltimore.
For Baltimoreans, that may seem a small price to pay for a source of entertainment, pride and civic unity. "If there had been a referendum," Dr. Hamilton said, "asking people in the Baltimore area if they were willing to pay $15 a household to keep the Orioles from leaving, I think it would have passed." Voters would have assumed that the stadium was essential to keep the Orioles from fleeing to a better deal elsewhere in the country.
But fans in the New York area don't have to worry much about their teams' heading to an upstart city in the Sun Belt. The teams are already in the biggest and most lucrative market in the country. A team can cross the Hudson in search of a better deal without leaving that market, but any move out of the metropolitan area could be financially disastrous.
"New York has much more bargaining power than Baltimore," Dr. Hamilton said. "Its baseball and football teams are not going to a smaller city somewhere else. It would be more sensible for New York to forge an agreement with New Jersey not to bid against each other. Instead of paying a billion dollars for a new stadium for the Yankees, New York might pay New Jersey a much smaller amount to keep them from trying to steal the Yankees."

HEADLINE: Level of Consumer Confidence Falls From May's Record High

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27

 BODY:
Consumer confidence fell in June from a record high a month earlier, dampened by higher gasoline prices and the Federal Reserve's efforts to slow the economy, a survey showed today.
The Conference Board's consumer confidence index fell to 138.8 this month from 144.7 in May, which had matched January's record. The index's average in the second quarter was the second best ever. 
 While the figures suggest consumer spending is unlikely to slow much in the coming months, "a touch of nervousness is entering into their thinking," said Joel Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa.
That is what Fed policy makers, who have raised interest rates six times the last year to slow spending, want to see. The Fed's Open Market Committee, wrapping up its meetings on Wednesday, is expected to leave the federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks unchanged at 6.5 percent.
As for fuel prices. the national average price for regular, self-service gasoline recently reached a record $1.68 a gallon. Fuel prices, particularly the $2-a-gallon cost in the Midwest, "are enough to make a difference if customers view them as permanent," said George Pipas, a spokesman for the Ford Motor Company.
But many customers, he said, "expect prices to go down once the dust settles."
Consumers are also scaling back their vacation and car-buying plans because of higher prices at the pump and rising interest rates.
An index measuring vacations intended within the next six months fell to 44 in June -- the lowest reading since December 1982 -- from 46.3 in May, the survey showed. Plans to travel by car on vacation fell to the lowest level since record-keeping started in 1978.
Consumers planning to buy cars fell to 7.3 percent from 10.1 percent the previous month. Car sales could slow, particularly sales of fuel-guzzling sport utility vehicles and trucks, though there has been little evidence of that year. Sales of sport utility vehicles rose 11 percent in May compared with figures a year earlier, according to the Autodata Corporation.
The confidence index averaged 140.4 in the second quarter, down just barely from the record average of 140.9 in the first three months of the year.
"While latest signals suggest that U.S. economic activity should decelerate in coming months, consumers are not expecting this record-breaking economic expansion to end anytime soon," said Lynn Franco, head of the Conference Board's survey.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A forecaster revises his ad-spending predictions upward -- again -- for this year and next.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliot 

 BODY:
A LEADING forecaster of advertising spending has raised his estimates for 2000, citing economic conditions that are more robust than he expected as well as strong spending so far this year by marketers in major categories from automobiles to computers to drugs.
And in a sign that the sustained boom on Madison Avenue shows little likelihood of slowing down -- dot-coms or not-coms -- a preliminary prognostication for 2001 was similarly upbeat. 
 "We think these good trends will continue," Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at Universal McCann, said at a presentation of his predictions yesterday at the University Club in Midtown Manhattan. "There is continued strong demand for media time and space."
Ad spending is considered a sensitive barometer of the economy, particularly the willingness of consumers to continue shopping as enthusiastically as they have. Though the Conference Board reported yesterday that consumer confidence fell this month from a record in May, the data for the second quarter was the second best ever. That suggested that the consumer spending spree was unlikely to slow significantly.
"There are legs to the story" of continued sustained ad spending growth, said Karen R. Ficker, a managing director at ING Barings in New York who attended Mr. Coen's presentation.
In addition to the categories cited by Mr. Coen, which also included alcoholic beverages, brokers and mutual funds, restaurants and resorts, Ms. Ficker said she expected big increases in ad spending in "emerging categories" like wireless and hand-held devices that "are going to need to brand themselves to differentiate themselves."
In his presentation, which Mr. Coen makes twice a year, he predicted that ad spending this year in the United States would total a record $235.6 billion, up 9.4 percent from a revised figure of $215.3 billion spent in 1999.
The 1999 figure was an increase of 6.8 percent from the $201.6 billion spent in 1998 -- and was "very good for an odd-numbered year," Mr. Coen said, that did not have the stimulative effects of elections and the Olympics. Those events are of course adding to the projected increases for 2000, along with special campaigns with millennium themes.
An increase of 9.4 percent this year would be the largest percentage gain since 1984 -- also a year of Olympics and elections -- when ad spending climbed 15.8 percent.
The estimate yesterday was the second time that Mr. Coen, who has been following ad spending trends since 1948, had raised his 2000 forecast. His first prediction, made in June 1999, was for an increase of 7.5 percent; six months later, he revised his outlook to an increase of 8.3 percent.
"The economic expectations are considerably brighter for 2000 than they were in December," Mr. Coen said, primarily because many advertisers "are posting phenomenal increases" in ad spending.
National ad spending this year is now expected to rise 11.1 percent, to $141.9 billion, compared with Mr. Coen's estimate in December of 9.1 percent to $139.2 billion.
Local ad spending, however, is now expected to rise 7 percent, to $93.8 billion, rather than 7.1 percent, to $93.9 billion. Mr. Coen attributed the slight decrease in his estimate to "a weak performance in retail" advertising in newspapers.
If Mr. Coen's latest estimates for 2000 prove right, ad spending as a percentage of gross domestic product would reach a record 2.4 percent, compared with 2.33 percent in 1999 and 2.3 percent in 1998.
That pleased another analyst attending the presentation, Leland A. Westerfield of PaineWebber in New York, who has theorized that ad spending may be breaking out from historic norms. Until now, Mr. Westerfield said, when ad spending reached or exceeded 2.3 percent of gross domestic product, it would drop back down below that rate.
"There's no one else who can bring 50-plus years of economic observations to his forecasts," Mr. Westerfield said, "which provides a large measure of credibility when Bob says advertising can outpace G.D.P. growth."
If advertisers cooperate with Mr. Coen's initial estimate for 2001 -- $251 billion, an increase of 6.5 percent from his adjusted forecast for 2000 -- ad spending next year would amount to 2.42 percent of projected gross domestic product.
Turning to ad spending abroad, Mr. Coen was also optimistic, citing expected gains in several countries that account for about two-thirds of all spending outside the United States, among them Canada, France, Germany and Italy.
Spending overseas should total $229.2 billion, Mr. Coen said, an increase of 7.2 percent from a final total of $213.8 billion for 1999, which has been adjusted downward from earlier estimates of $216.3 billion. The revised total for 1999 marked a gain of 4.2 percent from $205.2 billion spent abroad in 1998.
For 2000, then, Mr. Coen's worldwide total estimate is $464.8 billion, up 8.3 percent from his final figure of $429.1 billion for 1999. That would be the biggest one-year percentage increase since 1995, when worldwide ad spending rose 11.5 percent. The final 1999 figure represented an increase of 5.5 percent from the $205.2 billion spent in 1998.
Looking ahead to 2001, Mr. Coen said that ad spending abroad would reach $247 billion, up 7.8 percent from his revised forecast for 2000; that would also be the biggest one-year percentage increase since 1995.
So Mr. Coen's worldwide total estimate for 2001 is $498 billion, an increase of 7.1 percent from his projected total for 2000.
"I couldn't quite juggle those percentages to get to $500 billion, half a trillion," Mr. Coen said, laughing.
One audience member at the presentation suggested with a smile that if Mr. Coen was "worried about getting to $500 billion," he should raise his estimate for online ad spending, now set at in 2000 of $3.4 billion, up 75 percent from 1999. (Actually, Mr. Coen had; the figure he projected in December was $3.2 billion.)
As for dot-com spending in the traditional media, which may decline if more e-commerce companies close or conserve cash to remain afloat, Mr. Coen was sanguine.
"If two of these companies lose their ability to buy traditional media," he said, "10 more can fly in to replace them."
Universal McCann, where Mr. Coen works, is the media services division of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising. That agency is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group, owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

HEADLINE: Diane Blair, Professor of Politics; Friend of the Clintons Was 61

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Diane Divers Blair, who taught and practiced politics in Arkansas for 30 years, becoming fast friends with Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, died on Monday at her home in Fayetteville, Ark. She was 61.
The cause was lung cancer, her family said. 
 At her death she was professor emeritus of political science at the University of Arkansas, where she lectured and wrote from 1968 until her retirement three years ago.
Mrs. Blair befriended the Clintons in the mid-1970's. She worked as a researcher for Mr. Clinton's presidential campaign in 1992, and as an adviser in his 1996 re-election effort. In 1993, Mr. Clinton appointed her to the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
The friendship drew scrutiny in Mr. Clinton's first term after it was revealed that Mrs. Blair's husband, James B. Blair, the chief counsel to Tyson Foods, had helped Mrs. Clinton make nearly $100,000 in profits from trading in commodity futures.
Professor Blair was a regular guest at the White House, and the Clintons reciprocated, visiting her in Fayetteville three times in recent months during her illness.
The Clintons are expected to attend a memorial service for her next month.
Professor Blair was born in Washington. She graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Cornell University in 1959 and received an M.A. in political science at the University of Arkansas in 1967.
In between she worked as an analyst for the President's Committee on Government Contracts, a researcher for the Senate Special Committee on Unemployment and legislative secretary to Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri.
After moving to Arkansas, she served Governors Dale L. Bumpers and David H. Pryor on various state commissions.
In 1980, Governor Clinton appointed her a commissioner of the Arkansas Educational Television Network, and she served until 1993. The board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting elected her chairman in 1997 for a two-year term.
In addition to writing many articles and book chapters, she was the author of "Arkansas Government and Politics: Do the People Rule?" (University of Nebraska Press, 1988).
In addition to her husband of 21 years, Professor Blair is survived by a son and a daughter by an earlier marriage, William R. Kincaid of Washington and Kathryn K. Jong of Fayetteville; two stepdaughters and a stepson, Heather E. Blair of Chicago, Arden S. Blair of Columbia, Md., and James R. Blair of Fort Worth; a sister, Lois Alard of Fayetteville, and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Sells Tokyo Sowa Bank to an Investment Fund

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 27

 BODY:
The Japanese government said today that it would sell the bankrupt Tokyo Sowa Bank to an investment fund led by Wilbur L. Ross, a specialist in corporate rescues who has made a name for himself through investing in financially distressed companies in the United States.
Mr. Ross's fund, the Asia Recovery Fund, will pay 35 billion yen, or about $331 million at current exchange rates, for Tokyo Sowa, the second Japanese bank it has bought. Last month, the government sold the failed Kofuku Bank, which operates mainly in Osaka, to the fund. 
 Tokyo Sowa is the third bank the government has sold to foreigners and the sixth nationalized bank it has returned to the private sector since it began overhauling the country's shaky financial system two years ago. By the time it hands Tokyo Sowa over to Mr. Ross, the government will have spent 70 billion yen, or about $673 million, cleaning it up.
Mr. Ross has been one of the most serious foreign investors in Asia since the financial crisis that gripped much of the region in 1997.
A bankruptcy specialist in the United States, he has promoted the idea of vulture investing here, or buying distressed businesses that can be salvaged for profit.
Mr. Ross says he sees great opportunities in the Japanese banking industry, which has been riddled with bad loans as a legacy of the speculative-bubble economy of the 1980's.
By melding the two troubled Japanese banks he is buying, Mr. Ross plans to create a network of 200 branches offering services to individuals and small and midsize companies in and around Tokyo and Osaka, Japan's two largest cities. "This will give us critical mass, making critical investments in information technology and marketing more affordable," Mr. Ross said.
Tokyo Sowa is smaller than Kofuku but has several strengths that Mr. Ross hopes will enhance the investment. The Tokyo bank is known for having one of the best automated teller machine networks in Japan, distinguishing itself by offering a broad range of 24-hour services, still relatively rare here. It also issues credit cards, a business that Kofuku abandoned but would now like to re-enter. "We now will have a big distribution system through which we can offer money management, insurance and other products that generate fees," Mr. Ross said. "Increasing sales of fee-based products is key for Japanese banks. Interest rates are too low here to make a good rate of return with your balance sheet alone."
Japanese interest rates have been near zero for more than a year because of Japan's weak economy. The low rates have helped banks by keeping their own borrowing costs down. But the low rates also mean the banks have little reason to loan more money out and must find other ways to be profitable. Mr. Ross has been making a name for himself in Asia, at a time when many private equity investors are complaining about what they call the difficulty of finding attractive deals.
Last week, Mr. Ross's investment firm, W. L. Ross & Company, joined with the American International Group, a leading American insurer, to invest $800 million in a mutual fund company that is part of South Korea's giant Hyundai conglomerate. Mr. Ross's firm also owns a life insurance company in South Korea and is managing the resolution of some defaulted loans for the South Korean government.
In Japan, Mr. Ross has put money into a bankrupt auto parts manufacturer and the two banks. "It's baloney to say there aren't opportunities in this region," Mr. Ross said. "You just have to be prepared to do things differently than the way we do them in the United States."
In the bidding for Tokyo Sowa, Mr. Ross beat out Shinsei Bank, formerly known as Long-Term Credit Bank, which is owned by a group of investors led by Ripplewood Holdings, a Wall Street investment firm, and the H.I.S. Company, a travel agency that specializes in selling discount tickets. The government said the deal with Mr. Ross's group was the best for Japanese taxpayers. But officials at the Financial Reconstruction Commission, the agency overseeing the restructuring of the financial sector, may also be irritated with Shinsei because the bank has effectively put the government in the position of rescuing a private company.
To facilitate the sale of Shinsei last year, the government pledged to buy back loans made by Shinsei whose value falls by a certain percentage. Shinsei exercised that agreement yesterday, placing the government in an awkward position.
Critics of the government have said such an arrangement is unfairly generous to Shinsei and victimizes Japanese taxpayers.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
Excerpts From the Vice President's Speech on Energy Policy

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, June 27

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Vice President Al Gore's speech today on energy policy, as released by his campaign:
All of you who drove to work today know that the cost of gasoline is simply too high for America's working families. In the first part of this year, oil company profits increased nearly 500 percent. That's why I've called for a federal investigation of concentration, noncompetitiveness and pricing practices in the oil industry. Now that the investigation has started, I would like to call for public hearings so the voices of American consumers can be heard.
But now is also the time to recognize that the challenge we face is even broader than soaring gasoline prices. We see the same underlying problem in our aging power systems that are becoming less reliable. And we see it in the old engines and power plants that waste so much energy and in doing so create way too much pollution that makes our air unhealthy, and our world warmer. 
 But we don't have to accept a future of more pollution. We don't have to accept a future where kids and grandparents have to stay indoors on a muggy day, and where the days themselves get muggier still.
Here's the good news: we have the means and the technology to meet all these challenges. . . .
Today, I'm proposing a new Energy Security and Environment Trust, a bold and unprecedented commitment to achieve an even more prosperous economy, powered by cleaner, more reliable energy, in a healthy, truly livable environment.
First, we will modernize and improve our nation's power systems, to prevent future power outages before they affect you and your family. We will ensure reliable and affordable electricity by providing new incentives to industry to improve our power lines. And we will give special incentives to companies that want to use their own, more efficient power systems on-site, or use renewable energy, such as wind or solar power.
Second, we will do more to protect our kids and our parents from the smog and soot that cause asthma.
One of the best ways we can do this is by giving new incentives to industry to transform dirty old power plants into modern, clean sources of energy. For that, we will need enforceable, market-based standards that are comprehensive instead of piecemeal. And we need to end monopolies, and instead let competition bring us clean energy and smaller energy bills.
We are blessed with abundant supplies of coal, petroleum and natural gas; we have to use these resources wisely.
With new technology, we can make all our energy sources cleaner, safer and healthier for our families. We will bring together the best minds from the private sector and create an open competition to design the best incentives for old power plants and industries to change, to improve, to modernize and move ahead.
Through the power of free markets, we will take a dramatic step forward for our children's health, which will also be a dramatic new step toward a stable climate.
Third, while we modernize our power systems and reduce pollution here at home, we must aggressively pursue the global market for new energy technology that is expected to reach $10 trillion in the next two decades, as other countries also take steps to overcome pollution and the threat of global warming.
As the world implements the Kyoto treaty, we must ensure that all developed and developing nations do their part.
Fourth, as we reduce America's dependence on big oil and imported oil for the long term by finding new and better ways to produce clean, affordable, and reliable energy here in America we will work even more closely with industry and labor to bring cleaner cars, trucks and buses to showrooms and streets around the world.
This is a multi-hundred-billion-dollar industry; we've got to seize the lead, before Japan or any nation beats us to it.
Fifth, we will cut taxes so families can start buying those 100-mile-per-gallon cars as they hit the showrooms. Even the best innovations are of little use if they are stuck in a lab, unaffordable and unattainable to you, your family or your business. But tax credits can make them competitive, and then mass production will bring the prices down even further.
We will also give tax credits so that it is not far-reaching fantasy to put a solar roof on your home, or to renovate your home to make it more energy efficient, but an affordable and money-saving practicality.
We will also make major new investments in light rail and mass transit, to make your neighborhoods more livable and to liberate families from having to buy gas at any price, if they'd really prefer not to.
Finally, we will do more than use the technologies of the future; we as a nation will aggressively invest in the skill and creativity of the people who discover them, and the factory workers who produce them.
There will be no new bureaucracies; no new agencies or organizations, because the era of old government is over. We'll measure performance carefully and ensure that we reach our goals with common-sense standards.
But it is America's innovators and entrepreneurs, investors and working men and women who will forge the real solutions, not the federal government.
I know these challenges are not easy. And for me, they have never been without controversy. But my commitment to the environment has always run deeper than politics. We have to do what's right for our earth because it is the moral thing to do.
It involves all of our lives, from the simple security of having safe, reliable, affordable electricity for your home; to America's ability to keep building and selling the best new cars, trucks, and technology to the world; to guarding our children from the summer smog that is made worse by global warming, and securing for our grandchildren the expectation of a joyful array of seasons that we took for granted when we grew up ourselves. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Per-Pupil Spending Significantly Exceeds Peak Reached Before Recession in Early 90's

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
For the first time in a decade, inflation-adjusted spending on public school students in New York City has significantly exceeded the peak it reached before the city plunged into recession in the early 1990's, the Board of Education reported yesterday.
In the school year that ends this week, the board expects to spend at least $10.5 billion, or an average of $9,573 for each of its 1.1 million students. That is an increase of almost 7 percent from the 1998-99 school year, when spending totaled $8,957 per student. 
 Measured in constant 1990 dollars, this year's spending is expected to total $7,600 per student, the first significant gain over the $7,400 that was spent in the 1989-90 school year and again last year. With the onset of a national recession in 1990-91 -- one whose effects lingered in the New York region longer than in many other areas of the country -- per-pupil spending fell steadily, to a low of $6,600 per student in the 1997-98 school year, before beginning to rebound.
The Board of Education was also able to direct a higher percentage of its total outlays into the classroom this year than in each of the three previous years, thanks in large part to the long boom on Wall Street. Meanwhile, fewer dollars were directed to programs like building maintenance and school safety.
The budget figures released yesterday were part of the board's annual School-Based Budget Reports, which are preliminary estimates of year-end figures based on spending through May 17.
Final reports on the year's actual expenditures, which are expected to be closer to $10.8 billion, will be released in January.
Because gains in the city's financial investments this year reduced its required contribution to pension plans for retired board employees, proportionately more dollars were scheduled this year for classroom instruction, one of seven major categories of spending tracked by the board.
Spending on classroom instruction, which includes expenses for teacher salaries, books and supplies and teacher training, is expected to total 54.5 percent of outlays this year. That is the highest since the Board of Education began releasing detailed budget breakdowns in the 1996-97 school year. Last year, classroom spending accounted for 52.7 percent of total expenses.
Much of the new money is paying for teacher training programs and instructional supplies, according to the budget reports.
Professional development and other contracted instructional services rose to 2.9 percent of total spending this year from 1.9 percent last year, while instructional supplies and equipment -- which covers everything from software to furniture -- rose to 2.2 percent of spending from 1.1 percent.
Several categories of spending are expected to decline this year, both in total dollars and percentage of total outlays, including building maintenance and school safety.
Projected spending on school safety officers and supplies declined to $102.8 million, or 1 percent of the budget, from $117 million, or 1.2 percent of total spending last year.
Beverly Donohue, the board's chief financial officer, said that spending would jump significantly next year with the addition of 500 safety officers recently approved by the Giuliani administration.
Building maintenance, which includes salaries and supplies for maintenance but not for the separate custodial services, is expected to account for $180 million, or 1.7 percent of the total budget. Last year, spending on building maintenance totaled $187 million, or 1.9 percent of outlays.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Changing Designs, A Project Revives

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
In 1985, 20 years after the blackout that plunged much of the Northeast into darkness, New York commemorated the anniversary with a festival called Urban Light. Among the enthusiastic participants, even though it would not formally open for another year, was the International Design Center in Long Island City, Queens, for which the architectural firm of I. M. Pei & Partners designed the master plan.
Yet five years after its opening, the $150 million design center was itself nearly plunged into darkness, not from a power failure but from an exodus of tenants. The showrooms and shops in the center and the developer, the Lazard Development Corporation, had badly overestimated the willingness of design companies and their customers to make the leap across the East River from Manhattan. 
 But after several false starts, multiple owners and bankruptcy, the lights are back on at the center. Now, however, the one-million-square-foot complex is known as the Queens Atrium Corporate Center, and the center's two buildings, at 30-20 and 30-30 Thomson Avenue, are fully leased to corporations and city agencies.
When MCI Worldcom Network Services recently asked for more space in the center -- in addition to the 260,000 square feet it had leased for 15 years toward the end of 1999 -- Insignia/ESG, the center's leasing and management agent, was able to accommodate the request only by buying out a tenant.
"Through the 90's, the center was only 40 to 50 percent occupied," said Richard Karson, executive director of Insignia/ESG. "And right before we were hired to reposition the property at the end of 1996, the building was in danger of losing its biggest tenant, whose lease was set to expire."
One of the buildings in the complex, a 6-story, 500,000-square-foot structure constructed in 1919, had already been through any number of changes. Perhaps the most visible came when the American Chicle Company moved its factory and headquarters there from Manhattan in 1923. American Chicle remained there for 48 years, its huge rooftop signs, proclaiming the company's Chiclets and Dentyne brands, dominating the Long Island City skyline.
When Lazard Development, a subsidiary of Lazard Freres & Company, the investment banking firm, began developing the site in the early 1980's, at the urging of New York City officials and after a $23 million federal urban development action grant, it added an atrium and full-length skylight to the former American Chicle building and added an atrium to the neighboring 8-story, 450,000-square-foot Bucilla Building, which was built in 1914.
The original intent was to convert the buildings into offices, showrooms and retail shops for furniture, lighting and accessories in a single, convenient location, just across the Queensboro Bridge from Manhattan. The consensus of investors, tenants and the city fathers was that the combination of easy access, rents 20 percent to 60 percent less than comparable space in Manhattan and generous tax breaks would add up to a sure thing. Mr. Pei predicted, "We will have one-stop design shopping."
The way things turned out, "no-stop shopping" would have been more accurate. As one visitor described it in 1991, "the center looks like an archaeological site."
Adam H. Foster, managing director of Insignia/ESG, said many people had a psychological block about being so close to Manhattan without actually being there -- a mind-set that still poses a problem for his brokers. "When we were trying to interest tenants in the corporate center," he said, "our biggest problem was getting chief financial officers and other decision makers to come over the bridge or jump on the subway."
As recently as a year or two ago, Mr. Foster said, before commercial rental space became so scarce and expensive in Manhattan, "we had companies turn down coming here even though it would cost them $10 million to $15 million more a year to be in Manhattan."
From the beginning, the repositioning plan consisted of going after tenants who needed lots of space, instead of the warrens that were there in the buildings' previous incarnation. In addition, Insignia/ESG obtained a package of financial incentives from the New York City Economic Development Corporation for qualifying tenants. So while annual rents for the corporate center run in the mid-$20's per square foot, the incentives typically bring it down to the high teens.
Despite the corporate center's name, the space is almost evenly divided between corporate tenants and New York City agencies. Those agencies are the New York City School Construction Authority, which recently signed a 12-year renewal lease; the Department of Transportation and the Department of Design and Construction. Together, the three take up about 95 percent of the space in Center One, the handsome six-story building.
The revived fortunes of the corporate center received a big boost in 1998 (a year after Oaktree Capital Management of Los Angeles bought the buildings from the Bank of New York) when the DeVry Institute of Technology, based in Illinois, was looking to expand its chain of 18 colleges into New York.
"DeVry was chasing several deals in Manhattan," Mr. Foster said, "but as prices there rose, they kept losing out on them. So we contacted their broker, and they wound up taking two floors and an option on a third."
Mr. Karson of Insignia/ESG said the school was attracted to the Queens Atrium Corporate Center for the same reasons most of the corporate tenants were, and because it was only a block from CUNY's La Guardia Community College. DeVry opened in the corporate center in the fall of 1998 with 500 students; last fall's count was 1,200.
"Now that rental space is almost impossible to find at any price in Manhattan, corporations aren't as reluctant to come here," Mr. Karson said, pointing toward a number of nearby buildings with corporate tenants. And with both buildings of the Queens Atrium Corporate Center sold out, he lamented, "if only we had another half-million square feet to rent."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Unveils $125 Billion Energy Plan

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, June 27

 BODY:
Offering a sweeping vision of a future in which pollution is conquered and cars run without a "drop of oil or gasoline," Vice President Al Gore proposed tax breaks and other incentives today for both reducing America's dependence on oil and cleaning up the environment.
And he made clear that he wanted to claim these issues in the presidential election not only with his soaring oratory but with the amount of money that he was willing to devote to them, more than $125 billion over 10 years. 
 The plans that the vice president outlined today -- mostly various forms of tax breaks for businesses that provided or invested in more efficient, less conventional or less polluting sources of energy -- represented an estimated $75 billion in lost federal tax revenue or spending over 10 years, aides said. But they said that the additional proposals that Mr. Gore was expected to make on Wednesday and Thursday would bring that figure up to more than $125 billion.
Mr. Gore framed that investment as both an opportunity and an obligation created by the country's current period of extraordinary prosperity.
"There can be a next stage of prosperity in which American creativity builds not just a better product but also a healthier planet," Mr. Gore said outside an energy plant here that was a model for the use of newer, cleaner, more efficient technology.
"We will say to the nation's inventors and entrepreneurs: if you invest in these new technologies, America will invest in you," Mr. Gore continued. "And we will prove, once and for all, that we can clean up pollution, make our power systems more efficient and more reliable, and move away from dependence on others all with no new taxes, no new bureaucracies, and no onerous regulations."
While economists and business executives often worry that more clean-air efforts and stringent environmental regulations would hamper industry and limit the creation of new jobs, Mr. Gore's approach emphasized the carrot of tax savings rather than the stick of restrictions, and it anticipated the growth of new companies and new jobs on the cutting edge of fuel technology.
But Mr. Gore's pitch was more than just an exhortation for a cleaner environment. It also reflected the sudden emergence of high gasoline prices as a potent issue in the 2000 presidential elections. Republicans have assailed the Clinton administration for an energy policy that they say has left the country too vulnerable to the whims of foreign oil producers.
Mr. Gore even folded into his speech a call for the Federal Trade Commission's investigation into possible price-gouging by the oil industry to include public hearings, possibly with testimony from consumers.
Earlier this month, when Mr. Gore embarked on what he called a "prosperity and progress" tour, he said he would spend this week talking about environmental policy. But since then, gas prices have become an increasingly heated point of contention between Republicans and Democrats, and today, the word energy accompanied and even preceded the word environment in the headlines atop the written remarks and policy summaries that Mr. Gore's aides distributed to reporters.
And Mr. Gore frequently alluded in his 26-minute address to the problems of American dependence on "big oil," a phrase undoubtedly meant as a dig against his Republican rival, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, a former oil company executive. Democrats have said that Mr. Bush's former professional ties and the enormous sums of campaign money he has received from oil companies would make him unwilling to press for lower prices at the gas pump.
In any case, Mr. Gore said in his speech, "Our next-stage prosperity must be built on our ability to make sure Americans will be free forever from the dominance of big oil and foreign oil."
Mr. Gore said that America today stood "on a new frontier of energy independence and environmental protection" and should not fail to explore it. "It is an old, timid way of thinking to build our lives and livelihoods around a fuel source that is distant, uncertain and easily manipulated," he said. "It is a new, bold way of thinking to demand and develop new technologies to free ourselves from gas-tank price-gouging."
Later, in a satellite interview with an ABC affiliate in Green Bay, Wis., Mr. Gore attacked Mr. Bush more directly.
"I have never been afraid to take on big oil," Mr. Gore said. But, the vice president added, "My opponent comes out of the oil industry. His experience is as an oil company executive. He called for higher oil prices to boost the oil companies' profits."
Officials with the Bush campaign noted that Mr. Bush had endorsed the Federal Trade Commission's investigation into oil companies and said that Mr. Gore was merely trying to deflect attention from the Clinton administration's responsibility for gas prices that have risen as much as 50 cents a gallon in some areas of the Midwest. Mr. Gore, as it happens, will be taking his new energy message to that region over the next few days.
Mr. Bush's aides further said that what Mr. Gore unveiled today was really a set of environmental proposals, none of them especially visionary, that were recast and reconfigured to sound like an energy plan because the political landscape had changed so quickly.
"The vice president seems to forget who's been in office for seven years," Mr. Bush said at a news conference in Michigan this afternoon. "This is an administration that's been in charge and the price of gasoline has risen steadily."
The plan that Mr. Gore began to outline today centered on an unspecified "menu of financial mechanisms," as material distributed by his aides called it, of tax incentives, loans, grants and bonds to help "power plants and industries that come forward with projects that promise to dramatically reduce climate and health-threatening pollution."
Some of Mr. Gore's proposals represented expansions of current federal programs, while others were new. They included doubling the tax credit for businesses that turn wind or landfill methane into electricity and giving accelerated tax deductions to companies for the purchase of equipment that makes cleaner and more efficient use of fuel. In the coming days, Mr. Gore's aides said, the vice president will talk about tax breaks for consumers who use solar energy or buy products, like cars, that do not use traditional sources of fuel like oil.
Mr. Gore's proposals seem to veer in somewhat different directions from those of the last Democratic president to offer a sweeping set of proposals on energy use, Jimmy Carter. As a way of trying to reduce dependence on foreign oil, Mr. Carter set import quotas on the amount of foreign oil accepted into American ports. And he encouraged the development of alternative sources of fuel, including coal, oil shale, unconventional gas and the sun. Mr. Carter asked that utility companies cut their use of oil by 50 percent over a decade, and switch to other fuels, particularly coal.
And most famously, he ordered thermostats turned down in the winter as a conservation measure and wore a sweater in the chilly White House.

HEADLINE: Agency Cites Growing Danger Of Erosion Along U.S. Coasts

BYLINE: By CORNELIA DEAN 

 BODY:
The Federal Emergency Management Agency said yesterday in a report to Congress that a quarter or more of houses within 500 feet of the United States coast may be lost to erosion in the next 60 years, putting intolerable strain on the federal Flood Insurance Program.
The report called for a major new effort to map coastal erosion, identify hazard areas and raise premiums in the insurance program, perhaps even doubling them, to take erosion risk into account. And it suggested that the agency consider adopting setback requirements to limit building at the edge of the sea. 
 Though the report covers all ocean and Great Lakes coasts, it said the erosion problem was particularly severe on the Atlantic, where beaches retreat on average two to three feet a year, and the Gulf Coast, where the overall annual erosion rate is six feet.
More than 1,500 coastal structures now fall to erosion annually, James Lee Witt, director of the emergency management agency, said in an interview yesterday, adding that the figure could rise to as many as 10,000 in 10 years. Almost 350,000 houses are within 500 feet of the coastline, according to the report. Though most are not covered by the federal program, "we have a lot more structures out there at risk than we anticipated," Mr. Witt said.
He said the situation would get worse if sea level continued to rise and Americans continued to migrate toward coastal regions.
"You have on average 3,600 people relocating to these regions per day," he said. "You're looking at an awful lot of risk."
Stephen P. Leatherman, a coastal geologist at Florida International University, where he heads the International Hurricane Center, led the team of researchers who produced the report.
"A lot people have been startled by the findings," Mr. Leatherman said. "What we see is a lot of properties that have been insured by FEMA that were built when there was a wide beach and a big sand dune. Those have either been diminished or in some places are completely gone."
Mr. Witt said erosion hazard maps and better building codes would reduce property damage, but he also praised setback requirements as "a first step and a good step."
Advocates for coastal property owners called the report a thinly disguised effort to use federal insurance regulations to force people off the beach.
"There is a small group of self-proclaimed experts who are convinced that no one should live anywhere near the coast," the American Coastal Coalition, an advocacy group for coastal communities, said in a statement. "Unfortunately the report cloaks bad policy recommendations in the garments of scientific respectability."
Howard Marlowe, the coalition's president, said in an interview that it was important for coastal residents, or prospective coastal residents, to understand the hazards. But Mr. Marlowe said the federal government should not use its insurance program to discourage people who want to build at the coast.
As for setback requirements, he said it was crucial for decisions to be made locally. "We don't want to put the federal government into the business of making zoning ordinances," he said.
Michael Buckley, who heads FEMA's mapping effort, said the agency would seek Congressional approval of money to cover erosion mapping and whatever authorization was needed for changes in insurance rates. A similar effort, including setback requirements, foundered a decade ago amid opposition from representatives of coastal areas.
The agency administers the Flood Insurance Program, which since its establishment in 1968 has offered coverage to homeowners in coastal areas who might otherwise have been unable to obtain it. Towns seeking to make the insurance available to residents must enact FEMA-approved building codes that, among other things, call for structures to be elevated in zones where flood waters would spread in major storms. Structures built in compliance with FEMA codes have consistently survived with less damage in coastal storms.
Critics assert that the program, by offering coverage that private insurance companies are increasingly unwilling to provide, inadvertently encourages unwise development of the coast.
In any event, in establishing its zones and insurance rates, the program did not take erosion into account. The report issued yesterday says that was a mistake.
"Within the first few hundred feet bordering the nation's coast, property owners face as large a risk of damage from erosion as they do from flooding," it says. Unless rates are altered to reflect that risk, it says, "erosion losses will be subsidized by policyholders in noneroding areas or general taxpayers."
To fully reflect this risk, the report says, insurance rates in high-risk areas would be, on average, twice as high as they are now, typically $700 to $2,000 per $100,000 worth of coverage. Coverage is capped at $250,000 for a house and $100,000 for its contents.
The report, produced by the H. John Heinz III Center for Science Economics and Environment under contract with FEMA, is available at www.heinzcenter.org.
It estimates that it would cost about $5 million a year to identify erosion hazard areas, map them, maintain the maps and make the information available to potential buyers or local officials. But the investment would save money in the long run, it says, because "if all currently empty lots in areas most susceptible to erosion are built on, damage from erosion would rise by roughly $100 million per year for the value of the structures alone."
The report notes that several methods, notably beach nourishment and hard structures like groins, revetments or sea walls can protect structures on the beach. But hard structures can, as the report put it, "have negative impacts on the physical and aesthetic characteristics of beaches." And replacing sand lost from eroding beaches costs an average of $300,000 a year per mile of coast, the report said.
"Shoreline protection measures can augment, but are not substitutes for, other options," it says.

HEADLINE: LESSONS;
Taking a New Look at Uniforms And Their Impact on Schools

BYLINE: By James Sterngold 

DATELINE: LONG BEACH, Calif.

 BODY:
FOR Carl Cohn, the path to educational innovation began a decade ago on a gritty Long Beach street when a few dozen children, caught in the middle of a gang shootout, were forced to the floor of a school bus.
Mr. Cohn was a former truant officer in this heavily industrialized port city adjacent to Los Angeles, and in the wake of that lawlessness he was asked to head an antigang task force. Its principal aim was, like that of some United Nations peacekeeping missions, to protect noncombatants, known elsewhere as primary school students. 
 "We needed to give safe passage for students through some very tricky terrain," said Mr. Cohn, now the superintendent of schools here. "We realized the way to make it visible who the students were was clothing, uniforms. We didn't think about all the other issues. It was safety, pure and simple."
It was an unusual start for what came to be hailed as a major step in helping to reinvigorate public education, not just here but across the country.
In 1994, Long Beach mandated uniforms at all its elementary schools after trials at a couple of schools. Test scores and grades rose. Absenteeism, failures and discipline problems declined. Schools in more than 35 states have now adopted uniforms policies, with Philadelphia set to adopt such a policy this fall.
But it is worth recalling the sobering origins of that success as Long Beach takes the next step, completing the introduction of uniforms at its first high school. The school district that helped push school uniforms to the front lines has now pulled them back, if slightly, as a tool.
Woodrow Wilson High School, to which students must apply for entry, has phased uniforms in one year at a time, and next year, students in all grades will be wearing khaki bottoms and burgundy or white collared shirts. But a visit to the school and conversations with administrators, parents and students reveal a subtle appreciation for the limitations as well as the merits of uniforms.
For one thing, if uniforms mean uniformity, these are a failure. The school allows the students to fulfill the requirements in many ways. They can wear trousers, skirts, baggy shorts or capri pants on the bottom and a range of tops on condition they are white or burgundy and have collars.
Jon Meyer, the school's co-principal, said the administrators chose loose standards to allow older students to express themselves while minimizing the potentially divisive effects of dress, like designating gang affiliation or economic differences. He is even toying with eliminating a rule requiring students to keep their shirts tucked in in the classrooms.
The point, Mr. Meyer said, is that they have found uniforms just one of several tools for refocusing the school, and, he insisted, they require complete support by parents and students.
'It's not the answer, but it contributes," he said. 'I don't think that the uniform alone does a whole lot, actually."
Nonetheless, there have been improvements. Three years ago, the school had 861 suspensions. This past year, there were 280.
And that is not just because the school began a policy three years ago that students apply to get in. Despite that, the student body still represents a cross section of the city. Well over a half of the students come from families with incomes below the poverty line, said Keith Hansen, the assistant principal, and 350 of the students speak English as a second language.
But the real issue is that uniforms were just the most visible of several reforms introduced. Students are required to take more credits, including four years of a foreign language, math, science and English. They must maintain a C average.
Noelle Ebright, who will begin her senior year at Wilson in the fall and was the student government president last year, said of uniforms, "They aggravate me more than they help me." But she added that they appeared to have cut down on the number of fights.
Richard Flanary, a senior administrator at the National Association of Secondary School Principals, in Arlington, Va., said the limited amount of research on the subject had placed only modest emphasis on uniforms as a way of turning around a troubled high school.
"There is no direct link between uniforms and performance," Mr. Flanary said, "but we know there is a link between the school environment and performance. Uniforms might be one way of affecting the environment, but just one."
Still, even with their expectations moderated, Long Beach officials are believers, if well-informed believers.
"Frankly, it's a very good question as to whether 5 or 7 years from now uniforms will still be a priority," Mr. Cohn said. "There is a part of me that says if we really want to grow these young people into young adults, it is, in fact, their behavior that will really mark them, not what they wear.
"Having said that, these are difficult times. And there is the reality that there is something to be gained if these young people spend less time paying attention to their dress."

HEADLINE: I.R.S. Figures Show Spread Of Prosperity

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
New government data shows just how far prosperity has spread across America, with stock options, two-career couples and capital gains helping to lift a record number of families to six-figure annual incomes. One taxpayer in 15 resided in this economic realm in 1998, the government reported yesterday -- an increase of 1.1 million over 1997.
The number of taxpayers (the I.R.S. counts a married couple who file jointly as one taxpayer) with incomes of $100,000 or more soared in 1998 to 8.3 million, up 15 percent from 7.2 million in 1997, preliminary figures from 1998 income tax returns showed.. 
 The thick book of dry statistical tables issued by the Internal Revenue Service included some minor surprises.
The data helps explain why federal tax revenues are surging, prompting President Clinton on Monday to raise the budget surplus over the next decade to $1.9 trillion, from the February estimate of $792 billion.
Analysis of the I.R.S. data also showed that the share of the economic pie going to those making $100,000 or more expanded to 36.9 percent in 1998 from 34.2 percent in 1997.
In the first glimpse of the impact of the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997, the taxes paid by these prosperous Americans rose 30.4 percent as more of their income was subject to the 31 percent, 36 percent and 39.6 percent rates.
The 6.6 percent of taxpayers earning more than $100,000 paid 58 percent of all income taxes in 1998.
Many more taxpayers -- 828,000, a 40 percent increase over the previous year -- paid the Alternative Minimum Tax in 1998, the new data shows. The tax, which phases out deductions for state and local taxes, and even for children, was adopted 31 years ago to stop rich taxpayers from making such aggressive use of legitimate tax breaks that they paid no federal income taxes.
"This shows how this frightening tax complexity monster is growing in our midst," said David Keating of the National Taxpayers Union.
Because Congress has not updated the law for inflation, the minimum tax now reaches so far down the economic ladder that it can sometimes tax a single parent making $28,000.
The new tax data also raised questions about the effectiveness of the sharp reduction in capital gains taxes, a major element of the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997, which was sponsored by the House Republican leadership.
The highest long-term capital gains rate was cut to 20 percent, from 28 percent in 1996 and part of 1997, yet the rate of growth in capital gains fell by half, from 48 percent in 1996 to 22 percent in 1998.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, promoted the lower rate as a key to increasing savings and investment and building a prosperous future. At first glance, taxpayers with incomes less than $15,000 seem to be lagging behind inflation. But interpreting the data is hard because the lowest income category is now heavy with rich children.
The number of people with incomes of less than $15,000 declined by 3 percent, from 40.4 million in 1997 to 40.1 million in 1998. Still, the average income grew by just 0.6 percent, far less than the rate of inflation, to $6,290, an increase of a scant $45 over 1997. Complicating the picture is the growing number of prosperous families who must file tax returns in the names of children who have their own college funds.
The one indication that the lowest income category is now heavy with rich children is that 44 percent of this group's income came from capital gains, four times the contribution of capital gains to the incomes of those making $30,000 to $100,000.
Analysis of the I.R.S. data also showed that the boom at the top is overwhelmingly the result of more people crossing the $100,000 income threshold, rather than of increases in income among those already there.
Among the 6.2 million taxpayers making $100,000 to $200,000, the average income fell by $514, to $131,189, from $131,703 in 1997. This suggests that many people just made it over the $100,000 threshold.
Among the 2 million taxpayers making more than $200,000, total income was up a robust 17.7 percent, but the average income rose only 3.1 percent to $568,941.
