HEADLINE: On Edge but Optimistic, New York Blacks Offer Complex Views in Poll

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 

 BODY:
Black residents of New York City are afraid of being brutalized by the police, but they welcome and appreciate officers who keep criminals out of their neighborhood.
At all income levels, blacks in the city are convinced that racial discrimination limits their income and holds back job advancement. Yet they also believe that the major reason that young black men have troubled lives is not discrimination, but the breakdown of black families and a lack of personal motivation.
Amid New York's economic boom, with overall unemployment at a 12-year low, blacks in the city say their most important problem is a lack of jobs. But they are convinced that their children will be more successful than they have been. 
 These ambivalent attitudes are part of a wide-ranging State of Black New York poll conducted this month for the New York Urban League. Based on random telephone interviews with 801 blacks across the city, the survey paints a portrait of a community on edge, one that feels victimized by unemployment, police brutality and racial discrimination.
But it also shows that most blacks are optimistic about the future, deeply committed to their churches and introspective about a breakdown in black family life, which they link to the poor performance of many young blacks in schools and the workplace.
"I thought there would be more consistency," said Dennis M. Walcott, president of the New York Urban League, who helped write the questions in the poll. "The relationship between the local cop and the black community is not as strained or as simple as has been portrayed in the media."
Another surprise in the poll was the relative lack of support among New York blacks for school vouchers.
While blacks had serious concerns about the quality of public schools, only 41 percent of those polled supported using tax money for vouchers. Fifty-three percent said tax money should be used for only public education.
The findings differ from most nationwide polls of blacks, which have found support for vouchers running about 60 percent.
Support for vouchers, as measured by the poll, increased sharply among New York blacks as income decreased. A narrow majority of households with yearly incomes under $10,000 supported vouchers. But at income levels above $50,000, there was strong opposition to shifting public money to private schools.
Income made little difference, though, in the perception among blacks in New York that racial discrimination stains nearly every aspect of their lives.
"This survey shows that no matter how successful black people become, they still suffer the slings and arrows of racism," Mr. Walcott said. "Whether it is engagement with the police department or issues involving promotion or disparity in wages, the figures show that people feel that racism has touched their lives."
Asked to name places where racial discrimination was most common, the greatest proportion of those polled, 30 percent, mentioned stores, where blacks have long complained about being followed by clerks and security officers.
Based on their perception of discrimination, more than four out of five respondents said that affirmative action was still needed in jobs and schools. Support for affirmative action was strongest in households earning more than $50,000 a year.
"What jumps out at me from this survey is the emphasis on jobs and economic development," said Walter Stafford, a professor of public policy and urban planning at New York University who analyzed the poll for the Urban League. "Across the board, people tend to perceive discrimination in access to jobs and mobility -- even at high income levels."
The city's unemployment rate in 1999 was 11.8 percent for black men and 10.4 percent for women, compared with a citywide average of 6.7 percent last year. Black men and women had nearly double the unemployment rates of whites in 1999.
"What also strikes me is that this is not a secure group," Professor Stafford said, pointing to results showing that 53 percent of respondents said they had no pensions other than Social Security.
The survey, from June 5 to 16, was done for the New York Urban League by Blum & Weprin Associates, a New York polling firm. About 70 percent of the respondents identified themselves as black or African-American; about 30 percent said they were Caribbean or West Indian blacks.
Many of the poll's findings, particularly those concerning black attitudes toward the police, echo some results of two recent polls by The New York Times and CBS News. Those polls were conducted after the police shooting of Amadou Diallo in February 1999 and the shooting of Patrick M. Dorismond this March.
Compared with The Times' polls, which surveyed New Yorkers of all races, the Urban League survey contacted three to five times as many black respondents in the city, making it relatively more precise in assessing black views. The poll's margin of error is plus or minus three percentage points.
The Urban League survey found a deep and pervasive ambivalence among black New Yorkers in their attitudes toward the police. While they feel that the police disproportionately victimize them because they are black, they also want police protection against crime, the poll found.
"It is like straddling a fence," said Lileathea Grays-Wallace, 44, a divorced mother of three who lives in the South Bronx and who participated in the poll. "I am worried about the police on one side and the criminals on the other."
Like 45 percent of those polled in the survey, Ms. Grays-Wallace said that she believed that the police in her immediate neighborhood (she lives a block from a police station) did a good-to-excellent job of being helpful and friendly.
"But four blocks down, I don't know," said Ms. Grays-Wallace, who, like nearly 9 of out 10 respondents in the survey, said police brutality was a "serious problem."
Her oldest daughter works as a dispatcher for the police department, she said. Still, she said she was afraid that her younger daughters, who are 13 and 8, would say the wrong thing to the police on the street and be arrested or abused.
"It is a miscommunication thing," she said. "I tell my daughters they will be judged by what they look like. I explain to them to keep their senses up and show respect."
This simultaneous need for and fear of the police has overwhelmed the life of Daisy Boyd, 77, who lives in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn and also participated in the poll.
Five years ago, her son, Daniel Lee, then 30, was shot to death in front of her apartment when he tried to chase away gang members selling drugs, Mrs. Boyd said. Last week, she said that another son, Jasper, 33, was arrested by the police and was forced to spend a night in jail after he tried to stop a fight outside a homeless shelter in Brooklyn.
"It hurt my son so bad to be arrested that he just cried, and he is a college graduate," Mrs. Boyd said. "Some of the police are just mean. They don't like the black man, no way. The police seem to be pretty nice to me, but they are not so nice to the young people."
The Urban League poll avoided questions about politics and politicians, other than to ask if the withdrawal of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani from the Senate race would make black residents more or less likely to vote in November. About three-quarters of those polled said the withdrawal of the mayor, who is widely blamed by blacks for worsening racial tensions in the city, would not affect their interest in voting.
Supporting the longstanding importance of the church in black communities, the poll found religion plays a significant role in the lives of an overwhelming majority of black New Yorkers. Nearly four out of five respondents said that religion is either extremely or very important, while 61 percent said they attended church at least once a month and 35 percent said that they volunteer at least 5 hours a month at their church.
"Across all income levels, the church is important," said Mr. Walcott of the New York Urban League.
Mr. Walcott said that high levels of religious involvement are connected to what he described as the poll's findings of "introspection on the part of the black community."
"The poll got at the issue of family structure and how it contributes to a lack of success for young black men," he said. "It also talked about family dysfunction as a reason for poor performance in school. The black community isn't solely dealing with external conditions such as racism. It is also aware of the internal issues that need to be addressed for equal opportunity to be achieved."
As much as black New Yorkers say they feel oppressed by discrimination, only about 11 percent felt that the quality of life in the city had grown worse in the last five years. Forty-four percent felt that the quality of life had remained about the same and 43 percent said it had improved.
Ms. Grays-Wallace, the mother in the South Bronx, is among those blacks in the city who are upset about racism and afraid of the police for her children. But she says she believes that her life and that of her children is improving.
"Everything is just a little better, just a little calmer," she said. "It is not relaxed. New Yorkers do not relax."

HEADLINE: Media Metrix Plans to Merge with Jupiter Communications

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Media Metrix Inc., an influential arbiter of who's hot and who's not in the Internet world, will acquire Jupiter Communications, a leading analyst of Internet trends, the two companies said yesterday.
Combining the two companies will create "the definitive source for Internet measurement and analysis," said Tod Johnson, chairman and chief executive of Media Metrix, which calculates the popularity of more than 21,000 Web sites based on software tracking the habits of 70,000 computer users in the United States and overseas. 
 Both Media Metrix and Jupiter are seen as industry leaders in providing valuable insights into trends however questionable the actual figures on which they are based.
"Media Metrix's monthly reports definitely move stocks," said Henry Blodgett, who tracks a broad portfolio of Internet companies for Merrill Lynch. "It's the closest thing there is to a standard."
Mr. Johnson said that the merger should help the two companies expand overseas where demand for Internet information is growing rapidly. It is also intended to provide opportunities for "hybrid" products, including analytical commentaries on Media Metrix data and databases that help Jupiter produce analysis of more narrowly defined market segments.
Media Metrix's largest competitor is Nielsen/NetRatings (an alliance of Nielsen Media Research and NetRatings Inc.). Jupiter, which gets most of its revenue from subscribers to monthly research reports and seminars, competes most directly with Forrester Research, based in Cambridge, Mass.
Investors were not immediately impressed by the possibilities of Jupiter Media Metrix. Shares of Media Metrix fell $4.875, or 17 percent, to $23.375, while Jupiter's dipped $1.937, or 8 percent, to $21.625. Under the terms of the agreement, Jupiter shareholders will receive 0.946 share of Media Metrix stock for each of their shares. The stock swap, which was valued at about $414 million when the deal was announced, was worth $343 million by the end of trading.

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS;
Remote Streams Worth the Effort

BYLINE: By Nicholas Karas 

 BODY:
Trout fishing on many of the Catskills' blue-ribbon streams has become so crowded in the last year or two, especially on weekends, that it is S.R.O. The trout streams' surge in popularity parallels the rise in fly fishing's growth in America and has also ushered in a new-found economy among these verdant hills. Local entrepreneurs have responded by refurbishing restaurants and motels, adding new tackle shops, museums and a booming guide service.
The crowded conditions on the better-known streams and pools were succinctly impressed upon me, first and fittingly, on April 1, the opening day of the trout season in New York State. At about 6 a.m. on that day, I was there in Roscoe, N.Y., alias Trout Town U.S.A, standing in a line of anglers on the Route 17A bridge that spans the famed Beaverkill. A hundred yards downstream, it meets Willowemoc Creek and forms the famous Junction Pool. 
 I was there because fishing Junction Pool is one of the required rites of spring for all Catskills anglers. The fishermen before me were waiting their turn to jog down the well-worn path on the bridge's west abutment so they could gain access to the well-publicized confluence.
Forget it! It was standing-room-only on the banks. Even if I were able to get to the water's edge, I'd be shoulder-to-shoulder with other anglers. I drove downstream on old Route 17, which parallels the Beaverkill, looking for a pool with space.
At one time, you could easily tell the productive spots on the river by the number of cars pulled off the road. The technique still works but the Theodore Gordon Fly Fishers have made life easier for the itinerant angler. At each pool, they've placed sturdy, cast-iron signs, similar to historical markers the state erects. They identify the pools and give a description of why it bears that name.
I passed Ferdon's, Barnhart's and Hendrickson's pools and Horse Block Run, all packed with cars and anglers. I slowed at Cairn's Pool to tally the number of anglers and lost count after 25. I passed Wagon Tracks, School House, Trestle, Mountain and Lower Mountain pools and stopped at Cemetery Pool. All were filled with anglers. I realized I couldn't fish the Beaverkill.
I returned on a weekend in mid-May, during "Bug Week," to find the crowding even worse. "Kind of tough getting to the water, isn't it?" asked a stocky, wader-clad angler who wore a heavily laden fishing vest and a wide-brimmed hat. He sat down next to me on a newly constructed wooden ramp that led down from the road, via a switch-back, to the water's edge. His left ear was pierced by a silver, metallic trout jumping through the bottom of the lobe.
"Where's your rod?" I asked.
"Never use one when I'm guiding," said Rick Miller.
Miller, 57, was born in Stamford, Conn., but made a beeline for Roscoe when he retired after 30 years in the fire department.
"Since I was 20, I've been coming here to fish," he said. "In those days, we worked the Golden Triangle. It was composed of the Neversink, Willowemoc, Beaverkill, East Branch" -- of the Delaware River -- "Esopus, Schoharie and Roundout. Finding space on a pool was never a problem in those days."
Miller built a fishing lodge in Craig-E-Clair, five miles from Roscoe. From there, he guides about 150 days a year. His service has grown so rapidly that during the busier times of the season, he uses several area guides.
"I saw this coming," he said as we watched one of his rods set the hook on a fish. "For the last three years, I've made a serious effort to inventory the trout fishing in almost every tributary stream in the six counties of the Catskills. I've found that at times fishing on these streams off the beaten track can be as good, if not better, than on the main streams. One thing is sure, the ambience and solitude is well worth the added effort of searching them out."
Reluctantly, he disclosed the streams' names but cautioned that on some access is limited, while on others the state has acquired the fishing rights.
Off the West Branch of the Delaware, they include Little Delaware, Falls, Honest and Elk Creeks and Betty Brook. On the West Branch, they include Read Creek, Baxter, Trout and Downs Brooks, and Batavia and Bush Kills. On the Beaverkill, they include Trout, Horton and Russell Brooks, and off the Willowemoc, Little Beaverkill, Mongaup Creek and Fir Brook. Off the lower Delaware River, there's East Branch Callicoon Creek and Panther Rock Brook.
If you want to avoid crowds and fish streams off the beaten track, your first task is to get a free map/brochure called "I Love New York Catskill Fishing." It is available at all Department of Environmental Conservation offices and at most tackle shops and motels in the area or can be obtained by calling (800) NYS-CATS. Or you can contact Rick Miller at (800) 884-7088. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: F.D.A. Considers Switching Some Prescription Drugs to Over-the-Counter Status

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27

 BODY:
Spurred by two pharmaceutical companies that want to take their cholesterol-lowering medications over the counter, the Food and Drug Administration is considering whether many more medicines -- from antibiotics to birth control pills -- should be made available without a doctor's prescription.
Beginning with public hearings on Wednesday and Thursday, the drug agency will re-examine the way it regulates over-the-counter drugs, the first such review in nearly three decades. The last one, in 1972, created a new system for approving over-the-counter drugs that enabled more than 600 drugs to switch from prescription to nonprescription status. 
 Typically, nonprescription drugs treat mild conditions, like headaches, colds and athlete's foot. But now, in addition to looking at infection-fighting agents and oral contraceptives, the agency is raising a new question: whether patients with chronic conditions, like high blood pressure, high cholesterol and osteoporosis, should be able to treat themselves.
"We are open to the possibility of having more and different kinds of medicines available to consumers," said Dr. Robert DeLap, the agency official leading the review.
"The health care environment has changed tremendously in recent years," Dr. DeLap said. "People are much more interested in self-care, and in being able to manage their minor conditions themselves."
But what constitutes a minor condition is a matter of debate, and some drug safety experts worry that broadening access to medications will only harm patients, enabling them to take drugs in dangerous combinations. And in making more drugs available without a prescription, the drug agency could greatly affect the $100 billion pharmaceutical industry, changing the dynamic of who pays for medicines and how much they cost at a time when these issues are at the center of the political debate in Congress.
Nonprescription drugs are generally cheaper than prescription drugs, and also save money on doctors' visits. The Consumer Healthcare Products Association, which represents nonprescription drug manufacturers, says consumers save nearly $13 billion a year by using over-the-counter medicines that were once available by prescription only. But while these drugs cost less, patients, and not insurance companies, must pay for them.
Agency officials said they are not certain whether or when any regulations will change, but the review is already generating controversy.
In all, 55 people are scheduled to testify at this week's hearings, including drug and insurance company officials, safety advocates, infectious disease specialists worried about antibiotic resistance and abortion opponents, who are fighting an over-the-counter birth control pill, which taken in high doses can be used as a morning-after contraceptive.
"Anytime you tamper with the health care system, you run into very emotional responses," said Steve Francesco, a consultant who advises the drug industry on changing drugs from prescription to nonprescription status. "The F.D.A. is saying let's throw a rock in this pond and see where the waves move. I think that's very courageous, and long overdue."
One case in point is Claritin, the best-selling allergy medication, which last year generated $2.3 billion of its $2.7 billion in sales from the United States. Claritin is available in other countries without a prescription, and Blue Cross of California has petitioned the drug agency to give it over-the-counter status.
A switch would inevitably force the drug's maker, Schering Plough Corporation, to lower Claritin's price, to make it competitive with other over-the-counter antihistamines, and the company opposes it. But health insurers, like Blue Cross, would benefit from such a move because they would no longer have to pay for the medication.
The drug agency typically does not make a drug over-the-counter unless the manufacturer requests it. But as the agency reopens the issue of over-the-counter drug regulation, the Claritin debate is generating fears within the industry that the longstanding policy will change.
"Pharmaceutical companies have the most detailed knowledge of their drugs, and they should decide when to make the switch," said Jeff Trewhitt, a spokesman for the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers Association, a trade group. "Economics should not play a role."
But economics does play a role. "What's at stake here is money, and control and safety," said Matthew Weinberg, an industry consultant.
Before 1972, the F.D.A. did not formally review all over-the-counter drugs for safety and effectiveness. That year, the agency began to set standards for the 300,000 to 400,000 nonprescription drugs that were already available; drugs that met those standards were permitted to remain on the market. But new medicines had to submit to a formal review by the agency.
In the years since, a range of medicines, from Rogaine for hair loss to Aleve for pain to Monistat for vaginal yeast infections, have switched from prescription to over-the-counter status.
Now regulators must consider whether to add cholesterol-lowering medication to that list. Next month, the drug agency is scheduled to convene a panel of scientific experts to evaluate applications from two drug manufacturers, Merck and Bristol-Myers Squibb, to make low-dose versions of their anti-cholesterol pills available without a prescription.
Merck's request comes a year before the patent on its drug, Mevacor, is due to expire; in seeking to market a 10-milligram dose without a prescription, financial analysts say Merck is trying to build brand loyalty and increase profits before a generic equivalent goes on the market. Mevacor's United States sales dropped to $480 million from $593 million from 1998 and 1999.
The Bristol-Myers Squibb drug, Pravachol, does not face patent expiration until 2005. In submitting its application to the F.D.A., analysts say, the company is trying to compete with Merck.
Officials at both companies cast the discussion in terms of patients, not profits. They argue that consumers who are not being treated for high cholesterol would benefit from easy access to their drugs.
But Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, who as director of Public Citizen's Health Research Group, an advocacy organization, is a frequent critic of the drug agency, said it would be both "dumb and dangerous" to permit cholesterol-lowering pills to be sold without a doctor's orders.
Unlike a patient who has a headache, Dr. Wolfe said, a patient with high cholesterol may not have symptoms. A test is needed to detect the problem, he said, and a doctor is needed to interpret that test and follow the patient to make certain the cholesterol condition does not deteriorate into a case of serious heart disease. The drugs also have the potential to cause liver damage.
For those reasons, some financial analysts are skeptical that the drug agency will approve the Merck and Bristol-Myers Squibb requests.
If cholesterol sounds like a thorny issue, consider oral contraceptives. Women's health advocates are expected to argue that the "morning after pill," which is used for emergency contraception, should be made available over-the-counter.
But abortion opponents have flooded the drug agency with letters arguing against any change that would make the birth control pill readily available to teenagers.
Some have suggested that the agency follow Canada's lead, and create a category known as "under-the-counter" drugs. These drugs do not require a prescription but cannot simply be picked up off store shelves. Instead, the pharmacist would control access, acting as a buffer between consumers and potentially dangerous medications, said Dr. Raymond Woosley, chairman of the pharmacology department at Georgetown University. "That is a classification we have not had in the past," Dr. Woosley said, "and I think it is one we should be discussing."

House Moving to End Ban on Food Sales to Cuba

American farmers and agricultural businesses could sell directly to Cuba, but the federal government and American banks could not provide any financing for Cuba. A1

In Black Poll, Complexity In Views on Police and Bias
Black city residents are afraid of being brutalized by the police, but they welcome and appreciate officers who keep criminals out of their neighborhoods, a poll for the New York Urban League found. At all income levels, blacks are convinced that racial discrimination limits their income and holds back job advancement. Yet they also believe that the major reason that young black men have troubled lives is not bias but the breakdown of black families and a lack of motivation. B1

HEADLINE: Cuba Embargo: Desired Results?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "'On Trade, Cuba Is Not China" (Op-Ed, June 24): 
 Jesse Helms argues that an end to the Cuba embargo will not bring about democratic changes in Cuba. But he overlooks the potential results of increased engagement with Cuba.
Eventually, change will come to Cuba. When change does occur, which is preferable: a Cuban society gradually led toward democracy by slow exposure to the outside world, or one coping with the ill effects of sudden exposure to the global economy as seen elsewhere?
 
CRAIG WATSON
Brooklyn, June 24, 2000

HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
ALBANY: FOSTER PARENT LAW -- The State Legislature has passed a bill allowing some felons to become foster and adoptive parents. The bill is expected to be signed by Gov. George E. Pataki, a spokesman for his office said. If it becomes law, it would overturn the current law, which requires fingerprinting of all foster and adoptive parents. If violent felonies are found in the parents' background, their children must be removed, even if caseworkers had determined that the children were safe. Two State Family Court judges have already ruled the provision unconstitutional, and advocates for foster parents and children and city child welfare officials want the law overturned. Somini Sengupta (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: MONEY LAUNDERING RING -- Federal prosecutors in Manhattan and Brooklyn yesterday charged 17 people, including nine city employees, with conspiracy to launder money. The authorities said repeated cash deposits of just less than $10,000 were made to avoid federal laws that require banks to report large cash deposits to the Internal Revenue Service. About $200,000 was seized from one defendant. The Department of Investigation said yesterday that the implicated city workers were not high-level employees and not in law enforcement. John Sullivan (NYT) 

BROOKLYN: SEX ABUSE CHARGED -- In two separate incidents, four primary school students were arrested yesterday on charges of sexually abusing 9-year-old girls inside their Brooklyn schools, the police said. In the first incident, a girl was in a bathroom at Public School 56 on Gates Avenue in the Clinton Hill section when two other 9-year-old girls sexually abused her, said Detective Edward Reuss, a police spokesman. The attack happened on June 16 but was not reported to the police until yesterday, he said. In the second incident, which took place yesterday morning, two boys, 10 and 11, attacked a 9-year-old girl in the hallway of P.S. 25 on Lafayette Street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Detective Reuss said. An investigator said the boys threw the girl to the ground and grabbed at her through her clothing. ANDY NEWMAN (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: GUN CAMPAIGN -- Andrew M. Cuomo, left, secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and Eliot L. Spitzer, New York attorney general, yesterday urged New York City to join 400 other cities in a campaign of economic pressure on handgun manufacturers.
The cities give preference in their police handgun purchases to Smith & Wesson, the largest handgun producer and the only one that has agreed to install trigger locks and other safety features on its guns. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: JANITOR HUNGER STRIKE -- Eight janitors who work at a Brooklyn office tower began a hunger strike on Monday to protest the building owner's fight against their efforts to join the city's largest janitors' union, Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union.
For six weeks, 31 janitors at the building, Brooklyn Renaissance Plaza, which is owned by Muss Development, have been on strike. They say many of them are paid less than half the $16 an hour earned by New York's unionized janitors. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)
 
NEW JERSEY
 
TRENTON: MORE MINORITIES STOPPED -- New data gathered by the state police show that more members of minorities are stopped by troopers on the New Jersey Turnpike than elsewhere in the state. The data, compiled under a consent decree in a recent racial profiling case, show that 38.3 percent of drivers stopped on the turnpike from January through April were members of minority groups, compared with 22.1 percent of drivers stopped by troopers in other places. Officials declined to comment on the data. David M. Halbfinger (NYT)
 
TRENTON: TROOPERS OBJECT -- Lawyers for James Kenna and John Hogan, the state troopers who face trial on attempted murder and aggravated assault charges in the 1998 shooting of three minority men in a van on the New Jersey Turnpike, accused prosecutors of misleading and improperly influencing the grand jury to obtain indictments against the troopers. Judge Andrew J. Smithson of Superior Court said he would rule on the defendants' motion to dismiss the indictments on July 25. David M. Halbfinger (NYT)
 
TRENTON: H.M.O. BAILOUT -- New Jersey's health maintenance organizations sued the state yesterday to overturn a law requiring them to pay $50 million in claims by doctors and hospitals against two H.M.O.'s that went bankrupt in 1998. The New Jersey Association of Health Plans filed the suit in Superior Court in Mercer County, asserting that their forced bailout of the companies, HIP Health Plan of New Jersey and American Preferred Provider Plan, was an unconstitutional taking of property. The Department of Banking and Insurance ordered the payment as part of a $100 million bailout plan. Steve Strunsky (NYT)
 
TRENTON: BEACH FEES -- A senior Assembly Democrat yesterday called for constitutional amendments banning fees for New Jersey beaches and establishing a lottery to pay for beach maintenance. The assemblyman, Neil M. Cohen, Democrat of Elizabeth, introduced a bill last month to hold a referendum on the issue. Steve Strunsky (NYT)
 
CONNECTICUT
 
HARTFORD: LAWMAKERS CRITICIZED -- The Connecticut League of Conservation Voters yesterday criticized the Connecticut General Assembly, saying it did little about environmental legislation. The league said only one of nine bills it tracked passed. The failed bills included proposals to reduce solid waste and minimize power-plant pollution. Theresa Crapanzano (NYT)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Army Hires Burnett In Recruiting Campaign

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOT 

 BODY:
The Army has ended an unusually public review for its account, with ad spending estimated at $95 million annually, by hiring a new lineup of agencies led by Leo Burnett Worldwide in Chicago, part of the B Com3 Group.
The review began in January when the Army expressed dissatisfaction with the incumbent agency since 1987, Young & Rubicam Advertising in New York, and unexpectedly decided not to exercise a one-year renewal option clause in a long-term contract. Two months later, Y.& R. Advertising decided not to take part in the review, which narrowed down to Burnett and Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. 
 The Army contract with Burnett, announced yesterday at the Pentagon, is for one year with three one-year renewal options, and for the first time will partly tie the agency's compensation to the Army's recruitment success. Unhappiness grew with Y.& R. after the Army failed to meet goals for enlistees, who have been harder to find as the economy improves and young men and women seek jobs in the private sector.
In addition to Burnett, the Army hired three agencies for specialized tasks. Images U.S.A. in Atlanta will handle marketing aimed at African-Americans, which had been at the Chisholm-Mingo Group in New York. Cartel Creativo in San Antonio will handle marketing aimed at people who speak Spanish, which had been handled by the Bravo Group in New York. And Starcom U.S.A. in Chicago, also a B Com3 unit, will handle media services, which had been at Media Edge in New York. Like Y.& R. Advertising, Bravo and Media Edge are owned by Y.& R. Inc.

HEADLINE: HOUSE G.O.P. IS SET TO ALLOW THE SALE OF FOOD TO CUBA

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27

 BODY:
House Republican leaders agreed today to end four decades of sanctions on sales of food to Cuba, in a decision that carried great political significance.
But the economic value is relatively minor, as Cuban-American lawmakers managed to place severe restrictions in the bill. 
 The deal would in principle allow American farmers and agricultural businesses to sell their goods directly to Cuba for the first time since 1962. The agreement also echoes existing policy allowing the sale of medicine.
But the federal government and American banks would be barred from providing any financing for Cuba, making it difficult for Cuba, with little cash, to buy goods.
In addition, the trade would be one-way: Cuba would not be permitted to export to the United States.
The Senate has already approved a more expansive version of the legislation as part of its agriculture spending bill. The House and Senate must now resolve their differences, but the more stringent House language is expected to win approval. If not, the deal among House Republican leaders will probably fall apart.
The full House and Senate could take up the bill in the coming weeks as part of a larger spending package. That means there would be no vote specifically on lifting the Cuba sanctions, only on the larger bill.
 The bill would also lift unilateral food and medicine sanctions against Libya, Sudan, North Korea and Iran. Under the bill, Iran would also be ineligible for private financing from American banks.
The House Republican leaders reached their agreement early this morning after nearly six hours of negotiations.
House Republican leaders long opposed any weakening of the embargo against Cuba, which is meant to put pressure on President Fidel Castro. But an intense lobbying campaign by agribusiness and recent action by Congress and the Clinton administration to ease trade restrictions on other nations, including China and North Korea, helped soften the Republican opposition this year.
Even so, the White House expressed reservations about the deal, mostly because it would require the president to get Congress to approve the imposing of future sanctions on sales of food and medicine to other countries. That has been a presidential prerogative.
Representative George W. Nethercutt, the Washington Republican who championed the bill, described the agreement as a "fundamental shift in American foreign policy."
Doing business with Cuba, he said, is "not as easy as it would otherwise be" because of the restrictions. "But the door is open and that's what's important."
Representatives Lincoln Diaz-Balart and Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, Florida Republicans, said they viewed the agreement as a symbolic matter that benefited their agenda as well. For instance, the bill would turn existing federal restrictions on tourism into law. Currently, federal rules specify who can travel to Cuba, with cultural and religious groups among them.
That provision brought a round of criticism from House and Senate Democrats.
The Republican proposal "not only does too little to insure that U.S. food and medicine will reach the Cuban people," said Representative Sam Gejdenson, a Connecticut Democrat, in a typical comment. "It also will unnecessarily interfere with critical people-to-people contacts."
The reaction from Cuba was negative. The president of the National Assembly, Ricardo Alarcon, said the bill contained "unacceptable discriminatory conditions."
The bill is silent on existing law that complicates the transport of farm goods to Cuba. Under a 1992 law, any ship that visits Cuba, whether registered in the United States or a foreign country, is barred from calling at any United States port for six months, and most analysts agreed this adds another obstacle to the deal.
The limitation "makes it less attractive commercially," said Wally Workman, vice president of international affairs for the United States Chamber of Commerce.
Still, agricultural and business groups, as well as academic experts, said the bill could be the first chink in the armor of American sanctions to clear Congress.
"The main thing that it means politically is that this is the first time that the U.S. Congress has taken a decision to open up economic sanctions with Cuba, I think ever," said Jorge Dominguez, a professor of government at Harvard University.
For the House Republican leadership, the agreement was a political calculation. Mr. Nethercutt faces a tough re-election bid in a swing district and, with a slim Republican majority in the House, leaders did not want to defeat him on his signature issue and anger his constituents. Neither did they want to anger Cuban-Americans.
The Elian Gonzalez saga also played into Congressional sensibilities this year after the boy's plight prompted a widespread discussion of America's policy toward Cuba.
Gov. George W. Bush, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, said today at a news conference in Wayne, Mich., that he continued to oppose the legislation, saying no softening in sanctions are warranted until Mr. Castro puts an end to human rights violations.
"I have opposed lifting the sanctions, and I still continue to do so," Mr. Bush said. He expressed skepticism that Mr. Castro would let food reach his people, and added, "I like to remind people this is a man who is tyrannical."
Aides for Vice President Al Gore, the likely Democratic nominee, said Mr. Gore took issue with the bill's interference with a president's right to issue sanctions.
The biggest beneficiaries of the bill would be large agricultural companies, which have lobbied Congress for years to lift the embargo.
They are best equipped to help obtain loans for Cuba from foreign banks. But unlike Iran, with its oil, Cuba has no hard currency exports to speak of.
Cuba withdrew from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in the 1960's and so is barred from any financing from them.
Cuba buys from countries like France, China and Canada, whose governments heavily subsidize the sales.
The American Farm Bureau calculates that Cuba spends $1 billion a year on agricultural products.
In the next 12 months, American farmers stand to make sales to Cuba of $25 million to $45 million, according to an estimate by the U.S.-Cuba Trade and Economic Council, a center financed by businesses.
The Cuban-American National Foundation, the leading anti-Castro lobby, said it would fight the bill.

HEADLINE: Justice Dept. Moves to Block Merger of Two Phone Giants

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL with DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The Justice Department sought to curb the headlong consolidation of the telecommunications industry yesterday by moving to block WorldCom's proposed $115 billion acquisition of the Sprint Corporation.
At the same time, in the face of opposition in Europe, WorldCom and Sprint formally withdrew their deal from consideration by the European Commission, reserving the option to file again in the future. 
 The Justice Department, while seeking an injunction against the deal in Federal court, cited concerns that the combined company would stifle competition on the Internet and in the long-distance telephone industry. Industry executives said the filing probably doomed the deal, which was agreed to last year and would have created an Internet powerhouse and the nation's second-largest long-distance phone company after AT&T. Two days ago, the European Commission's top antitrust regulator said he was unlikely to support the deal, contending that it would place too much Internet traffic under control of one company.
Regarding their plans, the companies said only that they would review their options. WorldCom and Sprint could fight the government in court, but executives from the companies have said in the past that they would almost surely abandon their deal in the face of a government suit.
People close to the companies said that while Sprint and WorldCom remained unlikely to battle the Justice Department through an entire trial, they might file preliminary objections to the suit in hopes of reopening negotiations to win approval.
Shares of Sprint fell $1.1875, to $58.375, while Worldcom stock rose $2.1875, to $39.6875.
The attempted merger is the biggest the department has ever tried to block, dwarfing the previous largest -- Lockheed Martin's $8.3 billion plan to acquire Northrop Grumman, which would have created a behemoth in the military industry. Lockheed and Northrop abandoned their pact in 1998 in the face of the Justice Department's opposition.
Yesterday's move indicates that the Justice Department intends to draw limits, even amid the multibillion-dollar consolidation in various sectors of the telecommunications industry, as companies of all size and description try to expand their geographic and technical reach.
Earlier this month, AT&T won conditional approval from the Federal Communications Commission for its $58 billion acquisition of the MediaOne Group Inc., one of the nation's biggest cable television companies. And less than two weeks later Bell Atlantic won the F.C.C.'s conditional approval of the company's $53 billion acquisition of the GTE Corporation, a deal that will create the nation's biggest phone company. In both cases, the Justice Department had already signed off on the mergers, provided that certain conditions were met.
One merger still pending antitrust and regulatory review is America Online Inc.'s proposed $165 billion acquisition of Time Warner Inc. That deal would create the biggest company in both traditional and electronic media.
But the America Online-Time Warner deal could have an easier time with regulators than the WorldCom-Sprint merger, at least on antitrust grounds. Because WorldCom and Sprint currently compete in many of the same markets, their merger appears much more vulnerable to a traditional antitrust challenge than the deal between America Online and Time Warner, which are not significant competitors in any of their far-flung operations.
Antitrust regulators traditionally consider whether a merger would reduce competition and, as a result, limit customer choices. In its filing with the United States District Court in Washington, the Justice Department made just such an argument, saying that a Sprint-WorldCom merger would reduce competition in markets where the two companies are currently rivals.
"This merger threatens to undermine the competitive gains achieved since the department challenged AT&T's monopoly 25 years ago," Attorney General Janet Reno said in a statement yesterday. "It is critical to our economy that we preserve competition for services that many of us rely upon in our everyday lives -- long-distance calls, data network services and Internet connections."
At a news conference, Joel I. Klein, the assistant attorney general in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said that his main concern about the WorldCom-Sprint deal was that it would reduce the number of major competitors in the long-distance market from three to two.
WorldCom acquired the MCI Communications Corporation in 1998 and still uses the MCI brand for some products. AT&T controls roughly half of the $80 billion long-distance business while WorldCom currently controls about 20 percent and Sprint about 8 percent.
"The difference between two and three bidders can be very, very significant," Mr. Klein said in an interview. "They're both on the tube and in telemarketing to compete for your business. When you take one of them out, most consumers are aware, that restricts your options,"
Similar considerations would probably not apply in the America Online-Time Warner deal, because the companies generally do not compete in the same markets. The exception is areas where Time Warner's Roadrunner cable modem Internet-access service competes against America Online's Internet service over telephone lines.
"Sprint-WorldCom is irrelevant to AOL-Time Warner," said Scott Cleland, a regulatory analyst in Washington for the Precursor Group, an independent research firm. "WorldCom-Sprint is a very different sort of merger in that it is a straight horizontal merger, and AOL-Time Warner is a vertical merger. The horizontal mergers have a lot of precedents and very clear guidelines. Vertical mergers have very few guidelines and few standards so it's much more an unknown."
Mr. Cleland said the closer comparison for AOL-Time Warner would be the AT&T-MediaOne deal that the government has already approved. That comparison is cold comfort for WorldCom.
People close to WorldCom and Sprint had said last week that the two companies were considering big concessions -- including a complete spinoff of Sprint's long-distance telephone business and Internet operation -- to appease antitrust regulators. But in the end, the concession offer never came, those people said, because the Justice Department wanted the companies to also agree to a spinoff of Sprint's local phone business. WorldCom was reluctant to agree, while Sprint was adamantly opposed, they said. Mr. Klein refused to discuss details of his negotiations with the two companies.
WorldCom could consider some concessions because its main goal in acquiring Sprint was to gain control of Sprint's extensive wireless telephone network -- a business in which WorldCom has a neglible presence.
In a terse statement yesterday, WorldCom said: "WorldCom was advised today that the U.S. Department of Justice intends to file suit to block WorldCom's proposed merger with Sprint. WorldCom will promptly review its options with Sprint."
J. Richard Devlin, Sprint's general counsel, said in a statement: "We are disappointed that we have been unable to convince the Justice Department that the merger is in the best interest of the American public and would advance competition. Over the next several days we will determine our next steps."
Investors yesterday were already trying to handicap the companies' next moves. If WorldCom and Sprint do in fact tear up their deal, WorldCom will still lack a wireless operation and will probably still seek one.
The most likely candidates are Nextel Communications Inc., based in Reston, Va., and the VoiceStream Wireless Corporation, based in Bellevue, Wash. Shares of both companies rose yesterday on speculation that either could become the next potential target for WorldCom. Nextel stock rose by $1.4375, to $60.625, while shares of VoiceStream closed at $126, up $4.875 in Nasdaq trading.
If Sprint remains single, its most likely consolidation partners appear to be the BellSouth Corporation and Deutsche Telekom of Germany. BellSouth, the only one of the seven original Baby Bell local phone companies that has not yet participated in a major merger, lost a bidding war for Sprint with WorldCom last year.
Deutsche Telekom, meanwhile, has long cast about for entree to the United States market and until last year was a partner with Sprint in an international venture called Global One. Each of those companies, however, could face serious regulatory or legal hurdles.
BellSouth, as one of the regional Bell companies that emerged from the breakup of the old American Telephone & Telegraph Company in 1984, is currently not allowed to sell long-distance communications services to customers in its core Southeastern region. Long-distance, of course, is Sprint's main business.
Under current laws and regulations, Deutsche Telekom, Germany's main phone company, would probably face few serious hurdles to acquiring Sprint. But yesterday, Senator Ernest Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, introduced a bill that could block such a deal.
"All American companies are vulnerable to takeover, and we want full control," the senator said.
Under the Hollings bill, companies in which foreign governments own a stake of 25 percent or more would not be allowed to acquire United States communications companies. The German government owns 58 percent of Deutsche Telekom.

HEADLINE: Oracle Hired a Detective Agency To Investigate Microsoft's Allies

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF and MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 27

 BODY:
The Oracle Corporation acknowledged today that it had hired a prominent Washington detective firm to investigate groups sympathetic to its archrival, the Microsoft Corporation, an effort that yielded documents embarrassing to Microsoft in the midst of its antitrust battle with the government.
Oracle's admission today followed reports linking the detective firm, the Investigative Group International, to an unsuccessful attempt this month to obtain documents from a pro-Microsoft trade group, the Association for Competitive Technology, by offering payments to janitors at the group's Washington office. 
 Oracle said the investigations on its behalf had established that the association and two other organizations "were misrepresenting themselves as independent advocacy groups, when in fact their work was funded by Microsoft for the express purpose of influencing public opinion in favor of Microsoft during its antitrust trial."
Documents from two of the organizations were cited in articles in The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal showing that the groups had received financing from Microsoft.
An official of one of the groups said he thought documents that later showed up in the news media were on two laptops stolen from the group last June. But an Oracle spokesman said the company had stipulated to the detectives that nothing illegal was to be done in the operation.
"When Oracle asked I.G.I. to investigate numerous Microsoft front organizations, we didn't specify how I.G.I. should go about gathering information," the spokesman said. "We did, however, insist that whatever methods I.G.I. employed must be legal." He said Oracle was repeatedly given such assurances.
Norman Harrison, president and chief executive of the detective firm, issued a statement saying he had no comment. The firm's chairman, Terry Lenzner, did not return calls.
The episode indicates the profound bitterness of the software-industry rivalry between Microsoft and Oracle, companies headed by two of the world's richest men: William H. Gates of Microsoft and Lawrence J. Ellison of Oracle.
Vivek Varma, a Microsoft spokesman, said tonight, "This is further proof that our competitors have conducted and paid for and orchestrated a public relations and lobbying campaign to generate government intervention into a industry that is highly competitive and delivering for consumers."
The detective that Oracle turned to, Mr. Lenzner, a onetime Watergate investigator, has come to prominence in recent years in his work for the tobacco industry and the Clinton White House, gathering information on their accusers. A Microsoft law firm even hired the Lenzner firm earlier this year to assist in a software piracy and counterfeiting case.
Oracle said it had retained the detective firm in June 1999 to investigate the Independent Institute of Oakland, Calif., a free-market policy institute that had just placed full-page advertisements defending Microsoft -- signed by 240 academic figures and portrayed as reflecting independent views -- in The Washington Post and The New York Times.
In September, The Times, citing internal institute documents, reported that the Independent Institute's ad was actually paid for by Microsoft. The Times said the documents had been provided by a Microsoft adversary associated with the computer industry who refused to be further identified.
A Times spokeswoman, Catherine Mathis, said it had long been the paper's policy not to disclose the names of confidential sources.
Last month, an article in The Wall Street Journal reported that the National Taxpayers Union, which had issued a study blaming the antitrust case for a loss of value in state pension funds, had received financing from Microsoft. It attributed the information to a person familiar with the group's corporate fund-raising.
"We take it that there has been no suggestion of any improper activity by The Journal, or any knowledge by The Journal of any such activity by any of its sources, and we know of none," said Richard Tofel, a spokesman for the newspaper.
The other group that Oracle acknowledged was a target of the investigation, the Association for Competitive Technology, is a pro-Microsoft trade group. According to documents from the company that manages the association's office space, a woman offered two cleaning workers cash on two occasions early this month to hand over trash from the group's office.
The offers were rebuffed. The woman making them had gained access using a key from another tenant, whose credit application bore the name of an investigator identified in the past as an agent of the Lenzner firm.
A Oracle executive said the company knew nothing about that incident other than what had been reported in the press.
And the executive said Oracle had had no involvement in another episode, in which Microsoft's support for a free-market lobbying group called Citizens for a Sound Economy was reported in The Washington Post.
Both that group and the Independent Institute reported recent thefts of laptop computers from their offices that they said might have contained documents that later appeared in the press.
The targets of the Oracle-backed investigation expressed outrage this evening, suggesting that the company was guilty of the same dirty-pool tactics of which it has long accused Microsoft.
"It's despicable," said Jonathan Zuck, president of the Association for Competitive Technology. "I would hope to get a letter of apology from Larry Ellison and an explanation of how, in a climate over so much concern over the issue of privacy, he could think this is an acceptable business practice."
He said he was considering legal action over what he said was a violation of his employees' privacy in the trash-buying attempt.
"This is not dumpster diving in offices outside the building, this is bribery," he said. "It's also a security issue."
Repeated requests by phone and e-mail for comment from Mr. Ellison, the Oracle chairman, were unavailing.
David J. Theroux, president of the Independent Institute, said Oracle had called into question its own credibility. "Clearly anybody who stoops to whatever was done here, you can't trust," he said.
He asserted that the documents that were cited in The Times obscured the debate because they implied that the Independent Institute was a front for Microsoft. Mr. Theroux said the Institute was advocating free-market policies for years before Microsoft ever became a supporter.
"It's unfortunate that instead of engaging the issues in a visible public forum," Mr. Theroux said, speaking of Oracle, "it was considered to be appropriate to use subterfuge and back-alley tactics to deal with the issues."
John Berthoud, president of the National Taxpayers Union, based in Alexandria, Va., said, "It's disappointing but perhaps not unexpected that Microsoft opponents, who are trying to use the American judicial system to run down Microsoft, would stoop to these kind of political tactics against the voices of the free market."
Mr. Berthoud said he had been approached by reporters contending they had been given internal financial documents from his group. But he said he had not seen the documents and could not verify their authenticity.
He said his group "engages in the rough and tumble of politics," but added, "This kind of nonsense is uncalled for and below the belt."

HEADLINE: Higher Demand Raises Pressure On Power Grid

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
The breakdown of three electric feeder cables on the Upper East Side of Manhattan on Monday forced Consolidated Edison to take emergency measures to prevent a widespread power failure. It was, on a smaller scale, exactly the same type of failure that started a chain of events leading to the 19-hour blackout in northern Manhattan during a heat wave last July.
Months of recriminations and investigations followed last year's blackout, and Con Ed said it would spend $315 million to prevent the situation from ever happening again. 
 Con Ed officials said yesterday that despite the problems Monday, the system worked as intended, with only eight buildings affected and 76,000 customers inconvenienced.
"Over all, the system performed very, very well," said Bill Donohue, Con Ed's vice president for electrical operations. "Remember we serve about 3.1 million customers, and we are talking about the fact that we asked eight buildings to reduce the load for a couple of hours."
But with the summer heat just beginning to settle in, Monday's incident served as a reminder that power companies in the New York region are confronting two distinct challenges -- routine equipment breakdowns, like failure of transmission lines, and a limited capacity to generate power -- each of which has the potential to pitch large sections of the city and its suburbs into dark misery at little or no warning.
In either case, the problems stem from a seemingly inexorable rise in energy demand. The record for power use, set before last year's blackout, is expected to be broken again this year. At the same time, electric power producers in New York State have reached their maximum generating capacity, and the first of a new generation of power plants will not open for at least two more years.
"Another summer and another crisis is what we have," said Ashok Gupta, a senior economist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group. "And this is going to be true for the next two or three summers." He and other energy experts suggest a more foreboding situation: the prospect that even with local distribution lines working perfectly, there will not be enough power to meet public demand.
The problem is not specific to New York. Across the country, with the economy booming and more people taking for granted air-conditioning, computers and gadgets of various shapes and sizes, demand for electricity is swiftly outpacing supply. Experts say only a steady program of power plant construction and energy conservation can ensure smooth operation of millions and millions of television sets, personal computers and cellular phone chargers and, yes, plain old light bulbs.
The public's insatiable thirst for energy comes at the same time that many states, including New York, are experiencing profound changes in how the sale and distribution of electricity are managed with the nationwide deregulation of public utilities. Con Ed, for example, is getting out of the power generation business to become primarily a distributor.
As with any deregulation, the result is more competition with a goal of cheaper energy. Lower prices, of course, only further increase demand. Free market fluctuation can also go the other way, as it did with huge price increases in May, caused by a surge in demand because of hot weather and higher prices for fossil fuels used to create electricity.
Experts say it is hard to predict what, if any, effect the shortage in the New York power supply will have on residential electric bills between now and the opening of new power plants in two to three years. Because of deregulation, prices are expected to be lower during nonpeak months.
Because of the May increases, which took prices from a normal level of $30 per megawatt-hour to $3,900 per megawatt-hour, the New York State Public Service Commission has proposed a rate cap of $1,000 a megawatt-hour. The cap is opposed by energy producers and distributors as well as by environmentalists who say lower prices just raise demand.
Regardless of price and even with sufficient generating capacity, as with any mechanical system, breakdowns are inevitable.
In Connecticut and throughout New England, officials declared a power watch yesterday and urged consumers to reduce their energy use after a minor problem Monday night caused a disruption in energy supplied by the Seabrook nuclear power plant in southern New Hampshire.
Interruptions of energy supply -- a plant's unexpectedly going off line, for instance, or a main supply line breaking down -- can usually be handled by tapping into energy reserves, which all power grid operators are required to maintain. New England officials declared the power watch to avoid tapping too deeply into their reserves in case further problems arose from yesterday's hot weather.
In New York, the peak electricity demand this summer is expected to reach 30,200 megawatts, up from about 29,700 megawatts in 1999. With reserves, the state can produce a total capacity of about 35,600 megawatts, said William J. Museler, president of New York Independent System Operator, an organization that operates the state power grid. "We do believe we have enough capacity to supply the load this summer, but on any given day, when you get up to these levels, it's tight," he said. "The problem is there is not much more in New York, and some of the capacity that we count on in New York comes from other regions."
But New York City and Long Island are "load pockets," areas that because of geography can import only a limited amount of electricity. New York City, which is generally required to maintain reserves equal to 18 percent of its daily load, has been operating at about 300 megawatts, or 3 percent, less than that, local energy executives said. Long Island, too, has barely maintained its reserve levels.
"We are about 300 megawatts short in the New York metropolitan area," said Richard Cattle, chief executive of Keyspan, which produces more than 6,000 megawatts in the city and on Long Island.
Unlike supply problems, distribution problems are much less predictable. Overhead power lines can get knocked down by wind or snow or a car accident. Underground lines can overheat. Local transformers can fail. Careful monitoring of the system can help predict some but in no way all of these problems. And these are the problems most likely to cause summer blackouts.
Con Ed officials said they were confident that the extra money being spent this year to reinforce the distribution system would prove effective. On the supply side, companies are pushing to build power plants. The first of a new generation of plants, to be built in Greene County, received final approval in May. Companies have proposed more than a dozen other power plants in the state.
Energy executives, regulators and environmentalists say communication is a major part of the solution: to warn of problems, encourage conservation and efficiency. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that city officials would meet with Con Ed to assure better communication in case of future problems.

SECTION: Section G; Page 1; Column 1; Circuits

LENGTH: 1204 words

HEADLINE: In China, Web Revolution Means Games

BYLINE: By JENNIFER 8. LEE

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
THREE a.m. on a summer Friday here. A smoke-filled room is packed with men, faces lighted by computer monitors, adrenaline running from online combat. Bicycles clutter the alley outside the door under the sign that reads NG Cafe.
The men are muttering into their headsets, discussing attack strategies with teammates seated only a few computers away. Brown and green scenes of soldiers, terrain and tanks scroll rapidly across the screens. A mobile phone rings. "What?" a man snaps at the caller who interrupted him. "I'm playing computer games." 
 NG Cafe is a Net cafe, or a wangba, the businesses that serve as late-night entertainment sites for hundreds of Beijing residents. The putative reason the wangbas operate is to provide online access. But the global scope of the Internet seemed to be mostly an afterthought in a room where 18 of the 20 computers were engaged in electronic warfare with opponents sitting nearby. To many Chinese men, the emergence of the networked computer has less to do with e-commerce than it has with e-battle.
Six juniors from nearby Peking University have come for an all-night session of Starcraft, a popular multiplayer computer game. One of the students, Simon Zhang, said that his economics professor had joked that Americans routed the Iraqis in the Gulf War because they had more experience playing video games. "There's some logic to his joke," Mr. Zhang said.
Everyone in the room is male, a demographic reflected in the fact that the bathroom has only a urinal. Everyone else is directed to a brick hut across the alley. Most of the men, mainly students and professionals who work nearby, arrived around midnight, and many will not leave until dawn.
One man has fallen asleep, his head collapsed against the table. Another is asleep, sprawled across three chairs. An orange sign on the wall reads: "Loud Yelling is Prohibited"; it was prompted by the frequent over-exuberance of players in the throes of victory or defeat. Smoke burns their eyes, and some computer keys are charred from errantly placed cigarettes.
The fact that the government considers the playing of computer games in wangbas illegal has not stopped thousands of them, and their cousins, the game parlors (which typically do not provide Internet access, just locally networked computers) from springing up across China. The term cafe seems excessively elegant for the one-room hovels heated by coal stoves that are NG Cafe's lower-end counterparts and where customers generally pay about 50 cents an hour and play for hours on end.
But the proliferation of wangbas and game parlors in the last three years has vexed a government that aspires to monitor social, political and economic trends. Wangbas, the government believes, have the potential to alter all three.
When the Internet came to China about five years ago, observers around the world thought that it would help reshape the politics and economics of the country by introducing residents to ideas and ways of life that the government had tried to restrict.
When NG Cafe opened, its owners predicted that most of the business would come from people seeking Internet access.
But Wang Peng, who works nights at the cafe, said that in the seven months since the NG Cafe opened, game playing had grown to about 70 percent of business. Visits to wangbas and game parlors from Kashgar to Kunming to Kaifeng revealed similar ratios: people are less likely to be chatting online than battling online. Some wangbas, particularly those near universities, have customers who mostly use the computers for e-mail messaging, chatting or surfing the Web. But the further the cafes are from educated affluent areas, the more computer games take center stage.
Computer games are to Chinese men what pickup basketball games are to American men. Instead of going to the neighborhood court, Chinese men head to their neighborhood wangba. Here, those who are most savvy on the battlefield earn the respect of their peers and engage in the digital equivalent of trash talk.
"It's a social activity," Mr. Zhang said. "Playing a game on the Net is very different from playing a game on a machine because you can feel other people's hearts beating during the game."
He typed in a message to his teammates in Chinglish, a Chinese-English hybrid: "go zhou. wo dian ta." (Go attack Zhou, I've electrified him.)
Mr. Zhang's roommate, Otto Hua, 21, said there were some weeks when he played multiplayer games for more than 20 hours.
In 1998, the government prohibited the playing of computer games in wangbas, a restriction that has been sporadically enforced. (Wangbas were still permitted to provide Internet access, just not for gameplaying.)
In 1999, the government repeated the restriction as part of a collection of regulations that also prohibited wangba customers from engaging in activities endangering national security and disrupting public security and order.
Editorials published in The People's Daily depict wangbas, game parlors and computer games as a "plague" and a "poison." Newspapers and television broadcasts regularly report on students addicted to computer games who do not return home for days, steal money from their parents and give themselves to the wangbas in indentured servitude to pay their bills.
Wangba owners must now go to their local public security bureau to register within 30 days of receiving a business license. In the last several months, government enforcement has become stricter. Several hundred unregistered wangbas and game parlors in Beijing were closed in March, and several hundred wangbas and game parlors in Shanghai were raided last year.
Some wangbas have responded to the clampdown. Feiyu, a wangba chain south of Peking University, has restricted game playing. But other wangba owners are resisting limits on their lucrative businesses. Last year, a wangba owner in the province of Zhejiang challenged the restrictions in court saying that despite its social harm, computer gaming has the potential of aiding development of information technology in China. In February, the courts rejected the claim, citing wangbas' societal harm.
By 4:30 a.m., the sky over NG Cafe is light. Mr. Zhang and his classmates leave at 5:30 a.m. after five hours. By 8 a.m., most of the older customers have left and another wave of players, mostly younger, arrives, ignoring the sign that prohibits elementary and middle school students from entering.
"We're not afraid of the regulations," said Zhang Shi Miao, 13, a student at a middle school. "The government is overreacting. Most people don't become addicted to computer games. It's just for fun."
Many customers are unaware that playing computer games in wangbas is forbidden.
"We don't know about these rules. Therefore the responsibility is not on us," said Mr. Zhang when told of the regulations. "If they don't strictly administer the law, then we can still go on playing."
He said it was unlikely that the government would suddenly strictly enforce the prohibitions.
"There are too many interests in computer-game playing for that to happen," he said. "In America you would call it lobbying. In China we call it bribery."

SECTION: Section F; Page 2; Column 5; House & Home/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 781 words

HEADLINE: TURF;
Minorities Still Lag In Homeownership

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
AS the United States roars through the Year 2000 still in the midst of the longest housing boom on record, there are disturbing signs that minorities remain at the bottom of the homeownership gap, according to a report issued this week by the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University.
The report found that although government loan programs directed toward minorities have increased significantly, a greater percentage of whites than blacks own homes, creating a gap of 25.8 percent, about the same as in 1994. Hispanics, who are fast becoming major players in the country's housing market, still fall 23 percent below whites in terms of homeownership. 
 Especially in such prosperous times, these problems of affordability are "deeply troubling," said Nicolas P. Retsinas, the center's director. "The signs are that, yes, the gap will keep getting bigger. The history is that in good times the gaps narrow. But in these good times -- about the best we know of -- they have not."
At the same time, minorities are becoming a larger part of the population. While today 75 percent of households are white, that number will shrink to 71 percent by 2010. There will be nearly 12 million more households, and minorities -- classified in three groups, as black, Hispanic, and Asian and others -- will make up nearly two-thirds of that growth.
The Harvard study noted that rising housing costs create pain for everyone, regardless of race and income. Rents have risen across the country, signficantly in the Northeast and the West where Portland, Seattle and San Francisco have posted record rents.
Homes cost more, and so do mortgages. Adjusted for inflation, mortage costs rose nearly 5 percent between 1998 and 1999. Down payments rose 3.5 percent, for an average increase of $442. House prices hit record highs in 15 of the nation's 39 biggest cities: only Buffalo, Miami and Rochester saw a decline in prices. But the study found disproportionate impacts on the poor. As house prices and mortgage costs rise, the poor are experiencing increased difficulty in finding homes, not only to buy but also to rent. Ninety-thousand federally subsidized housing rental units have been lost since the early 90's, as landlords have opted out of federal programs, in many cases because they want the freedom to raise rents to market levels. Housing authorities are also demolishing public housing projects without replacing them in equal numbers.
The stock market has made fortunes for many people. But the biggest investment for most Americans is their home. This is especially true among homeowners who are black or Hispanic.
In the face of these statistics, Darren Walker, the chief operating officer for the Abyssinian Development Corporation, which builds housing in Harlem, says he finds it incomprehensible that the largest lenders in New York are not writing more loans for African-American applicants.
The study reported that many minorities were taking out more expensive loans -- called subprime -- which are geared to home buyers with poor credit. The Harvard study found that such high-interest loans had risen fivefold from 1993 to 1998.
Mr. Walker contended that minority homeowners in Harlem are the focus of intense advertising efforts by the subprime lenders; often, home buyers -- even those with excellent credit -- do not realize they must pay higher interest for these subprime loans than what would be offered by a mainstream bank.
"These numbers reinforce our contention that the mainstream lenders have still not fully embraced the minority communities," he said.
Mr. Walker said that subprime lenders, whose interest rates are currently one to three percentage points higher than the prevailing 8 1/4 percent home mortgage rate, at least "allow people who wouldn't otherwise own a home to be able to swing it."
The annual Harvard report, "The State of the Nation's Housing," poked holes in the belief that home buyers and renters alike are increasingly drawn to center cities. While some households choose lofts and condominiums downtown, the report found that Americans still prefer the suburbs, often with good reason: from 1990 to 1997, jobs in the lower-density fringes of metropolitan areas grew 19 percent, compared with only 4 percent in the urban core.
In 1998, the report said, most minority and low-income buyers chose the suburbs. In the Northeast, a full 72 percent of low-income buyers bought in the suburbs, compared with 60 percent in the West. Hartford, Atlanta and Miami were the most unpopular cities among home buyers: 85 percent of low-income borrowers in those markets chose not to live in their downtowns.
