HEADLINE: President, a Team Player, Goes to Bat Once More for Gore

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28

 BODY:
President Clinton turned an hourlong news conference today into an effort to bolster Vice President Al Gore's campaign and to defend him from accusations of campaign finance irregularities. He said Mr. Gore made "a compelling case" that he did nothing wrong and argued that the "so-called scandals" of the last eight years "were bogus."
In a wide-ranging discussion that included gasoline prices, the death penalty, missile defense, Elian Gonzalez, prescription drug coverage and how much brain power it takes to be president, Mr. Clinton invoked Mr. Gore's name more than a dozen times. 
 He dismissed polls showing Mr. Gore running behind Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, noting that this week alone one poll showed a 13-point lead for the presumed Republican candidate while another indicated a virtual tie. The president said that once Americans examine Mr. Gore's record, his economic policy and his understanding of new technology, "it's still more likely than not that he will win."
Mr. Clinton said he did not see a need for Attorney General Janet Reno to appoint a special counsel to investigate Mr. Gore's involvement in campaign fund-raising, including his appearance at a Buddhist temple in California in April 1996. The president said that she had already considered, and rejected, an outside review and that "the best thing to do is for the American people to make their own judgments about it."
But he seized the moment -- as he does increasingly often these days -- to argue that his White House has been repeatedly vindicated of wrongdoing despite a Washington "scandal machine."
"The word 'scandal' has been thrown around here like a clanging teapot for seven years," he said. And he quickly cited a Washington Post column that he said concluded "a whole bunch of this stuff was just garbage, and that we had totally innocent people prosecuted because they wouldn't lie." He cited numerous investigations of members of his cabinet, and of his own financial dealings in Arkansas, but never mentioned his impeachment.
The president also plugged Mr. Gore when asked about the brain power needed to be a good president and gently tweaked Mr. Bush, who has said he plans to surround himself with the best advisers to compensate for areas in which he is not an expert.
"I don't think it's so much a question of intelligence generically," Mr. Clinton said in describing the qualities it takes to be president. "I mean, I think it's more a question of curiosity and willingness to learn what you think is important," a clear reference to suggestions that Mr. Bush often skims the surface rather than delving deeply.
"I guess I think that no president can say, well, it should be enough for the voters if I get the best advisers in my party and they come up with a position and I take it," he added. "So what the voters will have to analyze here is how important is the fact that Al Gore spent 20 years working on arms control issues, for example, and dealing with all these things?"
Mr. Clinton spent most of his time pressing the legislative agenda for his last seven months in office. He urged Congress to take the deal he offered this week: prescription drug coverage for senior citizens, a longtime item on Mr. Clinton's list, in return for the elimination of the "marriage penalty" in the tax system, a longtime Republican desire.
He urged the Senate to approve permanent normal trade relations with China, as the House has already. "I ask Congress, let's not waste these precious weeks," he said. But his advisers acknowledge that Mr. Clinton will be lucky to get one or two of his priorities through an election-year Congress, and say he will focus instead on negotiating an Israeli-Palestinian peace by September, and other foreign policy initiatives.
Asked about capital punishment, Mr. Clinton expressed concern about racial disparities among those facing execution for federal crimes. Seventeen of the 21 federal prisoners facing the death penalty are members of minority groups. Mr. Clinton also said he was concerned that prosecutors in a dozen Southern states had accounted for more than half of the federal cases in which the death penalty had been sought.
Mr. Clinton's comments gave some hope to lawyers for Juan Raul Garza, a migrant farm worker convicted of marijuana smuggling and three drug-related murders. He is scheduled next month to become the first person facing a federal execution in nearly 40 years.
"We're encouraged by the president's comments," said Gregory Wiercioch, a lawyer with the Texas Defender Service who is representing Mr. Garza and preparing to file a request for clemency. "What President Clinton is realizing is that the Justice Department's authorization is like a rigged lottery."
Mr. Clinton's news conference came shortly after the Supreme Court handed down several major rulings, and Mr. Clinton fielded questions on many of them, including the court's refusal to hear a case dealing with Elian Gonzalez -- who left Washington for Cuba only hours after Mr. Clinton spoke -- and its decision backing the Boy Scouts' ability to exclude gay members.
He said he wished the return of Elian to Cuba had "unfolded in a less dramatic, less traumatic way for all concerned." He made a last-minute offer to the departing family, "If he and his father decided they wanted to stay here, it would be fine with me."
Yet Mr. Clinton signaled no major departure from the United States embargo on Cuba, saying it would be up to Fidel Castro to reach out to the United States. He deflected comparisons to his recent decision to lift the embargo of commercial exchanges against North Korea -- despite the fact that North Korea had engaged in actions that closely parallel those he accused Fidel Castro of committing.
While Mr. Clinton said he supported the notion of selling American food and medicine to Havana, the substance of a deal struck this week among House Congressional leaders, he said he was concerned about restrictions in the legislation on travel to the island.
On the Supreme Court's decision to permit the Boy Scouts to bar gays, Mr. Clinton called the Scouts, of which he is honorary president, "a great group." But he said he hoped the decision was "just one step along the way of a movement toward greater inclusion in our society because I think that's the direction we ought to be going in."

HEADLINE: Federal Reserve Calls a Time Out on Raising Interest Rates

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, giving itself more time to determine whether the series of rate increases it has imposed the last year are slowing the economy sufficiently to avoid an upturn in inflation.
But the central bank warned that it could start raising rates again as soon as its next meeting, on Aug. 22. Analysts said the Fed would probably tighten policy in August unless economic indicators in coming weeks provided assurance that the red-hot pace of economic growth earlier this year had given way to a more sustainable path that reduces the threat of an inflationary spiral in wages and prices. 
 The Federal Reserve's decision had been widely expected by economists and investors, and Wall Street took the news largely in stride. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed more than 100 points but fell back after the Fed announcement to close at 10,527.79, up 23.33, for the day. The Nasdaq composite index rose 81.38, to 3,940.34.
In calling a time out today in its campaign of rate increases -- six over the last year, pushing its benchmark federal funds target rate up 1.75 percentage points, to 6.5 percent -- the Fed acknowledged that there had been some evidence that the economy was cooling off. And the central bank noted that while inflation by some measures had been accelerating, price pressures were being held down by continuing improvements in productivity, a measure of the economy's ability to produce more for less.
But the central bank's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee suggested that it remained unconvinced that the economic slowdown was real. And it stressed its continuing concern that the current low rate of unemployment -- 4.1 percent in May -- could lead wages to rise so fast that companies would be forced to raise their prices.
Signs of moderating growth "are still tentative and preliminary, and the utilization of the pool of available workers remains at an unusually high level," the committee said in a statement released at the conclusion of a two-day meeting.
Under those circumstances, the statement said, "the committee believes the risks continue to be weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate heightened inflation pressures in the foreseeable future."
Analysts said the wording of the statement was intended in part to keep investors off balance and keep stock prices from surging on the assumption that the Fed was finished or nearly finished raising rates.
Economists said there was a good chance that the Fed would push rates up another quarter percentage point in August, but that the decision would be driven by the economic statistics that come out between now and then.
"We're back on data watch," said Ian Morris, an economist at HSBC Securities.
Economists pointed to today's report on orders for durable goods as evidence that some of the weakness exhibited by the economy the last few months might have been temporary. Orders for durable goods in May rose 6 percent, to $218.89 billion, more than reversing a 5.7 percent decline in April, the Commerce Department reported. Analysts had expected an increase of less than 3 percent.
"The big increase in durable goods today is telling you that this slowdown is going to be just moderate, that we're not going to have an extremely sharp slowdown," said Maury N. Harris, an economist at PaineWebber.
Mr. Harris said other important indicators in coming weeks could follow a similar pattern, with chances good that both job creation and average hourly earnings would rebound in June after being depressed in May.
He said he expected the Fed to raise its federal funds target rate on overnight loans between banks a quarter percentage point, to 6.75 percent, in August, and then to push the rate up again to 7 percent by the end of the year.
Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney, also said he expected the federal funds rate to rise to around 7 percent this year.
"We think that current financial conditions are not going to prove sufficiently restrictive to keep demand moving back into line," Mr. DiClemente said in a report today.
In explaining its decision to leave rates unchanged, the Fed suggested that it remained ambivalent -- or perhaps divided -- over the potential for inflation to take root.
The committee's statement gave equal emphasis to two competing ways of assessing the outlook. One view, often emphasized by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, is built on the idea that an acceleration in productivity growth is likely to continue, holding down costs and tempering any inflation pressures that might result from rising wages.
In this view, the goal of monetary policy is to bring economic growth down to "a pace closer to the rate of growth of the economy's potential to produce," as today's statement put it.
The economy grew at a 5.4 percent annual rate in the first quarter, and most Fed officials put the noninflationary growth rate at 3.5 percent to 4 percent a year.
But in expressing concern that the low unemployment rate could ignite inflation, the statement recognized a position advocated by a number of other Fed officials, including Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor. Mr. Meyer believes that with unemployment around 4 percent, even 3.5 percent annual growth might be enough to generate inflation pressures.
He has raised the possibility that the Fed might need to push growth below 3.5 or 4 percent for some period and allow the unemployment rate to rise to 5 percent or higher to squeeze inflation pressures out of the economy.
Mr. Greenspan works to bring consensus to policy making within the Fed, and the lines between the two camps are not firmly drawn. But even if the Fed agrees that tighter monetary policy is beginning to bite, it could still face a debate over how much further it needs to go in slowing the economy.

HEADLINE: Credit Card Issuer Will Repay Millions To Some Customers

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28

 BODY:
One of the nation's largest credit card companies agreed today to a demand from bank regulators to reimburse its customers at least $300 million for misleading and improperly billing them.
The regulators accused the Providian Financial Corporation, the nation's sixth-largest issuer of credit cards, of deceiving hundreds of thousands of consumers, many of them with credit problems, with phone calls and mass mailings full of confusing sales pitches. As a result, people paid annual fees when they had been told there would be none, received credit cards they did not know they had signed up for and were subjected to higher interest rates than the company had advertised, according to the government, which conducted a yearlong investigation. 
 Providian signed a joint agreement with the federal Comptroller of the Currency, the attorney general of California and the San Francisco district attorney's office. Providian agreed to halt the practices objected to by regulators.
About 3 million of Providian's 13 million customers are likely to receive reimbursement checks later this year, regulators said. In addition to the $300 million in reimbursements, which regulators called a minimum, Providian will pay a $5.5 million fine to the City of San Francisco.
Consumer advocates said the $300 million in restitution was one of the largest penalties they knew of in a case involving consumer deception. It is 10 times the amount Wall Street analysts had initially expected and will wipe out the equivalent of more than one-third of Providian's 1999 profits after taxes.
"Providian has engaged in a pattern of abusing consumers by misleading them," said Daniel P. Stipano, the director of the comptroller's enforcement and compliance division.
As part of the agreement, Providian, whose credit card operation is led by David R. Alvarez, neither acknowledged nor denied breaking the law but did agree to change its practices.
"Frankly, we thought seriously about fighting" the government, Shailesh Mehta, Providian's chief executive, said today in a conference call with reporters. "This was purely a business decision" based on the calculation that litigation would have cost more than the settlement, Mr. Mehta added.
In recent months, the number of consumers complaining to the comptroller's office about Providian's practices has declined significantly, Mr. Mehta said.
The bank, which is based in San Francisco, was the nation's fastest-growing issuer of credit cards over the 12 months ended March 31, increasing the size of its portfolio -- which is chiefly credit card debt -- by 54 percent, according to Friedman Billings Ramsey, an investment banking firm in Arlington, Va.
Providian focuses its marketing on the growing number of Americans who have credit problems and is known for its sophisticated use of databases in singling out potential customers.
The case, which regulators said began because of complaints from Providian customers, also offers the latest evidence of a growing consumer backlash against credit card companies struggling to maintain their profit margins. So many consumers have complained about receiving their bills too close to the payment deadline to avoid a late fee, for example, that the comptroller began an investigation into the practice earlier this year. Bank One's giant First USA credit card unit has received the most complaints.
The agreement comes as bank regulators, state officials and members of Congress are vowing to look more closely at predatory lending, particularly to people with bad credit histories or low incomes.
"This is an historic occasion," said June D. Cravett, the head of the consumer and environmental protection unit of the San Francisco district attorney's office. She said it indicated that federal regulators were now paying more attention to the banks' treatment of their customers.
Most of the current government efforts against this sort of fraud focus on confusing, high-interest home-equity loans that are pitched to people who often have few other lines of credit open to them and can lose their houses if they default. In 1994, Congress passed a law intended to curb deceptive loans by increasing disclosure by lenders, but regulators have since warned that the law has had little effect. The Federal Reserve recently formed a multiagency task force that is studying ways to curb predatory lending.
Consumer advocates said the Providian settlement showed that home-equity loans were not the only worrisome practice in the so-called sub-prime lending market. "People who don't have good credit are preyed upon in all sorts of areas -- when they try to get a credit card, when they try to get a home-equity loan, when they try to get a mortgage on a house," said Frank Torres, the legislative counsel at Consumers Union, an advocacy group that publishes Consumer Reports.
The case also reflects a new level of aggressiveness among bank regulators, they said. The comptroller, part of the Treasury Department, has indicated that it now considers deceptive lending practices to be a potential threat to banks' "safety and soundness," which it is responsible for monitoring. And the government's agreement with Providian is the first time regulators have punished a company by using the Federal Trade Commission Act, Mr. Stipano said. The act gives the government latitude to investigate marketing practices.
In its agreement with Providian, the comptroller described selling pitches that one regulator compared to a Catch-22.
In one pitch, Providian boasted of charging no annual fee but then required customers to pay $156 a year for credit protection, the government said. If, after seeing the charge, they asked not to receive the protection, they were charged an annual fee.
In another, Providian telemarketers, working from scripts, refused to tell people what interest rate they would receive no matter how many times they asked. Instead, the employees would repeat, using slightly varied language, the idea that Providian would significantly beat a consumer's current interest rate. In reality, the difference was usually slight and, because of the complicated rules, often ended up being higher, Mr. Stipano said.
Providian made the confusing sales pitches to people with both poor and normal credit.
To make the payments to customers, Providian said it would use $36 million of cash reserves and take a $163 million charge. Because restitution is tax deductible, it will not show up as a $300 million loss on the company's earnings report. Providian still faces many private lawsuits.
Last week, when Providian announced the likely size of a settlement, its stock fell more than 10 percent. Today, it gained $2, to $85, as investors were cheered by the news that the case is now largely over, said Todd Pitsinger, an analyst at Friedman Billings Ramsey.

HEADLINE: New State Rules Aim to Curb Loan Abuses

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
The New York State Banking Department released new rules yesterday meant to prevent the abuses of high-cost loans that have victimized thousands of homeowners.
Several consumer and housing groups, protesting the regulations as far too weak, briefly disrupted the presentation at the state banking board meeting in Lower Manhattan. 
 The rules, which the board is expected to adopt in the next few days, would make New York the second state to regulate so-called predatory lenders. The first was North Carolina, which enacted a law last year.
New York's superintendent of banking, Elizabeth McCaul, said that while many high-cost lenders help people who have limited credit ratings, "this regulation makes clear that abusive, predatory lending practices will not be tolerated."
Predatory lenders typically use high-pressure tactics to talk homeowners into exorbitant loans that often force them into bankruptcy or foreclosure. The most frequent victims are the elderly, women and residents of minority neighborhoods.
The rules cover the advertising, brokering and issuing of high-cost home loans. The state said they would help ensure that borrowers understood the terms of their loans and could afford to repay them. The rules would curb repeated refinancing that did not help borrowers and the "packing" of loans with excessive points, fees and other charges.
But critics said the rules were a major disappointment, especially since New York is the nation's biggest banking center and has had more predatory loans than any other state. New York's rules fall far short of the North Carolina law, the critics said, and the final version is weaker than the initial draft issued several months ago.
The new rules "would largely let predatory lenders off the hook," said Sarah Ludwig, director of the nonprofit Neighborhood Economic Development Advocacy Project and an organizer of New Yorkers for Responsible Lending. "The proposed regulation," she said, "invites shady lenders and brokers to find ways to get around the law."
Among the many criticisms were the failure to ban prepayment penalties, which tend to lock victims into onerous loans, and a loophole that would permit lenders to ignore "the borrower's apparent lack of capacity to repay the loan."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Lashes Out At Con Edison

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani attacked Consolidated Edison yesterday for Monday's power breakdowns, accusing the utility of shoddy management and saying he had decided to reinstate an investigatory panel to review the utility's service to consumers.
The city's top lawyer followed suit, saying the city was withdrawing a settlement offer it had made to the utility in a lawsuit over last year's blackout in Washington Heights. 
 Although Monday's power failure was smaller, confined to eight buildings on the Upper East Side, and briefer than others in recent years that crippled large sections of the city, several city officials said yesterday that they were angered by Con Ed's decision to reduce power so early in the summer.
"The troubling question is, if they can't handle an 88-degree day in June, what happens when it gets to 98 in August?" said Michael D. Hess, the corporation counsel.
Both the mayor and Mr. Hess expressed dissatisfaction with the company's explanation that it decided on the reductions because power consumption had nearly reached its capacity, especially since the city had received assurances that it would spend $315 million to upgrade its systems to prevent a recurrence of last year's blackout. That 19-hour power failure prompted the city to sue Con Ed, with the Giuliani administration seeking compensation for police and emergency service expenses and threatening to ask the Public Service Commission to take action against the company.
Mr. Hess said yesterday that the lawsuit had been "close to settlement until this hiccup on Monday."
A spokesman for Con Edison, Joseph Petta, responded to the mayor's complaints yesterday, saying that "no electrical power company in the world can guarantee no outages." But he said a $100 million upgrade of cables and other equipment in New York City since last year's blackout in upper Manhattan "has gone a long way to further improving the most reliable energy distribution system in the country."
Mr. Petta said that electrical consumption by New York City businesses and residents on Monday was at its third-highest level of any day in history, and that electric supplies were growing tighter because "the economy is booming and fuel prices are higher." He said Con Ed thought that "more plants are needed to meet the growing demand."
Con Edison officials have pointed out that just eight buildings and about 76,000 customers were affected for just a few hours on Monday.
At his daily press briefing, Mayor Giuliani rejected assertions by Con Ed executives that heavy use of air-conditioners, combined with the increased demands of computers and other electrical appliances, had pushed the generating capacity of the company's suppliers close to the limit.
"It's no excuse to say people use too much power," the mayor said. He then announced that he would reappoint a City Hall task force, including Mr. Hess and John Dyson, one of the mayor's closest advisers and a former deputy mayor, to examine the utility's performance in delivering electricity to New Yorkers. Last year, the panel was established to investigate Con Ed's management and distribution system, and to demand changes.
"Con Edison should be prepared for people using too much power," the mayor said, adding the the task force would "make recommendations on the demands we now should make" on the utility. Among them, he said, is likely to be a revised system of handling power disruptions like the one on Monday, in which "a lot of people at Con Ed didn't appear to know what they were doing."
In lashing out at the company yesterday, Mr. Giuliani joined other top city officials in viewing with some skepticism Con Ed's suggestion that it faces a severe long-term problem in generating capacity, instead of the more immediate snags caused by failures in its power lines and distribution system. Con Ed, under the mandates of federal deregulation of the electrical utility industry, sold all three of its oil-powered electrical plants in New York City last year.
Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker, who was consulted by Mr. Giuliani yesterday, said Con Ed's assertions that its generating capacity was being pushed to the limit "may be a ploy."
Mr. Vallone said Con Ed, working in consort with the utilities that have bought its New York City plants, might be using power disruptions to put pressure on regulators to approve construction of a new electrical power plant in the city.
Mr. Petta replied that Con Ed "can't comment, since we no longer own those plants." The three former Con Ed plants have been bought by KeySpan, Orion Power Holdings and the NRG unit of Northern States Power.
Mr. Giuliani said he had instructed Mr. Hess, Mr. Dyson and others he appointed to his mayoral task force to investigate Con Ed's management policies, and the broader assertions that it had reached the limit of its generating capacity.
"There is a management issue," he said, adding that Con Ed's senior management appeared on Monday not to immediately recognize the severity of the problem on the Upper East Side. He described management questions as "the most important in the short term."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Rise in a Sigh of Relief, for Now, on Interest Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond yields fell sharply yesterday amid weakness in stocks and investor relief that the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged on Wednesday.
In the currency market, the dollar was off against the euro and the yen, making dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors because of exchange-rate advantages. 
 The price of the 10-year Treasury note, which many market participants are using as the benchmark, rose 1 6/32, to 103 14/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.02 percent from 6.10 percent on Wednesday. The price of the 30-year bond rose 1 5/32, to 105 10/32. Its yield dropped to 5.87 percent from 5.95 percent.
Robert Pugliese, director of the fixed-income department at the J. W. Genesis Financial Corporation, said the moves were exaggerated by low liquidity and volume in the market.
He says that Treasury prices are too lofty, with the price of a 10-year note having run up too fast, and that more interest rate increases by the Fed are in the offing. "I don't see prices remaining at these high levels," he said. "Prices in bonds and equities will decline. The economic slowdown is a head fake, so there are more tightenings in the wings."
Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said the Federal Open Market Committee, at its meeting on Wednesday, refrained from tightening again "as more moderate economic and inflation data suggested that the previous tightenings instituted over the past year may finally be starting to lower the trend rate of economic growth to a more sustainable level, while at the same time keeping a lid on rising price pressures."
"But the issues of sustainability and extent of any slowdown are open questions at this juncture," he added, "and further Fed tightening at the August F.O.M.C. meeting seems probable in light of the economy's still-buoyant forward momentum, tight labor markets and continued upcreep in inflation."
The government securities market was bolstered by the Treasury's buyback program, some end-of-the-quarter buying and softer new-home sales data that ran counter to sales figures released earlier this week.
The release yesterday of updated figures for first-quarter gross domestic product caused few surprises. Some bond market participants think coming figures on consumer prices could prove unnerving, particularly if components of the price index outside of energy go up more than expected.
Mr. Fine is among those paying closer heed to other coming reports.
"The bond market's next major hurdle," Mr. Fine said, "will be the June labor market report, which should correct any misleading perceptions resulting from last month's presumably questionable information, which showed extraordinary weakness in the midst of a very tight labor market."

HEADLINE: Fed Vote in May to Raise Rates Was Unanimous, Minutes Show

BYLINE: Bridge News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 29

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers voted unanimously to raise interest rates by half a percentage point in May and to indicate that they suspected the risks to the economy were weighted mainly toward escalating inflation pressures, according to minutes of their May 16 meeting released today.
The minutes of the Open Market Committee showed that Fed officials felt that a "more forceful" tightening was desirable "in light of the extraordinary and persisting strength of overall demand," and "indications of growing pressures in already tight markets for labor and other resources." 
 The minutes suggested that the financial markets' expectations of an aggressive rate tightening were an influence on the May 16 decision. "Financial markets seem to have recognized the need for real interest rates to rise further under these circumstances," the minutes said.
The greater risk to the expansion at that point, the minutes said, was for monetary policy to be "too sluggish in adjusting," allowing inflationary "disturbances and dislocations to build."
The Fed minutes said a half-point increase would help avert a rise in inflation expectations, which in the view of some members were worsening.
While the Fed on May 16 agreed that the risks were biased toward higher inflation, a number of the members said they "did not want to prejudge the potential extent or pace of future policy tightening," according to the minutes.
These members said the committee should continue to assess the need for rate increases in light of conditions meeting by meeting.
Discussing the economic situation, the committee cited evidence that underlying inflation was beginning to pick up, the minutes said. Even so, the minutes said, unit costs were "still remarkably subdued and members saw no developments at this stage that might augur a sharp near-term deterioration in price inflation."
The Federal Open Market Committee noted more reports that rising labor costs could no longer be fully offset by productivity improvements and that more companies seemed to be trying to raise prices to help profits.
"However, their ability to set higher prices, or at least to raise them significantly, continued to be severely constrained by the persistence of strong competition across much of the economy," the minutes stated.
The minutes also reported that some committee members felt that less rapid consumer spending at that time might have been linked to lower stock prices. If stock prices did not rise much further, there would be a "neutral or negative" impact on the economy once the effects of the earlier stock prices wore off, but that would "take some time," the minutes said.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Border Dispute Will Get a Hearing

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 29

 BODY:
In a final day of housekeeping after concluding its term, the Supreme Court agreed today to settle a longstanding and increasingly bitter boundary dispute between New Hampshire and Maine about which state includes the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard.
The shipyard, a federal installation, sits on islands in the Piscataqua River, which flows into Portsmouth Harbor and forms the state boundary between Portsmouth, N.H., and Kittery, Me. According to Maine, the state boundary is in the middle of the channel, placing the shipyard on the Maine side. Consequently, Maine has been imposing its income tax on the people who work at the shipyard. 
 New Hampshire, asserting a historical claim to all the river up to the shoreline on the Maine side, says the shipyard is in New Hampshire, which has no income tax.
The United States owns the property in dispute, having begun in 1800 to acquire the five islands that make up the shipyard. For years, however, the Navy regarded the island as within New Hampshire's political jurisdiction. More recently, it has moved to an official position of neutrality, though the federal government has been withholding Maine income tax from the workers' paychecks.
In March, New Hampshire filed its case against Maine directly in the Supreme Court, invoking the court's constitutional "original" jurisdiction to hear suits between states. In agreeing today to take jurisdiction of the case, the justices instructed the federal government to file a brief and make its views known.
The case, New Hampshire v. Maine, No. 130 Original, is reminiscent of the "original" case the court heard two years ago between New York and New Jersey about which could claim Ellis Island. New Jersey emerged the winner.
The competing claims of New Hampshire and Maine date to the colonial period. New Hampshire says it is significant that the Port of Piscataqua, now Portsmouth Harbor, was excluded from the Massachusetts Bay colony in 1691. What is now Maine was originally part of Massachusetts.
For its part, Maine cites a decree signed in 1740 by King George II, setting the boundary as a line that "shall pass up thro' the mouth of Piscataqua Harbour and up the middle of the river."
In its brief asking the court to hear its case, New Hampshire said that the shipyard "has always been culturally, economically and politically connected to New Hampshire." The state "is not able to maintain its historic connections to the shipyard without judicial assistance," New Hampshire said.
The justices are likely to appoint a special master to hear evidence in the case and make a recommendation.
As the court began its summer recess, it took these other actions today.
 
Drug Sentencing
The court vacated a Denver man's 30-year sentence for distributing cocaine and instructed the federal appeals court in Denver to reconsider the sentence in light of the Supreme Court ruling this week that the sentencing provision of New Jersey's hate-crime law was unconstitutional. The court's action today in Jones v. United States, No. 99-8176, could portend a major upheaval in federal drug sentencing.
In its ruling on Monday in the New Jersey case, Apprendi v. New Jersey, the court held that any fact that increases the penalty for a crime beyond the statutory maximum had to be found by the jury beyond a reasonable doubt. The New Jersey law was unconstitutional because the judge, not the jury, determined after the defendant's conviction whether the crime had been motivated by bias, a finding that under the hate-crime law then resulted in an increased sentence.
The drug sentence the court vacated today in light of that ruling was typical of the way drug sentencing works in the federal system. Carless Jones was indicted on and convicted by a jury of two counts of distributing cocaine, a crime that carries a statutory penalty of 20 years.
The indictment did not specify a particular amount of cocaine, and the jury made no finding on that question. The presentence report informed the judge that the quantity of the drug, 165.5 grams, was enough for a life sentence. Over the defendant's objection, the judge imposed a sentence of 30 years on each count, to run concurrently. The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit upheld the sentence, ruling that the jury had found all the necessary elements of the offense, and that the judge could make the findings necessary to determine the sentence.
 
Abortion
Following its invalidation on Wednesday of a Nebraska abortion law, the court vacated rulings by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago, that upheld similar laws in Illinois (Hope Clinic v. Ryan, No. 99-1152) and Wisconsin (Planned Parenthood v. Doyle, No. 99-1156). The court also turned down an appeal by Iowa from a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, which struck down that state's so-called partial-birth abortion law last year at the same time it invalidated the Nebraska law. (Miller v. Planned Parenthood, No. 99-1112).

HEADLINE: Let's Take a Flier: The Return of Mega-Leverage to Stocks

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
BACK in the good old days, before there was a Securities and Exchange Commission and before the 1929 crash and the Depression that followed had given speculation a bad name, a plunger didn't need to actually buy shares to get all the excitement of the stock market.
He or she could go to bucket shops, which offered the ability to bet while putting up hardly any money. Unlike the real brokerage houses, which wanted a buyer to pay 10 percent or 20 percent of the stock's price to buy it, the bucket shops would let you "buy" a $100 share for a dollar. 
 A quarter of that dollar was a commission, and the rest was the margin. So if the stock fell 75 cents, your margin was wiped out and the dollar was gone. But if the stock went up and you got out, you could make money. Few did.
"The business was tremendously profitable," wrote Edwin Lefevre in his 1923 classic, "Reminiscences of a Stock Operator," a fictionalized memoir of the life of the speculator Jesse Livermore, who got his start in bucket shops. "When it was conducted legitimately -- I mean straight, as far as the bucket shop went -- the fluctuations took care of the shoestrings. It doesn't take much of a reaction to wipe out a margin of only three-quarters of a point."
Bucket shops eventually gained a bad reputation. But they were widely viewed as legitimate in the 1920's, even though speculators never really purchased stock.
Now the basic idea is back, albeit under a fancier name. The futures markets want to trade "single-stock futures," which in economic terms are virtually identical to stocks. This week the House and Senate Agriculture Committees unanimously approved bills to allow such trading even though many regulatory issues remain unsettled.
Once they become legal, you will be able to buy single-stock futures by putting up pennies on the dollar, in sharp contrast to the stock market, where you have to put up half the purchase price. The potential appeal is obvious.
Not unlike the old bucket shops, futures markets have intraday margin calls. If your stock future declines, you must put up more cash immediately or be wiped out.
Futures in commodities like wheat make sense because they allow for trading and price discovery without the need to ship millions of bushels of wheat. The advent of stock-index futures provided a way to hedge risk on broad baskets of stocks. Single-stock futures offer little more than a way to gamble on the cheap.
The futures markets talk of single-stock futures as providing "additional risk management tools," as Scott Gordon, chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, put it in an interview. They say that you can already duplicate a single-stock future with a complicated trade in the options market, so why worry?
The idea that stocks are inherently risky, and that the government should keep people from speculating with excessive leverage, seemed obvious in the 1930's. Then people thought the 1929 crash had been worsened because over-leveraged investors were forced to sell. Seven decades later, such things are forgotten, and free-market advocates claim that if we don't allow such blatant gambling on stocks, the action will simply go to some overseas market.
It is probably inevitable that single-stock futures will begin trading. But legislators who are voting in favor of them may regret that decision if, before they choose to retire, the public once again discovers that the stock market really is risky, and that very high leverage can increase the risks for both the speculators and the entire system.

HEADLINE: Revised Quarterly G.D.P. Stirs New Concern on Rates

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 29

 BODY:
The economy raced ahead more quickly than previously thought in the first quarter, according to revised government figures released today, raising the prospect of more interest-rate increases this year.
Gross domestic product, the broadest measure of total economic activity, expanded at an annual rate of 5.5 percent in the first quarter instead of the 5.4 percent that was estimated a month ago, the Commerce Department said. 
 That was down from a 7.3 percent growth rate in the final quarter of last year but well above levels that Federal Reserve policy makers consider best for safely sustaining growth without risk of igniting inflation.
First-quarter G.D.P. was fueled by the strongest consumer spending in 17 years, and prices climbed at the fastest pace in five and a half years -- developments that are both likely to heighten Fed concern that it might be difficult to slow demand enough to curb inflation.
The Fed left the rate on overnight loans among banks unchanged at 6.5 percent on Wednesday after raising it six times since last June. The policy makers warned, however, that they thought inflation risks were high.
That left the central bank poised to increase rates again as early as its next meeting, on Aug. 22, unless convincing signs of slowing appear.
The Fed said it saw hints that demand-fueled growth might be easing but called them "tentative and preliminary." Another hint came in a separate report today that said that sales of single-family homes fell slightly in May, by 0.2 percent, to a seasonally adjusted 875,000 a year.
The housing industry is especially sensitive to rising interest rates because both builders and buyers rely on borrowed money. And any slowing in housing quickly translates into reduced spending on furniture, appliances and other household items.
The economy completed a ninth full year of steady expansion in the first quarter. The last recession ended in March 1991, and the United States is in a period of record unbroken growth that the Fed is seeking to sustain by easing the advance of G.D.P. to a rate closer to 3.5 percent or 4 percent a year.
Fed policy makers said on Wednesday that they were worried about tight labor markets -- with unemployment at its lowest level in three decades, employers have difficulty finding people to hire.
Today, the Labor Department said initial claims for jobless benefits edged up 2,000 last week, to 306,000, mainly because of some layoffs in the auto industry, where sales have been leveling off.
The pattern for the economy over the last two years has been for some slowing to occur in the second quarter, and that is expected again this year. But in 1998 and 1999, G.D.P. accelerated in the second half.
There is abundant spending power in the economy, stemming from ample jobs and a strong stock market, but analysts and Fed policy makers hope that the lingering drag of the six increases in interest rates will be a restraint.
Consumer spending, the chief fuel for growth in the economy, increased at an annual rate of 7.7 percent in the first quarter, up from 7.5 percent estimated last month, for the strongest quarterly advance since an 8.6 percent surge in the second quarter of 1983.
Over all, most changes from last month's G.D.P. estimates were relatively minor, including a modestly better trade performance from stronger exports and slightly less inventory-building in the face of strong demand.

HEADLINE: William Blair, 82, Co-Founder of Country Journal

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
William S. Blair, a former publisher of Harper's magazine and co-founder of Country Journal, died on June 21 at a retirement home in Peterborough, N.H. He was 82.
It was at Harper's, in 1971, that Mr. Blair clashed with the younger editor in chief, Willie Morris, over declining circulation and huge financial losses at the magazine. Mr. Morris was a magnet for writing talent, revered by writers like Norman Mailer and William Styron. When Mr. Morris resigned from the magazine that year, six editors quit in stormy protest. 
 Mr. Blair became the publisher at Harper's in 1968. He was also president, and left soon after the departure of Mr. Morris. Before that, he was president and chief executive of Harper-Atlantic Sales, a company he joined in 1957. It was then a wholly owned subsidiary of Harper & Row and the Atlantic Monthly Company. Before that, he was a research director at Ogilvy, Benson & Mather.
After the trouble at Harper's, Mr. Blair moved to Guilford, Vt., where he and his wife, Mary, had bought a 106-acre farm in 1964. (It grew to more than 200 acres.) There, Mrs. Blair said, he grew 40 acres of daffodils, tulips and irises, reminiscent of the fields of flowers he used to wander through as a boy in Scotland. Local farmers grew corn and raised cattle on the property, and Mr. Blair spent afternoons fishing for trout.
"It was much more his speed," said Lewis H. Lapham, the current editor of Harper's, who knew Mr. Blair. "It was tweed coats. And people talked in civil tones."
It was there, too, in 1974, that he started Country Journal with a friend and colleague, Richard M. Ketchum. The magazine was written for people who had grown tired of hectic city and suburban life and took refuge in rural living, not unlike Mr. Blair. "The magazine was an extension of his own life," Mrs. Blair said. It was sold a decade later.
Mr. Blair was born in Glasgow in 1917, the son of a minister, and attended Oxford University in the late 1930's, earning a degree in economics, Mrs. Blair said. He moved to the United States in 1940, where he attended graduate school at Princeton and, during World War II, joined the Canadian Army.
In addition to his wife of 55 years, Mr. Blair is survived by two daughters, Sheila, of Richmond, N.H., and Fiona, of Brattleboro, Vt.; a son, Colin, of Arlington, Mass.; and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Is Expected to Ease Demands on Debtor Nations

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 29

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund, which has ordered developing nations to enact wrenching reforms as the price for emergency aid in recent years, is likely to curtail the demands it makes of clients who borrow money in the future, a senior fund official said today.
Streamlining the conditions the I.M.F. imposes on borrowers is one of the changes Horst Kohler, the fund's new managing director, is weighing as a panel he commissioned to study the role of the agency completes a draft report. Some government officials, academic experts, and private charity groups criticized the fund for requiring that Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia overhaul their economies during the Asian financial crisis in 1997 and 1998. 
 The I.M.F.'s demands for broad changes were captured in a widely reprinted 1997 photograph of Michel Camdessus, the fund's recently retired managing director, peering over the shoulder of former President Suharto of Indonesia as Mr. Suharto signed a lengthy letter of intent to receive emergency aid. The fund required Indonesia to overhaul its transportation and energy sectors and end price subsidies on some commodities, changes that fund officials now say might have been too much for Indonesia to swallow.
Mr. Kohler, who visited Indonesia during a tour of Asia earlier this month, has said that he wants the fund to focus on what he calls its "core competencies."
The senior official said today that the fund's main goal during a crisis should be to restore investor confidence quickly by helping troubled nations manage their finances and currencies. Dictating more sweeping economic changes as the price for assistance potentially works against that goal, the official said.
"Some people say that the fund has acted like a Trojan horse to impose the economic system of the West," the senior official said. "There may be more of a possibility for countries to find their own path."
Mr. Kohler, a German who took over as I.M.F. managing director in May, served previously as head of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and, before that, as a senior economic aide to Helmut Kohl when he was the German chancellor. He has said that one of his top priorities is to sort through several conflicting proposals for overhauling the I.M.F., including a plan put forward by Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers and another by a Congressional commission.
Mr. Summers suggested that the I.M.F. should limit its long-term lending programs and discourage repeat borrowing by developing nations, the better to preserve its capital to fight financial crises. The Congressional commission advocated a much more radical overhaul, which was dismissed by both the fund and the Clinton administration.
A senior Clinton administration official said today that he believed the I.M.F. overhaul process was headed in the right direction.
The Clinton administration strongly supported the fund's role during the Asian crisis, though Mr. Summers has subsequently said that some of the fund's initial demands on crisis-stricken nations were too severe. Administration officials today declined to comment on the fund's plan to streamline the requirements it imposes on developing nations during times of crisis.
The I.M.F. board plans a retreat in mid-July to discuss changes, the senior I.M.F. official said. The fund has also arranged a retreat with the World Bank, its sister lending agency, where officials will try to sort out things the two bodies should do together and others that they should do separately.
Many broad economic changes that the fund has required its client nations to carry out in recent years have in fact been designed by the World Bank, I.M.F. officials said. Fund officials now say they feel their lending programs should not be used as leverage to advance sometimes hotly disputed World Bank ideas, especially those involving the sale of state-owned companies.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:

Young Musicians In Museum Battle
First the singer SHERYL CROW, now 70 journeyman musicians and Juilliard students: the union representing striking workers at the Museum of Modern Art claimed credit yesterday for forcing the cancellation of the first week of the museum's Summergarden concerts.
The performances tonight and tomorrow would have featured musicians who graduated from the Juilliard School of Music this month or are still enrolled there, along with more experienced performers who belong to Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians. Over the eight-week series, 70 musicians were expected to play -- many in small ensembles, some in a 28-piece orchestra. 
 But Local 802 sent letters urging the students not to appear. "Crossing a picket line is not a great way to start your career," the letter said. "Even though you may not be a union member yet, your future is with the union."
ROBERT BATTERMAN, the museum's labor lawyer, took issue with Local 802's letter-writing. "If it weren't for the fact that we do not wish to embroil students from Juilliard in our problems, we would be seeking legal redress" against the musicians' union and the museum union under federal labor law, he said.
The strike by Local 2110 of the United Automobile Workers, which represents the museum's assistant curators, bookshop workers and other administrative workers, began on April 29. Museum officials postponed a May fund-raiser at which Ms. Crow was to perform, saying they did not want her or ticket holders to have to cross a picket line. The two sides remain divided on everything from wages to job security.
"Our supporters from all corners of the artistic community have been crucial in the course of this strike," MAIDA ROSENSTEIN, the president of Local 2110, said in a statement.
 
Father of the Bride
And of a Cartoon
Just in time for the movie "The Adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle," TIFFANY WARD was remembering what it was like to grow up amid the adventures of a certain squirrel, a certain moose and a certain father. That would be the animation pioneer JAY WARD, who created the squirrel and moose.
"I was a child when Rocky and Bullwinkle went on the air, and I was dazzled," Ms. Ward said. "It was on television -- there was a premiere."
But there were times when life with father -- her father, anyway -- was too much. Before her wedding, in 1969, for example. "He said I was much too conservative; I wasn't any fun," she recalled. "He said he would wash his hands of the wedding when I turned down his idea of having a popcorn vendor and monkey grinder inside the church. I was a young bride who kind of wanted this not to be a circus." Still, her father hired a skywriter to spell out a message of congratulations.
"When we got to the reception, the receiving line? Next to me, instead of my live father, was a dummy father. My real father and the comedy writers had done an hour of one-liners. Everybody kept going through to hear the dummy. The piece de resistance, which luckily didn't work out, was he had arranged for the Goodyear blimp to land on the golf course and take us away. It was foggy. They couldn't get clearance to take off."
 
Indigenous Sport
Gets Hall of Fame
Cooperstown, N.Y., has the Baseball Hall of Fame, and Cleveland has the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. ROBERT R. MacDONALD says Manhattan is about to become home to the stickball hall of fame.
Mr. MacDonald is the director of the Museum of the City of New York, where the new hall of fame will have its headquarters. "This is New York's indigenous sport," he said, "and its importance was, there were no economic barriers to play it. All it took to play it was the end of a broomstick and the inside of a tennis ball."
So how were the first 14 stickball hall of famers chosen? "Since there were no statistics, it was basically bragging rights," said CARLOS DIAZ, the president of the World Series of Stickball, which begins tomorrow. JAMES BARRON

HEADLINE: First Asian-American Picked for Cabinet

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 29

 BODY:
President Clinton nominated a former representative, Norman Y. Mineta, today as secretary of commerce for the final six months of his presidency, laying the groundwork for Mr. Mineta to become the first Asian-American to hold a Cabinet post.
Mr. Mineta, a Democrat, retired from the House in 1995 after 21 years representing the area around San Jose, Calif. He had been chairman of the Public Works and Transportation Committee and resigned in 1995 to become a senior vice president at Lockheed Martin. 
 If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Mineta would replace William M. Daley, who will formally step down on July 15 to become campaign chairman for Vice President Al Gore's presidential bid. He would be Mr. Clinton's fourth commerce secretary, following Mickey Kantor and the late Ron Brown, as well as Mr. Daley.
Mr. Mineta is 68. During World War II, when he was 10, his family was loaded onto a train and taken to an internment camp in Wyoming for Americans of Japanese descent. Years later, as a lawmaker, Mr. Mineta helped pass legislation granting $20,000 in compensation to every Japanese-American who had been interned.
"Norm Mineta's family story tells a lot about the promise of the American dream and the power of one person's devotion to opportunity and to justice," Mr. Clinton said in announcing the selection this morning in the Oval Office. Along with Mr. Mineta, the president was joined by Mr. Daley and Robert L. Mallett, the deputy commerce secretary, who had been a finalist for the top job.
The nomination brought immediate praise from Asian-American organizations. One side benefit of the selection, in the view of administration officials, is that it may help blunt criticism from Asian-Americans that followed the firing of Wen Ho Lee, the government scientist accused of mishandling secrets at the Los Alamos National Laboratory. Some Asian-Americans have also expressed unhappiness over the scrutiny people of Asian descent have faced during the investigations of campaign fund-raising abuses in 1996.
"I think it will go a long way toward bridging the divide," Mr. Mineta said in an interview today.
Mr. Mineta acknowledged that, even with a quick confirmation, his time in Mr. Clinton's Cabinet would be short. But he said that he was not taking the job as a caretaker and that he believed the Commerce Department would remain active until the very end of the president's term.
"Some might say that the months remaining in this administration is not a lot of time to make a difference in the life of our nation," Mr. Mineta said. "But I disagree. Six months is a virtual eternity in the new economy."
Mr. Mineta's decision to leave the House to go into private business with a year to go in his term, and just 10 months after Republicans gained control of Congress, rankled some of his Democratic colleagues at the time. A Republican, Representative Tom Campbell, won Mr. Mineta's seat in a special election.
Key Republican senators and supporters predicted a quick confirmation.
"This is a guy who will do very well in the sprint to the end," said Tom Donahue, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce. "He knows Congress well, and they know him."
Some union leaders also praised Mr. Mineta, saying their main concern was his support for the Clinton administration's free-trade agenda.
Not everybody, however, was enthusiastic.
"If his Congressional voting record is any measure, he's clearly out of touch with small business," said Nelson Litterst, a spokesman for the National Federation for Independent Business.
Despite a considerable salary increase when he went into the private sector, Mr. Mineta had clearly not turned his back entirely on politics. He served as an informal adviser to Mr. Gore's presidential effort and had recently considered a run for his old seat in Congress.
This was the second time Mr. Mineta had been offered a Cabinet post, he said. In 1992, President-elect Clinton considered Mr. Mineta for transportation secretary, and Mr. Mineta said today that he had been offered the job but turned it down. He was about to become a committee chairman, and thought he could assist his party more in that capacity, he said.
Nearly eight years later, when another Cabinet offer came, Mr. Mineta jumped at the chance.
John D. Podesta, the president's chief of staff, called Mr. Mineta last Friday to gauge his availability.
"Are you interested?" Mr. Podesta asked.
Mr. Mineta said he responded without hesitation: "Do you want me to crawl through the telephone line to your office right now?"

HEADLINE: After Boy's Return, Castro Tries to Keep Momentum

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: HAVANA, June 29

 BODY:
"At Last in the Fatherland!" declared the front-page headline in the official newspaper, Granma, above pictures of Elian Gonzalez stepping off the plane and being swept up in a relative's arms, an emotional end to the seven-month custody battle that captivated Cuba.
Despite the triumphal headline, the newspaper quickly reminded readers that the child's return was just the beginning of renewed efforts by Cuban officials who want to see an end to an American trade embargo. They contend that the embargo and other American policies weaken their economy and encourage people, like Elian's mother, to risk their lives at sea while seeking political asylum. 
 For those reasons, the government plans to continue the public rallies and televised discussions that provided a political play-by-play during the Elian custody battle.
Foreign officials based here see the continuing campaign as an attempt to tap into the Cuban public's overwhelming support for Elian's return in the hope of rekindling a revolutionary ardor that had cooled in recent years. They said the battle over Elian was the perfect opportunity for President Fidel Castro to restore his appeal.
"He got himself front and center before the country on a daily basis," said one foreign official. "He re-established himself in his image as the sole leader in Cuba who still has the oomph and fire to carry on the revolution. He got an issue he could mobilize the youth, who are his audience and a group that he had not had effective outreach to before."
It is not clear whether Mr. Castro will be able to sustain his appeal. Some people said they had tired of the government-sponsored rallies for Elian and the televised talks about the ills of American society. Many said they simply wanted the boy home with his family.
"Politics is politics," said Maria Gonzalez, who was shopping at a Havana market. "Human feelings should not be mixed up with that."
Yet today's newspapers were filled not only with praise for Elian and his father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, but also for the youths who attended the countless public rallies organized by the government. While insisting the government would not trot out the child as a symbol, the official newspaper made clear Elian's importance to a battle that it said must continue "immediately and without a truce."
"Ahead of us is the challenge that no new Elians continue to appear," one article said.
Already, the huge billboards with Elian's face have been replaced by others that call for the United States to end its Cuban Adjustment Act, which grants political asylum to Cubans who reach American soil. But while the custody battle strongly affected many Cubans, the policy issues now being tackled may not have the same resonance.
"Elian's story was so visual, with this child and his father," said one foreign official. "Can you keep that up with the Cuban Adjustment Act without any such visuals? It will be difficult."
In the short term, diplomats said, the Cuban government has scored some points through its campaign for Elian's return. They pointed to the easing of restrictions on American food sales passed this week by the United States Congress. They said that decision was a result of a growing sentiment against the embargo in the United States among people who favored Elian's return and who were turned off by the hardball tactics of Elian's Miami relatives and their supporters who sought to keep him.
"They noticed it was not just about a regime, but there were real people living in Cuba," one diplomat said. "A lot of people in the United States questioned the embargo, and Elian helped with that sentiment."

HEADLINE: New U.S. Farm Subsidy Plan Is Contrary to European Position

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, June 29

 BODY:
The Clinton administration introduced a sweeping new proposal today at the World Trade Organization to change the way governments subsidize farmers, challenging the European Union's extensive agricultural subsidies.
The American plan would simplify financial support to farmers and reduce or end disparities in tariffs to increase market openings for agricultural goods from other countries. 
 The proposal, disclosed today in Geneva and Washington, will be formally introduced Friday at a session of the W.T.O. agricultural talks, which began last March.
Under the plan, the current domestic subsidies system would be revised to eliminate those agricultural subsidies not directly linked to price and volume of output. There also would be a ceiling on the level of domestic subsidies based on a percentage of the country's total agricultural production.
While the approach by the United States was welcomed by exporting countries, it is likely to add to tension between the United States and the European Union, which are already at odds over a number of politically sensitive trade matters, including bananas and corporate tax breaks.
The failure to begin a new global trade round last December in Seattle was in large part attributed to serious differences in how to tackle the issue of agriculture. The United States and an 18-country group of agriculture exporters argue that European export subsidies hinder competition and drive up consumer prices. The E.U., Switzerland, Norway and Japan maintain that rural areas need such financial protection to ensure their survival.
Despite these differences, members of the W.T.O. are bound to negotiate farm subsidies because of commitments they have already made.
The new United States proposal is directly contrary to the position of the European Union, which spends about half of its total budget on agricultural subsidies and supports payments to farmers not to grow crops.
The 15-country trading bloc has criticized the United States government for denouncing subsidies at the same time it supports what the Europeans call a hidden subsidy, emergency aid, to farmers.
Last week Franz Fischler, the union's agricultural commissioner, criticized American farm spending, saying the Clinton administration had increased spending to record levels. Two weeks ago Congress passed a $15 billion relief bill to assist farmers who are facing a fourth year of economic downturn.
The American special negotiator for agriculture, Gregory Frazier, in Geneva, defended emergency aid packages to American farmers as falling within W.T.O. rules.

HEADLINE: Israeli Armorer in a Global Arena;
Aircraft Maker Runs Afoul of U.S. With China Radar Contract

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: LOD, Israel, June 28

 BODY:
Behind a tarpaulin-covered fence at the far edge of the Israel Aircraft Industries complex at Ben-Gurion International Airport here sits a refurbished Russian transport, its saucer-like radar pod temporarily removed for fine-tuning.
Within weeks, company officials say, the pod will be back, the radar switched on, and the distinctive droop-winged jet ready for its final test flights. The plane, a transformed Ilyushin-76, will be able to monitor air and telecommunications traffic more than 200 miles away -- the specifications ordered by the plane's owner, the People's Republic of China. 
 For Israel Aircraft Industries' president, Moshe Keret, who over the last 15 years has built a virtually bankrupt military contractor into Israel's biggest exporter, the sale was to have been one of his greatest achievements. The Phalcon early-warning radar system installed on the Chinese plane showcased all the strengths of I.A.I. -- as the state-owned company is known -- its technological prowess and its success in developing new markets abroad to help pay for Israel's weapons.
But if the Pentagon has its way, and the betting here is that it will, the converted Ilyushin will never reach China, which long ago gave Israel Aircraft the down payment on the $250 million spy plane.
Today, President Clinton reiterated Washington's concern that China could use the radar system against American forces in the Taiwan Strait. Earlier in the week, the House Appropriations Committee called on Israel to terminate the deal, with many members pledging to cut Israel's aid if it does not.
"We signed a contract," a top official of Israel Aircraft said. "We have their money. Now we say, 'No, sorry?' "
To foreign policy analysts, the Phalcon dispute is an illustration of how Israeli-American strategic ties are still often frayed by miscommunication and mistrust on both sides -- as well as by rare but deep divergences in each country's conception of its national interest. The China contract has opened the first significant rift between the Clinton administration and the government of Prime Minister Ehud Barak, just as both governments are trying to persuade the Palestinians to join them in Washington for a conclusive round of peace talks.
But to Mr. Keret, 65, who has worked at Israel Aircraft his entire adult life, the conflict is also a potential business catastrophe, one that he thinks directly threatens his company's prospects for survival in an increasingly competitive and consolidated global arms industry.
A threat to Israel Aircraft's future is seen by many Israeli leaders as a threat to the nation, both militarily and economically. The company, founded in 1953, is the centerpiece of a domestic arms and aeronautics industry that Israel considers the key to its defense.
"I don't want to talk about the Phalcon per se," Mr. Keret, who has been asked by the government not to comment on the deal, said at I.A.I. headquarters here. "But what is the environment in which we are operating? It is very competitive. Although we are a state-owned company, we get no subsidy, and no favoritism from the defense ministry."
Compared with Boeing and other behemoths of the global defense trade, Israel Aircraft is no giant: its $1 billion in foreign military sales puts it about 30th among major arms sellers abroad, according to independent assessments. Overall sales reached $2 billion last year, two-thirds from military contracts and the rest from commercial aircraft production and maintenance.
But it is difficult to overstate the company's importance to Israel. With 14,000 skilled workers, Israel Aircraft is by far the country's biggest industrial employer, comparable in American terms to General Motors and General Electric combined. A further 15,000 Israeli jobs are indirectly dependent on the company. And its $1.6 billion in military and commercial sales abroad make it the biggest exporter.
"If there is a disaster in I.A.I. for one reason or another," Mr. Keret said, "its effects would be felt throughout the country."
A certain disaster for the company would be any significant erosion of American aid. I.A.I. has been the biggest beneficiary of American rules permitting a quarter of military assistance to be spent in Israel -- for purchases of arms produced in this country. Yet Moshe Arens, a three-time former defense minister, whose views are widely shared here, said this week that $2 billion in annual military aid is "not sufficient to make us start accepting U.S. control over defense industry exports."
American officials seem mystified that Israel would jeopardize its critical international alliance by pursuing what appears to be a marginal weapons deal. Last fall, as the China controversy broke into the open, the same Israeli officials who were defending the Phalcon sale were presenting Washington with a $17 billion wish list of arms they said the country needed to compensate for the expected turnover of the Golan Heights to Syria. Now the Israelis are discussing a similar military aid package to safeguard a peace pact with the Palestinians.
"I have tried to explain to Israelis that Americans cannot understand why Israel was refusing to give up $250 million when it was asking the United States for $17 billion," said David Makovsky, who has been an Israeli analyst at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy.
But far more than $250 million is at stake, leaders of this country say. "We'll do our utmost to act sensitively and to be attentive to U.S. interests," Mr. Barak, who appoints Israel Aircraft's board, said. "At the same time, there's a contract with China, signed during the incumbency of the previous government. The state doesn't call off contracts to which it is a signatory just like that."
Even seen narrowly, the contract with China is potentially a $2 billion deal, huge by Israel Aircraft standards. Under terms negotiated three years ago, Beijing has options to buy seven more Phalcon-equipped Ilyushins. Fulfilling such a contract would catapult the company into an elite fraternity of major contractors in bidding for such systems -- and it would subsidize further technological advances at home. Though Israel Aircraft lost to Boeing in a recent bid to supply early-warning planes to Australia, it is competing for a $2 billion contract in Turkey.
Worse, executives say, the cancellation of the contract would be a signal to potential customers that no deal with Israel Aircraft is final, as the United States could effectively veto a promised delivery.
"Better to buy from the Europeans," a gloomy executive said. Or perhaps from the Russians, who supplied destroyers, cruise missiles and other heavy weaponry to the Chinese over the last decade with few protests from Washington.
Or, as others here cynically suggest, from the Americans themselves. Israelis point to the continuing export of advanced military technology to China by the United States in the last decade: since the ban by Congress in 1989 on military sales to Beijing, after the crackdown on pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square, the White House has issued waivers for some $300 million in exports of satellite and encryption equipment to the country.
Moreover, the United States did not renege on its own deals, Israelis note, fulfilling $36 million in orders placed by China before the ban, including anti-artillery radar systems.
In an editorial last week, the newspaper Maariv decried what it called "Washington's attempts to torpedo the deal and sabotage Israel's defense exports, perhaps out of the desire to protect the interests of giant U.S. corporations."
Yet Maariv, like other leading media voices here, concluded that Israel would have little choice but to renege on the contract. Until the dispute is resolved, another daily, Haaretz, said, "The Phalcon will continue to be a sword of Damocles hanging over Israel's head."
Mr. Keret seems surprised by the furor in Washington over the Phalcon deal. Until newspapers here published photos of the plane late last year, setting off the American outcry, company executives say they considered the contract old news.
When the company bid for the contract in 1996, Israel officially notified the United States that the Phalcon system did not incorporate protected American technology, a contention the Pentagon has never challenged. Though Washington officials say they objected to the sale on strategic and human rights grounds, there were no public complaints.
The deal, calling for delivery beginning in 2000, was concluded in highly publicized trips to Moscow and Beijing by Benjamin Netanyahu, then the prime minister, and Yitzhak Mordechai, the defense minister. In April 1998, the Phalcon sale was reported to Congress in a General Accounting Office review of recent Chinese arms purchases.
Again, there were no public American protests, though officials did say they tried to dissuade Israel from signing.
"As the deal went forward, they weren't hearing us anymore," a senior State Department official said.
Though American companies were prohibited from selling radar planes to China after the events there in June 1989, Israel Aircraft considered this a commercial opportunity. In the first foreign sale of its airborne radar, it sent a Phalcon-equipped Boeing 767 to Chile, which was then prohibited by Congressional strictures from buying Boeing Awacs surveillance planes. Washington raised no objections, Mr. Keret said.
From Central America in the 1980's to Turkey in the 1990's, the company provided other military equipment to countries where United States exports were constrained by human rights considerations.
And in China, Israel Aircraft was hardly alone. Competitors in Italy and Britain were offering advanced airborne radar systems to Beijing.
But the United States has since become more worried by Beijing's conflict with Taiwan, and officials are telling the Israeli contractor that no company so dependent on American trade and aid can consider itself geopolitically autonomous.
By design, Mr. Keret has made Israel Aircraft increasingly reliant on the United States as a market, supplier and business partner, creating joint ventures with all the major aerospace companies. And through its own American subsidiaries -- including its Galaxy corporate jet business, based in Fort Worth -- the company says it spends about $400 million yearly in the United States.
With such partners, the company specializes in upgrading American aircraft for foreign air forces -- and even for the United States Air Force, which recently awarded Israel Aircraft and Boeing a $400 million contract to revamp 450 of its T-38 Talon trainers. The small unmanned planes, an I.A.I. specialty, proved a crucial reconnaissance weapon for the United States Army in Kosovo, prompting other NATO orders.
In its most ambitious American joint venture, Israel Aircraft is the principal contractor on the Arrow, a $2 billion antiballistic-missile system deployed here this year.
American support has been critical to the company's turnaround. After weathering a worldwide plunge in military sales in the mid-1990's, it has stayed in the black for 14 consecutive quarters. Net profit last year rose to $70 million.
But just as Boeing and Lockheed Martin heed the Pentagon before pursuing foreign arms deals, so now must Israel Aircraft, many officials of this country reluctantly conclude.
The last time Israel Aircraft tried to buck the Pentagon and its military contractors, Mr. Keret painfully recalls, it almost destroyed the company. The project was his baby: I.A.I.'s own jet fighter, the Lavi, envisioned as a successor -- and competitor -- to the Air Force's F-16. The increasingly expensive project was canceled under pressure from Washington in 1987, just a year after the Lavi's maiden flight. The move wiped out 5,000 jobs and nearly propelled Israel Aircraft into receivership.
Mr. Keret is credited with rescuing the company from the Lavi debacle. The radar and navigation and missile-guidance systems developed for the Lavi were refined into independent products, many of them now installed on I.A.I.-refurbished F-16's.
But as he sits in his corporate offices here, which are still decorated with models and photographs of the extinct Israeli fighter, Mr. Keret says he regrets the loss of corporate and national independence that the Lavi symbolized. "It was a good plane," he said. "I'm sure we could have sold a lot of them."
